reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2015
reviewComment: This is an early WW II spy novel with an unusual twist. It is about convincing Americans to join the War before Pearl Harbor and the efforts the British put into it. I many ways I thought it was somewhat far-fetched. It was an enjoyable read but it was complicated by the inclusion of the daughter of the heroine's life. I did not see the need for the story about the daughter and thought it detracted from the main story. I thought the spy happenings were well done and developed. I thought the book could have been better done if it developed more of the spy story than relying on on the daughter's life as a filler.

review_title: The Best Novelist You've Probably Never Read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2013
reviewComment: There is no more imaginative novelist writing today than William Boyd. To cite just three of his novels, in addition to Restless, there is Any Human Heart, a chronicle spanning most of the 20th Century on four continents; an exciting and disturbing examination of chimpanzees and the scientist who study them, in Brazzaville Beach, set mostly in Africa; and The Blue Afternoon, in which Boyd  has crafted a compelling family mystery beginning in 1930s Los Angeles, moving to the turn of the last century in Manila, and concluding in Lisbon just prior to the second World War.  In Restless, Boyd returns to World War II, telling a thrilling story of a beautiful spy of Russian descent working for the British.  As she tells her story to her unsuspecting daughter some 30 years later, we learn of the sacrifices she and others made for their political and nationalistic goals, and the toll those choices took.  The novel has it all:  love, sex, cloak and dagger intrigue, shocking surprises, murder and betrayal.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2013
reviewComment: I ordered this as a Kindle Deal of the Day, and it is the first William Boyd novel I've ever read. I really enjoyed the book - the writing, the plot flow and the ending. The author transitions back and forth between past and present seamlessly, and creates an absorbing story that doesn't completely play out until the very end. The story of Eve Delectorskaya is interesting on its own, but its weaving with her current story and her daughter Ruth's life creates an interesting and absorbing tale. I especially liked the ending. So many novels fall apart at the end or don't necessarily tie all the loose ends together. I thought this might have the same kind of ending, since there were some things in Eve's story that didn't entirely make sense. But everything falls together at the end, both the confrontation with Romer and its aftermath, and the scholarly explanation (given by Ruth's potential love interest, a professor with an expertise in WW II espionage) of the confusing events that took place in New Mexico.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2013
reviewComment: This is an amazing if complicated spy story. The viewpoint is of a young single mother who is struggling with finishing her Doctorate at Oxford. When her seemingly daffy mum starts giving her biographical chapters of her (mums) life, her perspective and understanding of her own life start to get twisted. And she gets involved ...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2018
reviewComment: I liked this story so much that, having read it on my Kindle, I bought a paperback for my wife, and we both enjoyed the movie by the Brits!  Tough female characters among a strong group of others, realistic situations, and wide ranging story stretching from Paris to Great Britain, to New York City, to Canada and to the desert in New Mexico.  Time period covers World War II and the Cold War.  Most enjoyable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2013
reviewComment: This was a fast paced espionage tale recounted primarily by flashbacks from an aging spy's memoirs given to her daughter in the mid 1970s.  The story alternates smoothly between the war years and the 70s.  The daughter is stunned to learn of her mother's secret past, which turns out could be catching up with her.  There are enough double-crosses and murders to keep fans of the genre satisfied and the ending brought things to a clean end, which is something you don't always get. One thing I found odd was a number of characters that ended up having no significant role in the plot. I kept wondering what the present day connection would be with the past, but it turned out there really wasn't any connection.

review_title: Mothers can be a real mystery.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2016
reviewComment: Fascinating storyline about the mother and secondarily about the relationship with the daughter ..Almost doesnt require the daughters pursuit of the mothers history...which confirms ultimately her own realization of what her mother  was able ot provide and not give to her...The primary elements of the mother's life and the unique aspects of her underground spy work does create some provocative and tension induced features to hold the reader...the alternating adult daughter's life is relatively unimportant although the ending does have some impact overall as it brings it all together .

review_title: A Pretty Good Read--Espionage with Female Spy during WWII
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2012
reviewComment: I've never reviewed a book, before, and I don't intend to say much. I will say that I enjoy this type of book, but I have noticed that I enjoy most any genre if the book is written well enough.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2015
reviewComment: The first half of this book was interesting, but somewhat long-winded at times.  If I hadn't already paid for it, I might have just quit reading.  The story picked up in the second half, however, and kept me reading through to the end.  I felt that it should have ended a bit earlier with just an epilogue to add the finishing touches.  I did find the world of spies and espionage interesting but didn't care for how the chapters jumped from past to present, and from mother to daughter.  This got a bit annoying.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2012
reviewComment: I approach Sherlock Holmes pastiches with a great deal of trepidation.  Being a lover of the original cannon, I have read too many lousy mimics.  In fact, I had quit reading them until I came across this work authorized by the Conan Doyle estate.  I decided to dip my toe into the stream one more time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2015
reviewComment: For fans of Holmes and Watson this tale will at first seem too simple, more like one of Watson's short stories than a full-fledged novel. But read on. The game is indeed afoot, and very mysterious it is, too, with ample twists and turns. Yet it circles back around to the initial story eventually, and ties it all together neatly. It receives four stars instead of five because it seems to possess a few (very minor) turns of phrase that seem just a bit too modern. The core plot, also, is I think influenced strongly by modern sensibilities. But, unless you are well-versed in the Canon you won't even notice these things. A worthy addition to the collection of Holmes pastiches that compares very well with others (I am fond of those by Nicholas Meyer myself). Bravo.

review_title: A personal round of applause for Anthony Horowitz
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2015
reviewComment: For years now I have admired Anthony Horowitz for the fine writing he has done for the Poirot, Midsomer Murders TV series and his

review_title: An excellent new Sherlock Holmes book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2013
reviewComment: I read this book for my monthly mystery book club.  The entire club thoroughly enjoyed this book.  I know Sir Doyle would be proud to have a book like this written about his famous hero, Mr. Sherlock Holmes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2015
reviewComment: Starts off brightly, weaving various Doyle-like threads: the tale of theft and violence in a faraway place, the mysterious watcher outside the country house possibly seeking revenge, Holmes' remarkable deductions. But the whole thing quickly goes off the rails, descending into violence and derring-do that seems quite out of place in a Holmes mystery. What is more, anyone who has read a book will quickly divine what the House of Silk is even before the clues start rolling in.  Who the various villains are is obvious almost from the moment they are introduced. You don't have to be Holmes to spot the revealing statements, or figure from the circumstances who is responsible for a particular crime. (In one case, it simply could not be anyone else, which sort of ruins the mystery.) I kept expecting to be proven wrong in some remarkable and entertaining way. Alas, the only reason to keep reading the story is to find out exactly why the villains are the villains. That revelation manages to be both tortured and ludicrous, even employing the "Murder She Wrote" deceit of revealing various clues at the denouement that the reader was not privy to until that moment.

review_title: True to Watson and the literary agent, Doyle
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
reviewComment: As a lover of the Canon, I was impressed with the feeling that I was reading a true Holmes' case.  I think the author was faithful to his “ten rules.”  I also think that they were spot on and led to the great pleasure I had reading the book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2015
reviewComment: The book is great.  Easily 5 stars, but the copy I received was not what I expected.  I read the book a few years ago and loved it.  One or Horowitz's best.  I ordered the book last week that is supposed to have been a library copy.  Well when I received it I was shocked at how small it is.  I worked at a library for 11 years and had never seen a hardcover as small as this.  It reminds of a Readers Digest condensed copy.  So instead of adding it my collection I will be donating it my local friends of the library organization.  So if you are looking to read a great Sherlock Holmes novel I highly recommend this.  But if you plan on buying a copy do a bit more research than I did and get one you will want to keep.

review_title: Sherlock Holmes returns better than ever
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2012
reviewComment: Having grown up reading Conan Doyle's original works I am especially critical of authors attempting to emulate his style in creating new Sherlock Holmes stories.  Nicholas Meyer's Seven Percent Solution stands out as a notable exception to a number of others who have tried and failed to capture the style of the original Holmes mysteries.  Horowitz has achieved an astonishingly perfect novel that Dr. Watson could not have written any better.  The atmosphere of Victorian London is wonderfully recreated as well as the pacing and authenticity of the dialog between Holmes and Watson.  If you had only a passing familiarity with the Holmes stories you would be hard pressed to distinguish House of Silk from the original tales.  If you have loved Conan-Doyle's accounts of the famous consulting detective I strongly recommend this novel to your reading list.  I truly hope this isn't Horowitz' last adventure of Holmes and Watson

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2019
reviewComment: My dad is a Sherlock Holmes fan.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2021
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this story. Some friends that know Sherlock much better than I do had mixed reviews. They had some issues regarding how Sherlock was portrayed and they felt it was not true to form. I thought it was a compelling storyline and being less of a Sherlock student meant I was blind to this.

review_title: Definitely one I will cherish and read again and again!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2015
reviewComment: This is such a powerful story that really reaches into one's heart and shows you things that need to be made clear.  I have read the Bible almost daily for over 40 years, and although I have memorized a lot of it, some parts have always eluded me with their archaic and symbolic wording and anachronistic references.  But reading this book has brought many of my favorite scripture passages into a new light and a new form of understanding.  Things that made only a glimmer of sense before are now very clear.  I thank Mr. Rubart for that... nice job!

review_title: An amazing ride of twists and turns and I never saw it coming!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2015
reviewComment: I almost never give a 5 star review. Every book seems to be lacking something to make it the top. This book gets a rousing 5 star review. Someone wrote if Peretti wrote the shack it would be this book. I love peretti and I really enjoyed the twists of the shack but this book is far better. Imagine, someone loves you enough to build you a mansion really, and knows you well enough that it suits you perfectly and has your memories in it, then imagine the person is long dead and you can't even remember him. He also seems to know your every thought and move. Hmm... what would you give up for that? Mysterious doors appear? Mysterious strangers? Odd unexplainable happenings. Oh yes, this book causes you to think of Gods love and what he wants to give us, if we'll only allow Him to take charge. I truly had a hard time putting it down and stayed up late too many nights reading it. Will look for more from this author but he has set the bar pretty high for himself! By the way, I forgot to mention it isn't a horror book. Thriller yes, suspenseful yes, but not scary or horror.

review_title: A BOOK THAT REALLY MAKES. YOU THINK!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020
reviewComment: I read this book a few weeks ago. But I waited to review it because it's a book that I knew that I really needed to ponder first - so I did. While reading this book I had a love, like, and sometimes a dis-like relationship with it. Sometimes while reading it I would think "ok, would you get to the point?" But by the time I ended the book I had a love relationship with it because the way the  author ended it, leaves you with no doubt about God's love for all of us. I'm not going to give anything away - but I will warn you.......BE PREPARED FOR A WILD RIDE! A ride that by the time you're done, you'll be happy that you took! But I'm sure you'll be thinking about this book  for some time. The author - James Rubart sure has an amazing imagination.....I can only wonder what his dreams must be like!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2018
reviewComment: Fantasy Island: Holy Ghost Edition.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2018
Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2018
reviewComment: James L. Rubart, through his story of Micah Tayler, did a magnificent job showing the consequences of making life choices from a spiritual warfare standpoint. As people, we all make choices that take us down one path or another toward or away from heaven, God and eternity. Rubart's story of Micah Taylor brought the outcome of Micah's choices into clear view using Biblical teaching and scripture allowing the reader to see and feel the struggles Micah went through as he made decisions based on his own personal desires. Rubart's imagery was spectacular drawing the reader into the plot. Rooms is a story I won't soon forget. It's one of the best I have read using a fictional story to unveil the spiritual warfare that goes on daily for our lives. It helps the reader understand what could happen to them if they are careless with their choice.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2018
reviewComment: As a co-owner of a multi-million software company, Micah Taylor is a successful businessman who by all means has earned his way in life.  When Micah asked his father about the letter from great uncle Archie, inquiring as to whether or not the man would actually build him a 9,000 square ft house, his father basically said Micah should ignore it.  But seeing it is a whole other thing, making Micah think he may keep the house instead of selling it, which had been his original plan.  Micah instantly fell in love with it upon seeing the gorgeous home on the beach, and didn’t want to go back to Seattle once he was there, but the plan Archie had in mind got him there and change was about to happen.

review_title: It was a strange ride and I enjoyed the interesting ways the author used to deal with ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2018
reviewComment: Just picked this up on a whim during its sale price.  I wasn't expecting it to be a Christian supernatural book.  I'm not religious, but still found this book to be very compelling.  It was a strange ride and I enjoyed the interesting ways the author used to deal with past trauma's and how unconscious pain and conflicts can impact someone's life so profoundly.  For those that aren't that keen on Christian religion I think they can still enjoy this, since its focus is on the love and redemption qualities of modern Christianity, rather than dogma or the more controversial elements of the Bible itself.

review_title: Can be read more than once and should be
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2017
reviewComment: I know this is a Christian but it would be helpful to anyone. It reminded me of Larry Crabbs’ book “Inside Out”. It helps you look into your subconscious and take a serious look into your “Self” side and Gods side and the issues they cost. In this case it cost the main character a dream situation. It also reminds me of the Bible verse about seek and you will find. The doors to the “Rooms” show me that that verse can work both ways. You can open a door to your self will or one to Gods will.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2018
reviewComment: I felt moved when I first started this book, however, the middle and ending had me scrunching my eyebrows together in wonderment/confusion.

review_title: Great product, good price, delivered on time
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2013
reviewComment: Really great e-reader with its touch screen and buttons. Sometimes I like to change the pages using the buttons. That was a big part of choosing the nook over the kindle.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2014
reviewComment: Before I bought this one, I wanted to buy kindle, but then my major concern was I need something I can pack a lot of books with it,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2014
reviewComment: This is my second of the old version. Dropped the first one in my pool and thought for sure it would never work again but 2days of drying it out in a bag of rice and it's working perfectly. So now I have one I take to pool and my back up stays on nightstand. Great price and outstanding service. I had new one before old one dried out. Love this company...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2014
reviewComment: I love it for reading, but it takes forever to turn it on where you can get back to the place you left off reading.  Somewhere on it there are supposed to be "bookmarks" to use, but I only saw them listed once and can't seem to get back to them.  I've only used it for about 2 weeks so I will get used to it soon.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2013
reviewComment: I've used a nook simple touch for a long time now, at least a year, and I've always loved it but hated that I had to have a light on to read at night (this isn't the stone age, we have the technology) so I got myself the simple touch with glowlight for christmas and I LOVE it highly recommend it to any avid readers out there!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2013
reviewComment: After purchasing a reader prior, another family member wanted one. But they wanted just a reader. There is no better reader as the pages are crisp and so similar to paper. I held off for the longest time because I thought I had to have to feel of the cover and the pages. Once you read on a reader, you will be hooked.

review_title: Easy to use. but each one probably has its own fault
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2014
reviewComment: This is my first new nook (I had ordered my first ever nook that was used and I enjoyed it for a week till the battery refused to keep a charge, though my seller was kind enough to give me a full refund). So, I'll give my experience with both.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2013
reviewComment: I am so glad that I got the reader with the glowlight as I like to read in bed before I go to sleep. I see lots if people with those clip on lights attached to their reader and it looks uncomfortable when they have to change position.  Grest nook reader.

review_title: The glowlight feature is awesome! Couldn't be happier with this
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2017
reviewComment: Ordered this to replace the simple touch I had. Price was very reasonable for a refurb. It arrived quickly and looked brand new. The glowlight feature is awesome! Couldn't be happier with this! Thank you!!

review_title: Perfect combination of size, capacity and readability
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2013
reviewComment: Need I say more?  Ok I will: The price is right.  If your primary goal is READING ACTUAL WORDS (What a thought!!!) then this e-reader is an excellent choice. The GlowLight is particularly helpful if reading in bed or in situations where the device is being backlit (such as sunlight through a window).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 21, 2017
reviewComment: Research for a project I'm doing. No longer a live trail as such but I'm sure teenagers would love following fthem clues

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 29, 2015
reviewComment: Thank you.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 11, 2015
reviewComment: a very good book very interesting

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 8, 2015
reviewComment: Great book cant wait to start the 2nd

reviewDate: Reviewed in Italy on February 1, 2017
reviewComment: Il libro è arrivato secondo quanto previsto. Il prodotto si è presentato come descritto quindi sono soddisfatta dell'acquisto. Lo consiglio senza problemi.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Italy on July 30, 2015
reviewComment: Sono ancora alle prime pagina,ma già mi intriga. Unica pecca è che le "prove" le avrei preferite nel pacchetto e che si possono toccare,mentre sono solo disegnate su dei fogli. Il libro richiede una buona conoscenza del l'inglese

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2010
reviewComment: Song of Thunder was a GREAT Read!!! I really liked the fact that even though the story had a lot to do with technology, the Author didn't overwhelm me with a lot of technical jargon that I didn't understand. I stopped reading the last Clancy book because of that. Gimme a good well developed story with cool plot twists and interesting characters!! I sure wish the GOD was technology was available now... I'd trade in the piece of crap I am writing this review on tomorrow if that was the case.

review_title: Fast read. Lots of twists and turns.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
reviewComment: Good story, though some parts were unbelievable. I hope it is really fiction and not based on any real events. I liked the characters. They were believable to me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2010
reviewComment: Too many larger than life characters.  Too many times the hero arrives just in time to save the day.  Too many coincidences.  And sometimes the author's scene setting descriptions get too long.  Then why do I rate it five stars?  Because despite all that it's a damn good story! -- it's the best novel I've read in a long time.  It contains many deep and thought provoking reflections.  Also I don't remember a single typo, which is unusual for any novel.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2010
reviewComment: I bought this book on my Kindle based on the 5 star reviews, but hell, it was disappointing.

review_title: A ripping good yarn -- and an unnerving prediction of the future
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2010
reviewComment: Keith Ellis' new powerhouse read, "Song of Thunder". will resonate in the reader's mind long after her or she finishes feverishly turning the pages.  It's that good.  Ellis' obvious mastery of the idiom, coupled with a thorough understanding of the technology, assure that the most tech-savvy reader will feel right at home, along with the rest of us who just enjoy a stirring, involving read.  The character of Thunder is fascinating -- a man equally at home in the wilderness, in the halls of Washington, DC power, and in the hi-tech, high-stakes world of cutting-edge technology. After finishing the book -- and a sad moment that was (I was tempted to start all over again) -- I thought that two things were warranted: a sequel (soon please), and a major motion picture. I spent some time brainstorming ideal casting, with friends who had also read the book, but I'm not going to spoil your fun by telling you who got the nod. When all is said and done, you'll care about the characters and you'll worry about the probability of just such a scenario happening one day very soon. So run, don't walk, to get a copy of this fine book for yourself.  Soon you'll be singing the "Song of Thunder"!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2011
reviewComment: Just finished it!  I love a book that keeps me thinking of it even after I had to put it down for awhile. This was one of those books.  Well written, great characters with plenty of action and drama.  Only one drawback for me, IT WOULDN'T END!!!  How many times do the hero's need to save the world? It started getting boring after the air force capt. destroyed the final (not final) missile, Then Cassy needed to do it all over again, then the whole marine one argument, then the Chinese need to try and save themselves, and ooops! our missile's that went to Russia were destroyed easily and quickly while the one's we sent flying OVER Russia into China caused yet more drama. A good read but it needed a quicker ending.  (I can't believe I just said that)

review_title: A must read... can't wait for the movie!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2010
reviewComment: If you are a fan of thought provoking thrillers this is a MUST READ! Keith Ellis drives Song of Thunder with a fresh approach and a writing style that manages to bring you into the story in a way that is rarely seen anymore. His main character is perfectly developed in a way that makes you feel that you know him as soon as Ellis presents him in the story.  The plot is firmly grounded in reality with characters that display the kind of courage and intelligence that actually leave you feeling GOOD by the end of the story. This is truly one of those books that you pick up and can't put down until you've devoured the whole thing. Do yourself a favor and get this book. You'll be able to tell people that you were in on the ground floor of a great new author and be greatly entertained in the meantime. Highly recommended and I can't wait for his next effort. Many thanks to Mr. Ellis for a book worth every penny of its price!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2010
reviewComment: I bought "Quantum Ethics" (Keith Ellis) for my Kindle some time ago. Imagine my delight to see a second book listed by this author, "Song of Thunder." Then imagine my DISGUST in finding it is the same book (with some added material) as "Quantum Ethics." I am curious; how many people got sucked into buying "Song of Thunder" only to find they had been RIPPED OFF by Kindle reissuing an older book with a new title. If you own or have read "Quantum Ethics" don't waste your money on "Song of Thunder." And vise versa. Come on Kindle - if it's not new, why sell it. I doubt you would accept your customers to pay you with money copied from the real thing. That would be called counterfeiting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2010
reviewComment: WARNING! Don't begin to read this book unless you are prepared to read it all, RIGHT NOW!

review_title: A white-knuckled thrill ride that will shove you back in your seat!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2010
reviewComment: Seeking to satisfy your passion for a truly great techno-thriller? Does just the right read always deliver exceptionally powerful, truly memorable characters? Hungry for a superbly crafted story line with a pace that threatens to blow the text right off the page? A story which, at one and the same time, provokes, enlightens, challenges and threatens to scare the livin' hoo-ha out of you in the process?  Then look no further. It's right here, right now, right at your Kindle-tips! A seasoned and brilliant writer, Keith Ellis has managed to craft a searing story line with its own racing pulse. Song of Thunder is not only built for plot speed but holds your interest from 0-100 wpm and back again. A joy ride, absolutely. And when you least expect it, the comfortably brainy and athletic story line will stop in a single heartbeat --turn on an exclamation mark-- and thunder off in a cloud of printer spray heading in a brand new direction. And no reader will ever think twice about hanging on. An exceptional change-up thriller, with shades of Old School plot switchbacks framed by a wonderfully conceived, masterfully turned-out, racer's-edge barn burner of a page-turner.  NOT TO BE MISSED!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2013
reviewComment: The item is very complicated to use if you want to download public library books. quite an ordeal . you need first to get an adobe program then download book to computer etc. What is most objectionable is the pricing by amazon. The item is listed at $219 retail sold at amazon for $72 at a considerable markdown making it sound very attractive . Yet at Band N if you walk in, the same Nook is priced at $79 and you get a $20 gift card if you buy one . So there is something deceptive if not downright dishonest in the way the item is advertised at Amazon..

review_title: What Did I Do Before My Nook?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2013
reviewComment: I bought myself the Nook Simple Touch ebook reader for Christmas and I'm so pleased that I did.  This model doesn't have all the bells and whistles of the others Nooks but, in my opinion, you don't need them.

review_title: Super product for so ittle money,wow
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
reviewComment: super device and saved my sanity during this time of stay in

review_title: love the reader / hate barnes and noble
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2012
reviewComment: The reader is great except you cant use it until you register it. Went to the library and couldnt get on their wifi to do it. Nor could I use macdonalds where they have the at&t hotspot they promised would work. The nook wouldnt let me do it anywhere but a Barnes and Nobles store so I didnt get to use it for almost 2 weeks. Then I made my first purchase of an ebook...1 book...and they double charged me. once through barnesandnoble.com and again through barnesandnoble/marketplace. They appoligized but wouldnt be putting the money back for 5 days. Since this was cash money they took off my debit card I was just out for days...wonder what would have happened if Id bought 10 books? The nook seems to work great now that I can use it, but using barnes and noble for you ebooks might not be the best idea. They admitted they were having a problem with the double dipping and were trying to fix it. I had it happen 2 years ago when I ordered on line to have paper backs sent to me. So it hasnt been fixed in 2 years:( But I like the nook!

review_title: ... the screen when the touchscreen stops responding - otherwise perfect.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2017
reviewComment: Need to clean the screen when the touchscreen stops responding - otherwise perfect.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2012
reviewComment: I like my Nook. No, I love it. I'm sure Kindle is good too but this was in my price range and can read PDF and epub. I've read so  much on this thing since I bought it and I can't stress enough how much I don't miss hardback books. Those things were heavy! I suppose if I wanted to look at lovely color illustrations I go back to my paper books but as far as I'm concerned, most of my reading is done on this now.

review_title: Simple reader get the job done right!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2013
reviewComment: This is the second Nook ive owned. I was satisfied with the first and even more with the second. (The first didnt break or have any defects.) I love the compact size and the online capability of it. You can use a computer and login using your acount. You can review books, buy or get samples of books, and share books with your friends. The all touch screen makes flipping the page a snap! WOuld buy another any time!

review_title: Excellent delivery time. I actually accidentally ordered 2.. long story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2013
reviewComment: I Ordered two by accident didn't think the first order had gone thru. anyway on the order after writing to the seller to see if they could mail ASAP they did at no extra cost to me so my grandson got it for his birthday. On the return of the other they have been gracious and approved the return which will be mailed back today or  Monday. They have been wonderful  to work with and very kind  to a senior citizen that sometimes messes up(orders). Thank you soooo much for your kindness and my grandson loves the Nook.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2013
reviewComment: Great e-reader!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2013
reviewComment: The Nook simple touch e-book does all it purports.  I had a few difficult moments trying to download some books.  I am not that computer savvy yet but I managed. I viewed a how-to video to find out about other functions of the book.  I am still learning. Nook could provide some sort of introductory leaflet describing how to access the e-book's different functions. I look the book and enjoy reading while waiting at the Doctor's office, etc.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2020
reviewComment: I had heard of the book and of the films that were based on this book, so it was finally time to read it when Amazon put it on sale. I have not seen the original Omega Man nor the Will Smith version of the films. I read this book using immersion reading while listening to the audiobook version. Robertson Dean's narration was prefect, matching the emotion of the text. The idea of a mutated gene is relevant considering the pathogens known and unknown. The ending was quite surprising at first, but then I remembered that a good deal of early science fiction tended to be somewhat depressing. I believe that's why I'm such a Star Wars, Marvel and Star Trek fan, their views are based on hope, not the constant dirge of apocalyptic nightmares so many authors and books write about. Definitely not one of my favorites. I would've loved to have seen the Punisher take the vamps out.

review_title: More like “I am a Gross Racist Misogynist Man”
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2020
reviewComment: I really wanted to like this book before I read it. Learning about the struggle of one “uninflected” person left in the midst of the vampire apocalypse sounded so interesting. Even not knowing how different this book would be from the Movie adaptation of the same name, I wanted it to be intriguing. And it was in certain parts, but Robert was absolutely distasteful. His (or the author’s) racist and misogynist ideas seeped into every other aspect of the book. I wanted to sympathize with a person dealing with depression and addiction and loneliness and discovery but when Neville would reveal parts of himself in explaining the story I just hated him more and more. It just made me wish is Virginia or Kathy had lived rather than him, and much later that Ruth had instead been the main character.

review_title: One of the best classic horror stories
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2016
reviewComment: There are some books that, while good in and of themselves, later generations may have a hard time fully appreciating because they lack context. I am Legend feels like one of those books. While modern readers should appreciate it as good zombie apocalypse novel with a clever twist, connoisseurs of the genre will recognize it for the landmark novel it is.

review_title: A Solid Last Man on Earth Book (with Vampires!)
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
reviewComment: This is a fantastic novella from a brilliant writer. It was way ahead of its time and Matheson inspired so many giants in the horror field, including Stephen King. This book in particular is one of the main contributing forces that gave rise to the zombie genre. I wouldn't say this is a literary masterpiece so much as an amazing story that is solidly written. The premise is dazzling and it kept me turning the pages. I will refrain from giving it the fifth star because some of Neville's thinking got a touch repetitive for me and I was actually a little confused about what constituted a (WARNING, mild spoiler) vampire or another kind of undead type of vampire being that isn't quite a vampire. I honestly can't spoil it too bad because I don't clearly understand that part.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2019
reviewComment: I can't believe this was written in the 50s.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2019
reviewComment: The story is very slow, and we laboriously learn information that turns out to be pointless. Without giving away too much, we spend chapters slowly learning, exploring to get material to study and test hypotheses, forever testing... And then all in one swoop we find all that was for nothing, and had little to no bearing on the ending. I will say though, the last chapter is good. The build up just falls flat.

review_title: It sucks and it’s racist and it’s not like the movie
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2018
reviewComment: This is a thinly veiled metaphor for a World overrun by so called inferior races. The protagonist readily expresses contempt for the vampires while repeatedly seeking to suppress his deep desire for the wanton female vampires which is no more than a poor and obvious metaphors for racist white men’s objectification of black women and fear and dehumanization of black men. Take the time period the book was written in and a few more obvious clues early on and it’s clear this ‘vampire story’ is just a racist metaphor. We will be invaded by vampires (minorities) until our society decays to nothing

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
reviewComment: A lot of end-of-the-world fiction is poorly written, so it's nice to find a high quality gem in the genre. The movie was good, but I found the book to be even better. The primary characterization is spot-on, especially the in depth dive into alcoholism, which I can personally attest speaks to the truth of the disease. Making our hero somewhat of an as* is likewise genius, and when the reader experiences a bit of revulsion towards this main dude and his borderline misogyny, it's not bad writing, but good.

review_title: A little dated...but a good story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2019
reviewComment: I knew that this book was a far cry from the movie so no surprises there.  Overall, it’s a pretty good story.  However, it does suffer from a dated “70’s style” of writing.  For instance, the author assumes the reader doesn’t know about “mutant genes” and the activities of bacteria and viruses...which are all pretty common knowledge, nowadays.  Also, I’ve seen this with other authors from the 70’s...they seem to have an almost romantic fascination with smoking...and weird heavy drinking.

review_title: Easily the best horror book I've ever read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2019
reviewComment: Most apocalypse stories tell you about a Motley Crue of heroes who try to beat the odds and survive a hell on earth with more often than not have a form of a happy ending. Not this one. This book follows Robert Neville as he lives day to day with little to know hope in probably the most accurate form of life with depression I've seen written in a book (I have a depression and a lot of the storytelling hits very close to home.) There is dread and horror and an overwhelming feeling of hopelessness that pervades the entirety of this book. My only regret is not buying this book to read sooner.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2018
reviewComment: “My Heart, Christ’s Home”? That tiny book, about turning your heart into various rooms of a home and inviting Christ into each one to do a thorough cleaning, seems to be the premise for Rubart’s book “Rooms: a novel”.  The main character has had severe trauma as a child and consequently walked away from God and family in lieu of a life he could fully control that is centered around work. One day at the office he receives an official notice that a deceased uncle, seemingly unknown to him, has bequeathed him an extremely valuable, beachfront home. After one weekend visit to supposedly set up the sale of this place, our protagonist is off on an adventure of discovery and forgiveness that will reunite with his father and his FATHER. A bit difficult to catch on to the shifting times, places and POV’s but you’ll find it uplifting and worth the effort.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2019
reviewComment: Excellent with a but.  Though I try daily to walk the journey that with the Lords help will bring me to the peace and joy that passes all understanding, I found the references to the supernatural hard to understand in this writers work. Each of God’s people have their own journey to take that can be filled with pain and suffering or journeyed through in quiet grace.  So many times I found my own cry’s of  “Why” being unanswered in my journey and have thought that the Lord will only give us what we can bear. My thanks be to the Father for the Blessings he gives each of us and May the Father continue to Bless you on your journey to His Grace, Peace and All encompassing Love.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
reviewComment: I want to start this review in one of three ways: #1: "Wow, what a great allegory!" #2: "Wow, I didn't want to put this books down!" and #3: "Wow, reading this book was a spiritual experience for me!"

review_title: This should be made into a movie
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2017
reviewComment: I bought this book because my sister asked me to read it with her. It's something we share. We've both been going through some tough stuff and could use some inner and physical healing. At first, it was difficult for me to sympathize with the main character, who seemed to have everything I need. But the story unfolds to reveal he needs the same thing I really need. A closer relationship with God, a realization of the things and the voices that zap our passion and confuse our path.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2017
reviewComment: I am beyond words at how much I loved this book. There is rich, visual detail.  There is the clear battle between Heaven and Hell for a man's heart without it being corny. It emphasizes the importance of relationship with Christ over religious acts. It is full of direct Bible quotes. It has romance but it's not disgusting, soft porn or even the main story. I usually eschew any and all Christian books with romance but this was different. It addresses emotional pain in a way that makes you feel it with the character. The inherited house is such a point of great fascination, handled with incredible detail. I started this story slow but at chapter 3, I couldn't stop reading. After I started, I had the book finished in less than 24 hours.  I recommend this for the Christian reader who needs a little more supernatural than most Christian books seem to be offering. My only regret with this book is the fact that it's over.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2014
reviewComment: ROOMS by James L. Rubart

review_title: Rooms is a Journey Worth Taking
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2018
reviewComment: Rooms is a novel about one man's spiritual journey. He has found a life that appears rich and blessed but is in fact empty. This is a familiar theme to anyone who reads books that tell the stories of people who seem to have it all but inexplicably find their lives are empty. The challenge is to tell the story in a unique and surprising way. And that is exactly what Rubart does. It is a special gift to take what is a formulaic approach to a story and give it the twists and turns that keep it interesting and unique. This was a great read and I recommend it enthusiastically. Enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2014
reviewComment: Writing a review while still enveloped in the afterglow of reading it may not be the wisest time, yet I simply cannot wait a second longer to express my thoughts about this one. Let me start by saying that James Rubart is brilliant.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2018
reviewComment: This was a  great book.  I had no idea when I ordered this book that it would even be a Christian book. As a believer seeking God's will, I had decided to stop reading my favorite genre because I knew God didn't approve of  some of the sexuality explicit scenes in most of them.  I liked the cover of this book and ordered it. I can see the hand of God leading me to this book. I intend to start reading a lot more of James Rubarrt. His book was well written, and kept the interest like a magnet. Wish I  could give it ten stars!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2015
reviewComment: This is the first novel that I have read by James Rubart, and it will not be the last. The story of Micah Taylor, a millionaire, who has conquered the world of business prowess and luxuries many people dream about, has his life turned upside down when he receives a letter from a great uncle with whom he has never had a relationship. However, though his uncle has given him a mansion, he is also leading Micah on a path to face his past--the good and the bad, so that Micah can reconnect with a God whose voice is now a distant part of Micah's life. This novel is about the battle for a soul and only if Micah Taylor relinquishes his worldly life, as well as faces a past that he would prefer to not remember, not only will he allow God to truly have his heart but Micah Taylor will also be free.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2015
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz has achieved what others have tried and failed...to not only successfully write as A.C. Doyle / Dr. Watson, but to depict Sherlock Holmes as Watson depicted him and in the language and setting of the times. In reading The House of Silk I actually thought I as reading A.C. Doyle...and thoroughly enjoyed it!!! IT is so nice to be able to read more of Holmes and Watson and the further adventures. I've been a fan since a young boy and gladly grew old with them,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2016
reviewComment: As a BIG fan of all things Sherlock Holmes, I was excited to read this book! I think the author did a good job of capturing the mood of the original stories, describing a dark underbelly of crime in London, and staying true to the characterization of Holmes and Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2018
reviewComment: It’s easy to believe that this is an original, long lost Sherlock Holmes story. It sits happily amongst all his other delightful and page turning adventures. Once I reached about a third the way in I was well and truly hooked.  I abandoned the jobs of my day and read through to the most satisfying conclusion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2018
reviewComment: This is another Sherlock Holmes interesting read ...... As the storyteller Dr. Watson describes in detail the plot of the story and, rather than being boring, the detail adds to the enjoyment of the novel ...kudos to the author for continuing the legend of Sherlock Holmes ... I understand that the discovery of what was going on at the House of Silk is a current situation but I would have preferred a less disturbing way to tie up the loose ends of the plot ...overall it was a very good read

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2013
reviewComment: Solid mystery, moved along at decent pace, but I wasn't excited about this book. I don't want to give any spoilers away, so I have to keep my comments vague, but my big peeve was that the characters seemed very flat compared to the original stories, including some reactions to different situations that didn't seem in character at all to me. There was absolutely no purpose to an entire chapter where Watson encounters a famous name, except to have an appearance by that famous name in the book and that irked me. If you're looking for a good Sherlock Holmes Pastiche, read Laurie R King's 'Beekeeper's Apprentice' series or Lyndsay Faye's 'Dust and Shadow'.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2015
reviewComment: I have read with pleasure this new addition to the chronicles of Sherlock Holmes.  The tempo, though slightly different, is exactly as I remember Holmes stories to be.  Anyone wishing to revisit the twist and turns of this most famous detective should certainly read this book.  This story is not for the faint of heart.  It is a lot more modern in its rendition than Sir Arthur would have written but holds the suspense until the last, if not more graphic in its telling. Loved the book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
reviewComment: I love Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes . To me Anthony Horowitz's  versions are the best offered!  I enjoy how he writes as if he is in the 19 th century, even to the cadences of speech.

review_title: Excellent. True to Holmes and Watson Legacy
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2020
reviewComment: Loved it. Well written, kept my interest and was true to who Holmes and Watson are. Well worth the purchase price. Gave it to my picky Son afterward and sure he will like it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2019
reviewComment: I am a long time devotee of Sherlock Holmes, so I was a bit skeptical of this book. I am happy to say I was wrong! It's just very, very good and I think fans of the original stories will not be disappointed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2015
reviewComment: After just reading the compete works of Sherlock Holmes, I was hungry for more adventures.  This piece echoes closely the style of the original works and attempts to draw connections between some of A.C.D.'s individual mysteries.  The writing is more detailed and 2 mysteries are interweaved into one, which is more satisfying for modern readers who are also well familiar with crime television.  I highly recommend this book, however, I do agree with another reviewer that this book is not for young readers...personally, I would not allow my son to read it until he has reached adulthood.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2015
reviewComment: William Boyd seems to want to write from the female point of view and that rarely works.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2013
reviewComment: I read a New York Times preview of the TV movie, was intrigued and was fortunate to find this in book form.  A wonderful read!  The blending of two separate timelines was well done, flowing seamlessly from one generation to the other.  The story line reminded me of Scott Turow's "Ordinary Heroes", where "ordinary people did extraordinary things"  -  never ceases to amaze me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2012
reviewComment: I enjoyed the mind games in this novel, between spy and mentor, woman and man, America and Britain, mother and daughter. The games of espionage, love affairs, allied forces and family happened in WWII as well as at the present. Ambition, selfishness, mistrust and betrayal led to conflicts between those who were supposed to be partners. To win those games, you have to think what your opponent thinks what you are thinking and then surprise him, rock-paper-scissors.

review_title: Besides being one of Boyd's best novels, this is surely also the most accessible
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2015
reviewComment: Besides being one of Boyd's best novels, this is surely also the most accessible. It has all his hallmarks: the meticulous use of vocabulary, the careful historical research, the smart dialogue. It is a spy story but not a thriller, for Boyd feels no need to keep the reader on the edge of the seat. there are other considerations -- relationships, the sense of destiny, the watchfulness of every person's life -- and Boyd give them time. So the full thrust of the story is as good as the suspense he creates.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
reviewComment: William Boyd is a superb author.  His characters are human, and interesting; their stories intrigue us.  He's written 16 novels as of March 2021 and I plan to read them all.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2012
reviewComment: William Boyd really knows how to tell a good story.  This one is a tale of pre-WWII spycraft and one particularly resourceful and resolute woman working for a branch of the British secret service.  When the action jumps forward to the 1970s, the woman's daughter becomes a second and related focus of her mother's story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2015
reviewComment: The author provides some insight into spy training which is interesting. It also reviews the history of the UK and America leading up to the US entry into WW II. The plot is intriguing but not to complicated to follow. You do care about the fates of the leading characters. It is not a whodunnit but something a good deal more involved with several interesting turns. I found it compelling to read.

review_title: Set in 1976. A 28-year-old single mom who is ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2016
reviewComment: Set in 1976. A 28-year-old single mom who is sorta working on her thesis (the German Revolution 1918-1923) at Oxford and is definitely supporting herself teaching idiomatic spoken English to foreign students at Oxford  learns, little by little, about her widowed mother’s past – and that past is a doozy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2016
reviewComment: I was curious to read this book after watching the series, which I had thoroughly enjoyed.  The book was just as good.  Eva's cool-headedness and resourcefulness were well described, and some of the situations which were difficult to follow in the movie version were explained at greater length.  Ruth's story, however, was mundane and utterly unnecessary to the plot.  Her loser friends and aspiring lover added nothing to the story, and were wisely dropped from the series.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2014
reviewComment: I had so much fun reading this story.  Most of us have never heard of the effort that the British intelligence put into getting the US to join in the fight against Hitler. I was fascinated by the newspaper articles that were planted all over the world to mislead Hitler's war plans and the fake maps that were produced to sway our country to join the war. Enjoy this story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2010
reviewComment: Song of Thunder is more than a thriller. It bravely tackles the scariest and biggest questions of our day. Through his vivid characters' conversations, actions and backgrounds, the author has a way of bringing those questions to life in scenarios that really did keep me on the edge of my seat. Somehow he even gives the characters a sense of humor to keep them (and the reader) sane through it all..

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2010
reviewComment: Go ahead, just try to catch your breath while reading "Song of Thunder." Just when I thought Thunder and Co were out of the woods, I discovered they were in more trouble than health care reform. Great characters. Great pacing. One heck of alot of fun. Give "Song of Thunder" a try.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 29, 2012
reviewComment: I enjoyed The Poison Tree when it was published a few years ago, so I was keen to get my hands on a copy of this, the second murder thriller from Erin Kelly. In a nutshell, this is a story of unequal love and unequal friendship and their fatal consequences - played out in the late 1980s and the present in London, the Thames Estuary, and a historic garden near Leamington Spa. The sense of time and place are accurate, nostalgic and compelling; it's become a bit of a trademark forte for this author. The pace is slow enough to let the book breathe and fast enough to ensure that you will continue reading until the bitter end. This is really far too fun to be classed 'literaray' (thank God), but actually - it's pretty classy stuff. Kelly has been compared to de Maurier, which is unfair - she's much better. And if she's good enough for Stephen King for chrissakes ("I wish I'd written it") - she's good enough for the rest of us. A great read. Highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 14, 2014
reviewComment: I read Burning Air and then the Poison Tree so this was the 3rd book by Erin Kelly I have read. I like the way she goes into the past but I found it quite distracting this time.  She not only goes backwards and forwards into Paul's life she also does it to Louisa's life so it gets a bit comlicated at times. It begins in 2009 but goes back to 1989 and eventually you end up in 2010.  Still a good story and unusual.  I would recommend it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 6, 2014
reviewComment: The story is pacey and presents some quite gripping psychological tensions, but it just doesn't convince. The characters and dialogue are too stagey and the key relationship between 39-year-old middle class, downwardly mobile Laura and 19-year old victim Paul so implausible that it jars the whole way through. The book is presented as a literary work, with reading notes, but its reach exceeds its grasp.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 23, 2013
reviewComment: I could not put this book down! i nearly didn't buy this book, mostly because i wasn't very enamoured with The Poison Tree, but I am so glad I did. It is so much better than her first novel and emanates Ruth Rendell when she was at her best. The ending was unexpected, with twists along the way. I would definitely recommend reading this if you are a fan of Ruth Rendell's earlier work. I shall definitely be buying the next book by Erin Kelly.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 12, 2017
reviewComment: This is a brilliant book to read, couldn't put it down, was still thinking about it for days after I finished it, never had that feeling before, what a great book,definitely going to order some more of the authers  books

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 22, 2012
reviewComment: Erin Kelly has written yet another interesting and quirky thriller.  I did not like it quite as much as I liked her previous book, The Poison Tree, but I must admit, I found it hard to put down.  Kelly is excellent on atmosphere and characters, and this story about two misfit people of very differing age, was compelling.  They are both rather gullable and from the beginning, you can sense that there will be tears before bedtime - and there are.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 6, 2019
reviewComment: Absolutely guzzled this book, as I do all of Erin Kelly’s. I can’t put them down. Excellent pace, plot, just the right amount of “can’t look/have to look,” that all good suspense has.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 26, 2017
reviewComment: Stuck it out to the end but really wasn't worth the read .

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 9, 2017
reviewComment: After reading the Burning Air I wanted to read more of this author. I love the way she writes and the way the characters draw you in. I ended up really rooting for Paul and Louisa and actually feeling a bit sorry for Daniel . I thought he seemed quite a sad person whose failings were the catalyst for his anger.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 26, 2018
reviewComment: Fantastic fantastic fantastic fantastic fantastic fantastic. The author has the Midas Touch. Loved it, love the writing style (descriptive but not overly flowery) and as for the plot twists... well, I was gripped to the end.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2016
reviewComment: After watching the movie I wanted to read the book and see how they differed. To be honest, they are 2 completely different animals.

review_title: A Pioneering Effort in the Vampire Genre
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2014
reviewComment: I wanted to enjoy this novella more, but it didn't engage me enough to keep me turning the pages. I would put the book down for weeks and then pick it up again, read a bit more, and repeat the cycle.

review_title: A single book with no prequel or sequel that I know of
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
reviewComment: A single book with no prequel or sequel that I know of.  I read the well printed and bound MMPB published by Tor.  This book was originally published in 1954.

review_title: Mass market paperback is actually several stories
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2016
reviewComment: This book was awesome. No complaints about it at all. I'd been wanting to read the book since seeing "The Last Man on Earth" and "I am Legend" (which definitely wasn't as good as the former, of the book). The book is better than either movie (I can't speak to "The Omega Man" because I've never seen it). One thing I will point out is that if you are buying the mass market paperback version, please note that the book actually contains "I am Legend" as well as many other short stories. I was a little thrown off when reading the book, and about in the physical middle of the book the story ended and short stories picked up. Yea, there was a table of contents that I paid no mind to, because nothing on the book cover or in the book mentioned that it contained other short stories. I was a little disappointed thinking that I still had half a book left, only to realize I was at the end. Technically, all the extra short stories are bonuses, if you like horror short stories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
reviewComment: I found it interesting when thinking about what my expectations were versus what the story actually was just because of my familiarity with the latest movie version. The biggest being that it is an original take on the vampire, which blew me away. I had no idea that vampires were the antagonist, or of the era in which it takes place. It's not a very long story either and if I'd been able to read each night I probably would've finished it easily in a couple days. I was literally at the 50% point just two days ago and that second half was riveting. This was a great read and one I'd recommend to anyone interested in a classic.

review_title: Much better than the movie adaptions
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2014
reviewComment: I love my vampire and zombie fiction, but this really isn't either of those. Its a lot more than just bloody gore and jumpy scares. Its also about survival, and the struggles of man with his inner demons and loneliness. Themes that go a bit deeper than your average zombie apocalypse movie. For that I actually really liked it, though it did start out pretty slow but once I got past the first few chapters it quickly became a page turner for me. Like many others I first heard about this book through the movies, for me it was I Am Legend with Will Smith. In my opinion if you haven't seen the movies yet, or already have, then you should read the book as well. None of the movie adaptions have the same weight as the book does.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2020
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book. Its kinda cheesy but I really like the main character and the world the author builds around them. The meaning of the story that I found was satisfying. When I finished I Am Legend I was kinda disappointed however that the story didn't keep going and instead so far it seems like its just short stories. I mean they are fine but I mainly want to read more I Am Legend not short stories. I wont take off a star for it however but it is something to note.

review_title: Even depression and alcoholism can’t defeat a vampiric-zombie apocalypse.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2014
reviewComment: Despite its vampire origins, this book originated many medical, zombie, dystopian thrillers. Robert Neville is alone. Very alone. Well, not completely alone. His family, friends, and neighbors have all come down with a bad case of vampirism. However, this sickness more closely resembles zombism (without the brain eating). The vampires have an intelligence much closer to (but slightly above) your typical walking dead.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2020
reviewComment: I was so surprised when I read this the first time after seeing the movie because it's much shorter and some of the details are different.  I love the movie and I actually like this just as much even though it's different.  I didn't realize it was written in the 50's as a futuristic tale of the 70's.  I liked that Robert wasn't a scientist in the book; just a regular guy trying to figure out what happened.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2016
reviewComment: 4.5 Stars!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2017
reviewComment: This reader is almost iconic - there is nothing to compare with the readability, battery life and format compatibility. I purchased this to replace the exact same model that I have been using for nearly 10 years, and I'll be sad when I can't replace it again.

review_title: I love my Nook simple touch but BEWARE of buying from AMAZON
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2012
reviewComment: I love my Nook simple touch but will review another time.  Right now I want to alert everyone not to buy your Simple  Touch from Amazon.  While I love Amazon, I thought I would use my gift cards to purchase my Nook from them rather than going directly to Barnes & Noble.  Was directed to several dealers and selected Ricks Collectibles who had a great rating.  My Nook came quickly and everything seemed OK until I tried to purchase the extended coverage.  Apparently my Nook had been purchased in November at Sears, resold and somehow ended up at Ricks.  Although I purchased it Jan. 3, 30 days had elapsed from the date it was originally purchased it November and I couldn't purchase the service contract.  PLUS, my 1 year warranty actually started in November, so I got gyped there too.  I never realized I was going to run into this trouble when I purchased my Nook and the only reason I bought it this way was to use up my Amazon gift cards.  From what I've read on people's reviews they love the service contract...if they drop their Nook they get a replacement immediately.  If this is important to you....PLEASE DON'T PURCHASE YOUR NOOK FROM AMAZON.

review_title: Talked to a tech and he said PC was my best alternative for that
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2015
reviewComment: I had read that you could read still in copyright (about 75 yrs)public library books on this-FREE.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
reviewComment: This  nook really  was like new. I am  thrilled  as my old  one died and I love the plain simple touch. Great  transaction.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2012
reviewComment: I purchased this nook for a friend who was retireing.  She has had hand surgery and has difficulty with heavy objects.  She loves her nook simple touch.  She takes it everywhere she goes.  Fits easily in a purse or briefcase even a backpack.  It is easy to order and download books.  She even ordered magazines.  Great gift for anyone from toddlers to great grand parents.  Excellent for students.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2013
reviewComment: Just received my eBook Reader and am very pleased with it.  Only problem, the usb cable doesn't seem to keep a firm connection to the devise and it took longer than usual for the book to charge.  I finally used the usb cable that came with my first Nook and it charged in no time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2013
reviewComment: I bought this to replace a Sony PRS-300 that I thought was too heavy and too slow in the page turning.  Yes, the nook is quicker on the page turning and lighter but I am having too much trouble to appreciate faster and lighter.  I am having an infinite amount of trouble getting library books onto the nook - I've yet to succeed and the problems lie with adobe digital editions.  Why aren't nooks plug and play?  That's my first big problem.  I have no problem with my Sony and the library book I wanted is now on my Sony.  The second is that I like to read while I'm eating my lunch - ereader in left hand and fork in right.  It is not easy to change the page on the nook while eating - the bottom right corner is too far from my thumb and the bottom buttons are too high up the side.  The Sony has a set of buttons right in the bottom center, which is perfect placement.  I read the great reviews on the nook and for the price, I thought it was worth a try.  I'm also disappointed with the wifi registration requirement and wifi in general.  I don't need wifi on my ereader but it looks like they're all offering it now.  I also don't appreciate my registration info being used by B&N as permission to start emailing me crap - I am already unsubscribed from that 'service'.  I'm definitely not happy with the nook and I'm going to save up my money to buy another Sony.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
reviewComment: It’s okay, just the touch screen is slow to respond.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2014
reviewComment: I got this used, rooted it, and am loving it. However, I recently got the one with glowlight, which is even better (I can now read in the dark in the same room as my sleeping children and husband--yay!), although I'm praying it doesn't develop the light 'holes' that I've read about.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2016
reviewComment: I am not happy with this product at all, i ordered it for a friend for Christmas. We received a DEMO version of the nook and she was unable to log in and register it for her.I am returning this item and will be purchasing from someone else.

review_title: I love my Nook! It is now my most prized toy and portable library
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2014
reviewComment: I got a Nook from my husband for Christmas and I love it so much that I am shopping here to get one for him and another one for my brother who is an avid reader but who is pretty much stuck at home for health reasons. It's a perfect gift for those who find it difficult to get to stores or libraries to choose books. At [...] all the books are FREE and include most of the classics. They download in a flash and so do books from my library. Even the barnes and Noble website has good deals on books under 2.99.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2014
reviewComment: My wife have the older version of this Nick that was not backlit. She she told me she wanted this one and totally loves it. Now she's about to break me buying books all the time but it is well worth it. It's all so much cheaper than buying it in the stores anywhere. Great product.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2013
reviewComment: I would recommend this to all.  My daughter loves it and the big screen adjustable typeface make it a breeze to use, even for parents :)  Ordering books is so easy and you can download not only to your nook but to your laptop etc....for the same price.  Quality item and she really loves the illuminated background for traveling at night.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2014
reviewComment: I have been using the nook for around a month now and now, its like a Siamese twin. We are inseperable :) :). Okay, coming to the specs, the barnes and noble have thought of almost all features that are required by a reader. The inbuilt dictionary is a master stroke. One drawback is that, for PDFs, there is no option of looking up for using dictionary. The back light is very good and i am able to read for hours without any strain. In bright light, the nook is better than a book. I never expected so much clarity. A good buy. That too, the rate is so much less than a kobo, that has same features.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2014
reviewComment: Love this ereader..user friendly in making notes and highlights..you just have to put in a memory card so you will not experience slowing down in making notes..have used mine in making notes for my bible reading such have plenty of notes to write..

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2014
reviewComment: Bought this for my son for Christmas.  He had the Nook Color and didn't like the fact that the battery drained so quickly.  He only used it for reading and uses his computer for internet and gaming so this Nook was all he needed.  He loves it and has been able to keep it charged for much longer periods.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2016
reviewComment: So glad the Nook Simple Touch with Glow Light was available.  I love how you can page thru books with this device.  Works great!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2014
reviewComment: I bought this reader as a back up when I'm going on trips and will read outside in the sun. I normally use my Xoom tablet with the BN app. but sunlight is not your friend. This one is perfect for it AND I like have the light for when it's a little darker in a room

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2014
reviewComment: The GlowLight Nook Simple Touch was a gift for my husband who has severe arthritis but loves to read. Having this reader enables him to read without pain from holding a book. He reads for two to six hours a day. Every time he has some spare time he's on his Nook. Thank you for enabling him to continue to enjoy this pass time. As a retired senior with a computer the Nook Simple Touch GlowLight provides just enough technology without duplicating processes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2014
reviewComment: So glad I chose this!! It's easy to operate, has a clear picture, and the lighting doesn't hurt your eyes. It's also small enough that I can take it anywhere without a hassle. I love that I can just tap a word and be able to look it up or highlight it. And the battery life is amazing. I've been using it for 2 weeks and still have a nearly full charge.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2018
reviewComment: I'm having my Echo read this while I'm on my treadmill and it really keeps my attention and makes the time go fast. I tried to explain it to my daughter and called it paranormal which turned her off. But it isn't paranormal in a scary sense, at least so far. It's more of a psychological/fantasy/4th demension theme. Different than the usual book which is refreshing. My review is a bit premature since I haven't reached the end and hope it doesn't disappoint. But since I have over seven hours left and it will take some time to finish, I'll update this if my opinion changes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2013
reviewComment: It seems the blurb and cover of this book led some reviewers to think this would be a haunted house story. It's actually something like a Christian version of "Sliding Doors" which intrigued me from the start.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2018
reviewComment: I have to say that I didn't know what to expect from this book but it was not anything like I'm used to reading. I found myself on the edge of my seat with it. Sorry, spoiler alert! And I found myself trying to tell him not to believe what he was being told by the voice but then the things the voice were saying would start to make sense and I would think, 'am I wrong in thinking that he shouldn't listen to the voice?' But God tells us we have to be careful because the devil will hide his lies in the truth and we need to know the word so we can distinguish truth from untruth.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2015
reviewComment: Christian fantasy.  It's been used before, but I haven't seen it like this.  Micah is rich, but unfulfilled.  His father has treated him badly since his mother died years before.  He and Julie are partners and plan to be partners in life.  But she's not the right woman for him.  She is fully caught up in the world and what it holds for her.  Micah was very close to God at one time, but has drawn away.  A title to a home his great-uncle had built for him arrives.  Micah wants to go, but Julie won't.  The home is on the Oregon beach.  Micah goes and after looking through the whole house, he finds there's a new room that hadn't been there, and it holds an unfinished painting.  More rooms with different themes keep being added. Each one brings Micah new experiences.  There's a memory room where his memories are healed.  There are more rooms that must be explored.  So much happens that cannot be understood by human knowledge.

review_title: "All things are possible , through Christ who strengthen me".
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2013
