reviewComment: I wasn't too sure what to expect when I requested this book from Netgalley , a huge thanks by the way to Netgalley for providing me with a review copy - http://www.netgalley.com/ . I am now glad that I requested it . Rooms by James Rubart was such an amazing story that in parts are both believable and unbelievable and it goes to show that when God grants Miracles , they can be the impossible or at least fall into the impossible category, as the Bible verse goes "All things are possible , through Christ who strengthen me".

review_title: A Fantastic Story of Faith and Choices
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
reviewComment: Jim Rubart writes dynamic, out of the box fiction. Each book I've had the pleasure of reading by him is as unique as a snowflake and just as entrancing.

review_title: Choices--what importance do they really have?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2017
reviewComment: Super imaginative! I have never read any book that was as unique in its premise as this one. I was intrigued by it from the outset and couldn't wait to see what new turn it would take. The struggle between the old and new lives of the protagonist was accurately drawn and felt very real. The final decision was heart-wrenching and very well written. I enjoyed the narration as well. I would recommend this book to anyone who has ever struggled with following the narrow path that God has for us or agonized over whether our decisions have been the correct ones. This story will shed new light on those issues and give you a new way of thinking about future decisions.

review_title: Love it or hate it, kind of like how people view God
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2011
reviewComment: I am amazed at the vast differences in the reviews for this book.  So I am left with the thought that if you are seeking God you will enjoy the book.  If you don't give a rip about God you will hate this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2020
reviewComment: I found myself wanting it to be real.  Great story and the perfect mix of normal and paranormal.  Loved the way his choices, even in thought, made changes in his life.  Isn't that how it works in real life?  Great concept and well played out...the loss/gain comparison was very believable and satisfying.  I heard him interviewed in a podcast; now I'm ordering another by book by him.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2015
reviewComment: This is a book a person is going to get, or isn’t going to get – a book they’ll either find moving and that applies to them, or is complete hogwash and too spiritual and churchy-preachy. A young software tycoon with more baggage than Samsonite inherits a brand new home, from a long dead relative. A new home that was built just for him with specific instructions from the long dead relative. A house with rooms that appear out of nowhere, with the contents forcing him to face his past, his demons, his religious beliefs, and his future. Needless to say, the suddenly appearing rooms in his house that force him to confront issues are synonymous with the parts of his heart and head that have the same issues. The story itself is so-so, but the message contained therein has had me re-evaluating certain aspects of my own life that have long troubled me or that I’ve flat-out ignored. For that alone, it was worth the read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2018
reviewComment: This book is part of a longterm and ongoing personal study into the genetic sciences and historical reconstructions of the prehistory of humans and other species.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2019
reviewComment: So many words. So much conjecture. So little fact. Interesting at times. But more often disjointed. Always argumentative, not so often logical.

review_title: A History of Our Most Important Relationship
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2015
reviewComment: I read this book because I had an hypothesis that current thinking about the domestication of the wolf was wrong and that humans and dogs formed a symbiotic hunting relationship prior to us controlling their breeding. This was the only book I could find that touched on this topic. It  also covers the entire history of the spead of dogs and the many physical changes they have undergone to fit the uses towhich humans have put them -- hunting, herding, guarding etc. I think at times it is a bit long winded and repetative, but an enjoyable book overall.

review_title: Well documented summary of dog-human co-evolution
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2012
reviewComment: As a geologist, 'dog guy' and occasional K9 trainer, I greatly enjoyed this book. Mr. Derr has summarized current scientific literature on dog-human evolution (including genome research) and presented it in layman's terms and in a very readable way. He includes relevant archeological history, particularly canine/ human migration routes and settlement patterns.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2012
reviewComment: I concur with other reviewers that this book is very repetitious.  While I understand that most authors who are trying to make a specific argument often state the claim over and over, they also usually offer different examples or evidence to support that claim.  Derr restates the same claim and evidence in just about every chapter.  Also, he moves between periods and geographies without organization. Just when I thought he was moving forward in time, with foragers to farmers, he jumped back to foragers again.  Or, just when I thought I was along for the ride as humans were crossing the Berring Strait, he leapt back to the Middle East or Eastern Europe.  This disorganized book left me thinking that maybe there just isn't enough evidence to support a solid theory on how dogs became dogs.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2019
reviewComment: This is a great history how wolves became domesticated dogs! A great read for all ages!

review_title: A wonderfully fascinating and scientifically accurate rambling
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2017
reviewComment: A wonderfully fascinating and scientifically accurate rambling... like a dog sniffing down a trail... journey through the possibilities of how wild wolves and early humans realized an interaction could benefit both species. Science and prehistory done fun.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2017
reviewComment: a little confusing

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2012
reviewComment: I agree with one of the previous reviews, this book should have been subjected to much better editing.

review_title: goes great with the book Dogs
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2014
reviewComment: Very interesting study on the canid family, goes great with the book Dogs; Their fossil and evolutionary history

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2013
reviewComment: The prologue to THE GUILT OF OTHERS is exquisitely poignant: a mother refusing to let go her new born baby whose congenital birth defects were discovered in the womb when the foetus was five months. The baby's birth and death brings to the surface molten cracks in the Ryrie family that have simmered unacknowledged for years.

review_title: THE COST OF SECRETS ON A FAMILY....
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2011
reviewComment: Loss presents itself in its many forms throughout this portrait of a family:  the Ryries, who live in Nyack, NY, and seemingly live ordinary lives.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
reviewComment: Indeed the journey to this awakening in Cohen's immense novel is pain filled and tortured. Each member of the disparate group has their own devious travels. The characters reflect the imperfections of humankind.

review_title: Kindle reveals flaw, but overall excellent story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2011
reviewComment: The Grief of Others

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2013
reviewComment: Ricky Ryrie just gave birth to her son, Simon, who will in 57 hours, breathe his last breath.  Simon is diagnosed with a condition that is "incompatible with life" during Ricky's 5th month of pregnancy.  The choice that Ricky makes in that moment will affect each member of her family.  THE GRIEF OF OTHERS tells the story of the life before, during and after Simon.  The Ryrie family is falling apart.  Grief and lies tear them apart and grief and truth will pull them together.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2014
reviewComment: I found this book to be absolutely compelling and beautifully written. An intimate exploration of parenthood, childhood, and family life this book explores the impact of one mother's decision and its trickle-down effect upon her family. "The Grief of Others" raises many questions and attempts (wisely) to answer very few. I found it thought-provoking with thoroughly developed and complex characters. I highly recommend this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2015
reviewComment: Very disappointed in this novel. Whoever edited the book should be looking for work in another occupation. I found a number of situations where the characters contradicted themselves. The most interesting character is the young girl, Biscuit, but her role in the story fades away as the novel moves forward.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2013
reviewComment: While I haven't finished reading this book yet, I am thoroughly enjoying it.  Each character is portrayed in depth, giving the story wonderful texture.  I look forward each day to picking up where I left off the day before.  I would highly recommend it to others who love the story of imperfect families.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2014
reviewComment: I found this a strange read, as well, I can't really say but I found it had to similarities to where I live (which is where it is set) someone has my name, on and on, so I couldn't read it without identifying with it somehow?

review_title: A touching look at the ways that grief can affect a family
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2012
reviewComment: This book did not always ring true to me, but it is very well written and especially good at making readers care for the family.  I would recommend this to others with no problem

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2015
reviewComment: Even if you are not a Conan Doyle fan, you can enjoy Anthony Horowitz' addition  to Dr. Watson's chronicle of the cases solved by Sherlock Holmes.

review_title: For those of us who love Sherlock and John
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2017
reviewComment: For those of us who love Sherlock and John, this hit the spot.  Good twists and surprises and intrigue over a nasty nasty nasty subject.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2018
reviewComment: This is a very good read, extremely believable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2015
reviewComment: It was with a little trepidation that I started this book, but as one who thoroughly enjoys Foyles War, I felt perhaps that Anthony Horowitz had the the writing chops to make a new Holmes novel work!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2016
reviewComment: Having just read the original Sherlock Holmes stories by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and falling head over heels in love with them, I was ready for more, but was also a tad skeptical about the ability for any SH pastiches to live up the original stories.  Fortunately I found "House of Silk", and was pleasantly surprised - it's very well written and kept my attention throughout. I would love to read more adventures of Mr. Holmes and Dr. Watson from Mr. Holowitz in the near future!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
reviewComment: Writing a Holmes book of this caliber is no small task. I have read the complete works by Sir Doyle, and House of Silk compairs remarkably well. Congratulations on a job well done, Mr. Horowitz.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2014
reviewComment: I have been a fan of Doyle and Holmes since I was a teenager and first picked up the Canon and read it for myself. I could actually persuade myself that I was only reading the last of Doyles tales of the great detective when I started in on Anthony Horowitz's book "The House of Silk." Commissioned by the family of Sir Arthur, he captured quite wonderfully the essence of the time period, the people who lived in it and most importantly Watson's style of narration, although this tale is much darker than any before it. A truly excellent read, hard to put down until the very last page.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2016
reviewComment: Between the writer and the fact that the Conan Doyle family had put their approval on this manuscript, I expected better. The story line began well enough but ended poorly. I was very disappointed. I'm a huge Conan Doyle fan, began reading his Sherlock Holmes stories in the late 50s, and was thrilled to read the background of how this book came about. I am also a big Foyle's War fan so, how could THE HOUSE OF SILK be anything but a well-written story? Unfortunately,  it's not.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2018
reviewComment: being a major fan of christie, connan doyle and other great british crime novelists, i had major expectations from this piece. especially given the rest of horowitz's oeuvre (foyle, barnaby, and many tv adaptations of marple and poirot). i am happy to say i enjoyed every page of the book: read it twice, with equal pleasure, first for the sheer fun of whodunnit, and second time to appreciate the clever prose. thank you, mr. horowitz, for such a wonderful time. i recommend the book to any and all lovers of british-style mystery.

review_title: Perfect Holmes from the past conveyed in New Release
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2019
reviewComment: This book surpassed my expectations from use/description of the voices and mannerisms of Holmes and Watson. The inter-related stories created suspense not confusion as a lesser quality New Release of a Sherlock Holmes mystery. Bravo.

review_title: I'll be back for more Boyd
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2017
reviewComment: This is my first Boyd book and I'll be reading more of his work. He's more than just a skillful story teller, he's a stylist. His writing seems a notch above many historical fiction authors. His characters are rich and his prose is sometimes borderline complex yet quite appealing.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2021
reviewComment: Lovely story of a woman's role during WWII.  How she out witted her male counterparts and helped her country fight its war.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2020
reviewComment: It was just great, the writing was excellent and you were kept guessing throughout!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2012
reviewComment: Restless is one of the best spy books I have ever read. The story is told in chapters alternating between England in the 1970's and WWII. The main characters in the 1970's are a young woman and her middle-aged mother. The WWII passages are about the mother, who was a spy. There is a traitor, too. The plot is realistic and the characters quite believable.

review_title: I have encourage seven people to read this book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2018
reviewComment: The first paragraph made me want to read the book.  It is interesting that a Grandmother had keep a secret from her husband and daughter and friends.

review_title: A spy with a very long memory
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2013
reviewComment: I thoroughly enjoyed this page-turner of a book, set in World War 2 and in the present day. Told in alternating points of view by a former spy and her daughter, who has just discovered that her mother is not who she thought she was, it captures the relationships between mother and daughter, spy and spy handler and daughter and lovers really convincingly. Lots of accurate historical detail, plenty of suspense and a couple of red herrings keep the plot moving along. Great fun.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2018
reviewComment: Well written. Held my interest throughout the book.  Great creation of the characters and interaction.  Will definitely lookforward to reading more of this author

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2020
reviewComment: Fantastic book, both historically plausible and currently timely. Full of observation, not just flights of contra factual fancy

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2016
reviewComment: Just finished this.  I never like "spy books" but this is a very human one, with little glitz, glamor, or shoot-em-outs.  The protagonist is a woman, with a strong yet feminine persona. Most of the story takes place just before the USA entered WWII.  As a reader who doesn't know a lot of history, I also learned from this book.  And bottom line, it was a good read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2007
reviewComment: This is a well written, finely crafted work of literary fiction in the form a a spy novel. As others have commented here, there are parallel running stories of mother and daughter. Mother was recruited as a spy while living in Paris in 1939. With training, her Russian emigre identity was effaced as she became a fully professional operative.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016
reviewComment: As a college student, I always try to find to best way to spend my money. Books are not exempted from it. This is a very good price for what it offers, it was cheaper than buying it directly from the company's website. I hesitated at first because I can't believe they can offer it at a price cheaper but I decided to take a risk and didn't regret that decision.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2018
reviewComment: Works great and cheaper than buying the same thing at the college bookstore.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2015
reviewComment: I could not use it because it was already used by another user!!

review_title: Pretty good but would nice if it had a feature ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2017
reviewComment: Pretty good but would nice if it had a feature to query by a keyword in a search field. Otherwise, it was easy to navigate, and the external links were a nice feature.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2017
reviewComment: Product was exactly as expected.  Worked well for the class I needed it for.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2017
reviewComment: Totally worthless. Was not school or class specific. I could not activate. A waste of money!!!!

review_title: I got a problem with the handbook, I couldn't ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2015
reviewComment: I got a problem with the handbook, I couldn't  accessed it I want to return it what  should I do to send it? Thanks

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2017
reviewComment: The pass was delivered earlier than expected. It did exactly what it was supposed to do. I am a satisfied customer.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2017
reviewComment: It served its purpose

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2017
reviewComment: Easy to use, no hassles.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
reviewComment: I chose to read this book because I enjoy the most recent movie adaptation (I’m still years behind). While there were some similarities, there were also enough differences to make the novel enjoyable. This isn’t just about Robert Neville’s physical survival, but also his mental and emotional survival. The author did a great job giving the reader a look into his psyche. I certainly recommend the read.

review_title: One of the first and best 'end-of-the-world' apocalyptic novels
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2016
reviewComment: Richard Matheson is one of my favorite authors. I have always enjoyed his novels and I especially enjoyed the episodes he wrote for The Twilight Zone television series.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2014
reviewComment: Having seen "The Omega Man" with Charlton Heston and heard a lot about the Will Smith version of the novel, I was hesitant to read the novel. I did so only because a book group was reading it this month.  I am not a fan of dystopian fiction so the first 10 percent or so was good but not great. Man alone hiding from infected former humans during the night foraging during the day.  But the conflict soon develops not just between the narrator, Robert Neville, and the vampire infected around him, but Robert's internal struggle.  First Robert is struggling within himself to remain sane, to accept the fact that he is alone. Robert's desire for human companionship and memories of his wife and daughter are eating at him almost driving him insane.  Then it becomes a battle against the "disease" of the infected. He reads and studies about viruses and bacteria.  He studies the blood under a microscope trying to find the cause and the cure of the infection.  Along the way he finds "almost" companions but the emphasis is not so much on the companionship but on looking for a cure for the infected.  Robert Neville is a fascinating character as he struggles with his environment, society, and himself.

review_title: Melancholy Dystopia More Than Vampire Horror
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2012
reviewComment: More melancholy than scary, I felt this was more of a dystopia than a horror book. For that reason, it only gets a 3/5ths of a scream rating. Still, it does have vampires in it so it isn't a walk in the park or anything. (Yet the vampires are more dumb than scary for the most part.)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2012
reviewComment: When the modern film adaptation I Am Legend came out in 2007, many people were annoyed or angered by the movie.  I heard things like, "it's nothing like the book", "the ending sucks" and "it misses the point".  Now I know why.  Let me just tell you, the movie does miss the point, particularly with the theatrical ending.  That version of the film misses the point like the missing the broad side of a barn  with a tactical nuke at point-blank range.  That's not to say I dislike the movie.  I thought that, with the alternate ending, it was pretty good.  I still think that.  However, reading the original story has changed my feelings about it a bit, namely that I like certain things about it less than the novel.  Now, I don't remember if the credits say "based on I Am Legend by Richard Matheson", but if they do, I believe they definitely commit the crime of false advertising.  The most it should say is "inspired by..."  The only similarities I can think of between the book and what I remember of the movie are:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2013
reviewComment: I have a passion for punishing myself by reading the books that inspired movies. The movies sometimes augment the books, assuming that the details you need you've already read from the print versions. Harry Potter was very much this experience. In some cases, I've enjoyed the books much more than the movie adaptations...Jurassic Park was one such movie. As beautiful as the film was, the book was leaps and bounds better.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2012
reviewComment: A virus of unknown origin has swept across the planet killing the majority of humans and mutating the rest - all except for one man who seems to be immune. The mutants have developed vampire-like traits, and the lone survivor, Robert Neville, barricades himself in his home by night to avoid being drained by them, and systematically searches for and destroys the mutants when they become comatose during the day.

review_title: A classic I suppose but not what I had hoped for
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2019
reviewComment: I understand that the book is seen as a classic by many, even if just in its genre, but for me the story felt flat. There were so many protagonists but no real resolution save for the message that society will always devolve to its lesser basic instincts.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2012
reviewComment: This is one of those classic books I've been meaning to get around to.  When it was finally on sale for less than a buck on the Kindle, I decided to take the plunge and I was not disappointed.

review_title: A little dated, but still a fun, quick read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2012
reviewComment: Let me start by being completely transparent: the main reason I bought "I Am Legend" was, essentially, to "kill time" until "The Twelve" by Justin Cronin is released.  I wanted a fairly short, quick read for my Kindle, that was also inexpensive.  Having heard and read many good things about Richard Matheson's work, I decided this would be the perfect appetizer to set me up for Cronin's main course.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 10, 2018
reviewComment: Not a patch on The Burning Air or He said, She said. Somewhat ponderous and predictable. I struggled to finish it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 30, 2013
reviewComment: I purchased this as it was described as a psychological thriller.  But, in my view, it doesn't quite meet this genre.  It was however, gripping and I couldn't put the book down waiting to read what happened to the characters.  A good read.  I haven't read any of Erin Kelly's books before but would definitely purchase this author again.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 16, 2018
reviewComment: Excellent story.  How will it end? Exciting finale.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 21, 2020

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 23, 2013
reviewComment: This is the 2nd of Erin Kelly's books that I have read and I plan to read more. Captivating - this book made me want to wake up early the next day to read another chapter before work.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 3, 2019

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2013
reviewComment: Because the Nook Simple Touch runs Android (albeit with most signs of it covered up), it can be rooted to allow the installation of Android apps. Opera Mobile allows for web browsing; various RSS readers make keeping up with the news a cinch; Mango provides more manga than I can ever hope to read; you can even install Amazon's Kindle app for Android! There are limitations, of course. Rooting the Nook (via Nooter), while not difficult, does require some level of computer know-how. The Simple Touch does not have any sort of audio output, and the e-ink screen can't handle video.  Still, having near-instant access to news, weather, email, books, comics, and most websites makes the Nook Simple Touch a great little device, especially if you can find one used.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2014
reviewComment: Relatively easy to use. Enjoying reading in bed without the issue of turning pages or holding a thick or heavy book open. Easy to plop into my purse for travel. I may want to upgrade to the colored and lit version, but will test this one out further.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2013
reviewComment: Unboxed the Nook. Charged it up. Won't connect to my Wifi network when three laptops in my house will. And it won't work at all until you register it. Posts on the Internet say its a complex technical issue. I'm calling the B&N tech people. If they can't fix it fast then this thing is going back. I didn't sign up for hours of struggling with Nook's technical problems. I have better things to do.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2012
reviewComment: Didn't realize you need a credit card on file to be able to load books onto the Nook. This was a gift for a 17 y/o along with a gift card to order books. She has been unable to actually use this item since she does not have  a credit card and neither do her parents. Should have researched this item more as it has not been very functional for the child I bought it for

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2012
reviewComment: Easy to use, bright screen and since its capacity can be expanded up to 32 gb by adding a micro sd card I think it is better than a Kindle. With this ability you are practically able to carry a library worth thousands of books. Also mobi and other file types can be easily converted to epub and organized using the free Calibre software you can download from the Calibre website. I have also purchased a CaseCrown Regal Flip Case from Amazon at a bargain price. It fits the Nook very well and is also a beautifull case.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2013
reviewComment: I wanted to buy an e-book and decided on a nook. Broke in 3 months. NOT WORTH YOUR MONEY. I tried to get support and the company refused to help me. Evidentally, there are screen problems with the Nooks. I did research and alot of other people had that same problem. Getting support for it is even worse. Don't bother with it. Go with a Kindle or a Sony.

review_title: thanks for the possibility to order the product to Europe
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2013
reviewComment: I am very happy with the product purchased. I'm glad I decided not to buy a kindle. The nook have the opportunity to expand store for. Meets all my needs. It is a pity that there are limits to America and Canada. If it were possible to record payment cards in Europe would be easier to me to buy the book. After all, I'm very happy with my purchase.

review_title: Great ebook reader and easily hackable
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2013
reviewComment: While it doesn't have a light and its screen has been far surpassed by other readers throughout the years. However since it uses android you can easily root it and install apps that allows you to read Kindle books and pretty much anything else your heart desires. Even can play Angry Birds if you really wanted to.

review_title: It performs well and I am very satisfied with it
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
reviewComment: This was purchased to replace an older, defective, Simple Touch reader. It performs well and I am very satisfied with it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2016
reviewComment: Really enjoying my Nook.  Easy to use and I'm able to check books out of my local library and download from websites like Project Gutenberg online (as well as purchase books from B&N)!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2014
reviewComment: This is my very first e-reader so I did not know this upfront, but unless you register your Nook with BN.com (which I choose not to do because I only bought it to read epubs and pdfs I already own) AND some of your content is purchased directly from BN.com, you will only have 240MB of space on the device.  So in effect, I found myself with 1/8 of the space I thought I'd bought.

reviewComment: It's an excellent product. I would give it 5 stars except for the screen, which scratches way, way, way too easily. I scratched it twice on the first day of use. There's no reason a product like this should be super-sensitive.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2014
reviewComment: A christmas gift for my husband. No time for the library so this is a perfect product for him. He loves the light and the size. It is very convenient. I would recommend this for any avid reader! I would recommend a Pro Tek case to keep it safe.

reviewComment: It  had the information I was interested in and I was looking for.I am completely satisfied with this purchase. thanks

review_title: Good Dog history, tough for the casual reader.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2013
reviewComment: This is a great book for the dog lover whose interest goes beyond the dog we have today and more to how it became this way. What this book mainly lacks is visual concepts and drawings of what Mark is saying to the reader. He brings up a lot of interesting points about the evolution of the domestic dog; however I have to keep a computer nearby so that I can look up the geologic time and Canis ancestor terms that he liberally throws at the reader. Also I want visual references of the dog's ancestors that he mentions and I have to look those up as well.

review_title: How the Dog Became the Dog from Wolves
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2014
reviewComment: As I am a pet lover, I like to read anything about dogs so as to make my pets life better and I enjoy his company so it is a good read this book as I always learn somthing

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2015
reviewComment: Good product

review_title: I was looking for something easier to read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2012
reviewComment: I was looking for something a little less like a college compare and contrast paper.  This book reads like it was an assignment for college.  The author compares conflicting theories of dog domestication.  I wanted to know what the author believes, not what the entire scientific community debates on dog domestication.  It could have been an wasy to read narrative but instead was a confusing jumble of facts.  I would get through one paragraph only to be told in the next that what I read previously was wrong.  What a waste of time!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2012
reviewComment: The author should have subtitled this book "Derr's hypothesis" or filed it under fiction.  Others have detailed the factual shortcomings so I'll just say it is so much baloney.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2013
reviewComment: My daughter is a vet, and over the years, I have given her books for her library, coffee table, night stand.  She loves the book!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2018
reviewComment: If you’re not a Christian, but don’t fear reading books where there’s a lesson to being a follower of Christ..then it’ll be cool to read. It’s not what you’re doing as far as unbelievers think followers of Jesus are doing...like being hypocrites. It’s the story behind what the author is trying to get across. If I’m not making sense I would sincerely listen/read, whichever medium you like. The prose is really amazing and it truly opens your eyes. Just keep in mind “things are not what you think they are.” Highly recommend for everyone and keep an open mind...you will find yourself receiving a lesson that’s good! Will definitely be reading/listening again..also downloaded the next book too 👊

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2018
reviewComment: God has given us so many blessings.  As I read this book, I felt as if the main character was being led by God/the Holy Spirit, much in the same way I believe He leads each of us - if we'll but listen.  The main character's circumstances were amazing, but the things that happened to him weren't so far-fetched.  Okay, things appearing that weren't there before - do we ever notice something later on that was there all along?  God shows up but we don't always notice Him.  Our bad!  This book helped to make me more aware of the choices I have made and are yet to make, and how paths you choose create your circumstances.  I really enjoyed the book!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2013
reviewComment: Rooms is the imaginative use of two parallel universes to convey the concept of man's two sides. The first universe we encounter stars Micah Taylor as a Satan driven entrepreneur who loves the thrill of risk taking to get money and power. In the other universe we see Micah appearing as his God fearing self, seeking the transforming healing and freedoms of Christ. His deceased Uncle Archie has left him revealing letters saying"If what you do brings freedom and life-it is most likely Christianity.If it doesn't it is probably religion and there's already too much of that in the world." He tells Micah that the Lord is about liberty,which states the theme of the book. Many dreams and spiritual encounters are brought about in the different rooms of the house his Uncle had built for him, hence the title"Rooms".Rubart uses vivid, picturesque imagery of the Northwest and imaginative metaphors,so classic in his works, to make them enjoyable. So if you want to read a fast paced mystery full of a compelling sense of immediacy and sound Biblical truths with a touch of romance thrown in,Rooms is the book for you.

review_title: Suspenseful Christian Fiction So Hard To Put Down
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2010

review_title: Christian fiction with some things to think about
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2012
reviewComment: Micah Taylor has it all (in the eyes of the world) - he's an entrepreneur in the software industry, a millionaire living in a penthouse apartment in Seattle, dating his business partner.  His mother died when he was young and he has a rocky relationship with his father, but he inherits a beach house from a deceased uncle he barely knew. Although he plans to sell the beach house, Micah spends some time there and begins having very strange experiences, including the discovery of new rooms that weren't there before, an unfinished painting that becomes more complete each time he sees it and a stack of letters written to him years ago by his uncle. When Micah returns to Seattle, things get even stranger as he runs into people who don't remember meeting him and his apartment changes floors. In the end Micah must choose between his extravagant penthouse lifestyle or his relationship with God.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2014
reviewComment: Micah is a very successful young man, but is spiritually disconnected, and slowly becomes aware that there may be a different and better way to live his life. Micah becomes the owner of a beautiful, one-of-a-kind house and learns various life and spiritual lessons in each of the special rooms. Throughout this book, there was a tug-of-war between good and evil to get Micah to make certain choices which would send him down incredibly different paths. This was a spiritual journey that involved second chances and forgiveness. Through letters from a dead uncle,Micah received guidance and encouragement to complete his journey. As Micah made various life choices, the realities in his life changed, often dramatically. The interactions and conversations with spiritual beings were powerful and packed an emotional punch. Beautiful, descriptive writing was thought provoking and gripping at times. A rewarding romance was woven into the main storyline. A satisfying and enjoyable read...I loved it!

review_title: Some readers MIGHT benefit from this book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2018
reviewComment: It is a real insult to compare this book to Screwtape Letters.  It is neither scary, nor witty, nor enightening unless you have never thought about  God-  or an equivalent.  Events are extremely repetitious and the author successfully avoided using a "big word" in the entire book.  Nevertheless, if you have never thought about supernatural existence you might benefit somewhat by reading this book.  Young adult level.

review_title: IF YOU LIKED THE SHACK, DON'T MISS ROOMS!!!!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2016
reviewComment: What a wonderful, deep book, and so Spiritual!!!  I couldn't put it down!!!  Micah gets a letter from his about 25 year deceased uncle whom he later found out he had seen once, but didn't remember.  It tells him that his uncle has had built a mansion for him on the ocean...bad news is it's where he has very bad memories of his Mothers death and bad treatment from his Father, so he's not anxious to go.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2010
reviewComment: There are no words to adequately express thoughts and emotions reading this book stirred up inside of me. I originally started with only the sample, but had to purchase the rest of the book as soon as I finished those few pages. My family and I were on a long road trip and I literally read "Rooms" in its entirety on the trip. It was that good. The characters were well fleshed out and seemed very real to me. The description of the house and each new room...amazing. Best of all, however, was the main character's journey back to a relationship with God.

review_title: I like it better than The Shack
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2010
reviewComment: Rooms reminded me of The Shack. That is a bit ironic since the story is a about a mansion that the protagonist inherits. This book had plenty of things for me to relate to, which is one reason why I found it so enjoyable.  There was no trace of Papa Jemima (a little Shack pancake humor), but there was plenty of action revolving around father - both earthly and Heavenly. Micah Taylor is not extremely fond of either of them at the outset. Piece by piece the puzzle as to why he loathes even calling his biological father on the phone are revealed to the reader. You might call it a mini-mystery.  That's only one of the themes of the book. The main course deals with Taylor's heavenly father. Rubart does a great job of stringing the readers along, giving them enough of a bread-crumb trail to figure out the majority of the background for the anguish that torments Micah despite his impressive success in the business world. And the primary antagonist turns out to be Micah himself. This inner conflict is depicted through the sights and sounds of the various rooms that spring into existence in the mysterious mansion his great-uncle had custom built for him.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2011
reviewComment: This book was a disappointment.  The first chapter was beautiful and made me cry and the second chapter was breathtaking, but the rest of the book was almost as dull as dishwater. The author seems to have come from the "Tell, don't show" school of writing.  As for the characters, they are passive and self-centered. Also, for people who are constantly thinking about this or that, they seem awfully dense.  For example, one of the main characters cheats on her husband (twice) and then tells him a whopping lie and then refuses to have sex with him.  And yet she is surprised that he appears not to be interested in staying with her?  Duh.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2015
reviewComment: Beautiful story and characters.

review_title: I wanted something more from this book.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2015
reviewComment: It seemed to get close to revelation and then never quite touch it. Some good observations though, enough to get me to read to the end, but I am not sure I am any the wiser for it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2011
reviewComment: This book had a Rashomon quality letting you appreciate the experience of several characters of different ages . Cohen was very intuitive and psychologically brilliant in conveying this so well.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2013
reviewComment: Quick, smooth transaction.  Haven't read book as yet but it is of my interest and book is in great shape.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: I got this book based on the great review it got on the front page of the New York Times Book Review. It sounded like the sort of book I could get lost in. The reviewer gushed with praise. I really looked forward to it. I read and read and about half way in, I started skipping ahead, thinking let's get on with it. There were pages and pages about who the characters were and how they were feeling and how it was that they were feeling what they were feeling. In my mind, the characters should be doing and saying and thereby letting me know who they are, instead of the author telling me. My preference in books are those that are character driven, not plot driven, so it's not that I need constant action. I just want the characters to speak for themselves. Near the end of the book, one of the characters asked a question and it was four pages before the other character replied. In between, the author had to explain it all to me. That's a copout. By the end of the book, I knew the characters outside in, not inside out.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2013
reviewComment: Arrived fast.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2017
reviewComment: Every now and again there comes an author who treats prose like poetry and describes everyday situations in a way that makes for a delicious read. This is such an author and such a book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2015
reviewComment: Quite a good read - solidly plotted and with interesting and engaging characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2015
reviewComment: Similar to a Sparks book and movie will be predictably same

review_title: From Wimbledon to Limehouse, the Game's Afoot
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2011
reviewComment: So what is the house of silk--an organization, an operation, a location; all of the above?  Sherlock Holmes is determined to find out, with the help of the now-married Dr. John Watson.  Horowitz's Watson is writing in retrospect, years after the case has been closed, for its nature was so horrid that the tale could not be told at that time.  The dust jacket notes describe the case as `too shocking, too monstrous, ever to appear in print . . . until now.'  While that is a bit hyperbolic, there is enough evil to go around and even (mini-SPOILER) a cameo appearance by our favorite mathematician and chemist, Professor James Moriarty, as well as an appearance by Holmes's obese brother, Mycroft.

review_title: Great addition to the Sherlock oeuvre
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2018
reviewComment: Lots of twists and turns from start to end, just as one might expect in a Holmes story. I thought he captured the spirit of Conan Doyle brilliantly.  I'm good at figuring out mysteries and I'd tumble to the outcome until it unfolded. A great read too!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2018
reviewComment: If you’re a fan of Sherlock Holmes you will find this a worthy continuation of his adventures. Horowitz has done an excellent job of positioning the story in the right time and, of course, the right narrative of Dr. Watson. You’ll not be disappointed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2014
reviewComment: I'm familiar with Horowitz from his creative efforts on Foyle's War for PBS (a favorite program of mind), so understood at least one reason why he was chosen to write this book. It felt as though I was reconnecting with my old friend Dr. Watson, after not visiting with him for a good many years. I admit that at first I was focused on the writing (would Horowitz achieve what he intended), but it didn't take long for me to shift gears and become fully engaged in the story. Horowitz's writing gave me no choice. Excellent job!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2013
reviewComment: This is a Sherlock Holmes mystery, the first time that the Conan Doyle Estate has authorized a new novel. Anthony Horowitz does a fabulous job following in those elusive footsteps of Conan Doyle. I love the ramblings of Dr. John Watson, and his portrayal of Sherlock Holmes. Due to the nature of the investigation, Holmes brings his brother, Mycroft, into the case. Poor Watson, did not even know of the existence of Mycroft. After watching many of the PBS programs, I can imagine this book as a presentation. The Sherlock Holmes novels are interesting in the detective work and the development of theories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2016
reviewComment: I felt that a few of the characters, Lestrade in particular, were portrayed badly, and not according to canon. Some aspects of the story felt anachronistic, and by the end, the story had developed an anti-Church antagonism. I was quite disappointed.

review_title: A worthy continuation to Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2018
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz has accomplished the nearly impossible task of both capturing Arthur Conan Doyle’s style and constructing a devilishly complex plot worthy of the best of Sherlock Holmes. This is a wonderfully enjoyable read. You owe it to yourself to give it a whirl.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2017
reviewComment: A Great Sherlock! And I should know, see my name! This author has done his research and he know his Arthur Conan Doyle. The language and setting are both authentic. So is Dr. Watson's narrative voice. The story? It's simply a superb Sherlock mystery! Hoping Anthony Horowitz writes more.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2020
reviewComment: If you loved the original Sherlock stories than you will thoroughly enjoy this book.  In every discernible way Horowitz has captured the essence of Sherlock, Watson and turn of the century London.  There were plenty of plot twists, red herrings and head-scratchers to keep you on the edge of your seat.  In sum it was a terrific read that I highly recommend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2015
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz approaches Holmes' world with great respect for what has been crafted by Doyle. This VERY clever and absorbing story fits in with the cannon without being merely derivative. Watson is at his best as he reflects back on this case, his tongue now being freed as certain of those involved are no longer living. I will give no spoilers, nor will I reveal the plot here. You are reading this because you are hungry for another Holmes adventure. You have found it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2015
reviewComment: Multi-generational tale of who really is your mother? Is her history what she told you in the past, or what you read now in a manuscript about escape from Russia, France, and spying for British Intelligence? Step-by-step we get brought into this world of characters and spies. Great read!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2012
reviewComment: I wasn't actually prepared for how good this was... it had been a Kindle discounted deal and I got it because it was reasonably rated and the topic looked interesting, but it far exceeded my expectations. I completely loved it and actually went back and reread sections again. I'm also thinking of recommending it for my book club — strong female character(s), lots of intrigue, twists and turns, and a whole new insight into what was happening in the beginning of WWII. Highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2017
reviewComment: A excellent story and William Boyd is a gifted writer. I have read it several times and watched a film version; it is always most entertaining. A classic in my library!

review_title: Enjoyable spy thriller with a twist
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2014
reviewComment: The book starts off slowly, but gradually ups the tension, and the surprises come faster and faster. Very human, mostly likeable characters, and a very plausible plot. Characters are well drawn and described, nd a satisfactory ending is achieved. Easy to read, with a clever technique to switch between the past and the present. Most enjoyable.

review_title: Enjoyed it too but definitely read the book first
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2017
reviewComment: I found this a really exciting read. Have since watched the TV serial of the book. Enjoyed it too but definitely read the book first.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2014
reviewComment: From the first page, it's a powerful book that grabs your attention; I am currently halfway through the novel and love it. It's one of those books that I will be sorry to finish - I am enjoying it so. Also, I was very happy with the condition of the used paperback I purchased as well as the short amount of time from ordering to delivery.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2020
reviewComment: I love this book for the interaction between the past and the present, the mother and the daughter, and the various countries covered in this spy intrigue novel

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2016
reviewComment: Except for a bit of gratuitous sex, this was a very interesting read.  The "outcome" is very hard to predict although there are "clues" throughout.  The ending was very unexpected but highly satisfactory.  Gave my copy to my neighbor who shares my opinion: an excellent read!

review_title: Boyd enjoys a sweet spot. I'm happy to report that Restless
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2015
reviewComment: I happened upon this book and its author, William Boyd, through one of Amazon's book blasts where the company makes reading suggestions based on a customer's prior purchases. As it happens, I read about one novel for every ten non-fiction books and as Amazon correctly concluded when I read novels it is often a mystery/thriller preferably cast in the noir genre. The interwar period between WWI and WWII has always been fertile ground for noir writers and it is where Mr. Boyd enjoys a sweet spot.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2020
reviewComment: The ending was extremely underwhelming for me. This is the reason for 3 stars. However I like his style of prose. Definitely worth a read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2017
reviewComment: Came on time and works perfectly!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2017
reviewComment: This worked for me without an issue!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 3, 2013

However, I'm so glad I persevered - it is really, really good - much better written, more likeable characters, better story.  I'm really looking forwward to the next book now!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2015
reviewComment: I absolutely love this little thing. I now have a lot of books and enjoy reading a couple of hours before going to bed. I have considered jailbreaking it, but as for now I'm happy with the default options.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2013
reviewComment: after holding out for so long in converting from paper to digital, i decided to take the plunge and buy the nook.  i wanted something simple, no frills, so this fit the bill perfectly.  i researched kindle versus nook, and i'm a happy customer with this nook.  very compact, lightweight, and i love the ease of downloading books.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2014
reviewComment: Product arrived sooner than shipping estimate, which was a wonderful surprise.  We bought this to replace one that my husband short-circuited, and it's already up and running.  We like the small size.. easier to tote around than the larger ones.  Had thought about upgrading, but why mess with success.  It's a shame B&N isn't carrying them anymore, bigger is not necessarily better in our opinion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
reviewComment: Delivery was fast. This nook was just what I wanted, just a reader with WiFi. No other apps taking up space and slowing it down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2015
reviewComment: Love how simple it is also light weight and durable only down sides are you can't download the kindle app or any other apps and no back light making it more difficult to read if it had the back light and kindle app I'd definitely give it 5stars

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2014
reviewComment: Fantastic device!  Easy to use, simple to carry.  Does exactly what it says on the box.  Mounts w/o any strangeness right on the desktop so you can move epub files on and off it as you wish, with no additional software.  Love it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2012
reviewComment: I ordered this for my husband who is in the navy and was leaving on an 8 month deployment the day of his birthday.  I was SO EXCITED to have thought of such a useful gift as I figured we could download a ton of books and he would have reading material on ship without having to pack 40 books.

review_title: And am super excited to take it to Florida when I live ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2015
reviewComment: I couldn't live with out this. I take it everywhere. And am super excited to take it to Florida when I live there for 8 months. I recommend this product to people who don't have the time to lug big books with them every where they go and need something to do on a flight or while waiting for anything.  I hope this helped.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2012
reviewComment: I love this ereader. I used kindles sony readers - this one's got very fast and responsive screen, the brightest eink screen i've seen so far. The limitations though are terrible. So you'd better jailbreak the sucker, which i did. Now i've got Kindle app, FB2 reading app, opera, email apps. Bible Youversion offline app! It's just Awesome!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2014
reviewComment: This arrived as described, packaged well, and worked well. The only issue I have ever had with them is its not as user friendly as it could be. I had to go to online blogs to find the rest of the steps to download an eBook. Whether it was from Barnes and Noble or the library.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
reviewComment: Having seen all the movies based on this book many times I felt I should read the original story. Not the sensationalized Hollywood story of zombies and killing zombies. The book is much simpler and yet there is a lot of depth to it. Vampires, zombies, it's really a book about people. With the covid scare going around, who knows, maybe it could turn out like the movies.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2013
reviewComment: I've seen the movie version of I Am Legend at least twice, probably three times. And up until maybe a year ago, I didn't realise that it was actually a book, and a sci-fi classic to boot. Which also made me think - how many movies are based on, or inspired by a book we don't even know about?

review_title: "He turned from the bar as if he could leave the question there. But questions have no location; they could follow him around."
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2018
reviewComment: I never saw the movie of the same title, but I did see The Last Man on Earth several years ago, which was also based on the book, and that's what finally lead me to Matheson's book.  The book itself, while perhaps the first story of a zombie-like vampire-ridden post-apocalypse, is also a great story of human loneliness.  Well worthy of five stars.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2020
reviewComment: I got sucked into reading a horror novel.  I was hoping it was more than that, but in the end that's all it was.  Clever premise for the ending, but unsatisfying.  Because the ending revealed the author's kernel of thought, as clever as it was, and in going so made the whole book a gothic travail.  Which I'm tired of, middle aged in the year 2020: it's too easy and trite, and real life has enough gothic content to make reading more depressing and unrewarding.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2014
reviewComment: After Dracula, I Am Legend is my favorite vampire novel. I first read it when I was twelve, and I've reread it many times and enjoyed it every time. Yes, some of this enjoyment is nostalgia, but it is true sci-fi horror and very well done.  The vampires are the result of a plague, and there is nothing romantic about them.  They want Robert Neville's blood.  He manages to keep them at bay, tries to adapt to a new existence without going bonkers, and suffers from loneliness and angst because he believes he is the last original human alive, at least in his corner of the world.  It has a real twist for an ending.  It's a quick read, but well worth your time, and truer to the spirit of what vampires are really all about: day sleeping blood-suckers!  Come on!

review_title: More nuanced and complex than the movie
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2012
reviewComment: Reviewing a book by comparing it to its movie is not the ideal thing to do, but I did watch the Will Smith movie first, which itself was not the first movie adaptation of the book - The Last Man on Earth and The Omega Man both were based on the novel and came out more than 30 years ago, and only more than a year later read the novel.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2012
reviewComment: It's not very often that I read a book that isn't YA.  It's even more infrequent that I read a book that wasn't written in the last 2 years.  I Am Legend was first published in 1954...  So why did I pick it up?  Well, mostly because I really liked the movie, and that's mostly because Will Smith is one of my favorite actors, if not my favorite.

review_title: it took a while to get going, but once it did...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2013
reviewComment: I Am Legend.  After reading the book, now I see why people got so annoyed at the movie.  They are COMPLETELY different.  Though, I'm not one to get too upset by such things myself,  I do get why other people might have been upset by the liberties the movie took.  Anyways, that being said, I liked this book.  I didn't think I was going to at first though.  In my opinion, this book took a very long time to get moving with any substantial plot or action.  I appreciate that they wanted to set the tone and the mood of the world for the reader, but if I remember correctly, it's like 9 chapters into the book before the word Vampire is even mentioned.  I almost gave up several times.  The only reason I stuck with it was that for years I'd heard how good the book was from various people.  Luckily, once the book gets rolling it's quite entertaining, and pretty much maintains that pace throughout.  With the exception of a few out dated (and potentially offensive, if you are sensitive)  references to African Americans, this book reads well for a novel written over 30 years ago.  Lots of action and lots of interesting characters.  Certainly ended up being worth the read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2012
reviewComment: Reviewing a classic is rather strange for me. It's like reviewing Oliver Twist, when almost everyone knows what it's about, due to movies, TV show references, and most recently in commercials urging kids to use manners.

review_title: What does it mean to be normal?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2009
reviewComment: This is one of those rare cases where I saw a movie before I read the book it was based on.  I enjoyed the film with Will Smith, but it was totally different than the book.  To me, the film was more about the triumph of the human spirit; one man fighting for humanity.  The book is more of a philosophical examination of what it means to be normal - part of the majority.  Matheson chose vampirism to be his plague, but really, he could have chosen anything.  The question becomes, is a person still normal when the rest of the world is different, is it right to keep fighting against change?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2014
reviewComment: Simply the best in terms of price and functionality. And if you root it you can access your email, read the online newspapers, post on facebook, etc. An excellent device.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2014
reviewComment: I love this NOOK. I can read in the dark now and that makes my hubbie happy. I recommend the insurance though. I have a star in my screen already because I carry it everywhere with me

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2015
reviewComment: This has been such a great product for me that I bought a second one after stepping on my old one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2016
reviewComment: Works just as I thought it would.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2014
reviewComment: It was a Christmas present for my daughter. She went to Barnes & Noble and traded it in for the more expensive model, don't remember the name of it. She's very happy, tho, with the new one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2014
reviewComment: I have the normal simple touch, which I love. But I wanted to get the glowLight for my dad. He really likes it and right away downloaded a book :-) we are very happy readers!
