reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2014
reviewComment: Excellent crisp E-ink, high contrast and resolution,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2014
reviewComment: My NOOK Simple Touch was quickly delivered and is everything I wanted it to be. I especially love the GlowLight that it has, makes reading at bedtime so much easier!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2015
reviewComment: I read over 60% of this story and felt like it really was going nowhere.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2011
reviewComment: This book is 371 pages long.  Great!  I love long books.  The more to enjoy!  BUT -- my God, this book needed an editor -- someone to cut the crap and get to the heart of the story.  I read to page 294, and finally threw it down and said "Enough, goddam it!"  The heart of this story can be told in half the wordage, half the length.  It's a good story, she can write well enough -- but --- I am furious that I believed the review in the NY Times -- furious that I spent $27 for this book  and then had to wade through the sludge of words to get to the spots that were relevant and interesting to the story.  Ai-yi-yi,  Send in the editor, please!

review_title: A Package That Entices Yet Disappoints
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2011
reviewComment: The Grief of Others reminds me of an elegant package, with layers and layers of exquisite paper.  Yet when everything is opened, what remains is a mystery box, something that entices and at the same time, disappoints.

review_title: Of the frailty of human beings and the incredible strength of human love.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2011
reviewComment: When I picked up "The Grief of Others", I had finished another book and just needed another 10 minutes or so of reading to put me to sleep.  This was in my "To Be Reviewed" pile and I was sure that I'd read a page or two and then choose something else a bit more mindless for that last bit of reading time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2011
reviewComment: The Grief of Others by Leah Hager Cohen is a novel that takes us deep into a family's grief and subsequent breakdown.  How does a family and marriage survive grief or more importantly survive secrets kept that have the ability to tear everyone apart?  Once betrayed, how does a family pull itself together, forgive each other, and try to rebuild their lives.  The Grief of  Others takes us into the the lives of the Ryrie's and their struggle to rebuild when everything seems to fall apart around them.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2011
reviewComment: Sometimes it takes me a while to determine how I feel about a novel. In the first 6 pages of The Grief of Others by Leah Cohen, I recognized this book was special. I found myself clutching my chest as I empathized and closing my eyes because sometimes you can find magic in a novel. In the introduction, the author describes how Ricky, the mother in the novel, longs to bottle her infant's breaths so she can keep them forever. I related to this so much. Even though my son is now 10, I find myself having those thoughts at times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2016
reviewComment: This book chronicles the choices and feelings before, during, and after a traumatic event. I loved the honesty of the characters and the dichotomies that can reside within any of us. The story line was interesting and kept my attention. I didn't like some of the unrealistic qualities about the characters. I won't give any spoilers but I can't see a person showing up and the adults not checking with that child's parents about the circumstances that brought that child to your door. Some of the sexual details could have been more tactful. I think the impact of grief on the intimate lives of those involved is worth exploring, so I'm glad it's discussed, but the author could've done that without giving so much detail. Overall, It an interesting read...not enough to make me want to read it again though.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: I typically don't do well with books that involve the death of children or animals.  But the demise of the Ryrie family baby - an event that serves as prologue and organizing theme - is recounted in such a dispassionate manner that I was unable to engage.  The emphasis on descriptive metaphors is particularly off-putting, sort of like looking at a painting and wondering at the brand of brush used, or listening to music and envisioning only notes on a page.  Analytical and disconnected.

review_title: Sad story about one family's grief
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2011
reviewComment: The Ryrie family has suffered the tragic loss of a baby just a few days after his birth. Mother and father Ricky and John are trying to desperately maintain normalcy in their family, despite the fact that their marriage is falling apart and neither one of them has figured out how to deal with their grief. Their older child, thirteen-year-old Paul, is an outcast at his school and dealing with his own grief in some interesting ways. Their younger daughter, Biscuit, is confused about why her baby brother never came home from the hospital and begins acting out to display her confusion and anger. When an unexpected family member arrives at their front door, the Ryrie family must come together and try to understand what one another is feeling, as their family dynamic is unraveling rather quickly.

review_title: Loss is private, universal, and shared
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2011
reviewComment: What is grief? It has no physical properties, but it fills a room, a life, many lives, and creates pain. It's bigger than a boulder, but is amorphous. You can't domesticate or quarantine grief, but it can isolate, alienate, afflict. The sun rises and sets, our shadows shorten and lengthen, but grief reaches into darkness and obscures the light. Its stride is long and its span is spacious, but it has no measure. Grief is timeless, but time heals, according to the maxim.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2011
reviewComment: Well, I have finally read this book and let me just tell you I am so glad I did! I hate that I have put it off for this long. I am not sure exactly how to go about explaining it to you, but I will do my best. Let me just say it is a Christian version of the Twilight Zone and I loved every minute of it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2018
reviewComment: Step onto a wild ride into the spiritual world!  Enjoyed seeing what was going to happen next with each passing page.  The main character gets a glimpse of what life could have been like(was?) in his life with and without God in a vey unique story.  Truly a one of a kind and brilliant read, worthy of becoming a classic.  Recommended for teens and up.  Nothing objectionable but all worthy of taking to heart and opening minds to God and His loving heart for each of us.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2010
reviewComment: Book Review of Rooms by James Rubart

review_title: Not your Mamma's Christian love story. Rooms is a love story that refuses ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2018
reviewComment: Not your Mamma's Christian love story. Rooms is a love story that refuses to limit God to the small box most of us reserve for Him. A man's life is torn apart and then reassembled by the hand of God and His angels. The pain of losing is well, painful, the joy of discovery is overwhelming. God is good and when your life is not going according to His plan, He can become quite forceful. Great read. Challenging to the brain, the heart and the spirit.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
reviewComment: Not a whole lot of books can accomplish the goal of being both a page-turner and thought-provoking. This novel succeeds in both goals and manages to explore the spiritual nature of man at the same time. I highly recommend it to anyone looking  for something to read, for those going through spiritual struggles, or even just for those who are fans of "It's A Wonderful Life" and other, similar alternate history fiction.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
reviewComment: You have to know a little about Christianity to really appreciate this book.  I pray for those that gave this book a low rating because they need its message more than anyone.  I want to say that this book made my head hurt, but only in the way that it made me think so much.  It made me examine my own life.  Have I really given my whole heart to Christ.  I think I have, but what rooms are still hidden in my heart that I need to expose and work through.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2014
reviewComment: If you're an opened minded person and a fan of "The Shack" then you will enjoy this book.  Imagine if you were able to compartmentalize all the areas of your life into separate rooms, and visit them to see the life you've lived and how the various parts of your life have shaped who you are.  Of course, our choices in life can and do affect the future, but if you could go back and revisit how and why you made that choice and the underlying reasons for how you chose to live, then this book is for you.  Also, who are you really listening to when you hear the inner voice of reason, even though it may be telling you exactly what you want to hear.  Recognizing the voice of God is critical in our decision making and this book will definitely give insight on this subject.  Again, you have to have an open mind and not be adverse to viewing things from a different perspective.  Enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2010
reviewComment: Going into this book, I had certain expectations.  I thought this was going to be a scary, suspenseful story about a "haunted" house, but much to my temporary disappointment, this book is quite different.  Once I realized this book was going to be different than I thought, I opened my mind and let my imagination go wild and quickly found myself engrossed in this story.  Micah is just a regular person like all of us who has to make difficult decisions like the rest of us.  We all face the same battles that Micah faces, which is why this story is so engrossing - and so relevant.  Some of the spiritual and religious parts felt a little heavy, but the author balanced them very well with lighter moments of Micah spending time with Rick or with Sarah or simply enjoying his house.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
reviewComment: Wow I loved this book!! One man’s fight to find real LIFE through trials and failures and mis-direction. Clear writing, profound theology applied to daily struggles. A glorious picture of God and honest struggles of man. Plot twists and surprises. All that and fantasy too! (as an editor, what a joy to read something that has no mistakes.) I’m so glad you did write this book so you (We) could all read it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2018
reviewComment: This book wasn’t terrible. It was very well written. But I didn’t realize that it was a catholic based novel. I find it utterly ridiculous that Micah had to give up the company that he worked so hard for, for God. This book basically tells you that if you’re wealthy, you are evil, and cannot love God. That’s unfair. Being successful doesn’t make you inherently evil.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2012
reviewComment: I am not surprised that this book has both strongly positive and strongly negative reviews. There is a lot of information in this book, much of it firmly backed up with the latest scientific research, but I have to agree with the reviewers who questioned the editing: the book is poorly organized and the same facts, anecdotes, and theories appear over and over again. Having been a student of Mark Derr's in a graduate-level class on the history of dog breeds, I know that he has a lot of knowledge but is often disorganized in presenting it. This is why authors have editors; the editors did not come through here.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2014
reviewComment: This seemed to be a very interesting topic and appeared to be scientifically based. Mark Derr certainly gathered many resources and on first glance presents his points technically. However, after finding many glaringly wrong or suspiciously twisted statements, the book simply didn't deserve the time to read it past chapter 13. The author appears to have formed his opinions and insights on his own experiences, some anecdotes, and his own scientific readings, but not education. From the start, he tries to redefine words which already have a scientifically accepted meaning, such as "tame" and "domestic", then jumbles his new definitions around so many times that the reader no longer knows what he is referring to. His understanding of genetics is less than that of a high school graduate..it's almost embarrassing! He obviously has no real-world experience in captive breeding of wild animals and makes the typical assumptions of the inexperienced when he discusses it. He occasionally does make insightful comments, but they seem almost accidental.

review_title: speculation, innuendo, circumstantial evidence and unsupported claims passing for science
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2013
reviewComment: I am very disappointed in _How the Dog Became the Dog_.  I had hoped for a scientific exposition on cannine evolution, but instead got a volume of unsupported claims and bunk.  Derr's central thesis is that cannines have been domesticated (the term itself is slippery as defined here) for at least 15,000 years prior to the scientific concensus (Derr would push it back to 35,000 years ago from 15,000 years ago.)  The idea is intriguing, and I would even entertain it as plausible were it not for the poor reasoning and shocking lack of evidence.

review_title: Very informative, but stylistically quirky. Derr uses enormous ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2017
reviewComment: Very informative, but stylistically quirky. Derr uses enormous labyrinthine sentences with inadequate punctuation, making it difficult to follow his thought at times. His sentence structure sometimes seems 'backwards'. He also uses the pronoun 'who' to refer to animals, which is uncalled-for.

review_title: A Dry and Hard to Read Narrative on How maybe Dog Wolves ran into humans or humanoid like creatures and maybe became dogs.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2016
reviewComment: I really wanted to like this book going in. It seemed like something right up my alley as someone with interest in evolutionary genetics. I thought the book would start out by describing exactly what makes a dog a dog. He could have gone into the breeds, talking about the differences in dog size and lineage, describing how that isn't true speciation. Perhaps he could slowly work his way backward from what we 'know' about where the breakoff point for the breeds descended from, and maybe give us a half dozen starting points. Then from there, he could move into the less known. How did dogs serve in ancient cultures, what were the triggers for change, why did those changes occur? Finally, he could move back to wolves, and give us an account of dog wolves, and the conjecture. He COULD have done something like this. He didn't.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2011
reviewComment: If one wants to understand the nature of dogs, this is a must read. First of all, beware critical reviews that fail to address the specifics of the argument Derr is making, which he backs up with the latest science woven into a logical train of speculation, the connective tissue in any theory, and which is clearly delineated as such. These critics use a vague complaint in lieu of critical argument. Expect a lot of resistance to Derr's thesis due to the current state of political correctness in dogdom which is trying to write the wolf out of the domestic dog's makeup, most especially to counteract the media phenomenon of Cesar Milan. (Ironically several years ago Mark Derr wrote an Op Ed piece in the NY Times entitled: "Pack of Lies" rebutting Milan's approach.) This is straight science by an accomplished scientific journalist and if you're willing to consider a fuller as well as the latest findings on how the dog became the dog, this book should sit right next to Coppinger's "Dogs" in your library. And then let them have at it in your mind.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2012
reviewComment: I found this to be a disappointing book. (I had eagerly anticipated it.) It starts out by discussing the tracks of a boy and a wolf or "dogwolf" found in association in the famous Chauvet Cave. The author sets much store on this supposed association. He completely disregards the possibilities mentioned in Werner Herzog's recent documentary on the cave that wolf might have been stalking the boy...or that the tracks were made thousands of years apart.

review_title: Why How the Dog Became the Dog is a Dog
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2012
reviewComment: I purchased this book after hearing an NPR interview with the author.

review_title: Thin slice of cheese in a hefty bun
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2011
reviewComment: There is not much too this book, and I'm leaning toward the view that it is essentially an inflated magazine article.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2014
reviewComment: I agree with previous reviewers: this author has something interesting to say, but the book is so badly written and organised, the ideas do not come across. It needs the traditional blue pencil and an editor that is willing to slash, burn and most imprtantly check facts. Disappointing.

review_title: great information, but the links don't work
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 24, 2016
reviewComment: I have long admired Don Campbell's work, and this book is no exception.  More of a survey than an in-depth treatise, it is actually quite useful just because of that.  The main problem I have is that in the attempt to stay "up-to-date" by including links to websites instead of putting fuller information into footnotes or reference notes, the publishers have failed rather badly: most of the links don't connect with anything now, only 4 years after the publication date.  Actual printed-in-the-book information, with names and titles and the like, would have been, in the long run, far more useful, for far longer. Or, since the book has its own website, why couldn't the publishers have arranged to have the sound and video clips all on their own site so they stay available?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2018
reviewComment: This was a wrath of knowledge and I loved every minute i spent reading this book as someone who is pursuing education in the healing arts! Highly recommend!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2017
reviewComment: This is a really amazing book. Who knew music affected the body and mind in so many ways?  VERY interesting book; it may change what you choose to listen to and when...

review_title: An Engaging Read, A  Novel Approach and Wonderful Information!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2011
reviewComment: I haven't finished reading  this book yet but am so enjoying it that I wanted to put some initial impressions down on paper. I'll re-review after I have completely finished reading it the first time, I can see that I will probably be referring back to this book for quite some time to come. I ended up buying the hardbound edition, and the Kindle edition.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2012
reviewComment: This is a well-written, in-depth discussion of the applications of music and sound. It is very well researched and provides extensive sources and external links. If you're interested in how you can use sound to change your own life or the life of those around you, or if you're just interested on an intellectual level, then this book is for you.

review_title: Wonderful information.  I have the Kindle and Audible versions
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2011
reviewComment: Wonderful concepts and information.  I have never really thought about the "sound" environment that surrounds me everyday, and ways to improve that in my life and the lives of my family and friends. The computer links in the book send you to wonderful examples of the concepts online. After absorbing the information I purchased the music compilations that the authors have developed to supplement the ideas in the book.

review_title: Healing At a The Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2014
reviewComment: A friend recommended this book to me because of my interest in sound and depression. It's a great read and an even greater resource for me. This book presents for a layperson like me an enlightening understanding of the great impact noise, commotion or sound- whatever one wants to call it on our daily lives.

review_title: Insights into sound, health, and auditory processing issues
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2011
reviewComment: We're concerned with what we eat, our emotional stressors, and the environmental toxins that may be affecting us, but few of us consider our sound environment. What does it do to us when we're constantly exposed to artificial and noxious sounds--and what are the benefits of hearing natural, harmonious sounds? Healing at the Speed of Sound is a fascinating look into how we can improve our well being, our level of energy, and even our physical health by altering our sound environment.

review_title: Research purposes for college writing class
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2014
reviewComment: Having picked a subject for a large writing project... now I was on the hunt for information to back up a philosophical medical question..Can music assist in healing for various medical conditions and if so, what is the impact on recovery?  This book answers all of these questions and more!  Really well researched and helped so much on my paper...but more than that was the happy surprise to find this book offers so much more than just information.  It can be used as a kind of self-help guide to how you can choose music that will enhance your day, feed your soul and increase your productivity on a job or in school (if you happen to be a student like me!).

review_title: This is an amazing, different and special book, This book is so much different than anything else i have read,
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2014
reviewComment: This is an amazing, different and special book, This book is so much different than anything else i have read, it is a must for anyone, and anybody who wants to upgrade their quality of life. I also think this book will improve my families health and well being together with expanding our knowledge.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2015
reviewComment: Horowitz was well-chosen to continue AC Doyle's famed detective in new adventures. It's a little 'darker' than Doyle's works, but a good mystery. Watson is spot-on in his 'voice' as he narrates the tale, and although the secret of the House of Silk was obvious several pages before the reveal, the author neatly intertwined two mysteries into a connected thread. Well-done, a worthwhile read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2020
reviewComment: Enjoyed the story, the style and the pacing. The Arthur Conan Doyle Estate was well.served!! Horowitz gave all honor to the world's greatest detective.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2019
reviewComment: I liked the story, but would have liked to have seen the author use his own characters and not those of Holmes and Watson.

review_title: Enjoyable Fare for Sherlock Holmes Fans
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2013
reviewComment: The House of Silk is a recent "reboot" of the Sherlock Holmes franchise and should give fans what they look for: the sharp, precise characters of Holmes and Watson and a fascinating and scintillating story of suspense.  The work feels both traditional (classic) and contemporary.  Great care has been made to incorporate the language and plot structure of the original.  Parental warning for those offering this to young readers, as subject matter might be disturbing.

review_title: A More Modern Look at Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
reviewComment: Horowitz has in his own way brought Holmes to a different level addressing human evil. I would agree with the first two reviews that this is written in an even better style than Doyle.  The plot is quite involved but the clues are there for the reader. As always the reader is like Lestrade and Watson, good but not as great as Holmes. I recall reading the stories in high school and this is just as engaging now. And the reason is that Holmes power of observation and deduction is always front and center, and well recounted by Watson. The story without revealing it is certainly on the dark side of humanity which is why Watson could nto publish it at the time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2018
reviewComment: Gadzooks!  The game's afoot!  Clearly gifted, Horowitz captures Doyle's style in this Holmes novel that was commissioned by the Sherlock Society.  A really enjoyable read -- just like when I first discovered Sherlock Holmes years ago!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2015
reviewComment: Whether used to reference Watson's recollections of Holmes or Horowitz's reflections of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's style, The House of Silk proved itself to be an enjoyable journey back to a bygone era. This was one of those novels that had you consuming content in record time while wishing it wouldn't ever end. If he is able to repeat the success that he had with The House of Silk, I would really like to see more "new Holmes" from Mr. Horowitz.

review_title: Could have been written by Conan Doyle
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
reviewComment: Amazing. I am a long-time fan of Sir Arthur and Sherlock Holmes. I'm also very sceptical of writings, including tv and movie scripts, that purport to be accurate representations of these iconic characters. So I never would have opened this book if the Conan Doyle Estate hadn't given their approval. I'm so glad I read it. Mr. Horowitz did a masterful job. There were many times I forgot who wrote it. It was Watson's voice and a true Holmes story from start to finish. Thank you.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
reviewComment: Excellent book for fans of Sherlock Holmes. Anthony Horowitz has been given license from the family of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle to write a Sherlock Holmes story for the first time ever. He has delivered a gem.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2020
reviewComment: Fun  take on a Sherlock theme. Did a credible story and recognizable characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2015
reviewComment: Just what the doctor ordered

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2015
reviewComment: This is exactly what I needed and it arrived before estimated arrival which is a definite plus.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2016
reviewComment: Overpiced

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2014
reviewComment: It is exactly what I wears looking for

reviewComment: Please be advised that these codes have been stolen from Flat World Knowledge and will not work!!!! Buyer BEWARE! Legal actions are being taken.

reviewComment: brilliant !

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 21, 2017
reviewComment: A cracking good read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 5, 2017
reviewComment: but loved the author more and can't get enough or her books she puts the story and herself into my head

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 14, 2014
reviewComment: I love the way it's written & the psychology of it.. We all know an Alan or someone controlled or the what if??

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 12, 2015
reviewComment: A good  book  could not put it down  enjoyed the story well worth reading

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 15, 2013
reviewComment: Great read that kept me gripped through night feeds with a small baby. Plot was pacey with enough twists to keep me hanging but not so many that I lost track. Recommended for lovers of thrilles and suspense.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 17, 2013
reviewComment: Amazingly choreographed story! 5/5 sometimes it's just about being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Erin Kelly is never predictable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 3, 2013
reviewComment: Brilliant book, loved it, once I had started I had to finish it as soon as possible... ignoring my husband for days ;)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 20, 2014
reviewComment: Sleepless nights as I didn't want to put book down! Great work Erin... Now need to locate next book! Amazing

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 28, 2013
reviewComment: I enjoyed the book  once i had got used to the story jumping around . An unexpected ending. Will read more of this Author's books

review_title: required a software update right away
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2013
reviewComment: but it will serve the purpose of replacing paperbacks for my son who is in the military. Convenient sized, easy to use after the software issue was resolved. The online support was very patient in helping me figure out why I couldn't connect and how to download the required software update. Works fine now.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2014
reviewComment: This is a sold update to the older nook, but gez you have to hit the webs just to find out you need to charge it OVERNIGHT in a WALL PLUG only before first usage AND that it MUST be turned on before trying to connect to windows.  Now knowing these two VERY IMPORTANT points, I can enjoy my "Nook 2".

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2018
reviewComment: Very good product. Highly recommend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2012
reviewComment: I liked the Nook Simple Touch that I purchased and the price was right, but I purchased this model by mistake. I thought it had the glow light and it didn't (my bad!). The company took it back without a problem and charged me a minimal restocking fee. Thanks for understanding!

review_title: Not a good experience and a lousy product
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2017
reviewComment: I bought the Barnes and Noble Ebook and it lasted barely six months.  It won't open the ebook and you can't power it off.  So these are basically junk from this company so save yourself some money and buy elsewhere.  Not a good experience and a lousy product.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2014
reviewComment: Bought this for my 92 year old mother, & I wasn't sure if she could manage a "electronic" reader, but she loves it! It is easy for her to operate & lightweight for her to hold for a long time, since she reads all day.

review_title: Nook is good B&N is OK
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2012
reviewComment: I will start by saying that as far as an ereader goes, the NOok can't really be beat. You can use this just like a book outside in the sun. What I don't like about it is not about it as much as purchasing books from Barns and Noble. Seems like every book I get is list price. All I can do is download from B&N too, it's not like I can shop on Amazon which I do a lot. so, Nook is great Barnse and nobel is just OK, maybe less than OK in my book (that's a pun!)

review_title: I wouldn't recommend it to anyone
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2017
reviewComment: It hasn't worked correctly since i got it.  When i try to type in letters another key inserts it self  When trying to turn it off, i press turn off and the cancel button comes on instead.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2018
reviewComment: The battery only lasts a few hours

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2015
reviewComment: Great little e-reader especially if you want to read outside.  The screen is excellent and the battery lasts for days.  It's light weight and easy to fit in your purse or back pack.  The internet on it is a little slow, but that's not very important to me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2005
reviewComment: Though this novel is certainly quite well known, particularly amongst horror fans, it's not quite as famous as I'd imagine it would be, or as it ought to be, for that matter.  It's pretty damn influential, particularly in films as it was a primary inspiration for 'Night of the Living Dead'. (And, it was adapted for film twice, first as 'The Last Man on Earth', then as 'The Omega Man' (which it resembles in only the vaguest manner.)  But adaptations are quite entertaining I think, if far from truly satisfactory.)  Anyway, this is definitely one of my favorite novels, horror or otherwise. (Well, I'd probably call it a 'novella', but whatever)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2008
reviewComment: Let me begin by stating that this is a short story compilation, something that was never mentioned to me at any point in time.  True, the title story is by far the longest in the book, and would qualify as a novella, but it is in length similar to "The Mist" being the largest short story in "Skeleton Crew."

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2018
reviewComment: The shear desperation of Robert Neville was a driving force propelling this book forward. The mystery, as Neville tries to find a reason for the plague, was compelling even as you're getting the idea that he's been alone too long and is most likely crazy.  Parts of it were also incredibly sad as he tries to cope with being alone.  With all of that combined, I just couldn't put this book down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2009
reviewComment: The premise of this story is very simple. A man named Robert Neville is the last man alive on Earth. Everyone else have become vampires and this story is about Robert's life being alone in a world full of hideous beings. It is a very simple and basic premise and yet Richard Matheson has taken it and spun a really deep and complex tale out of it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2013
reviewComment: I read the other reviews. Unlike others my Kindle eBook contained no other stories but the title story (purchased Feb, 2013). I did  not mind the descriptions, the story held me and the descriptions help me understand what the man was going through. Since most of the story only has the one character I don't see how it could have been otherwise. Keep in mind this was written in 1954. I compare the story line to the movie Castaway with Tom Hanks. It is the story of a man alone in the world trying to survive a plague that turns everyone else (as far as he can tell) into zombie like creatures. I enjoyed it.  A short read.  You understand what he is going through, the stress, his breakdowns, his escape through booze, his series of spirit shattering disappointments.  I don't want to give anything away by giving more details.  Suffice to say that the latest movie (based in a large city) is very loosely based on this story which is in a suburb of a small town. I understand the Will Smith movie was the 3rd based on this story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2008
reviewComment: I bought this a few months ago, before the movie came out, although it had been on my wish list forever.  I read Hell House years ago and it was one of my favorite horror novels, so I've wanted to read I Am Legend for a long time.  I read it before the movie came out, but the movie was so different that it really didn't matter.  The book was written in the early 1950's and I think it was pretty innovative for that time.  Apparently it was first marketed as sci-fi, and only later became known as a horror classic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2011
reviewComment: This book came across my email when Kindle was having a sale and I thought, "Why not?"

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2007
reviewComment: If you are not, as I was/am, a lover of this Vampire genre you should be pleasantly surprised with this book as it is really nothing like you'd imagine a vampire book to be.  In fact, the "bad guys" could be any bad guys, for example I could see this as the end of "The Road" or any other apocaplyse book.  I was not one to be drawn to the Vampire stories, other than the old Ann Rice "Lestat."  I actually notice that some of the 'tags' are for zombies.

review_title: A mix of old and timeless sufferings and triumphs of the human spirit
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2013
reviewComment: I loved this book. I read a lot of the reviews before purchasing this book. I cannot understand the negative reviews this book received. You have to be some kind of desensitized child not to appreciate the amazing development and emotions of the characters and themes of this book. And though it does not focus on action and Gore this book truly does belong to the genera of horror. If you can read this book and take on the emotions as your own then you will find a terror just as thrilling and far deeper than that of your contemporary horror novels. Yes the book is short but I did not feel the ending was rushed or let me down. And one must remember this was written as a futuristic piece back in the fifties. If you're looking for a book about the movie don't bother, this came way before and the movie was only loosely based on it. However I loved the movie too. If you love the horror genera and have a good mind there is no way you should skip this book. It's a must read for horror/vampire lovers. 5*

review_title: Nothing like the movie but still great!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2017
reviewComment: The movie featuring Will Smith led me to reading this book, but it is different in almost every way. However, don't take this the wrong way. The book is great! It's mostly focused on the lead character's psychological struggle in a lonely vampire infested world. There are a handful of heart-stopping suspense filled moments throughout the book. I would recommend to anyone interested in a horror themed survival tale.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2014
reviewComment: What a great writer.  5 wholehearted stars.  Boyd's style is simple, almost minimalist, a few easy words to paint a complex picture.  Clean, interesting story, and - unlike the dozens of inferior writers whose work you will find at airports everywhere - the effortless style is never a distraction. This is right up there with classics like The Miernick Dossier, or LeCarre at his very best.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2015
reviewComment: This book was an enjoyable read.  It seems the pages went fast.  I enjoyed this book to the very end.  I think other's will enjoy it as well.  I would recommend this book.  I hope to be able to read more books by this author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2012
reviewComment: I actually give this close to 5 stars, maybe more like 4.5. It's a wonderful story with marvelous locales, dialogue, plot twists and so on. I was milady annoyed by the alternation of chapters between the mother and daughter's lives but that was essential for the story, and I wasn't quite so enthralled with the daughter's life and times, but I still give it a ver, very high rating as very well written and extremely enjoyable

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2016
reviewComment: An absorbing spy novel, the first I've read by Mr. Boyd.  On a par with Allen Furst (that's a compliment!), but missing the brooding darkness of LeCarre at his best.  I will now read lots more Boyd!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2013
reviewComment: There's no need for another summary of the book, but I think it's important to understand this isn't the usually mystery thriller that so many current bestsellers are.  It's a pre-WWII spy novel, and as long as you know what you're getting and you like this type of novel, you'll enjoy it.  Maybe a bit slow at times, but I enjoy that subtle behind-the-scenes stuff.  Well written with some interesting twists.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2015
reviewComment: The spy story was hard to understand.  I tried to keep up w/ the mother and present day daughter story, but the intricacies of the spying done by the mother alluded me.  I know I did not catch everything, but I did finish the book anyway,  and got out of it what I could.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2020
reviewComment: Loved the book

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2019
reviewComment: Takes the reader on yet another well researched adventure, this time in the less known context of Britains working in the USA during WW2 to help persuade the Yanks to enter the war.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2019
reviewComment: I enjoyed reading this book. The plot built slowly and relentlessly and the characters were great.

review_title: Well written story with interesting female protagonists
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2017
reviewComment: Boyd can write beautifully and he made this story informative and entertaining through the eyes of two smart British women.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2011
reviewComment: Fantastic! I ordered two hard copies, specifically not e-versions, for gifts. Excellent study of man's best friend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2011
reviewComment: Mr. Derr's book shows an excellent understanding of dogs, dog behavior and dog/human evolution. It is a well written and cogent review of the science of dog evolution. I've been deeply involved with dogs for years. I have bred and raised many puppies. This book increased my understanding of dog evolution, breeding and behavior. I would highly recommend this book.

review_title: Looks to be great based on WSJ excerpt
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2011
reviewComment: The latest copy of the Wall Street Journal had a great summary of this book - which unfortunately has not gotten the accurate and positive reviews it deserves on Amazon yet.

review_title: How the Dog Became the Dog --- Mark Derr, 2011
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2012
reviewComment: HOW THE DOG BECAME THE DOG

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2011
reviewComment: This book was a major, major disappointment. I read a review of it in the Wall Street Journal, and it sounded like it was just up my alley. As a dog lover, it is fascinating to me to think that my Shiba, and every other dog, from tiny Chihuahuas to St. Bernards, from pugs to greyhounds, all descend from wolves. And they can all interbreed. How is that possible? The time spans that I have seen just seem too short for such variety in evolution. Could we "breed" humans into giants and midgets and people with six-inch noses? What exactly is the process involved, how do scientists think this happened, and when and where did each breed get created? When you read, for instance, that dachshunds were breed to follow prey in tunnels, what exactly does that mean? You couldn't just decide you needed a dog with short legs and make it. It must have taken a very long time. Were they purposefully bred?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2011
reviewComment: Let me know when it's available on Kindle. Hardcopy is not for me. I'm a fairly enthusiastic reader and space limitations required me to cut back on hard copies. Lo, I loved it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2011
reviewComment: "How the dog became the wolf is a FACT of evolution and history?". "How the wolf became the dog is a mystery?" What exactly is this book about?Evolution is a theory..period .A mystery is just that..a mystery..So for all of the pontification about this and that, we still dont know and we probably never will.Worthless

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 24, 2018
reviewComment: Really good book

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 13, 2018
reviewComment: Great book

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 9, 2014
reviewComment: An erudite analysis of why we live with wolves, and why they live with us. Hugely informative and thought-provoking. Get a copy for your dog.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2017
reviewComment: This is a story about a man's journey back to Christ. It's told in a highly creative, twilight zone type of manner. I loved it. Without spilling the beans, this story will fascinate you, make you smile, and shock you with a few twists and turns. If you're someone just looking for a good read, seeking to hear God's voice, wondering about your role in life, or questioning your current one, I'd recommend this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2017
reviewComment: At first, it was good enough to catch me and keep me reading, but then I couldn't put it down. I'll admit, there were several times I was like "oh no, where is he going with this," not sure I wanted to continue. But it was engaging enough I had to find out for sure, and he surprised me pleasantly every time. Wonderful twists and well constructed every step of the way. It ended most edifyingly and satisfyingly. You know it's well written when you get to the point where you start laughing, gasping, cringing and sighing out loud as you read. I don't want to give you any spoilers, so I won't. It's just a good book. A really good book. Worth reading, seriously.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2021
reviewComment: The book has an interesting concept with the house, and I like that the main character is working through his issues. Some of the theology didn't sit exactly right with me and the book went a little long in the middle, but I think this is a novel that men would enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2019
reviewComment: I read & listened to this book & it was amazing. I travel 5 hours one day a week & really enjoyed listening to this book last week as I traveled ... it really made the time fly by. God’s Love, freedom, & redemption are woven throughout this book & the concept of the “Rooms” blew me away. I highly recommend this book & am really looking forward to reading & listening to another of James L. Rubart’s books, “Book of Days”!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2019
reviewComment: I feel like I need to apologize for not liking the book.  The rooms became monotonous  and I dreaded picking up the book.  Yet, it was a very imaginative book and different.

review_title: There's a lot going on here...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
reviewComment: This book was interesting, but I found it had so many things going on, that I had a hard time focusing.  If you've ever read a Ted Dekker book and enjoyed it, you will probably like this as well.  The book has a supernatural layer, with some "what if you had chosen differently?" plot twists along the way.  It did keep me wanting to read, but overall I wouldn't rate it as a book I will read again.  Give it a try and see what you think!

review_title: Wow! This was an awesome book.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
reviewComment: This book was amazing! I had a hard time putting it down. It kept me on the edge of my seat, anxiously anticipating what would happen next. Contained many surprises, but even better than that.... I could feel the Holy Spirit doing a work in me.Before I was even finished with the book, God was revealing things to me about my life, and my walk with Him. I could feel in my spirit things were changing, and that I had some changes to make, and some "rooms" to visit. Visiting these rooms has drawn me closer to Him.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2018
reviewComment: There are few books that inspire, intrigue & motivate me all at once. Few books that stay with me long after the last page is turned. Rare is the book that goes beyond pleasure in reading it to making me want more...more of Jesus, my personal Savior & dearest friend. Praise goes to HIM for giving you, James L. Rubart, the deep, abiding & endearing story. Thanks goes to you for sharing it. (less)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2020
reviewComment: Such a truly awesome story, saying there are twists and turns in this book is not really saying anything; there are so many twists it is just amazing. I thought it was excellent and highly recommend this book and author, you will not regret it. Thank you Mr. Rubart

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2018
reviewComment: A very different type of book. I found it slow in the beginning and in parts throughout the book. I almost quit several times, but curiosity compelled me to finish it. I'm glad I did. The story seems far fetched if you don't understand the spiritual battle going on in our world. I don't believe this book is on par with Frank Peretti, but similar. It is the story of Micah Taylor as he journeys to a closer walk with God.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2011
reviewComment: Grief of any kind is a strange bedfellow but when it descends unexpectedly and alters the course of a young child's life it becomes monumental and unforgiving.  When you have lost a loved one it is beyond comprehension this loss and the subsequent hole in one's life would not be noticed.  Yet talking about the loss in their lives is what does NOT happen and the revealing story about this horrible lack of communication overhwhelms an ordinary family, propelling them towards inevitable disaster.

review_title: The Grief of Others: Sad and Hopeful Women's Fiction
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2011
reviewComment: Leah Hager Cohen's newest novel, The Grief of Others, shares the story of the Ryrie family who has lost their baby after his birth just a year before. John and Ricky find their marriage deteriorating, whether from this tragedy or from other secrets they have kept. Their daughter Biscuit has been skipping school and their son Paul has become the victim of bullying, something they are unaware of until he is suspended for fighting. John's grown daughter from a previous relationship, now pregnant and single, shows up in the midst of this, adding another dimension to this story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2011
reviewComment: "What doesn't kill me makes me stronger," according to Nietzsche.

review_title: It's Best in the Small Moments
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2012
reviewComment: This is a story about the Ryrie family, which is composed of mother and father Ricky and John and kids Paul, Biscuit and Jessica, along with sort of about a young man named Gordie who becomes entangled with this family.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2011
reviewComment: The Grief of Others is a heartbreaking story about the death of a newborn, and how such a loss affects the entire family.  Ricky and John Ryrie's newborn son dies just days after birth, as a result of a serious birth defect. While this situation in itself would be painful enough to deal with, for the Ryries the situation is made worse by the fact, Ricky knew her risk was high for having an infant that might not survive, yet she chose to keep the info to herself, just in case the tests, indicating the possibility of a rare brain deformity, were wrong. She ignores the radiologist's statement that most couples in this situation would opt for an abortion -- for Ricky this was never an option.

review_title: A fine exploration of a family in crisis
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2011
reviewComment: This novel of a family that is on the verge of imploding after suffering the death of their infant has many fine themes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2012
reviewComment: The story should have been much more compelling, but it suffers from weak characters and is poorly told.

review_title: I won't read a better book this year.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2012
reviewComment: That's a big claim to make in February, but this moving novel of a family falling apart in the face of grief is that beautiful. From the remarkable opening chapter, in which a mother embraces her loss, to the closing passage that left me in tears, the story of this family and the people who circle around it was perfectly told.

review_title: A Deeper Understanding of the Grief of Others
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2011
reviewComment: I really loved the concept behind this book- taking a look at the grief of others. It will open your eyes (if they're not open already) to the fact that everyone is basically alone. Everyone feels grief. And it is our daily interactions with others that can either lessen the grief or make it more severe.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2011
reviewComment: "The Grief of Others" is a multidimensional family drama.  This is an ensemble piece, with no one character any more important than the other.

review_title: There is something seriously wrong with this edition.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2020
reviewComment: I purchased this book on my Kindle and got about two or three pages into it and noticed that something was terribly wrong with the English. It reads like a bad translation from another language. And that's not because' it's Victorian-era British English. As the original Sherlock Holmes books by Arthur Conan Doyle are in the public domain, their texts are everywhere on the Internet. I just wanted to read this on my Kindle and was willing to pay the $3.99 to do so.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2019
reviewComment: I am no expert but I have read all of Conan Doyle's Holmes novels and short stories plus a number of pastiches of Sherlock Holmes.  I recommend The Adventures Of Sherlock Holmes to anyone who has never read this material.  Much like wading into the ocean (instead of running and diving), the Adventures offer small samplings of Conan Doyle's work without intimidating the reader. Considering how well-deservedly famous they are,  I do not intend to insinuate that these stories are lesser than the novels but that they offer a simpler and quicker tasting of the material.  The Adventures are well-written but in smaller form and easier to digest.  The stories are indeed mysteries but their subject matter and length do not lend themselves to a long denouement or extensive flashback as in A Study In Scarlet or The Sign Of The Four. Sampling these shorter works might encourage a new reader to venture further into the canon and educate his or her literary palate.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
reviewComment: It is a frustrating read. Some stories are incomplete. Other stories are duplicated. A very poor job done by the editor.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2020
reviewComment: This was my first foray into Sherlock Holmes and Arthur Conan Doyle. I bought this Kindle edition because it had Whispersync to the audiobook edition. I, like most people in the English-speaking world, had heard of Sherlock Holmes but had never read any of the stories or books until now. I love the style of writing, the vocabulary that Arthur Conan Doyle uses and the vivid descriptions he illustrates with his writing. Sherlock Holmes is the epitome of genius when it comes to investigating and deducing facts, but the way he arrives at his solutions is so intriguing. I also really enjoyed the relationship between Holmes and Watson and the equally intriguing flaws that Holmes has, vis-á-vis, tobacco and cocaine. It makes him a bit more fallible; a little more real. I've subsequently bought A Study in Scarlet and The Hound of the Baskervilles (because they too have Whispersync with audiobook), to continue my newly discovered love of old classics.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020
reviewComment: I would rate this a ZERO if I could. Do not buy this edition as it reads like it was typeset by a seven year old and no editor ever saw it after. I spent so much time trying to decipher the typos, double words, bizarre syntax, and gobbledy gook english that I had to shelve it. It was cheap, but Amazon should be ashamed to sell a book as bad as this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2012
reviewComment: I'm not exactly certain how many of us are reading these stories for the first time. Holmes & Watson form a most engaging pair as they set about solving mysteries. As always, these are mostly riveting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2012
reviewComment: "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" is classic mystery reading from the 19th century.  I never would have bought the book, except that it's free on the Kindle and I needed something to read in a pinch.  I downloaded it, and I'm glad that I did.  The story-telling takes some getting used to, due to the style of English used during that period.  But once you've read a few of the stories, you get used to it.  Among the 12 mysteries in the book, my favorites were "The Man with the Twisted Lip" and "The Blue Carbuncle".  But all 12 were fun to read.

review_title: Great value for readers looking only for The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2010
reviewComment: This Kindle freebie is great for readers who are only keen to read the adventures of Sherlock Holmes. The stories contained within this title are:

review_title: excellent, short getaways for the mystery reader
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2010
reviewComment: Reading these stories brings the atmosphere of 1880-90s London back as thick as the fog.  I thoroughly enjoyed the exploits of Holmes and Watson as they unravel the problems presented to the famous detective.  I feel as if I'm sitting in the drawing room on Baker Street warming by the fire with our heros as Watson and I observe Holmes' mind churning his inexorable logic until the solution presents itself.  The stories in this collection are among the best and most popular of the Holmes mysteries.  The Speckled Band and Orange Pips in particular are frequently rated near the top and are a delight at each reading.  These are classic detective stories at their best.  The stories are easy reading, yet well written, and bite-size for a quick mental snack.  The short stories are perfect for grabbing up and reading one or two while you are between appointments, although I found myself devouring the whole thing in a few sittings, not able to read just one.  I read these on my Kindle, with links to the beginning of each story, and well formatted.  The only exception to this is a problem displaying the British Pound symbol.  However, this does nothing to hinder one's understanding or reading experience.  I highly recommend this collection for any fan of the genre.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2010
reviewComment: The adventures that this one includes is A Scandal in Bohemia, The Red-Headed League, A Case of Identity, The Boscombe Valley Mystery, The Five Orange Pips, The Man with the Twisted Lip, The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle, The Adventure of the Speckled Band, The Adventure of the Engineer's Thumb, The Adventure of the Noble Bachelor, The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet, and The Adventure of the Copper Beeches. The flow of it was easy to follow and even being in the dark and coming into a story midstride sometimes was well thought through. You don't feel bogged down with too many details, nor do you feel left out of some. At first I didn't like not getting some descriptions before hand, but I know including them would only have cluttered the writing with too many details.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2018
reviewComment: The author writes just like Arthur Conan Doyle. His plot leads us from

review_title: A Legitimate Addition to the Sherlock Holmes Canon
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2017
reviewComment: This book has been drifting around my TBR for a bit. But after my recent read of From Holmes to Sherlock by Mattias Boström, I find myself moving any and all Sherlock Holmes stories up on my to-read list. This book is significant because is is one of the only stories to win the seal of approval from Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s estate, his heirs being determined to jealously preserve the Holmes mystique. So with all that in mind, there’s a lot of pressure on Horowitz to deliver not only a good mystery, but also a Sherlock Holmes mystery.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2016
reviewComment: I've always been a fan of Sherlock Holmes, and would have been disappointed if this larger than life character had not been properly portrayed. This story perfectly captures the character of Sherlock Holmes and his biographer/companion, Dr. John Watson. The story moves briskly and is quite engrossing all the way through. If you've read this author before, you know he seldom disappoints. Great book!

review_title: A winner of a Sherlock copy
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
reviewComment: Very dark, but a great re writing following the style of Arthur Conan Doyle.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2017
reviewComment: Mr Horowitz cooks up a foggy, horse-drawn London full of mystery and deceit. There is conspiracy and a satisfying ending. Like his Foyle character, Horowitz's Holmes reasons implacably. The eponymous House of Silk,, however, is a shallow straw man and hardly credible.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
reviewComment: Another great Horowitz/Holmes novel.  Didn't see how Sherlock could extricate himself nor how all the characters were interconnected.  Evil folks.  Great mystery.

review_title: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, how I have missed you
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2011
reviewComment: I have been a long time admirer of Sir Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes' books and short stories.  During the late 80's and early 90's I enjoyed PBS's Sherlock Holmes Series.  When I went to England on a vacation a few years ago, I even found 221B Baker Street and enjoyed going through Mrs. Hudson's home.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
reviewComment: Lyrical, engaging and well-crafted. I felt myself walking and riding the streets of London with Watson and Holmes. Well done.

reviewComment: I thought the book started out as too much of a Conan Doyle homage. There were so many references to the canon through much of the first half of the book. But after the death of a Baker Street Irregular the pace seemed to quicken and the writing focused more on the story at hand then on what Holmes and Watson had been through before. This was when I really began enjoying Mr. Horowitz's talent as a storyteller all the way to the lovely end.

Paul, 19 years old, is sent to the same garden project for his own protection as he is a witness in a murder trial.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 2, 2012

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 12, 2013
reviewComment: I enjoyed Erin Kelly's first novel and bought this hoping it would be as entertaining. Unfortunately The Sick Rose is not a patch on The Poison Tree. The characters are not overly believable and  are poorly sketched. My feeling is that if the book had been longer there would have been a chance to develop the cast. The whole book felt rushed, possibly there was pressure to publish a second novel and Ms. Kelly felt she had to dish-up an undercooked book. Who knows! Hopefully the third novel (if there is one) will be better thought out and a better read. Having said all this it's an okay novel to while away a couple of hours but if I'd read this before The Poison Tree I wouldn't have sought out any more titles by this author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2012
reviewComment: The NOOK e-book reader compares favourably with the KINDLE, as well as being cheaper.  Once you have mastered the idiosyncratic technique for converting books to EPUB format and loading them onto the NOOK - I suggest getting a copy of CALIBRE which will streamline the conversion process.  The NOOK is lighter and more convenient to carry around than the KINDLE - my wife crocheted a nice neat carry bag for mine.  I still have not mastered the bookmarking techniques (maybe I should read the instructions) but the NOOK has a convenient one or two click method of returning to where you were last.  TO sum up - I am very satisfied.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2018
reviewComment: The product stop working after 3years. I couldn't purchase ebooks due to my regional location which made the product useless to me in the 3 years that it was working.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2014
reviewComment: A very surprising book and very good twist at the end. It was nothing like the movie, much like the book world war z is nothing like the movie. It's hard to imagine a work of horror like this being written 60 years ago and by the end you can see how Mr Matheson would have been a great fit to write Alfred Hitchcock shows and books. I was surprised by the writing style and how much 50-60 years has made a difference in how we speak and write, not bad just different. I gave the book 4/5 stars not because it's not good, just because I was not a fan of the ending and I felt it could have been more expanded upon. If you enjoy a good read and a classic story then pick this book up and give it a try. It's a masterpiece and that is the reason why it has been made into a movie soooo many different times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
reviewComment: Great story. I have found that when I watch a movie before reading the book for that movie, I always enjoy the movie better. And the same is true when I read the book first. This book is one of those cases. I really enjoyed this book, but the movie was much better in my opinion. If you look at both the book and the movie as seperate stories, it is much easier to enjoy both of them independently.

review_title: One of the original post-apocalyptic vampire novels
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2009
reviewComment: Richard Matheson's I Am Legend is a short story about a man named Robert Neville, the last living human on the planet. To complicate things, due to a bacteria there are now vampires running amok who know where he lives. By day he hunts the vampires and kills them while they sleep, by night he inebriates himself and holes up in his house. He finds a dog, and another survivor, but both feed the fire of despair, loneliness and inebriation. And by day the legend grows.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2001
reviewComment: I was apprehensive about getting this book because of all the "good" reviews surrounding it.  I am somewhat skeptical of what everyone else thinks is good because I like to form my own opinions.  It's not that I go out looking for things with bad reviews, (because most of the time, they're right *grin*) just that I don't like to be overly influenced by other people.  However in this case I can assure you, the hype is all that.  All the stories in this collection are worth your while.  Some are funny, some gross, all intriguing.  I am Legend is the stand alone best though.  It reminded me of The Omega Man, a movie with Charleton Heston, or perhaps it should be other way around. . .I am not sure about the dates.  The one "true" man against a world of monsters.  It is fantastic, people at work kept giving me strange looks because of how obivously into the book I was.  I read it very fast, then again, it goes fast once you get past I am Legend, which takes up most of the book.  The book is set up with I am Legend which is like 126 pages or so, and the others are kind of tag alongs, they don't deal with the first story at all, in fact none of the stories are related in any way, but as I said before, each have their own flavor and I loved each one and began to respect Mr. Matheson more and more as I went on.  Check it out, if you're into horror, you don't know what you're missing.  Five worthy stars!

review_title: This is a collection of stories
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2006
reviewComment: "I Am Legend" is an amazing story describing a plague that turns the entire world into Vampires, with the exception of one man, who spends the rest of his life simply existing and fighting to maintain his life by killing vampires. It is a very interesting story and I was intrigued by the day to day events the protagonist goes through and the effect the plague has on his sanity. The storytelling is not chronological and jumps right into things, with the protagonist recalling how the plague started and events that happened before it became full blown.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2007
reviewComment: I first read this book many years ago as a teenager.  It left a very long lasting impression of what it means to be utterly isolated and completely alone.  A terrifying prospect for most of us.  Throw in the fact that you are completely surrounded by souless former human beings, and it becomes an unbearable premise.  Richard Matheson pioneered this concept in literature to great effect.  Witness the number of similar books that have been written since.  Not to mention the three (that I am aware of) film renditions:  The Last Man On Earth, with Vincent Price, The Omega Man, with Charlton Heston, and now the first film to actually bear the title of the book. I look forward to the new film.  Although I'm not sure Will Smith was the right casting choice.  We'll see.  At one time Arnold Schwarzeneger had planned to film and star in another remake!  That would have been an interesting signature film for his acting career.  In any case.  This book still has the ability to chill and make one feel the unbearable loneliness of the protaganist. It also evokes the atmosphere, quite effectively, of an empty (of humanity), lonely world.  New fans of this genre should find this book affecting and entertaining, if somewhat dated.  (It was written in 1953 after all!) I recommend it highly.

review_title: Never Judge A Book By Its Movie(s) - Highly Recommended!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2012
reviewComment: Ok, I actually liked all of the movies (

review_title: So much better than the movie...

reviewComment: Maybe too late for most reading this review, but I would recommend reading the book before seeing the movie. The ending in the book is far more rewarding in my opinion. The movie could have been better if it held to more of the essence of the book I think. You should also know that "I Am Legend" is a novella and only constitutes about half of this book, the rest being other short stories. ("Witch War" one of the more twisted of these, with the Voodoo doll story from the 70's camp classic "Trilogy of Terror" being another)

But every single moment was intense and enthralling. Now I sit here, worried that it’s going to take many, many more finished books before I find another read this good. Sigh.

Boyd made the women real, and the mother's story especially was compelling enough for me to finish the book in one read from 2 to 5 a.m. on a sleepless night.  But, then again, I am a sucker for WWII espionage plots involving ordinary people.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2017

reviewComment: I can't remember why I bought this for my kindle, but I'm really glad I did. I usually don't like mysteries, but this one was different. I truly enjoyed it.  The characters were very believable. The plot had me guessing and surprised me many times, and isn't that what we want in a mystery? I might try another one by this author.

reviewComment: "Restless" is a rivetting book. I enjoyed it enormously. I couldn't wait to get back to reading it. I think Boyd did a great job of writing from a woman's point of view. I reread the last chapter to be sure I understood all the twists and turns. Thank you Mr. Boyd for a both an intriguing and fascinating book.

reviewComment: This well-bound hardcover book is a medium brown color without the dust jacket, and has gold lettering on the spine.  There's also a lightly embossed picture of the front cover on the hardcover.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2011
reviewComment: As someone before has stated, there are several technical glitches throughout the book, for example in the signature of the letter of the first story, in the word "employee" as well as in place of (money) values in the second story.. (and that is as far as I have gotten so far). It is highly annoying. I am merely reading the kindle version as a means to pass the time while I wait for a different, annotated version in print to come from the library; I also have another electronic version I can consult every time I come across a glitch of unintelligible symbols (I hate not knowing what they intend to say).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2014
reviewComment: Doyle's Sherlock Holmes novels and short stories are always a treat.  This collection is no exception.  If you're a Sherlock Holmes fan, or even if you've never read any of Doyle's Sherlock stories before, this book is a good continuation/introduction of the world-famous sleuth.  However, if you'd like to start out at the 'beginning', I suggest reading the novels first, like I did.  I purchased The Complete Illustrated Novels of Sherlock Holmes and read those first.  Then I read this collection of short stories.  I will next be purchasing and reading The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes.  This order I have listed, from what I have gathered, contains Doyle's works in chronological publishing order.  The only reason I would suggest reading them in this order is that later stories make mention of events and characters from the earlier novels and stories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2016
reviewComment: Classic and must read for everyone!  Sherlock Holmes has grown in popularity recently.  With the tv shows and movies.  I highly recommend reading the book.  I don't like to write too much in book reviews because I feel that in order to adequately write a review, I would have to give away information that would be key to plot. I don't like to be the person to give away spoilers. Therefore my book reviews are always very short and only say a few things in order to tell you, book reviews are much to subjective and I never read a book review before I read a book. I read a book based on what the book is about which I don't read a review to get. If you want more information, buy the book and read it. :)

review_title: Pretty good collection of twelve cases
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2013
reviewComment: This is a collection of twelve cases Sherlock Holmes solved, told through the perspective of his accomplice Watson. All of them are pretty short, which only takes about 1 hour 15 minutes to read one case. However, after a while, the cases start to sound kind of similar. For example, a few of the cases' victims are all enticed by money to do something, then find that it is suspicious, so they seek help from Holmes. A few of the cases sadly involve family conflict, with money and greed being the biggest issues. I liked the last two cases the most, the adventure of the Beryl Coronet and Copper Beeches. I didn't like the man with the twisted lip, because Doyle shouldn't discredit homeless people...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
reviewComment: I actually bought this book to do some book folding for my husband.  He loves Sherlock Holmes.  The book was in fantastic condition, and the pages were easy to fold, so I'm very pleased with this purchase.  It made a wonderful & inexpensive anniversary gift for my hubby, and he loves it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2010
reviewComment: I picked up the Sherlock Holmes Complete Collection because my mom had already downloaded it and I was mildly curious.  Holmes was the best book I've read in a while, definately my favorite in the Mystery genre.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2016
reviewComment: Prior to this, the only Sherlock Holmes I had attempted to read was "The Hound of The Baskervilles" which I started at least twice and never finished. I have been enjoying the PBS series "Sherlock" and a friend mentioned that some of the events on that series corresponded to the books, so when this book came up on Amazon as free, I downloaded it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2012
reviewComment: During a period of my life that I spent catching up on all the classic works that I'd never foudn time for, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes stands out.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2014
reviewComment: This is a beautiful presentation of a literary classic.  It may seem hard to believe, but Conan Doyle was an important influence on the entire field of criminal investigation.  Before Sherlock Holmes, there was little emphasis on scientific examination of crime scenes or evidence.  Doyle's characterization of Inspector Lestrade as a plodder seems to have been quite correct and quite typical..  With the debut of Sherlock Holmes in A Study in Scarlet there was suddenly an example of what was possible. The explanations of his approach and method caused real detectives to question themselves and say "I could do that".  And slowly but surely they did too.  And Holmes set the change in motion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2012
