reviewComment: This is the first book by Leah Hager Cohen that I have ever read.  I checked this book out from our local library ebook collection for Kindle.  I would have gladly paid to read this book. It was beautifully written.  This book flows from one point of view to the next with exquisit grace. Each transition leaves you sorry to switch to a new character and yet anxious to read about the next. Wow! The characters are perfect.  They were introduced in such a way that you felt profoundly connected to them. I wanted to reach into the pages and remove their grief and comfort them.  I longed for their broken hearts to be mended and for them to find a way to comfort one another.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2013
reviewComment: Well well. This book has so much emotion in it. I didn't expect to be affected by it. Although I have suffered a miscarriage, I couldn't imagine carrying a child, knowing the outcome and not telling anyone. With that being said, I totally understood how alone she felt and what her husband would have wanted her to do.

review_title: Grief affecting a family in so many ways...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2012
reviewComment: 57 hours after the birth of their third child, a son, John and Ricky Ryrie are thrown into the grief process.  Surprising is to learn that Ricky (the mother) knew in the 5th month of her pregnancy that this infant would probably not live very long after his birth.  He had a difficulty with his brain and he would not be able to sustain life for very long outside of the womb.  She chose not to share this information with anyone, including her husband, the father of this boy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2013
reviewComment: This is such a sad novel. A baby, who is born anencephalic (part of his brain  and the top of his skull are missing), dies days after he is born.  The Ryries try to put it behind them and move on with their lives but the infant's death changed all of their lives in some aspect.

review_title: Excellent account of a family in crisis
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2011
reviewComment: I am positively blown away by "The Grief of Others" by Leah Hager Cohen.  It has a depth rarely seen in "family in crisis" fiction, and I was impressed from the first page.

review_title: Excellent, poetic writing but poor character development.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2013
reviewComment: Cohen is a masterful writer. The crafting of this novel is almost poetic at times. I greatly enjoyed her gift of description. An author with such a talent can pull the reader in, making one feel like they are experiencing the novel first hand.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2012
reviewComment: Leah Hagar Cohen writes a touching and meaningful book with "The Grief of Others" that you will remember and possibly identify in several ways.  The book introduces you to a numbe rof characters either in or revolving around the Ryrie family. John and Ricky--the mother and father--have a tenuous marriage made even tougher by the death of their newborn son hours after his birth.  Their daughter Biscuit struggles to find her place in the family constantly challenging them and being somewhat mischievous in a calculating way. Their son Paul enters teen-hood and is a relative outcast at school. Others, including John's daughter from a previous relationship Jesse, enter the story and play big roles in helping the core family get back together and maintain some normal existence. In the end, the book is about grief but really to me it is about trust and how far you will go with a partner who you may or may not trust anymore.  A well-written, good book that moves quite quickly.

review_title: Great Book about a Sad Story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2014
reviewComment: The Grief of Others is a terrific book.  I think it would make a great book club suggestion--there is so much to talk about here.  The story is a family drama--but one told with a little bit a humor, which makes it so readable.  There are several plot lines here--the wife who does not tell her husband the truth about their unborn baby, the young woman escaping a life she does not need to escape, a young man struggling with the death of his father, two young children dealing with the death of their sibling.  The story is quite well-written--the dialogue flows and the story is a real page turner.  Enjoy!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2012
reviewComment: This is a story that could almost work as a non-fiction title on how different people, at different ages, etc. handle the losses in our lives. But it's not, it's a novel and the story narrative was well done and allowed us to get to know all the members of the Ryrie family and connect with them and their emotions. Some of the descriptions and 'moments' are jarring and made the book seem out of balance or a derail, but the author quickly gets back to the story at hand and I felt those moments actually gave the book it's best writing. For me, 'The Grief of Others' is a 4 and only a little choppiness kept a very good book from being great.

review_title: One of the best-written novels I've read in a long time!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2011
reviewComment: The opening chapter was so stunningly beautiful, I almost held my breath while reading it.  I thought the author couldn't possibly live up to its poignancy, its depth of emotion, but, amazingly enough, she did.  Having experienced the loss of a spouse, this story of how grief effects us, resonated with me.  I have little patience for the cheap romanticisation of death and dying which is so popular in American culture today.  This book is different in the tender honesty of the story, the truth of the characters and their personal struggles.  The author tells it all with so much love and compassion,it feels like a privilege to be invited into her world.  This book has stayed with me long after I finished it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2011
reviewComment: I downloaded this book to my Kindle many months ago. At the time, it was offered as free Amazon content. I was engrossed in another book and forgot about Rooms, until now.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
reviewComment: I have never read a book quite like this one. Absolutely loved it! Couldn't put it down! Even though it was bizarre, it was almost believable. Definitely made me reflect on my own life and whether or not I am living my best life, fully surrendered and sold out to Jesus.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2021
reviewComment: This is the best book I've ever read!  There were a few times I have to say my thoughts were "oh come on!".  But that's what also makes it extraordinary!  Not a dull paragraph or dull sentence in the entire book.  I can only compare it as a blend of Frank Perretti and Randy Acorn.  Supernatural and Super realistic!  You MUST read!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
reviewComment: I picked this up on an ad that claimed it was akin to a Ted Dekker book, and I think that may have colored my perception a bit. It lacked the subtle nuance that goes into a Dekker tale, and it also lacked the suspense and wonder when the mystery is revealed. The fact that I knew who the "bad guy" was the minute he was introduced was also unfortunate. Still fairly well-written, and I'd give Rubart another chance in the future.

review_title: WOW! Totally loved it! Best book I've read all year!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2011
reviewComment: I really REALLY enjoyed this book a lot. At the heart, I felt like this was a story of healing, forgiveness, and leaning to yield to God's Will - and finding true happiness in the Peace of God.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
reviewComment: The message in the book was spot on but for me it was hard to various 'world's together. I would give it a 3.5.  I'm don't usually read books that explore different realities.  It was an interesting read, made me think about my own life.

review_title: I feel like it helped my walk with God specifically identifying the one true voice from all the others
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2018
reviewComment: This book kept me interested and helped keep my mind on things of the kingdom and not of this Earth it has inspired me to seek God more and more and even calls me to envy and wish that I had the relationship with God that Micah does to experience God's love like that and I know that I can I recommend this book to any and every Christian I cannot say enough good about this book but I am so very thankful to have read it and would recommend it

review_title: I loved it, so will some of you
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2015
reviewComment: -WOW!!  totally unexpected read!  I just finished the book and yet I don't know exactly how to explain the depth of this book.  I loved it, so will some of  you, and some few may hate it or not understand it at all;  but I commend the author and recommend the book to anyone who wants more than just an idle read. This book made me think.  And there are lessons here to be learned by all who are interested in knowing what LIFE is all about; and how to live it abundantly.  This is definitely a keeper and one you can recommend to special friends.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2018
reviewComment: Wow.  This is a thought-provoking book.  It is one of the few books I could hardly put down so I could finish reading it.  It reveals in novel form how decisions we make, both good and unwise, effect other areas and people in our life.  It shows that belief in God and surrender to Jesus really is the most important decision a person can make.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2013
reviewComment: This book had so much hype so I think I might have expected way too much.  I very much enjoyed it - it's such a creative story and I loved the idea to have the main characters spiritual battle play out in his physical world as well.  Also, the ending was really moving and eye-opening for me.  I didn't give it 5-stars because throughout the book when there wasn't anything intense going on, the writing seemed really forced and didn't flow easily for me.  That's just a personal opinion, so don't take it too much to heart.  I just thought there were times when the writing was really overly descriptive in a way that wasn't very smooth or natural.  The similes and metaphors were just a little much at times, making it hard to get through those sections without losing all focus.  All in all, it was a great book with a great message.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
reviewComment: This is a very good pastiche.  Horowitz delves into the dark, seedy side of Victorian London in a clever plot that has lots of twists and turns.  His characterization of Holmes is pretty accurate, and he does a good job of capturing Watson's narrative voice.  I found it a very entertaining read.

review_title: You can never get enough Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2018
reviewComment: Horowitz captures the voice of Conan Doyle and via Dr. Watson spins a tale worthy of the master himself.  A rich complex plot with a nice twist makes this a very entertaining read.

review_title: An accomplishment truly in the spirit of Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2018
reviewComment: Mr Horowitz has told a tale that only Sherlock Holmes could

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2019
reviewComment: Unadulterated trash.  Not worth the paper it's printed on.  If Holmes and Watson were real they would be turning over in their graves.  Find something better to read than this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2015
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz does an excellent job in giving voice to Arthur Conan Doyle's master detective. The atmosphere in this novel and the plot twists really are a homage to Doyle. Shows like Elementary & Sherlock running simultaneously are a testament to Doyle.  I admired Horowitz's writing of scripts for Midsomer Murders & he does an equally wonderful job in House of Silk.  Now on to his novel Moriarty!

review_title: I almost believed I was reading a novel written by Arthur Conant Doyle.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2013
reviewComment: This novel by Anthony Horowitz was incredible.  He so captured the style of Arthur Conant Doyle that I thought it was absolutely written by Doyle from the grave.  Not only was the style captured, but all the characters, Watson, Holmes and the minor ones, were portrayed as if written by the 19th Century author.  Bravo to Horowitz and to the Conan Doyle estate who granted Horowitz the right to write this novel.  I would highly recommend this book to Sherlock Holmes fans.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2012
reviewComment: An interesting psychological study of Dr Watson.  However, modern writers seem to want to "humanize" Holmes by over analyzing him.  Holmes epitomized the Victorian Age.  An age of both prudishness and the industrialization of Europe and the English speaking world.  Holmes was written as a "thinking machine" the equivalent of Dr. Who without the Tardus.  That being said, I enjoyed reading the book and thought its plot worthy of Doyle and very timely.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2015
reviewComment: There is so much out there on SH  - i watch all the variations on tv: elementary, sherlock, as well as the older series and the movies. This was old style and more in keeping with AC Doyle pace of writing. I guess its a bit like chinese food. What you get in the west is so much tastier than the real stuff in China. I prefer the good rip offs to this faithful and genuine writing style of the orignal master.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2019
reviewComment: I love this book! It's amazing how he has captured the voice of the original Sherlock Holmes stories. I will read this book again, just like I enjoy reading Agatha Christie over again!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2021
reviewComment: Interesting aspect on Sherlock Holmes.  This is the second Horowitz book that I read and I like the way he writes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 8, 2013
reviewComment: the story sounded good and so did the reviews but to be honest I struggled to finish this..I did because I wanted to find out what happened but I didn't really enjoy it and gave it straight to the charity shop when I finished it

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 21, 2012
reviewComment: I found Erin Kelly's first novel, The Poison Tree, thoroughly gripping and original, so was looking forward to this one. It is another psychological thriller and has a similar structure. Here,though, the characters are less believable, and the denouement almost laughable. (I found myself thinking 'what a fuss about nothing!') So I can't recommend this one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 27, 2014
reviewComment: Not a patch on her first novel. Not bad but not one that i would recommend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 21, 2013
reviewComment: LOVE Erin Kelly's books. Lots of twists and turns and I just could not put it down. You do have to concentrate a bit with the plot as you can easily miss bits but soooh worth it. Great endings and you will not be disappointed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 13, 2011
reviewComment: For me, this is the sort of story that you really need to call in some favours, bunk off, shirk your responsiblities... do what it takes to give it your full attention until you've read it from start to finish.  Within a couple of pages, everything else (including sleep) was an irrelevance and irritation, getting in the way of finishing the next chapter.. and the next...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 5, 2013
reviewComment: This rating is nothing to do with the seller, I was very impressed with the price and speedy delivery but this book is a bit of a let down after reading Erin Kelly's first book The Poison Tree. That was gripping pretty much from the start but I am over half way through this one and only just starting to get into it. I definitely recommend The Poison Tree to anyone but if you read this first don't let it put you off her other novels.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 26, 2012
reviewComment: Bought this as a present for my wife, by an author about whom she had seen encouraging reports, so cannot comment further...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 24, 2012
reviewComment: I chose this book for our book club read, based on the reviews I'd read. We all agreed it was a very boring read with an extremely weak conclusion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2014
reviewComment: This was a gift to my son who often reads in the dark. He uses it often

review_title: It's a big waste of money
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2015
reviewComment: I Ordered 2 of these, one for myself and one for my husband. Started using mine and after a week it started getting these tiny tears within the screen so light was coming through many little spots.  So ended up just taking my husbands since he wasn't using it. Again within 2wks there appeared spots of light coming through. I emailed for an exchange and they said I would have to contact the company direct. I sent an email and got no response. I ended up getting a third one as a gift! You would think 3 times is a charm. Well it wasn't. It took a little longer but it eventually started happening again. I'm back to using the regular nook and using one of those lights u clip on:( I wouldn't even give this one star. It's a big waste of money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2015
reviewComment: My wife uses this all the time and she was really a book person.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2020
reviewComment: The old owners registration was not removed I am having trouble deregistering

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2014
reviewComment: Arrived quickly, packed well, happy with purchase. Excellent transaction.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2014
reviewComment: Ereader with built in glow light is just awesome! It is everything the NOOK Simple Touch is. I couldn't be any happier.

review_title: Barnes & Noble NOOK Simple Touch with GlowLight
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2013
reviewComment: I love this it is just what I was wanting for just reading books.  It is very light and fits in my purse perfectly.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2015
reviewComment: Bought as a present.  She loves it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2014
reviewComment: It is not as simple to get free read books. Suppose to be able to hook up and borrow library books but can't even hook to the library

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2013
reviewComment: Love how light it is! Perfect to tuck into a small bag to carry any where! I keep it tucked into my bag for any opertunity to pull it out and read.

review_title: Wow! This is exactly what I expected it to be!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2013
reviewComment: This is a super interesting book for anyone who is interested in sound, health, life, wellness, and music.  I gave it to my boyfriend as a gift and it was exactly as described.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2015
reviewComment: Excellent!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2015
reviewComment: Nice read

review_title: it reads like the transcript from an infomercial
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2015
reviewComment: This book is a bit disappointing, it reads like the transcript from an infomercial...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2011
reviewComment: I live in the country where the noise level is just the beautiful sounds of nature;  so, I am always aware of my acoustical surroundings.  I also have a large collection of music which I enjoy.  I was disappointed in this book because I was hoping to learn more about the effects of different types of music and sounds.  Instead it is more about listen to music (any type, including rap) and be aware of the noise level around you.  For me, I believe, I learned nothing from this book I didn't already know.

review_title: Pretty basic advice, but still interesting
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2012
reviewComment: "Healing at the Speed of Sound" is a scientific look at how music and noise (and silence) effect our emotions, our health, and even our ability to learn. They talked about managing noise, protecting your hearing, and using the music you like to influence your day (on waking up, for exercise, traveling to and from work, at work, in the evening, and before bed). The advice was pretty basic, and the "soundtrack for your day" is very much based on what you like. So you notice what songs effect you in certain ways and use them to wake up your mind instead of coffee, help you to keep going when exercising, relax when stressed, etc.

review_title: and can impact our world for better or worse
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2017
reviewComment: Drawing on over 10 years of brain research provides information, practical tips, and even exercises to help us understand and make positive use of the sounds that constantly surround us, and can impact our world for better or worse.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2011
reviewComment: This is a quick and easy read if you just read.  However there are 81 audio and video links as well (you have to type them if you are reading the paper book).  There are also 8 downloads.  Many of these links are inspiring videos or beautiful music.  If you like the music you can find them on Amazon or iTunes or Rhapsody or other music sites.  If you listen / watch all of these it will take significantly longer but it is worth it.

review_title: Healing at the Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2012
reviewComment: I was very intrigued by this book!  As the mother of a child who has benefitted from the type of music listening therapy programs discussed of in this book, as well as a practitioner of music listening therapy myself, I was eager to read this book- it did not disappoint!  I have a tendency to skip through books, reading here and there.  It is a good book when I read straight through- and do it in under a month!  I found this book to be a quick read and enjoyed every minute of it.  There is some material in the book that is more innately known by many people, but the authors do an amazing job at explaining how and why music affects us as it does- physically, mentally, emotionally, etc.  My favorite chapter (I think 4?) discusses more of the physiological changes that happens when certain music is playing- such as an increase (or decrease) in heart rate.  The authors also touch upon the amazing benefits of playing/listening to music- such as higher IQ's, lower stress, and living longer and more productive lives.  I am really energized to re-teach myself the violin that I stopped playing years ago, introduce my children to instruments, as well as incorporating music listening into our lives more.  I cannot recommend this book enough!

review_title: Healing at the Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: Compelling information for everyone! You'll be surprised how much useful information is in the book that you can apply to your life. Who knew sound was so important and could have such an impact on our life and health.

review_title: Monsters aren't what makes this a horror book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2011
reviewComment: Last night I finished reading I Am Legend and have to say: WHAT AN ENDING!! It is an incredibly original story because of the point of view from which Matheson chooses to narrate, to then turn the tables in the ending, leaving you every bit as astounded with the revelation as the main character is.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2019
reviewComment: I rarely read a book in one sitting and was not planning to, but this one had just the right pace to hold my interest and at the same time it was not too much work to keep going.  There was discovery and explanation mixed with struggle and danger and human emotion.  A great blend.  I was hooked immediately and stayed hooked.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
reviewComment: After reading this amazing book, I am pissed off at the Will Smith movie. It is two completely different stories. I enjoyed both but don't name a movie the exact title of the book and essentially change everything! Ugh! It's not even zombies in the book but vampires!!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2013
reviewComment: This is one of the must reads of classic horror fiction. The story is very tight, the characterizations have depth and are unflinching. It is important to look at this in the context of the time it was written--it shows some biases of that time prior to strong women's rights and women in the workforce. Nevertheless, it is still one of the best vampire stories set in modern times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2013
reviewComment: I have a really hard time giving a book five stars when I don't like the ending, however in this case I feel the writing is definitely worth it.  As a helpless idealist, I prefer happy endings, all is well with the world, everyone good survives, all the bad guys somehow miraculously are killed, jailed, converted or cured ... Oh yeah.  But somehow all the best books are more realistic, maybe because that's what life is!  Oh well, guess when I need a good happy ending, I'll have to pick we a nice romance novel, but for now ... I loved this book ... all of it.  Even though the ending was unexpected, or wanted (LOL), I can certainly imagine a book two with a surprise beginning!  I doubt it after all these years, but you never know.  Maybe Mr Matheson has one hidden somewhere that will be a surprise release someday.  In any case, I loved reading all the places where the movies (3) got their beginnings.  Great read.

review_title: Now I Know Why it's a Classic
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2012
reviewComment: I decided to read this book because it's a classic in the genre, it basically gave form to the modern zombie. Although the word vampire is used in this book, and aspects of vampire lore (garlic, crosses, etc..), the behavior of the "afflicted" is really what later characterizes the zombie.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2013
reviewComment: If you are among the few like me that saw the movie first and then read the book, I think you are in for a treat. Just go into it with an open mind that it has a very different ending.

review_title: If you've seen the movie the book actually helps makes sense of it all
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2011
reviewComment: I'm usually not one of those people that reads the book AFTER seeing the movie, but this was the case for this particular story. I seen the Will Smith version and was somewhat confused as not much was explained correctly.  It was all too 'extreme' with the way the movie portrays it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2006
reviewComment: I make it a habbit not to read too much into the reviews as too many times plots are ruined and the whole story is given away. I'm glad I didn't read the editorial review on this book here on Amazon as it gives just about everything away!!! If you haven't read it, good, don't! If you have, well it's still a great story eventhough the review blew the ending for you.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2017
reviewComment: Forget the movie made a few years ago, it was junk. Same as "The Omega Man". The movie that came closest was "The Last Man on Earth" with Vincent Price. Some chilling scenes. This novel is more than excellent. Once you start, you have to read it until the end. This volume also has several other of Matheson's short stories

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2013
reviewComment: Readability in Sunlight is super even when the sun is directly hitting the screen; can't be beat! The blacks are great and the contrasting white whites really helps these old eyes of mine! I like the Android operation too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2012
reviewComment: The Nook Simple Touch is a great little e-reader. It's easy to use and displays books well. It handles pdf files better than my husband's Sony T1 reader, which I have been delighted by as I often get review copies of books in pdf format.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2011
reviewComment: I am so pleased with my new Nook Touch. I have already purchased 4 books and am reading them all. The best part is that there are so many good books that are free ( even one OT/NT free Bible)and most others are under $10. There is also the ability to read samples of books before you buy without going out of the house because the Nook has Wi-Fi.

review_title: E-readers are a great way to build your library
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2013
reviewComment: Smart, sleek and easy-to-read, this Nook is my first E-reader and I am very happy with it. Easy to use all the controls on it and it features an easy to understand manual so you can access all of the reader's many features. Good price, too.

review_title: it is easy to use (add books
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2015
reviewComment: This was purchased as a present for an 8 year old, it is easy to use (add books, change books, read on). The text is clear and does not cause any more eye strain than a normal books.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2014
reviewComment: Exactly as described, wonderful condition, easy to use. Great for no nonsense book reading.  Awesome battery life, plenty of storage, with room for expansion if needed. All around excellent.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2012
reviewComment: Glad I splurged on this (which I never do). It is very light in weight, screen is crystal clear, very user interface friendly, and easy controls! The only problem I have run into is trying to have "nook friends"...I haven't figured out how to hook my library up with my friends' nooks...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2015
reviewComment: After using an iPad at night to read, and discovering it interferes with ability to sleep, I needed a non-backlit e-reader. This was inexpensive, and works like a charm. Recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2014
reviewComment: Bought this as a gift for my father-in-law and he has not put it down since! Great buy for the money. Quality is top notch. I would buy one again in a heartbeat. Came packaged very well for shipping.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2017
reviewComment: Great for 11 year old to access library books

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2013
reviewComment: I happened to see the film version of this story on Robert Redford's Sundance Channel. Intrigued, I bought a used paperback and couldn't put it down. No doubt about it. William Boyd spins a really engaging, historically accurate novel. I still go back and will read certain sections of this book. I would buy a DVD of this movie if possible.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2015
reviewComment: This was one that although well written, did not manage to get under my skin and linger. As usual, Boyd tells a very

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2007
reviewComment: Exciting novel of intelligence, in this case British misinformation work in the USA before America entered the war against Nazi Germany. The author writes well about what he knows well - the unwrapping of the layers of information years later. The unmasking of the villain and of his motivesis excellent; the account of the melodramatic events in America a little less so.

review_title: An intriguing war time mystery set in Europe and America ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2015
reviewComment: An intriguing war time mystery set in Europe and America. Drawn into the spy network out of loyalty to her dead brother, Eva finds that she likes the excitement and mystery of the challenges she meets. Events leading up to America' s entry into W.W.2 are revealing. A cracking story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2017
reviewComment: 2 stories of child and parent interweave.  A beautiful book that was absorbing from start to finish.  The descriptions of Oxfordshire and the season were very evocative and the story of wartime events was gripping.  A book that I would read again and recommend highly to others.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2011
reviewComment: Dear Steven,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2013
reviewComment: This is a story that should be read by all daughters.  So often we assume that the woman who bore us and raised us is a one dementional  caretaker.  This piece of fiction forces us to see our mothers as people....women who have lives above and beyond simple maternity and childrearing.  I enjoyed this book so very much.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2015
reviewComment: Excellent ! Spy/espionage is not my usual reading choice, but this book was focused on character, although there was plenty of undercover intrigue. Highly recommended.

review_title: Good writing, interesting characters, good storyline.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
reviewComment: Very descriptive writing. An interesting approach to a spy novel, well told. Characters worth visiting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2007
reviewComment: i have read all of william boyd's novels, his short stories, screenplays and most of his essays--he's far and away my favorite contemporary novelist.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2013
reviewComment: What a pleasant change after having just finished The Adventures of Arthur Conan Doyle!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2020
reviewComment: Product is great, packaging was great so item arrived in perfect condition. Shipping was painfully long. Shipped on September 12th arrived on October 16 so I'm not sure what's up with that, but it's here and being thoroughly enjoyed by the friend I ordered it for. Thanks

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2012
reviewComment: This ebook compiles 12 of the best and most well-known Sherlock Holmes stories. They're quite entertaining, and they're short, so it's easy to sneak one in when you have a little spare time.

review_title: The beauty of the old canon with the wonder of the modernisation
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2014
reviewComment: I could go on about the Sherlock Holmes stories, but seeing as how there are plenty of reviews for The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes itself, I'll just review the BBC Books reprint.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2019
reviewComment: This is the second audio book I have that is read by Simon Prebble.  He is a very gifted narrator.  There are many stories included and he sounds just like Basil Rathbone who has always been my favorite Holmes.  He can sound like so many different characters.

review_title: The master of insight and mindfulness
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2016
reviewComment: Doyle created an enduring character that, through various iterations over the decades, has become one of the most easily recognizable and most admired detectives. What is interesting, however, is that through reading the originals, I find that Holmes seemed to stretch the bonds of credulity with his deductions. Either that, or Watson was not the best narrator in his documenting of the cases. Still they are a fun read and certainly have made for some great viewing over the years.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
reviewComment: As always, I was captivated by the occupants of 224 Baker Street! Each story unique and well thought out, it makes for a literary delight. Even the narrator gets 5 stars for his part.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2012
reviewComment: As I sat at my study I heard a knock at the door. There, to my surprise stood my dear friend, Sherlock Holmes. "May I come in, Watson? I have a puzzling problem that I need your help solving." "Certainly," I replied. Sherlock entered and began to tell me of his plight. He had been contacted by Strand magazine to record some of his most interesting cases. But having no writing skills was in a quandary as to whom to ask to tackle his momentious task. Of course I accepted the duty with great relish (and enjoyment, I must add). After the prodigious job was completed I queried, "Who will illustrate your work, my dear Sherlock?" "It's elementary, my dear Watson," he exclaimed. "Only Sidney Padget is up to the task!"  And the rest is, as they say, history.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2013
reviewComment: This classic work is both interesting and informative, my dear Watson. The stories vary, but all are intriguing, showcasing the observation skills of the Master Detective. Truth be known, Dr Watson contributed much to the work, and I believe he was an actual person. Holmes had a drug habit, not illegal at that time, and probably an effort to hold his tremendous intellect in check. Eventually, he overcame it, and took a few years sabbatical, as it were, where he dropped out of sight to peruse the world cultures outside of England. I enjoyed reviewing the stories again, having read them years ago as a erstwhile detective. Some might say the book is "elementary" but the depth is cleverly hidden.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2012
reviewComment: Any one over the age of 50 should remember Basil Rathbone as Sherlock Holmes.  All the Sherlock Holmes movies were in black and white, and they always took place in the streets of London.  A very gloomy scenario.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2018
reviewComment: This is an intensely spiritual story. One unlike anything I've ever read!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2018
reviewComment: Four stars. The concept of this book was excellent but I thought the author could have developed the plot a little more. There was a lot of potential to do more impactful things with the main idea. That said, I still enjoyed this book and it has made me view some things differently. I have actually changed certain aspects of my behavior having read it. This is a book for Christians/believers. I'm sure agnostics and atheists will not enjoy it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2018
reviewComment: This book was not what I expected at all. It is a compelling story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2020
reviewComment: James L. Robert is an excellent author who does create a mind-bending spiritual journey of healing and freedom which  you will never forget. I look forward to reading more of his excellent novels.

review_title: One of my TOP reads of the year! Great book!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2014
reviewComment: A book that may not be to every person's taste, but I really enjoyed this one! Wonderful allegories, excellent writing, and a story that kept me reading even when I should have been doing other things, made this one of my top reads of the year. Plus, I've e-mailed many friends and recommended it to them! That does not happen often. It took me deep inside my own struggles, and uplifted me with scripture-based scenes and story parts. All in all, everyone should read this book to the end, then decide if it's to their taste, or whether they found it as life-changing as I did!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2017
reviewComment: Really, alk I cab say is Wow! This book needed to be written, the story needed to be told. It called out to me from the Amazon store and I couldnt put it down. It was God's plan for me to catch a cold so that I could stay in bed with this book of powerful messages from Him. I will and have already recommended this book to anyone who will listen. Perfection! I hope it is available in hard copy so that I can share it with those I love.

review_title: Rooms convey a place used specifially for ones needs/likes.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
reviewComment: Wow! What a book-amazing!  Very interesting plot that a distant relative could plan for a relative enough to know his personality as well as working with rooms that helped the very wealthy, disciplined man years later deal with His areas that needed emotional healing. Not giving it away but it is well worth the read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2011
reviewComment: Review by Jill Williamson

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2010
reviewComment: What a fabulous read!  This book describes the difference between committing your life to the Lord and how you can still be a Christian and live mired in sin and despair.  The Lord calls us to a better, victorious, peaceful, heartfelt life: His!  This book describes the emotional upheaval,  battle, and unspeakable prize of following the Lord.  This book is full of symbolism, fantasy to show how He changes you on the inside.  This is not entertainment; this is about your life and your journey to getting yourself right with God.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
reviewComment: This was a wonderful story.  I had to keep reading to find out what happened next.  So nice to read a story that didn’t contain foul language or graphic sex scenes.

review_title: My cerebral cortex was engaged by this book -- so suggests Annie Murphy Paul
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2012
reviewComment: A NYTimes Opinion article (March 17, 2012) by author Annie Murphy Paul proclaims that support for the value of fiction has arrived unexpectedly from the field of neuroscience. Wow. Although I write nonfiction, I certainly read fiction; most recently The Grief of Others by Leah Hager Cohen which I read with an unusual, inexplicable kind of enjoyment. I noticed how much her language engaged my thoughts and feelings in a way that had not ever happened to me in my earlier reading life. The Opinion piece fit what I felt and thought while reading Cohen's book, but couldn't clearly understand or describe. Until now.

review_title: The Most Engaging Parts Interrupt the Flow
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2011
reviewComment: This review comes from the uncorrected proof for limited distribution of "The Grief of Others".  The book addresses the reactions to loss and the grief that ensues....the real loss of two babies and a father through death, the emotional withdrawal of parental involvement from their children, the destruction of the underpinning of love within a marriage, the loss of family relationships, the loss of childhood and maybe, most of all, the loss of who each character thought they were.

review_title: A Poignant Picture of Painful Transitions
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2011
reviewComment: I had been disappointed by the books I'd been reading about family life and "issues" facing them when I picked up this novel. This was a pleasant shift in the trend. Often when a writer chooses a central theme--in this case grief--she fails to make sense of the connection, but Cohen does this beautifully, sensibly, subtly, but not so obscurely that it stretches credibility. The characters are poetically drawn, the relationships comfortable, and the writing engaging from the first page.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2012
reviewComment: The cover synopsis intrigued me and the first chapter was lovely. But I stopped reading when the father goes to the door and finds his soaking wet daughter, who has skipped school, with a strange man who brought her home. Dad is totally unconcerned, just asks, Oh, where have you been? And Biscuit, had she never been told to not get in a car with a stranger? The story lost me there.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2012
reviewComment: The Grief of Others is a beautifully written book about a family dealing with the loss of a baby and trying to move on in the face of insurmountable grief and anger.  I found this book to be completely engaging and heartbreaking.  Having lost a baby myself, I found the emotions of the family to be completely real and completely accurate.  This book was excellent and I am looking forward to reading others by the author.  I highly recommend this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2011
reviewComment: After the death of their infant son from anencephaly, the Ryrie family finds themselves grieving individually, isolated from one another. While they all pretend that outwardly their world is intact, inwardly the fabric of their family is fracturing itself into pieces.  John and Ricky are distant with each other, Biscuit and Paul struggle with normal childhood and pre-teen issues that are compounded by grief over the loss of a brother they never knew and distant parents.  Jess, overcome by unexpected pregnancy shows up searching for purpose and meaning.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2012
reviewComment: Others have summarized the plot well. Cohen's writing is of extremely high quality. I caution that reading about a doomed baby is not for everyone. In addition, the 10 and 13 year old children are too precocious to be believable. Nonetheless, the characters are compelling and I was disappointed not to learn more about their futures.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2011
reviewComment: Leah Hager Cohen is one of my favorite writers for a lot of reasons, not least of which is her ability to see, hear, and feel--and then share with readers her remarkable insights. The first pages of this novel are a masterpiece, a portrayal of grief  exquisitely rendered. The rest of the book fulfills the promise of those pages. But this is not just a novel about grief; it's also about the many facets of love and family and life on earth.  It often makes you smile, or laugh out loud, or creates in you some sort of recognition that makes you want to shout "Yes! That's just how it is!"  I loved every character, even--and perhaps especially-- when they were behaving badly. This is Cohen's best book yet, and now that I've finished it, I'm eagerly awaiting her next work.

review_title: Started off strong but fell short
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2012
reviewComment: I wanted to like it, I really did, especially after the poetic and lovely beginning. But it's just so depressing and some of the plot developments are odd and not that understandable such that it ultimately fell short for me.

review_title: A family in grief struggles to recover
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2011
reviewComment: This is an interesting novel about a family still grieving from the loss of a baby the year before and now they find the family relationships deteriorating.  Into this sadness comes a step-daughter, now grown, single and pregnant, and her arrival is an impetus for all sorts of changes in the family dynamics as they struggle to recapture the relationships they have lost.  It meanders a bit but gets there in the end and holds your attention.  Nice writing.

review_title: Need to Ramp Up YOUR Read Alouds?  This book is for you!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
reviewComment: Even if, no especially if, you are a veteran teacher who has been a READ ALOUD expert for years, you DO NEED this book.  Maria Walther has an easy to follow format, details and thoughtful thoroughness  in these read aloud texts published since 2015.  Your students will be completely engaged in these read alouds that will inspire your students to read and explore more text on their own.  Perfect for building background knowledge, talk around key literary components and straight into writing - perfect for all classrooms!  AND you can access a wide variety of curriculum content - Math, Science, Social Studies, Art, and Tech - to name just a view through these Read Alouds!  You will love the student learning that is a byproduct of your Ramped Up Read Alouds!

review_title: Dr. Walther has done it again!!!"The Ramped-Up Read Aloud" is a MUST HAVE for educators!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2018
reviewComment: WOW, where to begin with this one...! I opened the book and was immediately impressed by the very easy to follow format,  detail and thoughtful thoroughness that went into each of these read alouds. I have been avid in implementing Dr. Walther's lessons in my own classroom and know the satisfaction of, LITERALLY,  all of my students being totally engaged!  These lessons will not only inspire your class to read and explore even more literature on their own, but will also increase communication skills, build schema, (all key components in generating students to write) and most certainly,  excite and catapult your students into THE WRITING PROCESS! There are opportunities for writing extensions with almost every read-aloud lesson!  By doing all of this, the possibilities of your day become endless...  an advantageous journey of connecting your read alouds to ALL other subject areas throughout the day, (Science,Technology, Engineering, Art, Math and social studies...etc.).  It is also nice to know that you have the flexibility of inserting your own favorite read alouds into the lesson template!  Let's all Ramp-up our Read Alouds and encourage our students to ask questions and energize their ambitions to LEARN!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2018
reviewComment: Dr. Walther is highly dedicated to children and teachers. Her passion for helping teachers teach quality lessons is apparent in all of her professional books. However, this Ramped Up Read Aloud Book is by far the best!  She has actually used each and every one of the books listed within and has given tried and true information and lessons. She has given the framework so teachers can use her information and tweak it based on age levels of children. Knowing she’s experienced these picture books cover to cover makes reading this Ramped Up Book a joy. I personally love that when I read about a particular picture book she has reviewed that ideas and activities come to mind because she’s laid the foundation for teachers to use and be creative based on the needs of his/her students. Thank you Maria and can’t wait to see what is in store next.

review_title: If you are primary/elementary teacher, BUY THIS BOOK!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2021
reviewComment: I have been in public education for 32 years and counting. This is an amazing resource!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018
reviewComment: As a school librarian, words cannot express how many great ideas I got from this book. From the first page, you can see how passionate Dr. Walther is about connecting students to books. I was inspired by her countless ideas that I can use when teaching. Many of the books she referenced were recent titles— some familiar and some new-to-me. After reading this book, I have a list of great NEW books to share and ideas to help bring the joy of reading to my students. This book will be one that I will come back to reference over and over again.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2018
reviewComment: Dr. Maria Walther takes her passion for literacy and creates a comprehensive resource for anyone who works with young learners. The Ramped-Up Read Aloud is set up in a user-friendly format that not only celebrates the importance of the read-aloud experience but incorporates lessons with paired texts that will engage even the most reluctant readers. Dr. Walther's insightful recommendations and lessons will captivate students' engagement, build their literary delight, and cultivate an atmosphere of wonder in the classroom. Organized in a fashion where you can easily grab and go, this resource also allows for differentiation. Dr. Walther has taken the time to read, analyze, and connect hundreds of picture books to help teachers create literary rich classrooms. This book is simply AMAZING!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2018
reviewComment: I have not read this book cover to cover, but I have found that the layout makes it incredibly easy to use in the classroom.  I already have several lessons tabbed to use in Writer's Workshop, and LOVE the picture book titles that have been included.  The beginning lays out reasons for why read aloud is so vital to students, and the chapters are an easy to follow progression. Plus - there's spots for writing in your own ideas for books that could be used with the standards being taught. Another FABULOUS Dr. Walther book!

review_title: Great resource for beginning Teachers and Sub Plans
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
reviewComment: I did enjoy this book but felt like it didn't go far enough. There are many great lessons and examples that the book provides for teaching ELA in Early Childhood and Elementary classes. Walther provides great insights into what strategies make these lessons work. This is where I feel the book is kind of lacking because I wanted more detail on "why" these strategies work. I also feel as though we are being teased with ways to instill aesthetic learning, but never really crossing the line from surface level learning. To give credit, Walther's does remind readers of student intersectionality. Just because it works in one class, doesn't mean it will work in all classes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2019
reviewComment: This book is AMAZING! Such an asset to any teachers collection.  The texts and lesson suggestions are fabulous. Plus, the price is perfect for every teachers wallet. I highly recommend this to every teacher. I have seen such improvement in my students reading comprehension using these strategies.

review_title: A must have for every classroom teacher!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2018
reviewComment: I love everything by Maria Walther and  have been counting down the days for the release of this book! It did not disappoint! This book contains the latest and greatest in picture books to make your read aloud time a huge hit with your class. It is organized in a way that makes it a quick, grab and go resource for teachers. Ideas are easy to implement and are engaging for students. Ideas for differentiation are also included. This is my new go- to resource for my daily read aloud time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
reviewComment: I was surprised to find out that this book was with in the 1950's. I'd seen parts of the Will Smith movie. A deadly plague had struck Robert Neville's world. All the people he's known (friends, his wife, his daughter) are dying. That's bad enough, but they don't stay dead. They come back hungry for blood, infecting others. Soon, Robert is the only one left alive. At least that's what he believes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2008
reviewComment: Here is the story of Mr. Robert Neville, the sole witness and only survivor of the end of the world. One good day, people started to rise from the grave and turn into vampires. Our main character isolates himself in his house with everything he needs to survive.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2017
reviewComment: This book was purely entertaining.  An absolute page-turner.  I read the whole thing in one stretch and it was nearly responsible for me missing a flight as I sat in the lounge saying "I'll walk to my gate once I finish ONE more chapter."  If you've seen the Will Smith movie, you get the general gist.  But a single-character story is much better suited to book-form where you can more easily access the thoughts and emotions of that character.  While it has action, unlike the movie, it isn't really an action-based story

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2012
reviewComment: I had seen three movie versions of this book, the one with Vincent Price (my favourite), the one with Charlton Heston and the one with Will Smith, before reading the story and none of them come close to what the book is actually about.  The story starts with our hero hunting and killing vampires and ends up being the story of perception.  At times I felt the story was quite slow moving, but I believe that is part of the telling, because there are no other humans to help this man make the time pass.  I read several of the 1 and 2 starred reviews and I feel most of them were unjust because they were expecting the book version of the Will Smith movie.  Readers should know this book was written in 1954 and has the feel of the same era.  It is not a slash bang smash em up.  It is a commentary.

review_title: Book is dark not a horror.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2018
reviewComment: The book is dark. And I love that. People could easily get rejected thinking "oh it's a horror" but it's not. I would sound probably cocky or something if say "I can relate to this book a lot" but it is not because I think too highly of my self and it does not have any connection with the title, but it is because I had difficult times in my youth growing up through the surrounding that was really dark and people were really a mental wreck. And I could relate to Robert Neville's emotional difficulties and how hard it feels to meet that normal person that is almost impossible to find. That's what kept me through the book that I read 1-2 chapters a day. But seeing how he became a legend it left a mark on me of how through all those things he went through the book, he never changed his core self. And probably because it's a book and not a movie, it somehow stays so deep within you. It is awesome.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2018
reviewComment: WHat a chilling read! My husband and I devoured this book in one sitting, often arguing over who would get to read when! I recommend everyone to read this over watching the movie. I removed a star because I was hoping to have a regular copy, but instead I received one with Will Smith on the cover. I felt like it was false advertising and it really upset me and my husband.

review_title: Riveting Narrative of Survival in an Alternate Reality
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2014
reviewComment: This is a truly great short story of survival in a post-apocalyptic world that intentionally avoids long narrative and gratuitous violence.  Matheson draws you in quickly and paces the narrative so that you can't walk away.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2012
reviewComment: This seminal work is singlehandedly responsible for kicking off the modern zombie craze in my opinion. The book is dark, taught and gut-wrenching. It was originally published in the 1950s, and I can't begin to imagine what all those happy `Father Knows Best' readers made of it at the time. And remember, this was way before the Cuban Missile Crisis and the Cold War.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2020
reviewComment: The was an interesting twist to the movie. It kept me hanging on the words and not wanting to put it down. The ending I thought could have been better though.  Left me wanting a more in-depth ending.  But all in all a good read.

review_title: Read it for the ending if for no other reason!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2011
reviewComment: "I Am Legend" is a horror story written in 1954.  It is a founding book in what we now classify as "post apocalyptic" genre.  The story revolves around Robert Neville who is a one-man army against a land filled with Vampires.  In his quest to survive, we follow Robert over a three year period where he struggles with survival, depression, alcoholism, and the ever present hope that he is not the last "normal" human in the world.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2013
reviewComment: This thing has not worked right since I received it! You read three or four pages and it will freeze every time. I bought one from my daughter and have not had a problem with that one!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2013
reviewComment: In my opinion, the Nook Simple Touch is the best e-reader on the market because... well... it's simple. No distractions of email or social media, it lets me immerse myself in a book and I love it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2019
reviewComment: still have not been able to use.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2014
reviewComment: Bought this as a gift for my granddaughter.  She dropped it and it cracked in the corner; Barnes and Noble replaced it; no questions asked. Can't ask for better then that.

review_title: Good, but some book download issues
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2017
reviewComment: Works good, but has problems with downloading books.  Error message says book already returned.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2015
reviewComment: I bought this because my older nook battery is slowing down, and I love the nook.  You cannot easily buy a new battery, but I could

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2013
reviewComment: I know that there are reviews that warn against this item, but we have been very pleased with it.  Haven't run into any complications, but haven't had it that long.  If all you need is a reader, this is an awesome way to go!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2014
reviewComment: Love this eBook Reader.  Simple to use. Easy to read screen.  Am very pleased with this item and am satisfied with size.

review_title: Kind of felt bad buying the competitors product on Amazon
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2014
reviewComment: Kind of felt bad buying the competitors product on Amazon, but it's a great little device. Without the backlight, the battery lasts forever!

review_title: This item was new but failed to turn on after ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2017
reviewComment: This item was new but failed to turn on after fully charged.  We have used e-readers for years and this is the first one with this problem.

review_title: Highly recommended - Healing at the Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2011
reviewComment: Doman and Campbell make the compelling point in their new book "Healing at the Speed of Sound",  that many sounds including music that we are exposed to in our daily lives can have a detrimental effect on an individual or can be soothing and healing.  These sounds can change our basic physiology; possibly increasing our blood pressure and heart rate, to elevating anxiety levels and creating muscle tension.  Specific noises can create a negative environment that interrupt sleep cycles, reduces our ability to pay attention and stay focused while they can even manipulate our moods.

review_title: The Best Overview of Music & Sounds Effects on Us & Our Environment
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2012
reviewComment: Personally, after diet, I find sound therapy the most powerful way to help children and adults relax and learn. Many times people are interested in knowing more about sound therapy so I'm happy to share, "Healing at the Speed of Sound."

review_title: Understand Music & Sound in Your Own Life
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2011
reviewComment: I have always loved the idea of using music & sound in creative and practical ways and I know what a powerful impact it can have in our life.  The authors get that each person is unique in what works for them, so they offer ideas to teach us how to customize our own sound environment.  They have opened my eyes (and my ears) to the methods available to improve brain function through sound so we can live a healthy and productive life.  I enjoyed all the extras too:  Links throughout the book with videos to watch, music to listen to, and or other interesting articles to read and think about.  This book is SO engaging and I will refer to it again and again!

review_title: Great insight - this book is an Eye Opener!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2011
reviewComment: I got this book on the recommendation of a friend and LOVED it.  I highly recommend it!  I didn't appreciate the extent to which sound that I'm not in control of impacts my mood, productivity, enjoyment, relaxation, sleep -- my quality of life.  Thanks to the authors for helping me understand that OF COURSE I should be taking control of the sounds I "consume", just like I do with the foods I eat, rather than just listening to whatever other sounds are happening around me and my family.  I'm excited.  I feel empowered!

review_title: Healing at the Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2011
reviewComment: My entire family has found sound-based therapies extraordinarily valuable in managing life challenges, ranging from learning differences to stress to sleep.  At last, I've found a book with a depth of analysis great enough to explain the transformative qualities of music for me and my family.  Yet, thankfully, it is also written with an understanding and understandable voice, based on life experiences repeated in each of our lives.  My thanks to the authors.  Their layers of references will no doubt consume a great deal of my reading time.  But more important, they have given me a framework that will make following their research trail understandable. To all out there -- this is an important book in taking charge of your life!

review_title: Music Heals and Changes Our Brains
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2013
reviewComment: The information in this book helps us understand the important role that music plays in our lives. The author explains how music can be healing, energizing, relaxing and can affect us in subtle ways. It is filled with interesting anecdotes and studies.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2011
reviewComment: The world deserves this book! Every parent should know how stimulate their child's development with sounds. Every child should know how to soothe their aging parent. Every person should know the power of sound in their own life.  This book makes these events easy to achieve. The book itself is full of those experiences as sound literally rises from the pages and engages the reader in a journey towards wisdom & health. Our own healing occurs as we read. Thanks to the authors for a job brilliantly done!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2014
reviewComment: Great Experience!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2011
reviewComment: Easy read. A topic that most would not think is that important, but it really shows how sound affects us.  It affects us more than I was aware.  Was able to make some quick adjustments to my environment which have made a big difference.  Book was VERY entertaining and enjoyable.  None of the chapters sprawl on forever.  It moves fast and provides plenty of fun, relative links to music and videos.  LOVED IT!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: Loved this book! So much valuable information and the links are a great additional resource.  Sound affects us in more ways that we are generally aware of.  We make sure to eat right, exercise, get enough sleep, but what about all the sounds bombarding us on a daily basis?  This book helps us to handle that part of our lives.  I encourage anyone interested in better health or sense of well being to read this book and implement it into their lives.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2014
reviewComment: I love my Nook glowlight!  It's easy to use and hundreds of books are available to purchase and download.

review_title: Great value and backlight is a plus
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2014
reviewComment: This reader is great it regular or bright environments and now that it has a back light it can be used in the dark as well.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2014
reviewComment: This is the BEST nook, had all the top ratings, such as Consumer Reports- too bad they stopped this line at B & N. You have to buy it somewhere else, such as Amazon. Has the advantage of the side buttons so you can move the pages forward without having to reach with your hand and touch the screen, for example, when you are lying on your side holding the nook in your left hand, you can advance the pages using your left hand on the button, and not have to reach over with your right hand. You can't do that with the new Glowlight, apparently. Otherwise, the Glowlight works perfectly and is a real boon to anyone who wants to read in bed and leave the bedside light off. Otherwise, everything works the same. I enjoy having a dictionary handy so you can quickly look up interesting new words.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2014
reviewComment: The glow light option is awesome and easy to use. My son reads on it all the time and it works great.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2014
reviewComment: Fantastically lightweight and easy to read with. Its a great e-reader. Its well worth the same amount of money it costs as its works easily and well and makes reading a joy. Best for those you just want to read books.

review_title: I like the light weight of the nook and the light ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2014
reviewComment: I like the light weight of the nook and the light is perfect.  Still going strong a few years later.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2013
reviewComment: My wife  is 110 % satisfied with her new easy reader and I'm thrilled she doesn';t have to turn on the light to read with the glow option

review_title: this is the best e book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2014
reviewComment: In my opinion, this is the best e book.  I am so frustrated with the new version since they don't have sd card expansion although still prefer it over Kindle

review_title: ... and they screamed when they opened then and they like them very much
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2014
reviewComment: I gave two of these to my two grandchildren and they screamed when they opened then and they like them very much.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2014
reviewComment: This product was BETTER than I expected, still packed in a box with instructions, cord and in perfect condition. Got it quickly and love it.

review_title: Sherlock Holmes' fans will love it
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2019
reviewComment: As a long-time fan of Sherlock Holmes novels, I was expecting to be disappointed by Horovitz's attempt at resurrecting the characters.  I was completely wrong.  The atmosphere and characters and dialogue and plot were as satisfying as the original.

review_title: Very good attempt at duplicating Conan Doyle
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2016
reviewComment: Very good attempt at duplicating Conan Doyle.  A bit overlong; the plots twists at the end a bit of a stretch beyond Holmesian logic; the dramatic plots twists a bit cinematic in their modernity. All that said, this is the 21st Century and this was a fun, exciting read, with ultimately a nice tip of the hat to Holmes, Conan Doyle and the wonderful Sherlockian world.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2013
reviewComment: Back in the day, I read all of the original Sherlock Holmes stories, but I haven't paid much attention to the non-Conan-Doyle novels that have come along. (It's hard enough to keep up with the movies and the TV shows.) But the description of this one made it sound faithful to the Doyle style, and indeed, it's a nicely written, well researched, and twisty story with suspense and surprises. I'll probably look for another Horowitz when the TV shows start to pall.

review_title: A must for any Sherlock affciando!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2015
reviewComment: Mr. Horowitz was commissioned by his estate to write a new Holmes book and this is the end result. I very much enjoyed this Sherlock Holmes mystery. I am sorry to admit that I have never read Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. I am familiar with most of the original stories due the BBC series with Benedict Cumberbatch, but I am going to read the originals now.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2016
reviewComment: Despite the nastiness of the topic, this is by far the best Sherlock Holmes pastiche I've ever read. The author largely refrains from using his knowledge of the past to enhance the tale, a trap many others fall into, and gives an amazing story that could easily have been written by the great Sir Arthur himself.

review_title: Mr. Horowitz got in the skin of Sir Arthur - thankfully so.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2018
reviewComment: Brilliant  -  just brilliant!  Difficult to envision the cruelty the poor children of that era endured, however the story rang with clarity.  Entertaining to the last word. Mr. Horowitz did Sir Arthur proud.

review_title: It is Sherlock and Dr. Watson!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2017
reviewComment: True era story with Sherlock at his best and Dr. Watson along with him. As you read the story you feel like it is Arthur Conan Doyle because the author got his nuances perfectly. Recommend this book highly.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2016
reviewComment: I can say that I have thoroughly enjoyed this book.  It has been a joy from start to finish. I have just read it and now want to start it again. It has been a while since I've enjoyed a book as much.

review_title: How wonderful - more Holmes stories to read after a century without
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2013
reviewComment: If Conan Doyle was alive today writing Holmes novels, he would have written this book.  What else can I say?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2018
reviewComment: Amazing! Conan Doyle is one of my all time favorite authors and Horowitz does not disappoint with this. It's a must read for any Holmes fans.

review_title: An Adventure into a book I always desired to read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2020
reviewComment: I have been a Law Enforcement Officer for 47 years. It was interesting to go back and read a Classic of deduction in the step by step solving of various cases!

review_title: AUDIO SUCKS!! Don't buy if you want an actual voice actor to read it to you...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2017
reviewComment: This audiobook version sucks! You get what you pay for - janky, staticky reading of the book without accent. The audio isn't automatically downloaded with the book; you have to go to a whole other website in order to listen to it, which of course they don't tell you how to do. It was the Amazon Kindle customer service team that helped with this part.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2015
reviewComment: I've loved Sherlock  Holmes since I was 9 and first read The Hound of the Baskervilles. When I purchased this book, I looked forward to re-reading some of my favorites. It was surprising that this book didn't begin with A Study in Scarlet. Others were missing, too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2016
reviewComment: This is a great adaptation, what is even better is what due to public domain, the download was free.  I've been a fan of the works of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle since I was a child.  It is startling how many of his works are the basis of some of the more common tropes in movies and novels today.  That being said these stories still feel fresh and engaging in spite of this.  I highly recommend these books, not all classics age well, but this one did in every way that matters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2018
reviewComment: A classic text, which I first discovered on my grandfather's book shelf as a 13 year old and have returned to many times over my lifetime.  Of course the various modern TV and film versions are known to many nowadays and the cult Sir Arthur Conan Doyle created is still as popular, though drifting more and more into science fiction and fantasy of late.  It gave me the idea of becoming a forensic scientist, but I did not follow this aspiration, except to become another kind of pathologist and to observe and interpret in a way that in many ways was similar to Sherlock Holmes himself.  Such is the power and attraction of Doyle's fictional character to me!

review_title: A Classic and a Good Read.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2013
reviewComment: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes was one of the first books that I downloaded when I got my Kindle.  I read these stories twenty plus years ago and had enjoyed them then, so I decided that I needed to get this and to have another read.  While the language is slightly dated, the layout makes it an easy read.  My recommendation is to treat it as something you're going to read over time and not something to plough through from cover to cover.  The stories are interesting and with the return of Sherlock Holmes to both the big and little screen, relevant to understanding the great detective.  I highly recommend this book.

review_title: Great book beautiful bindings and cover. Higley recommend
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2020
