reviewComment: Great book print is not to small not to big. Lovely ribbon to keep one's place and eye pleasing looking cover. Well entertaining when I was recovering from surgery in August

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2018
reviewComment: It was great to read the original Sherlock Holmes stories & see how well the PBS Sherlock Holmes show captured the earn e of who Sherlock Holmes was as written by Doyle!

review_title: Classic short story collection of The greatest Detective ever
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2012
reviewComment: To say it's Sherlock Holmes would be enough except for this 20 word limit imposed by Amazon :-). If you're a lover of classic mystery stories, as I am, this book will be a delight. The collection contains stories as chronicled by Sherlock Holmes' able bodied assistant James Watson, The mysteries are always intriguing to Holmes and unique in such a way that they pose some form of deductive challenge for the world's best deductive reasoner. Once you begin to read you will be taken back to old England in a time where the world was just beginning to use science as a means of development rather than warfare and chivalry was still alive and kicking, this book is a must read for all you book lovers!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2009
reviewComment: Classic!  I'm very glad to own this book in it's Kindle edition and for a very reasonable price too, $0.00!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2020
reviewComment: Loved the ending! A powerful woman plays a man's game.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2013
reviewComment: Intricate, innovative story line that keeps your attention with usual Boyd approach to detail and complexity.

review_title: You May Unfasten Your Seatbelts Now
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2012
reviewComment: This is the type of book that you read once, having picked it up in an airport lounge and finished on a long ,or not that long a flight.  Read it once and enjoy it, but you never have to go back to it, because there is nothing else there.  A competent craftsman-like book much like one reviewer said, of the Ludlum-Follett school.  I could also like to add Tom Clancy.

review_title: Talk about a inside look at the media!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2017
reviewComment: This was a fascinating read! I have been drawn to reading about female spies lately, and here is an intelligent, strong, creative character that we can admire.  Loved it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2012
reviewComment: "Restless" performs a neat trick in paralleling the past and the present stories then melting the two into one.  One small complaint:  the Reuben Jones, the destroyer sunk by the Germans in the book, was in fact the Reuben James in real life.  I'm surprised at a writer as good as Boyd is would let a small fact like this not be double checked.  Inexcusable.

review_title: Talented Writer; Where Was His Editor?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2017
reviewComment: My overall impression of this novel is that it did not read like a final draft. There were a lot of strange word choices, over-wordiness, repetition of words, and some bad grammar, to-boot! A good editor could have corrected most of these flaws (and glaring typos). The style of writing was not smooth: sentences that had to be read over again to  make sense, and still didn't; scene breaks where skilful transitions would have made for a better flow; narrative that jumped unnecessarily in time within chapters. All in all, too many characters for the length of the book, which detracted from the most interesting story (Eva's). The alternating chapters with the different viewpoints and time periods made for a choppy read, and, as another reviewer pointed out, I felt Eva's story was not naturally told in the third person. Who writes their memoirs this way? It introduced a sense of distance to the immediacy of the events, which got more suspenseful as the book progressed, but which could have been even more suspenseful. There was a lot to like about this book--interesting insights and erudite information, some brilliant description. It just could have been so much better...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2017
reviewComment: Cleverly written.  A fun read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2006
reviewComment: Restless is the story of a mother who has concealed her true identity from her daughter.  Chapters alternate between WWII and contemporary Oxford.  The characters are complex and the settings detailed and evocative.  I loved this book and read it in one sitting--I wish it had been longer.  I love William Boyd's novels--he has a historically detailed imagination and knows how to tell a story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2013
reviewComment: Highly recommended -- Boyd at his recent best here.  Beginning with a young emigree living a perhaps Nina Berberova-esque existence in Paris entre guerres, Boyd weaves a compelling tale of the surprising and often unknown complexities that bind our presents to our pasts.  About as good as pop fiction gets today.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2012
reviewComment: If you like WWII spy novels, N.Y. and Hedy Lamar, this book is for you.  The book adds Russians into the mix instead of just Ivy League & Oxford vs. mean Nazi.  And some Baader-Meinhof is added to the mix, as well.  The book is not perfect, with people doing things a sane person would not do, but it is nonetheless a great read with interesting characters and a good story.  Worth the time, certainly.

review_title: I love the way Leah Cohen writes and the way she ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2014
reviewComment: I couldn't put this book down.  Each character is developed in an interesting way and we are brought back and forth in time to learn the story. I love the way Leah Cohen writes and the way she describes everything from the way the characters are thinking to the sky that day.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
reviewComment: I expect to get to the point of a story sometime, but it never happened. Very disappointing.

review_title: Great descriptions of the complexities of relationships
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2016
reviewComment: Great descriptions  of the complexities of relationships .

review_title: A Lot of Words and People Going Nowhere
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2011
reviewComment: There are two things I look for in a novel, interesting characters and a compelling story/plot.  Leah Hager Cohen is batting .000 in that she has struck out on both.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2011
reviewComment: Like many have said, this started out strongly with beautiful writing...and then just kept going, and going, and going, and going...until finally I just didn't even care enough about any of the characters to finish it! The wife's interaction with her husband was totally unrealistic; you wonder why they ever felt they were so in love in the first place!

review_title: It was good for a free library book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2015
reviewComment: I borrowed the electronic version from my library and read it on the Kindle App. It was good for a free library book. I liked the story and how easily it flowed.

review_title: ... a slow readout that's ok because the writing is amazing. Strory line might be difficult for some
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2015
reviewComment: This book is a slow readout that's ok because the writing is amazing. Strory  line might be difficult for some .

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2015
reviewComment: Great book. Very sad, but mirrors real-life families.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2012
reviewComment: I read many Amazon reviews, very rarely write one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2011
reviewComment: I do not remember when I read a book that was so turgidly depressing and boring. The more I read the less I cared about all these self-absorbed twits.

review_title: Great if You Have the Recommended Books
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2020
reviewComment: Very helpful for the novice and experienced teacher who needs support.  The downfall is not knowing which books are included. When I paged through the book,  I only had 3 recommended read aloud books. Not worth it to buy all the books in addition to this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2020
reviewComment: This is an excellent resource with detailed read aloud lessons for specific picture books, as well as suggestions on similar books to use for similar lessons. Each lesson also includes extension activities. I use this book for lessons in my K-3 library and it has been especially useful during this distance learning period.

review_title: Must have for K-2 Read Alouds!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2020
reviewComment: A colleague recommended this book to me for quick go to read aloud lessons.  This book is amazing and I really wish she'd come up with one geared for 3-5 students, just a suggestion.  The text suggestions are newer books and all are highly noted in the literature realm.  It was nice to have new current books with ideas and lessons, versus the same old, same old texts.  The lessons are quick and easy to look through and understand.  She even suggestions other books that are similar and would cover the same topic.  Highly recommend for K-2 teachers!

review_title: Wonderful book! Well worth the money.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2018
reviewComment: This is one of THE BEST professional books that I have purchased. It includes wonderful lesson plans for a variety of incredible read alouds. So easy to implement and give some oomph to my read alouds.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
reviewComment: This book is absolutely a must have for k-5 teachers. The lessons are simple to follow and do not require prep work. The pages are colorfully illustrated and there is a list of alternative books for each lesson in the case that you don't have the book the lesson is based on. We love it so much that I have purchased the books that go with each lesson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
reviewComment: I was so excited for this book to come and while I haven’t actually read the book yet, I am a little disappointed after skimming through it. I have hundreds and hundreds of children’s  books and I only have 2 of her 101 books included in The Ramped-Up Read Aloud

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2020
reviewComment: Love Love Love this book!!! It has inspired me and renewed by love of teaching littles!!! This book gave me so many great ideas that I cannot wait to take back to the classroom!

review_title: Must Have For Teachers of Reading
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2019
reviewComment: Exceptional resource for instant classroom use. After 2 teachers demonstrated ease in the classroom, I purchased multiple copies for teachers to check out of our school library, then coupled it with a single-copy of each text referenced in the book. An instantly usable bank of ideas and questions for novice to experienced teachers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2020
reviewComment: Wish there were a few newer books in this manual. So happy I got it. It has great lessons.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2020
reviewComment: I really love this book!  It gives great insight into picture books that can be used for all grade levels (K-8). I was, however, super disappoint in the fact that when my brand new book arrived, it had pages ripped and a deep scratch across the front. I'm not sure who deserves the blame for that. I just know that if I paid for a brand new book, it should NOT have been damaged.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2014
reviewComment: Great book

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: Once you begin reading this book you will understand quickly how the sounds that surround us play an important role in how we feel on a daily basis. I love the idea of creating perfect soundtracks for every task.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2011
reviewComment: Each chapter is filled with fascinating information, facts and examples on the hows and whys sound, particularly music, is so influential on how we feel each day. This little book has to be the best and easiest path to positive life change out there. A fascinating, entertaining and empowering read! I love this book and highly recommend it.

review_title: It is about sound, not about great classical music.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2014
reviewComment: Other reviewers call Healing At the Speed of Sound an "easy read". The book does not engage with the effects of listening to challenging classical music.

review_title: Healing at the Speed of Sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2011
reviewComment: This is an exceptional tool that will last you a lifetime. The power of music as medicine goes deep into the history of mankind and is a timely benefit in these difficult and troubling times. Doman and Campbell have harnessed the power of music in easy to understand terms. This is a significant and astonishing read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2011
reviewComment: Another phenomenal book by expert Don Campbell. This book has been long overdue! It is an excellent resource for professionals, educators and parents. There is something for everyone. He has a talent for taking cutting edge research and presenting it in a fun, yet relevant manner. There is also an interactive feature which makes it easier to integrate the concepts into your daily life. It is an excellent holiday gift as well - I've already ordered additional copies for family and co-workers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 19, 2012
reviewComment: This book is packed full of information and the latest research into the use of music for health and healing.  The interactive sections - via your e-reader or computer - are excellent and make it far more than just a book.  Don't under-estimate the power of music - we all know it affects us - but really it can be quite profound.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 15, 2020
reviewComment: Very interesting . I have always wondered how music affects humans.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 21, 2014
reviewComment: an overview of some interesting idea, but all rather old hat (at least to me)

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on November 8, 2015
reviewComment: Ein großartig und überaus sorgfältig recherchiertes Kompendium von zwei überaus kompetenten Autoren. Pflichtlektüre für alle, die sich umfassend über die praktischen Möglichkeiten im Zusammenhang mit diesem Thema informieren möchten

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2018
reviewComment: "Pretty sad that we define each other by what we do to put bread on the table rather than what makes us come alive."

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2015
reviewComment: Awesome story! If anyone is looking for a book to wake up their sleeping faith then this is it! Micah Taylor has it all, money, penthouse, a beautiful girlfriend, but is it really all his? When he inherits a house from his late great-uncle things happen in that house that causes Micah to question his life and his relationship with God. I cried more than once while reading this book; it touched deep places in my own heart and caused me to honestly answer the discussion questions at the end. I will definitely reread this book and others that this author has written!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2010
reviewComment: I am on the fence regarding these free Christian themed books for the Kindle. I really don't mind the whole preachy thing, even though it's really not my type of thing. Whatever, if other people like that's fine with me. It's just that the book wasn't that good. The plot sounded fascinating, but the execution just didn't hold my interest. I found myself looking to see how far along I was, percentage wise. I stopped sixty percent of the way through. The dialog between the characters was stultifying and the story just plods along. I know one should read the whole book and then write a review so my opinion is based on the first half of the book. Maybe one day I'll revisit this, but I'd rather actually pay for a book that I'll read and enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2010
reviewComment: I have mixed feelings about this book.  It's not a secular book and should not be mistaken for one.  It's a Christian book about a journey to discover a relationship with God.  I have no problem with a Christian book in and of itself.  On its own terms - theological terms - I have some problems with this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2018
reviewComment: This book deserves more than 5 stars.  It hooked me from the beginning and didn't let go.  I will go back and read it again more slowly when not trying to see the conclusion.  A must read for followers of Jesus Christ and thought-provoking for those who are seeking, or haven't yet embraced Him as Lord and Savior.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2020
reviewComment: This book was incredible! The imagery and storyline was imaginative, creative, and completely original - so unlike anything I've ever read or heard of.  I will gladly read this again, & recommend this to any & everyone. It is a great read for anyone seeking a fresh spin on God's creative possibilities to touch people's lives in a mind-blowing way. Wow!  Many thanx for a phenomenal adventure, Mr. Rubart!

review_title: Not a real fan of Christian fiction, but this was a favorite
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2015
reviewComment: Great book. Worth the read. As a picky reader, I struggle with a lot of Christian fiction, but I accept for the spiritual "feeding" they give, if even a little contrived. This one was probably my favorite so far. I liked it enough to buy a copy for all the teen girls in my bible study class. I thought it was better written than This Present Darkness (which I really appreciated), and was a serious page turner. I would often read another chapter or two past needing to go to bed.

review_title: Pretty good diet tips... if you want to be a stick thin model
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2011
reviewComment: This book really does what it sets out to do.  It tells you the tricks models and celebrities use to get skinny, like only eating 2 meals a day (many models) and having a piece of chicken for breakfast (Cameron Diaz).  If you are interested in little tricks, this is the book for you.  For overall health, I'd have to take away a couple of stars.  Some things these people do are obviously unhealthy.  I'd recommend the Live Food Factor if you care more about your overall health, rather than just want to get skinny.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2017

reviewComment: This book is a bit old school but the remedies in here actually works and its always best to use things that are naturally prepared for us. I even shared this book with my co workers and they went and order them also.

review_title: You can find some good stuff here
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2017
reviewComment: There's not a lot of new tips in this book and quite frankly the tips at times seem to contradict each other, especially when they come from the rich and famous.  Be a vegetarian, eat more protein, skip breakfast, eat a big breakfast, cut out carbs, cut out fat. Each star has her own tips, so it is best to take that portion with a grain of salt, or not as some stars avoid sodium.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2007
reviewComment: Diane Irons doesn't "recommend" yo-yo dieting, as some reviewers have stated.  She merely says it's less dangerous than being obese, so keep trying to lost the weight, even if you've failed numerous times.

review_title: A diet book that actually works!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2003
reviewComment: This is the only diet book I have read that really shows results! No, this is not one of those books with just one diet to follow. This book pulls together secrets from models, superstars, people who have had succesful diets, and more. Inside this book, you will find neat secrets that will help you lose weight without going through all that trouble! I also enjoyed learning how models, singers, and actresses stay so thin. For example, did you know that many models carry kelp tablets to speed up metabolism? Or, that Jamie Lee Curtis onece cut all fat from her diet and ate nothing but vegetables to get a role in a movie?! Not only that, but this book also includes many success stories of people who have been on diets and came out happy and appreciative of their bodies. You will also find free sources (mostly websites) which provide advice and tips for dieters. I also enjoyed the chapter with tons of delicious recipies all under 200 calories. Whether your goal is to lose 35 pounds in two months, or you just need to lose 5 pounds for a party next week, this book is a wonderful reference and very helpful.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2006
reviewComment: Okay, so basically, I love this book.  Yeah, yeah, yeah, some of the tips are unhealthy.  Okay.  You need to research a diet program before you begin, anyway.  Some of the tips are absolutely FABULOUS and as we all should know, it's the little things you change about your diet that can really help you lose weight.  And even if some of the celebrity dieting tricks are unhealthy, who doesn't want to know what the celebrities do to stay all fit and fab...aka skin and bone.

review_title: You will LOVE this book! It really caters to everyone...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2003
reviewComment: Aargh! I cant understand why this book got a 3/5. I guess it is most likely because people are criticizing the author on her lack of scientific information. BUT this book is valuable in so many ways. Perhaps most importantly, it is a lot of fun to read. I find myself perusing it often, and it keeps me motivated to stay healthy and it offers so many different approaches to health that you will never get bored with a regimen. The author offers dieters and people who are looking for ways to cut calories in general a HUGE variety of tips and tricks that are INEXPENSIVE (so inexpensive, I am a poor college student and find virtually all of her suggestions doable). The author has not done scientic research but has approached this subject in (I think) a much more valuable way, that is journalistically. Instead of buying some doctor's get rich fad diet book that works in theory but not in practice, you can buy this book and learn what celebities do to keep their weight down. Not that I am all that interested in celebrities, but when you consider that their fortunes rely a lot on their looks, you can trust that they know what works-at least for them. That is really the best thing about this book. It is so chock full of interesting tidbits, that you are bound to find some ideas that you can incorporate into your own lifestyle. So while not all suggestions will be relevant to you now (but who knows, maybe in a few years they will be), you are sure to find some tips that will be very valuable to you. The recipes in the back are also EASY to do, with no exotic ingredients to hunt down. Also, the author tells a lot of non celeb stories, and that is just as valuable if not more that her recounting of the celeb stories. This is an EXCELLENT book if you are just starting out as well, it will DEFINITELY get you motivated, and also theres a valubale lil part that makes you think about why you overeat. what more could you want in a diet book?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2001
Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2007
reviewComment: A cult classic that has been revitalized by the Will Smith movie.

review_title: Forget the movie, read the book.....
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2007
reviewComment: The absolute coolest vampire concept ever!  My friend recommend I read telling me how the ending left him speechless, and now having read it myself I can definately say it is the best ending of any book I've ever read.  The concept is that Nevelle is the last man alive due to a virus that changed everyone else into vampires.  The book starts with him making repairs to the outside of his, which he does every day due the damage the vampires do trying to get in at night.  His house has become his fort, the only thing that protects him each night from them.  He can't stray too far away during the day cause he needs to have enough time to get home and seal himself up at night, which removes any hope of him finding any survivors beyond a certain radius. By day he wonders out for supplies when he needs them and reinforces his house, and by night he locks himself in and tries to ignore the vampires outside trying to get him to come out.  The book is mostly about this one remaining man who's all alone, researching and trying to figure out what the virus is and how it works. At the end he is in a situation which explains the title of the book.  The book is very short, I was disappointed when I Am Legend ended after only 100+ pages with the rest being short stories.  But for such a short story it is still incredibly powerful and intresting, and the other short stories are worth a read too.... Don't let the movie ruin it for you, while it follows the same concept as the book it leaves out all the things that make the book so good.  They should be punished for changing the ending to the way they did.... BOO Hollywood...... LATE

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
reviewComment: I read this entire book in one sitting and could not put it down. Although it poses a great many questions that are never completely answered, it makes the point that not only do diseases mutate...societies do as well. Would an average person from 500 years ago recognize us? Would they think we were some new form of human? Or witches?

review_title: The Opening Story is Great, the Rest is Garbage
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2007
reviewComment: "I Am Legend", the title work of this anthology, is a classic vampire novel and very well written. I enjoyed it and would give it 4 or maybe 5 stars.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2018
reviewComment: Great classic page-turner. The narrative is an excellent post-apocalyptic/science-fiction story about loneliness. It's also an interesting reversal of classic fantasy stories about the hero going to slay the dragon (which to me) is epitomized in the title and ending. The prose can be choppy in dialogues at times but otherwise is good.

review_title: Familiar but Different to the Movie
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2014
reviewComment: This was an interesting read, not at all what I expected and yet sort of familiar from the movie experience. It would be terrible to be the last person on earth and this book paints a picture more detailed from a human point of view than the Day of the Triffids and yet not a lot occurs in the story. It feels a bit like the darker parts of Stocker's Dracula such as the scenes where Harker is trapped in the count's castle.

review_title: AFTER THE MOVIE, I JUST HAD TO READ THIS!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2008
reviewComment: My twelve year old came home from school two weeks ago and informed me that his friend had read "I Am Legend" and that it was entirely different than the movie. Well, I loved the movie but I was curious about the book. I bought it and took it to work to read. Whenever I am reading a good book at work and my phone rings; I jump so badly that my heart pounds for several minutes after the scare. This happened to me many times during the book. I became one hundred percent engrossed with the isolation feeling that the main character was experiencing. Then suddenly...BANG, the story abruptly ends mid-way through the book. I sat there scratching my head feeling very perplexed. This is something that anyone who is considering buying this book MUST KNOW. The book actually contains numerous short stories. I still highly recommend purchasing it though. It was different from the movie and I personally feel that it was just as good as the movie.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2004
reviewComment: As a little boy I remember watching "The Omega Man" through the crack of my bedroom door--bed-time was well past. It became my favorite horror film because it requires deep thinking and analysis of what the world--and your psyche--would be like when you are the last remaining "normal" human being. Movies based on books can be so far apart from the orignal story that it would seem that the name was highjacked only as a box-office draw. This book while not the same has all the darkness and developed ethos and pathos of "The Omega Man." I would--and will--read this book several more times in my life. It so well written that I wish the "great" authors would write more books like this. If you are a horror and/or sci-fi fan, here is a great book for you. If you are a modern day pseudo-vampire, you will be disappointed for there is no romance related to the life of a vampire. The author makes it is clear that the dead are really dead, the tertiary beings--who are now the new species of homo-sapien--are deluded, and Neville is and always will be Legend. This book the perfect companion for a long airline flight.

review_title: I love the book. The book is better than the movie. Set in LA NOT NY. Which is better lol

reviewComment: I love this book. Its a kind of somber and lonely book. And you can feel it. Easy read = easy to visualize what’s going on. Focuses more on the character than the creatures. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2004
reviewComment: I am Legend by Richard Mathenson stands out in the world of horror writing. While the story is only a novella, taking up roughly the first half of the book, I am Legend contains a huge amount of detail. It tells the story of a man who believes he is the last human left on a planet ravaged by vampires. Methodical in his methods, every day he hunts vampires in his neighborhood and gathers supplies, constantly searching for signs of life and encountering people he used to know in his former life, before they were transformed into vampires.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2014
reviewComment: I have always been a fan of Sherlock Holmes, the stories are just so intresting and entertaining. I read through this collection one story at a time, as I was laying in bed. The length of each story is perfect to use as a bed time story. I have already read all of these stories, but it has been so long that it was great to read them again. If by chance you have not read them, you owe it to yourself to find out what you have been missing. Also, with the stories being in public domain - they're free, so you have nothing to complain about.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2013
reviewComment: I already have the same book from a previous purchase, but when I discovered this version had copies of the original artwork that went into the magazines where Sherlock Holmes was serially published, I just had to get it. It was well worth it. A simple "double click" blows up the picture on my screen. It makes me feel like I'm actually part of what the original readers experienced...the only difference is I already know how the stories end. I love the artwork. It brings an additional dimension to the works.

review_title: I enjoyed this collection but it needs to be longer for character development.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2014
reviewComment: I gave the collection four stars not the writing nor the stories. I felt that the collection should have been a bit longer. In today's post-Doyle world there are two different approaches to making Sherlock Holmes characters, consistent with Arthur Canon Doyle's work or only in name similar.  Movies, and television have simulated caricatures of some form or another of the main people and this has made the classic writing harder to relate to if there is not enough writing to redeveloped the characters anew.  The collection might have been enough at one time but the collection exists now in a multimedia world and those characterizations invade the original which makes the original, need more support of character development to offset the preconceived notions. I know this is harsh and is not a critique of the author but it is a fact of losing poetic license.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2013
reviewComment: I have always enjoyed Sherlock Holmes stories and this book of course doesn't disappoint. That said there aren't many of the more famous stories in this book. Many of them are short and once in a blue moon rely on Sherlock solving the puzzle using information previously unknowable by the reader. However these mysteries are more for enjoying the journey, not trying to solve the mystery yourself. I would have liked some of them to be about twice as long as they were. Right after getting into it, it ends.

review_title: A Fantastic Adaptation of the Holmes Canon!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2017
reviewComment: The House of Silk by Anthony Horowitz is a novel that takes the Holmes and Watson characters originally written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and adds another story to the ever growing list of adaptations. Horowitz was one of the first authors to be officially endorsed by the Conan Doyle Estate, and not only uses the same characters but tries to emulate Doyle’s style as well. The novel begins with Holmes and Watson having a conversation with Edmund Carstairs, a middle-class man who believes someone has followed him back from America to torture and kill him. The case takes a turn when Ross a homeless boy that Holmes employs, is murdered as well as the discovery of the House of Silk, a secret society which seemingly operates at the highest levels of government. Throughout this narrative, poverty is intertwined into almost every scene and action. I believe that Anthony Horowitz successfully portrays the poverty plaguing the streets of Victorian London as well as emulates Doyle’s style, but he falls flat when faced with the cast of characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2015
reviewComment: This is a fast paced, twisting, sometimes frightening romp by Holmes and Watson through the "belly" of London.  Well researched 1800's London history provides Horowitz with a perfect brush to paint the sets of this mystery that stretches to the highest chambers of Her Magesty's government.  Good read by a fine Holmes impersonator.

reviewComment: I, like the author, have been changed by the genius of Doyle and Holmes. In that time I have read, watched, and played all the derivative works. Most are passable at best, some are offensive, a precious few stir me to an emotion. This has become, for now, the Great Work of homage to Holmes that all others should aspire to attain. The voice and method and pulse of it were perfect. For once I wasn't reading about an action hero with a supposed genius that solves more with violence. It was Holmes, the mind to equal the whole of London's police and criminal syndicates. I am becoming too hyperbolic so let me sum up with this-

reviewComment: I can't stomach religious themed books. Can't believe I got through the whole thing. Magical thinking (miracles, angels, the devil). I'm sorry I looked at the stars without reading the reviews. Kept waiting for some realism to kick in. Science fiction is more believable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2014
reviewComment: The first part of the book really swept me in.  I really liked the author's style.  However, the further I tried to read, the more I developed a dislike for it.  At first the rooms appearing seemed weird, but when it got to the room that it was 'himself' in the room, it was just silly to me.  I'm sure there is some subliminal message or thought to the story line, but I lost interest.  I don't want to have to guess what an author is saying.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2018
reviewComment: Okay, tough review to put into words....we're all searching right? I loved

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on August 21, 2016
reviewComment: A wonderful book to guide us with the deep vibrations between the heart and the brain..With this connection ,healing happens....with the speed of sound...!Danielle Schnupp

reviewDate: Reviewed in India on January 7, 2021
reviewComment: The book didn’t seem new. Has creases/lines all over the cover

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2018
reviewComment: Beautiful story of humans breaking down and finding themselves among the ruins.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 29, 2017
reviewComment: quite sad a great book

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on May 13, 2017
reviewComment: Fast shipping...... item as described!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 31, 2016
reviewComment: I found this book honestly overdone. The grief, guilt, misery, woe, complexity - you name it - are all laid on with a trowel and, for me, that made it hard to relate to. It got unbelievable very fast and at time was almost a parody. I didn't finish it - which is rare for me - and I did try reading it again a few months later but failed completely with it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 22, 2012
reviewComment: What this book lacks in pace it makes up for in prose. Hager Cohen writes beautifully, with almost poetic observation, but this cannot disguise the plodding plot of The Grief of Others.  It's unfortunate that there is an absence of intrigue in the novel - the subject matter is heart-wrenching and could have drawn in even the most emotionally-devoid reader but it doesn't. The family in this book have suffered a tragic loss with the death of their newborn son only 57 hours after his birth, due to the tragic defect Anencephaly.  This isn't the focus of the novel, however - it focuses (as suggested by the title) on the family's grief, or rather the lack of it as it would appear to others.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 4, 2012
reviewComment: The story of grief and the loss of a baby ,  a baby born with a condition " incompatible with life", and the family coming to terms with this and the changes this makes within their relationships.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 21, 2012
reviewComment: This book tells the story of one family, one year on from the tragic death of their baby-who died aged only 57 hours.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 10, 2012
reviewComment: This is not the easiest of books to read - at least l found it quite hard going.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 28, 2012
reviewComment: A very well written book with lots of description but for me, not a page turner.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 7, 2012
reviewComment: This book tells the story of the Ryrie family and is centered around the tragic loss of their newborn baby boy, who died at just 57 hours old.  You learn about each member of the family and how the loss has affected them.  For me I found this book slow and hard going, it was a depressing read and apart from feeling empathy for the family at having to go through such a loss, I didn't particularly like any of the characters.

review_title: I am highly impressed with it and recommend to anyone that is leery about it
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2017
reviewComment: I was hesitant to purchase a refurbished product but after using it I would never have guessed that it wasn't brand new. I am highly impressed with it and recommend to anyone that is leery about it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2014
reviewComment: It was a little spendy (because I can be cheap) but the overall product was great! Didn't want to deal with the return when I got another one for less. So I gave it to my other sister. They both love their nooks.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2014
reviewComment: I love it!  Crisp clear page!  I sit outside in my lawn chair in the bright sunlight and read without a problem!  My daughter took it to the beach with her and loves it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2015
reviewComment: works great.

review_title: Does the job and good for the money spent...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2013
reviewComment: Wife bought this for her elderly mother - but she couldn't quite get the hang of using it (tech challenged)... My wife has been using it instead and seems to like it pretty well... All is good :)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2013
reviewComment: very very good value for this reader, and I am grateful for the quick exchange they made when the first unit developed a problem right away.  They immediately sent a replacement.  Immediately.

review_title: It's a solid e-reader with an amazing battery life
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2014
reviewComment: It's a solid e-reader with an amazing battery life, but the screen broke under very little pressure inside of a backpack, wrapped in a jacket, on a flight. So disappointing.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
reviewComment: I bought this one to replace an old one that stopped working.

review_title: Nook makes reading pleasurable on the go
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2013
reviewComment: Easy to use.  I got it mainly for the ability to adjust the font size for easier reading as the public library has a limited number of large print books.  When we travel I don't have to lug around 3-4 books.  The Nook fits easily in a small travel bag or purse.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2016
reviewComment: Very good reader for price and specifications

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2016
reviewComment: This is an excellent Sci-Fi read. Matheson gets into the head of his character Robert Neville. He gets into the biology of the creatures Neville is dealing with. He explores the problems of isolation and the need and desire for human contact. It's a great Sci-Fi read, quick to get through, highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2014
reviewComment: Great read!  Kept me interested the whole story which I loved.  I had seen I am Legend with Will Smith which was good and he is a very good actor but of course some changes as expected from the book.  I truly love the book better.  The storyline is smooth and you never get lost.  Character development was wonderful.  Quite different ending from the movie but I really liked the ending in the book much better.  So much in line with the development of the story line.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2019
reviewComment: I'm glad I read this after I saw the movie. I enjoyed the movie well enough but this story is far superior. The author expresses so many things so well. His take on vampirism is brilliant. Truly a must read for sci-fi fans.

review_title: Outstanding novel marred by slipshod editing
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2014
reviewComment: I recently bought the kindle version and was disappointed to find sloppy editing had rendered portions of the beginning unintelligible. Buyer beware. However, please don't let that stop you from a compelling read. Unlike some of the clumsy Hollywood adaptations, "I am Legend" is subtle and introspective, with a solid foundation, regardless of the seemingly dated premise.

review_title: Got the book in expected time.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2020
reviewComment: This book was written in 1950s and up dated in 1980s. It is nothing like the movie. It is about vampires that talk to him at night who call him by name and wants him to go outside.

review_title: Shorter than I expected, but bleak and compelling
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2020
reviewComment: A good book. Well written, compelling and interesting (although surprisingly short). I had not seen the movie before (still haven't, as of writing this comment) and knew very little about it. I liked the bleak, fatalistic tone carried throughout.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2012
reviewComment: Robert Neville blockades himself in his home every night to ward off the hordes of vampires that have overtaken the world.  By day, he slays the undead in their sleep and researches their affliction, never suspecting what he himself is turning into.

review_title: An amazing story of the last survivor of mankind!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2013
reviewComment: This story for me was extremely well written and intriguing. The last survivor of the human race that is really pure human struggles with his situation while surrounded my enemies out of ancient legends. He is alone in the world and his mentality finds it difficult to just surrender and give up. His actions are geared to survive and actually fight back against his enemies. He is the last of an old race and he suddenly realizes that evil kills evil.  He realizes that he has become legend for the new race being born.....

review_title: Never felt like I was invested in it
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2018
reviewComment: Honestly, the story is just average for me. Never felt like I was invested in it. I would probably rate this a 3 star book, but I was annoyed that the story abruptly ends in the middle of the paperback. There is no marketing to suggest that half of this physical book contains unrelated short stories from the author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2014
reviewComment: It is amazing how different the movie was to the book. I understand it has to be modernized but at least they could have made a better effort. This story reveals what loneliness can actual feel like and what it can truly do to a person. How many people can truthfully say they're alone, utterly and completely isolated from anyone who can feel your pain or excitement and can truly converse with you. In this world of connectivity and social exposure I wouldn't think there would be many at all. The movie sensationalized the vampire aspect of the book instead of the true purpose of the story. This book is, as usual, much better than the movie and very different in the story. Enjoy!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2006
reviewComment: I agree with the reader(s) who said this book totally contradicts itself and seems thrown-together, as if no one proofread it.  In one chapter she'll recommend something; then later on she'll tell you it's ineffective and/or dangerous!  She gives a long, long list of herbal supplements that are supposed to aid weight loss -- but she just repeats all the advertisers' claims without any comments, recommendations or opinions of her own.  Personally I think most natural/ herbal supplements are a ripoff, but if she had given any testimonials by people who've found them to work, I might consider trying them. On the whole, this book is a waste of money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2001
reviewComment: This book is the best!  First, I loved the interviews with successful dieters.  Real stories (very blunt) about marriages breaking up, embarassing moments, you name it.  Then, I liked the research that Ms. Irons has done with scientists explaining myths and supplements.  Another area that this book has that no other diet book does is how to look your best while going down the scale.  That's a great approach!  What really makes me use this book each day to keep me motivated are the absolutely delicious recipes (about 100).  Not only are they easy to use, but they're all under 200 calories.  Cookies, meatloaf, even chocolate truffles (60 calories).  I've read every diet book on the market, not any come close to a realistic life plan.  This does it all!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2000
reviewComment: I feel this is the best diet value out there.  It's not one diet, but diet tips taken from famous people and every day people, a compilation of delicious recipes that I have found very easy to make (love the enchiladas & s'more fudge), as well as free resources.  Ms. Irons has done her homework, and has covered everything from supplements (with warnings!) and mind games that really work!  I would have paid $14.95 for the 100 recipes all under 200 calories alone.  The rest (spa secrets,anti-bloating, dressing thinner,) is an absolute bargain!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2014
reviewComment: Liked it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2001
reviewComment: I would just like to say, to all those other reveiws out there, just because you guys dont agree with the book, you dont have to put Diane Irons down!! You probly just dissagre with it because your jealous of all the skinny people in hollywood. You knew what to expect before picking the book up so stop complaining!!! Anywayyysss, for those gurls out there who want to drop a few quick pounds.....get this book!!its a great book to have on hand just incase your ex-boyfreinds coming to town, or you just want to impress your husband...its great!!

review_title: Read it in a half hour
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2007
reviewComment: I actually kind of like that this book is laid out in "snipets" of information. Most of it you've heard before. Each "dieter" has a completely different approach, so I found it to be confusing. But really all that means is the old "whatever works for you".

review_title: This book offers much more than a diet.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 1998
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book.  It offers many practical suggestions for  healthy eating and weight loss.  While it is not a diet, it offers  inspiration on many levels.  I plan to read  it regularly  to boost my  resolve and renew my commitment to the improvement of my own lifestyle.

review_title: ridiculous! Not worth the paper it is printed on!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2001
reviewComment: Diane, what exactly are you professing? That we all adopt ridiculous "hollywood secrets" to become anorexic in order to be thin? Your tips are dangerous, not sound nutrition and make you look like a snake-oil salesman trying to peddle this junk to the dieters of America.  Really, there needs to be some sort of standard someone must pass before they can put out a diet book, like that you should have had to atleast have been heavy once and used these tips to lose weight.  Those that can't.......teach~! right Diane!?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2001
reviewComment: A dangerous book for almost any woman to read.  The author believes we should all strive to be Elle Mcpherson (who, by the way, must choose between 2 meals a day) or other supermodels and female celebrities who fast for days to lose wieght.  The diet "tip" are hackneyed and there is not one passage about learning to like yourself.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2007
reviewComment: Fairly same information from her previous books that i bought

review_title: a worthy addition to the heritage
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2014
reviewComment: i have been reading, and rereading the sherlock holmes stories since i was 11, and have browsed the pastiches and what have you as well, wishing conan doyle had written more, or more properly, wishing i could return to that world. Horowitz has created a worth addition to that collection. it's not awesomely brilliant, but he has the characters right, i believe, and that makes it worthy of the time and treasure spent to purchase and read it. i wish he would write more!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
reviewComment: My husband and I love Sherlock Holmes novels and this was another great read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2018
reviewComment: A very enjoyable book for fans of Sherlock Holmes. I felt as if Dr. Watson had written this himself.  Highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
reviewComment: A wonderful read for Holmes fans. Everything rings true and remains faithful to the original Holmes stories, yet the author manages to make the story credibly dark and mature for modern readers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2011
reviewComment: After roughly one hundred years the Arthur Conan Doyle Estate has finally sanctioned a new Sherlock Holmes novel. The extraordinary honor of writing this book has been given to Anthony Horowitz, who in turn has created what I believe to be an instant classic that can definitely stand up to Doyle's best work.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2017
reviewComment: I haven’t read a lot of Conan Doyle’s work, but am familiar enough with it to enjoy this Horowitz send up. Great read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2018
reviewComment: All fans will enjoy this. Fans of Holmes and Watson will be happily drawn into a new and unsettling adventure.

review_title: My husband is a Sherlock Holmes fanatic and he loved this book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2017
reviewComment: My husband is a Sherlock Holmes fanatic and he loved this book. He couldn't put it down. He said it was like Sir Arthur Conan Doyle had written it himself. When he finished (in about a day!!), he immediately went out and bought the next one!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2012
reviewComment: this was like going back about 50 years. i loved sherlock holmes when i was young and this book fulfilled all my expectations. the author did an amazing job with style and atmosphere. i'm not sure i could have said conan doyle didn't write it. one strange thing happened while i was reading. some horrendous deed was to be uncovered and i was fascinated to find out what the villains were up to. when i found out i was somewhat disappointed because what they were doing is well known today and there are many films and tv series mentioning the subject. nothing new under the sun. if you like sherlock holmes - highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
reviewComment: Sherlock Holmes fans will not be disappointed with this mystery that he and faithful Watson pursue. Their characters and dialogue evoke Victorian London for the reader just as Conan Doyle did so many years ago.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2015
reviewComment: Gripping story, just the right degree of complexity, terrific, like able characters, and very well written. Couldn't put it down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2013
reviewComment: When a book takes the reader on journey through 3 or 4 decades it can be challenging,  Restless is more of an engrossing puzzle, with spies and intrigue and mystery.  Go ahead give it a read.

review_title: greatest war novels of all time
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2018
reviewComment: Found this book recomended on short list,  greatest war novels of all time. I personally don't think this book fits that category. That said, I read it all the way through. I don't finish books I don't like so 2 stars.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2016
reviewComment: Good Story and worth the money.

review_title: How little we know about anyone
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2013
reviewComment: Main characters in this book are a single mother with a young son and her relationship with her mother.  The daughter fears that her mother is going senile but the mother begins to write the story of her life and hands chapters to the daughter to read.  The unfolding plot is very suspenseful when the mother turns out to be someone that has a huge secret to tell.  A bit of historical fiction, relationship twists, and drama.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
reviewComment: Couldn’t put the book down.  William Boyd weaves a tangled tale of WWII espionage.  A fast read that is highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2013
reviewComment: An intriguing, at times mesmerizing story. It reminds one of the real story of Soviet spy Melita Norwood, outed by defector Vasili Metrokin in the early nineties. Her daughter and family were totally unaware of her espionage role until the truth was revealed when she was in her eighties. Boyd's elderly spy is believable. However, I think the writer missed the mark when trying to write from a female perspective, especially with daughter Ruth. Perhaps the spy's child should have been a boy!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2013
reviewComment: This book was a delightful journey ... I enjoyed it immensely. I rated it 4 stars as I felt that the book ended without final resolution to some questions. But the overall story was a terrific read. I will read more of this author's books.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
reviewComment: Great writing. Page-turner story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2013
reviewComment: I enjoyed this book but didn't love it.  The story was interesting but didn't really grab me, as I like a novel to do.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2014
reviewComment: AAAA

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2014
reviewComment: so much easier to read with the back light

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2014
reviewComment: Perfect condition. Just a described, and since the STWGL is so much better than that recent vintage, happy to have it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2013
reviewComment: I feel bad saying I hate this product because when I first received it I absolutely loved it.  The quality of the GlowLight when used was spectacular, the features where easy to use.  Then tiny "cracks / lines" started to appear in the screen / light which made it difficult to use at first; then as more appeared the device became completely unusable.  This device was not abused in anyway. It was kept in a case, not dropped, etc..  After further searching concerning this problem, it is not uncommon.  A significant number of people reported the same problem even though their care of the device was good.  The most disturbing part of all this is that the manufacturer of the product has known about this problem and to date the item is still being sold with the defect.  I was so disappointed because other than this problem I loved my NOOK Simple Touch with GlowLight.  I now have a Kindle Paperwhite, it is similar to the Nook but just enough difference that except for the defect I like the Nook by a slight margin but not enough to invest in a defective product again.  In addition, there is difference between customer service for both devices. The Nook customer service regarding defects / returns / replacements is poor compared to the good reports of customer service with the Kindle.  Wanted to like the NOOK Simple Touch but couldn't risk it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2014
reviewComment: I have three of nooks and they are great.  Two of them are glolite which is great for reading in the dark

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2014
reviewComment: The price is very good compare to the store. I received the item quickly. The visibility is very good under the sun, I recommand this item.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2014
reviewComment: I absolutely love my Nook.  Perfect size to carry around and holds plenty of books.  Definitely happy with my purchase.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2016
reviewComment: very happy with this Nook....thanks

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2014
reviewComment: Love my nook!

review_title: It does about the bare minimum of what you'd expect
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2014
reviewComment: The screen is very okay.  Not great, not terrible.  The lights are quite visible at the top of the screen, but the text is well lit.  The battery life is impressive, but the interface is clunky and awkward.

review_title: Very enjoyable set of Holmes mysteries
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2011
reviewComment: I downloaded this to have the "real" Kindle edition on my Kindle, though I had already downloaded Gutenberg's free version. (The Gutenberg version has a nice linked Table of Contents at the beginning that clicking "menu" and then "go to" and "table of contents" brings you to -- I'd rather have the easily accessible ToC. To get to the ToC for the Amazon download, you have to page back from the first story or page forward from the cover. It's odd that "go to" does not work for the official Kindle version but does for the Gutenberg mobi download.)

review_title: How could you not like the original!?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2017
reviewComment: This​ book is actually 12 stories featuring Sherlock Holmes and his partner Watson. Narrated from Watson's point of view, he regales us with some of the lesser known, yet still very thrilling, mysteries solved by Sherlock. If you love any of either the movies or the BBC mini series, you will definitely like to this book because they all ring true to this, the original stories of Mr. Holmes and Watson.

review_title: Fun read. Kindle edition is OK except for foreign ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2017
reviewComment: Fun read. Kindle edition is OK except for foreign symbols are messed up (currency, some words). Currency amounts can be an important detail in these stories, so this leaves a bit of a hole in the narrative. And disrupts the flow.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2016
reviewComment: Reading British mysteries is my kind of fun.  Especially the old ones!  Doyle was a master.  Engaging, witty, serious and ever so detailed!

review_title: A great introduction to the world of Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2010
reviewComment: I originally downloaded this collection of short stories in preparation for the Sherlock Holmes major motion picture that was coming out in 2009. As someone who had never read any of Sherlock Holmes' tales, this was a perfect introduction into the kind of stories Sir Arthur Conan Doyle penned for the legendary Holmes and Dr. Watson.

review_title: Sherlock is a wonderfully snarky and dry person counterpointed by Watson's absolute curiosity ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2016
reviewComment: I suggest every one read at least on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's master pieces. Sherlock is a wonderfully snarky and dry person counterpointed by Watson's absolute curiosity and charm. Seriously if you haven't give it a go. The language and pace can be a little drawn out sometimes, but it was written in Victorian tradition. That's what makes it a wonderful read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2011
reviewComment: An excellent selection of Holmes stories! It really was difficult to put down my Kindle while I was reading. This was my first experience with any of the original Holmes stories and I feel quite satisfied to have started here. Fellow fans of Holmes film interpretations will get a real kick out of these original adventures.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2013
reviewComment: Everything you'd expect is in here. Actually I did have some problems with the illustrations, some are cropped wrong so parts of the illustrations is cut off, or at very slightly skewed angles, or with double prints. It might have just been that I had an old style Kindle that couldn't process them, but it was a bit disappointing.  The text and stories are formatted well. The only thing I'd want was some footnotes that explain some archaic terms that pop up on occasion that aren't really in the dictionary, luckily I have a footnoted print version.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2013
reviewComment: You just gotta love Sherlock! It's been many years since I've read this book, so I decided to read it again. It is just as good the second time.

review_title: Sherlock Holmes, the original in a new cover
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2012
reviewComment: Although the stories are public domain, I adored this publication of the well-known Sherlock Holmes stories. I recently began watching the BBC series, Sherlock, and instantly was captivated by it. Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman convincingly and magnificently portrayed Sherlock Holmes and John Watson, respectively, and the writing of the show was equally impressive. Once I had finished season 1, which didn't take long as most Sherlockians know, I turned to the original Sherlock Holmes book series, to bide my time waiting for season 2 to air in America. I downloaded this copy of "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" on to my iPad, only because of the cover. The stories are incredible. Captivating and interesting, I could barely put the book down, unfortunately enough for my grades! At the end of the book, I found I had a better appreciation for the work Moffat and Gatiss put into the new series and for Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's original stories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 31, 2012
reviewComment: I agree totally with the review posted by Ripple.  Whilst the subject matter is worthy, I felt that the characters became rather self-obssessed and this made it a frustrating and slightly nauseating read.  Maybe this is deliberate; making them so divisive as of course the reader feels empathy with the characters for the awful experience of losing a child, and everyone has their own opinion on how they would handle the same situation themselves.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 10, 2012
reviewComment: I took this book with me on my holiday, hoping for a steady and interesting read.  The book was well written I felt, but the characters started to annoy me with their self obsessing and this for me put a damper on the book.  I might have enjoyed reading this more if I had been tucked up in bed with the flu feeling sorry for myself, but otherwise it is just too depressing to enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 21, 2012
reviewComment: This book is a story about a couple who lose their baby after only living for 57 hours.I expected it to be more emotional and read mainly about the emotions and turmoil when going through such a situation. Instead it seems to center mainly on other characters, mainly the couples children,including a child from a previous relationship. It goes back and forth in time and from character to charater. I found it to be very frustrating and hard going I wanted to give up half way through but carried hoping it would eventually focus more on the couple and their feelings and how they delt with their baby`s death but not so. I didnt really enjoy this book at all, sorry.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 14, 2012
reviewComment: What a beautiful, stunning, and amazing book. It deals so amazingly with loss and how it impacts a family. If you like Jodi Picoult or Diane Chamberlain, you'll want to check this one out. It has stayed with me, haunting me, and the story and emotions are sure to keep me thinking for days and weeks to come. Now please write more, beacause I want to read it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2018
reviewComment: Very different but definitely worth reading. What normally happens in the unseen realm, Micah gets to experience in the natural realm. Powerful.  It is for freedom that Christ has set us free! If you are willing, God can use this book to minister to you and change you.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
reviewComment: Made me reexamine how God has led me throughout my whole  life, how I've been led as different paths cane along and how my  life could have been so different if I had taken different rods  away from God.  I am an old lady now and I praise God that He has led me in His ways.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2018
reviewComment: If you like science fission or the unexplainable things that happen. This book would appeal to you. I found it felt very real. As if there could be alternate worlds.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2018
reviewComment: I would recommend this to those who have a complexing relationship with parents, more explicitly a father.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2010
reviewComment: First of all, I must agree with those who are upset about the misleading overview of this book. It appears that the author wanted to lure non-Christian readers into the book with his description. As a fellow Christian, I think we do damage to the reputation of Christ by using a lie to attempt to lure people into a book (or anything else). That approach does not represent the views of Christ nor the views of those who do their best to follow him.

Robert Neville is a brooding alcoholic layman who AFTER the "plague" has to teach himself science and virology between periods of drunken depression, he is NOT a colonel and brilliant scientist with a loving companion German Shepard.

review_title: An excellent novella exploring the theme of isolation.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2014
reviewComment: Richard Matheson's I Am Legend is an excellent story that differs widely from the typical zombie/vampire/apocalypse text. This story follows protagonist Robert Neville who is the survivor of a disease that has killed or mutated everyone else in the world. In addition to mourning his own family, Robert is tormented by the 'undead' who call to him from outside his barricaded house every night. What makes this book so interesting is that it explores the human side to Robert, his isolation, his longing for companionship, and his fight to avoid becoming mad. It also depicts Robert's level of knowledge and intelligence in a realistic way. Robert is not a scientist, but is able to gain a strong base of knowledge about the disease by his own research from the public library. I enjoyed this book because of the excellent depiction of Robert as the protagonist. This book was easy to read and enjoyable, and I would reccomend it to anyone who enjoys 'disaster' type stories, and also people who are interested in the psychology underlying isolation.

Even the ponderous Victorian explanations are in keeping with the original and though the ending was a wee bit too predictable, the overall story was fast-paced and reliable. Recommended for all the readers who have (regretably) memorized the original stories and in need of a further fix.

reviewComment: A well written and enjoyable Holmes adventure.  Was a little skeptical at first that he could capture the spirit & tone of Doyle, but Horowitz does just that.  For those who grew up loving these tales, as I did, I highly recommend it.

review_title: Is this the final Sherlock Holmes mystery?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2015
reviewComment: This is truly an excellent effort by the author to write a story that passes for Arthur Conan Doyle writing Sherlock Holmes.  There are a few times in the story where the syntax is a little more contemporary than ACD would have used, but all in all, the illusion is very well done, and the book draws the reader completely into London of the 1890's.  The story is more shocking in its content and premise than any other Sherlock Holmes mystery, and the ending chapter brings it all together so neatly, and with a bang, that the reader can only marvel at the construction of the novel.  Instead of a single story, there are two intertwining story lines here running parallel paths that intersect in the last third especially.  The good vs. evil features prominently as in all Holmes mysteries, but the story will leave you shaking your head at the final intersection, and I found myself wondering if Anthony Horowitz had any intentions of writing more about Sherlock Holmes.  If he did (or does) I will be in line for the next installment - well done indeed!  I understand that the ACD estate has found this story alone worthy of their endorsement, and it is easy to see why.  IMO if you liked Conan Doyles' Sherlock Holmes you are quite likely to like this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
reviewComment: This book would be a great resource for both a primary school teacher and a children's librarian. The introductory pages remind the reader of the value of read alouds as well as secrets to successful read aloud sessions.  The author then provides 101 read aloud experiences to be used in a classroom or even a library. Each includes the cover of the book with title, author and publication date (these are all books from 2009-2017); then there are questions for before, during and after reading the story.  The only reason for a missing star is the author did not include classics; I hope she writes another volume that includes them.

reviewComment: A plague has wiped out humanity and left vampiric creatures in its wake.  Robert Neville, a former factory worker, is the sole surviving human being as far as he knows.  He spends each night barricaded in his home with vampires outside his door calling for him to come out.  During the day, he fortifies his home, kills vampires, and even researches the cause of the plague.
