reviewComment: I read this and I am pretty sure I read it over 20 years ago. So much going on in a 100 page book. While not a huge monster story fan, the way science, horror, and apocalypse are blended together, makes this a must read.

review_title: Better than the movie reviews I've seen
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2008
reviewComment: It's funny that our hero is blond and blue eyed while the movie has a black man.  Really good story though.  I hesitated to read it because I'm not into zombies or vampires but this was surprisingly good and not what I expected.  A good story of survival.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2016
reviewComment: I have been obsessed with the plot line from I Am Legend ever since the movie came out staring Will Smith. The only problem I had with the movie, was that you sat through 3 hours worth of movie, you still didn't really know anything about the main character. It was flat, he wasn't developed and you didn't have the chance to emotionally connect with him. The book is amazing and fills in all the gaps that the movie may have left you wondering about. Richard Matheson is a creative genius.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2013
reviewComment: First off, if you saw the movie... forget everything.  The movie was changed so much from the book.  I saw the movie first and was shocked how different the book was... and I mean completely different.  The book tells about Robert Neville and how he survived the 'virus'.  It tells about how he lost his family, but the entire book is just him.  Except for at night when the vampires try to get in.  In  the end, he gets a visitor who he goes with.  He eventually learns that the vampires are adapting and are able to be out in the sun for periods of time.

review_title: The story is little better than pulp fiction, but it started two whole genres of horror-fiction.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
reviewComment: Before there was a Zombiepocalypse, there were vampires.  It is interesting that this book spawned three different movies (four if you count Night of the Living Dead).  The story is little better than pulp fiction, but it started two whole genres of horror-fiction.  I guess that says a great deal by itself.  It is worth reading for its importance as the genesis of both vampire/ghoul/zombie apocalypse and lone plague survivor style fictions.  If literature is defined by what it inspires, than this is it.

review_title: I read this once as a kid.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2014
reviewComment: It is the same book I remembered. It is a dark tale of the end of the human race, as we know it. A bioengineered virus has gotten loose in the world and all of mankind has succumbed. The protagonist is the only human he knows of that is still alive. And, he is under siege. The virus has transformed the population into vampires, and they are anxious for him to join them. The story is told from the protagonist's POV, and delineates his transformation from survivor to monster. Rereading this book as an adult changed my perspective on some of the events in the book. It was a great pleasure reading it again.

review_title: Do yourself a favor and read this classic
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2008
reviewComment: WOW!!! I saw the movie and was intrigued to read the original novel and i'm glad I did. The authot does an amazing job of putting you inside the mind of a man who has literally been alone for months. As cheesey and over-done as the whole vampire genre is, for a book that was written in 1954, Matheson added a new perspective to the classic myth by scientifically explaining what and how vampires come to be. The book is action-packed like the movie yet is very different in events that take place; for example, in the movie Robert had the dog from the beginning of the movie whereas in the book he finds the dog walking around the neighborhood one day. The ending is also amazing! Very surprising and totally different from the movie. In the movie he's called a legend because he discovers the vaccine for vampirism........in the book he's called a legend for a completely different reason!

review_title: I Am Legend is a Good Read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2007
reviewComment: I really liked the book.  It is a quick and entertaining read - especially for being written in 1954. I'm not really in to vampires, but this isn't about vampires. It's about a man who is the last man on earth and he's trying to deal with being alone, and trying to figure out what has happened to the rest of his race. I'd recommend this to anyone looking for some light summertime reading

review_title: Easy reading.Stiil like the interconnection between the Irish and Italian mobs.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019
reviewComment: Not as good as Kelly’s first book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
reviewComment: A great read. A well-told, interesting character driven book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2018
reviewComment: I bought this novel under the name " Payback " and liked it. They changed the  novel's name and artwork and sold it to me again!  Total rip off!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2012
reviewComment: I couldn't put this book down once I began it.  The story brings real life experiences and action to the reader in a most prolific way. The characters and what it is like to be a sandhog (tunnel worker) are described so clearly you feel you are working along side of them.  I have also read the author's two other novels in hard cover and they were just as wonderful.  Hope I can get them for my e-reader soon.  You won't be disappointed, this is a great writer.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2012
reviewComment: I found the book to be very entertaining and it was never dull. The characters were well thought out and the plot twists were great. Having read this book, I ordered "The Rackets" and "Empire Rising" from the same author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2014
reviewComment: Did not know this was Kelly's first novel apparently rewritten to a certain extent and republished.  As such, it does not measure up to his next two novels in this genre which I liked very much. Hope his next effort is as good as his last two.

review_title: This is a reprint of Payback
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2009
reviewComment: This is a great book, but it is a reprint of Payback. Unfortunately Amazon neglected to mention that fact before I bought it. Thanks Amazon for the lack of transparency.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2019
reviewComment: Horowitz carries on the Holmes tradition in his own style of clever wit and rapid pace.  Can’t help but visualize Cumberbatch and Freeman in the roles.  But the language is reminiscent of the period, and the book an overall joy to read.  Bravo Mr. Horowitz!

review_title: Horowitz does his normal and gives us a big surprise at the end.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
reviewComment: This is Doyle+.  It's like he (Doyle) was paying good attention to what he was writing.  So, it is also a Holmes+.  If you like Sherlock you most likely will love this book.  I did.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2017
reviewComment: The author successfully writes in the style of Arthur Conan Doyle.  The story had many twists and turns and a surprising ending.  It was a well done update of the original.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2018
reviewComment: Honestly  thought it would be more like a real Holmes. It was an ok read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2014
reviewComment: Horowitz has captured the writing style of Doyle, and takes you back to Victorian London.  You can all but sense the gas lamps and horse drawn conveyances of the era.  This is the strength of the novel.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2017
reviewComment: Good read!  I am glad to read someone who will try to write about Sherlock.  Not Sir Arthur Conan Doyle ,but good try.

review_title: well written, if dated and obvious. hard to really bring Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2018
reviewComment: into 21 century. Book tries,succeeds as best one can. In a way it’s a little too fake21 century in the old clothes o& the 19.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
reviewComment: So similar in style to the original Sherlock Homes stories, but even better. The plot was  intriguing, and well carried out. Characters were well developed.  The House of Silk has a fullness to it that was often lacking in the canonical stories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2015
reviewComment: Delightfully well written and a more than satisfactory substitute for Mr. Doyle. For those of us who simply cannot get enough of Sherlock Holmes this novel definitely fits the bill. It fills the imagination and takes you into the dark places of human nature. Well done Mr. Horowitz, a thoroughly good read.

review_title: Enemy of the State meets Downey's Sherlock Holmes for a less-than-inspiring story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2015
reviewComment: This. Is not Sherlock Holmes of Conan Doyle.

review_title: Excellent narration of a WW II spy story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2015
reviewComment: Excellent narration of a WW II spy story. The story line is always taut. The details are authentic. One of the best WW II spy novels.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2020
reviewComment: The book keeps the suspense from the beginning and develops it without pause.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2013
reviewComment: It lived up to it's hype.  The characters so well defined and plenty of surprises and twists and turns.  A reminder that we can never truly "know" another person even someone as close as a parent.  We cannot walk in anyone else's shoes.  An imperative to be very careful of how we judge others!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2013
reviewComment: Excellent plot, writing and characters. Interwoven plot through two distinct time periods with lots of twists and turns and forward movement. I discovered a new writer that I like, a real find.

review_title: I enjoyed this book because it has
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
reviewComment: A gripping story with a different slant on WW2. Interesting characters. Very honest descriptions of people and their successes and failures

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2013
reviewComment: This book had the potential to be very good but ultimately didn't live up to it.  Both female leads - mother & daughter - were affected and cold - it was hard to like/empathise with them.  Too many pointless characters in the daughter's story.  Liked the style of writing and the ending - which gave a good sense of the life of a spy

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2015
reviewComment: Well written, my first William Boyd novel....won't be the last.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2013
reviewComment: I've loved William Boyd ever since I saw the Masterpiece Theatre production of 'Any Human Heart." He has never let me down, and IMHO does not get the accolades he deserves.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
reviewComment: The book is always better than the video version.  This one doesn't disappoint.  I enjoyed both versions.

reviewComment: love it.

reviewComment: Excellent !!!!!!

reviewComment: love it

reviewComment: I Love my nook simple touch with glowlight. It is easy to use and have enough light to see in dim light.  I ave no problem with wifi and can shop with ease.I recommended to all my friends.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2013
reviewComment: After taking a Nexus 7 and an Ipad to the beach and failing to be able to read a book (dammit),  I bought the nook.  Using it in bright sunlight, and be able to read in the dark is Awesome!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2013
reviewComment: Too many eReaders are trying to force us into tablets, but the Simple Touch is a great reader without having to pay for a full fledged tablet. The eInk screen is easy to read, even in direct sunlight, and the backlight makes reading in bed very easy. It also has a great battery life, even with the GlowLight.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2013
reviewComment: Purchased two Nooks with Glowlights.  They arrived very promptly.  One was in perfect condition.  The other had a tear under the screen.  The Seller was very cooperative in offering a refund or replacement.  We elected to replace it.  The replacement was in perfect condition.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2014
reviewComment: The Barnes and Noble Nook is so easy to use. Its lightweight and compact. Reading made fun and easy! Would recommend to friends and family.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2014
reviewComment: wanted it to used the glowlight and other electronic connections

review_title: A read-aloud treasure chest of powerful ideas
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
reviewComment: I fell in love with Maria Walther's book the first time I read it at the annual NCTE Conference and I continue to share it with teachers everywhere. Over the years, read-aloud has been slowly reduced to a scripted basal reading process with controlled questions and step by step recipes. Maria shares her thinking for read-aloud with just two pages of flexible suggestions that read more like "possibilities" than a plan. Her open-ended recommendations do what no program could ever do - celebrate the role of professional decision-making by inviting teachers to the read-aloud process. I am so grateful for that refreshing view!

review_title: Sets the gold standard on best practices on reading aloud
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2018
reviewComment: If you’re in a position where you read aloud to children this book is the gold standard on learning how to do it best.  Teachers, library volunteers, parents can all be better at a task that can get confusing.  This book takes 101 actual and current picture books and leads you through the process of how to tackle the experience that will make it a good experience for both the reader and the listener.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2019
reviewComment: This is a teaching resource that is good not only for primary grades but can be useful in upper grades.  Puts some punch back into read aloud time. (One of my favorite parts of the day!)  Nice comprehensive approach for building enjoyment,  community, comprehension, book discussions, foundational skills and cross-over  writing connections.  Margins are conveniently organized to provide key words, target skills, specific book synopses. Has photos and graphics that make things very clear. Addresses many books I have not used (will need to visit a few libraries) but after  reading and using for a short time you will be able to apply to approaches to any of your favorite read alouds.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018
reviewComment: Love this book.  So many great suggestions for making curriculum connections to current read alouds.  Inferencing, point of view, opinions, compare and contrast, parts of speech, and so much more.  Students love a read aloud.  Unfortunately, teachers are forced to make everything curriculum.  This book is the key. Highly recommed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
reviewComment: This book is a wonderful resource for teachers who realize that reading aloud is an art and who want to get the most out of doing read alouds with their classes.  Whether you are a new or a veteran teacher, this book gives you lots of ideas for different ways to make the read aloud come alive for your students. I highly recommend it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2018
reviewComment: This is so excellent as a text, mostly in content but also in presentation. I’m amazed by this book, the ease of use and the aesthetic. It strengthens my teaching more than any other read-aloud info has.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018
reviewComment: Great resource for teachers, but also parents. Easy layout and good reference guide.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2020
reviewComment: Love the way this book laid out.  Very easy to understand, relevant and current book titles.  Best book I have purchased for my elementary school library lessons!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on September 1, 2018
reviewComment: Maria's encyclopedic knowledge of quality children's literature paired with her deep understanding of effective literacy instruction come together in this book to create an invaluable resource for K-3 teachers.  Maria guides teachers in choosing diverse, engaging books to read aloud to students then lays out for them how these books can be used to support important literacy skill development.  Not only did I learn of new children's literature titles by reading the book but I also came across some strategies that were new to me to implement with my students.  I am excited to use both the books and the strategies with my students all in the hopes of developing strong literacy learners who love books!

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on November 10, 2019
reviewComment: Colourful. Packed with ideas for new language learning.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2019
reviewComment: This audio book is ok, the narrator is rather bland

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2013
reviewComment: If you like Sherlock Holmes the movie or television show then cast your eyes upon Sir Arthur Conan Doyle original masterpiece with this read.  Engage your mind in the Adventures of Sherlock Holmes the way Sir Arthur created and compare with today's version .  You will find both young and older readers whether reading for the first time or many times over you will be swept up in the adventures and not want to put it down.  A classic.

review_title: Sherlock Holmes is always a treat.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
reviewComment: I enjoy re-reading the Sherlock stories over and over again. Alway enjoyable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2014
reviewComment: This is where forensic science all started.  Sherlock has to smell, feel, hear, observe, and even taste, sometimes, to uncover details that were overlooked at crime scenes at the time the book was written.  The book is very engaging, and even though it is a series of adventures that don't require having read previous tales to understand, you will still not want to put the book down until you have helped Sherlock Holmes solve all the crimes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2017
reviewComment: I so liked this book, I would be thrilled to read the Sherlock Holmes stories every day, over and over.  This is probably true because I was enthralled with them in my childhood, many, many years ago.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2012
reviewComment: A collection of 12 stories as it was originally published by Strand Magazine, this new publication by Top Five Classic of "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (Illustrated) includes the original accompanying illustrations by Sidney Paget.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2013
reviewComment: Like a lot of people, I came to Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock stories from the other adaptations of the character. Sherlock Holmes in the 22nd century, The Great Mouse Detective, the BBCs recent Sherlock series, etc.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2011
reviewComment: This is a fairly engaging classic read, and would be worth your while to download, especially as it is free. Given the mediocre (or, in some cases, even less than mediocre) free downloadables that Amazon has granted virtual publication through its site, reading this one would give your tortured minds a rest as you follow the genius of crime-solving Sherlock Holmes and his faithful companion, Dr. Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2014
reviewComment: He never lived but he is one of the most recognized ' persons' on the planet.  The power of the written word.  I believe that 221B Baker Street in London is a tourist attraction.  Check it out .  Sir Arthur Conan Doyle- his creator- is said to be by some --the father of modern forensic medicine.  My grankids- from the youngest to the teens enjoy watching his movies- even in black and white!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2012
reviewComment: I really enjoyed reading Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's works in this short collection of Sherlock Holmes stories. It was entertaining and interesting to read. These works and Sherlock Holmes are classics always to be remembered.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2014
reviewComment: I can't say enough about how great this book was.  I've read it three times now!  I first saw the movie (which I've seen over 10 times now) and then read the book.  This is rare, but I obviously loved both, even though the movie is quite different from the book.  In many ways, the book was much "scarier."  I won't go into details about the differences because they are probably not relevant, but it's such a great surprise when both the book and the movie are both great.

review_title: Very different and much better than the movie.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2019
reviewComment: I bought this for a horror book club and it didn't disappoint. If you're looking for a repeat of the movie, you won't find it. The book is different and much better.

review_title: i am legend is good, short stories not so good
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2007
reviewComment: first, let me say i had this book before i even knew they were making a movie out of it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2008
reviewComment: I enjoy "end time(s)" stories and this is a particularly good one written in 1954 by Richard Matheson.  I have seen the movie "I Am Legend" (2007) and an earlier movie version of Matheson's story, "The Omega Man", starring Charlton Heston (1971).  I think I prefer the written word, in this case, to either of the Hollywood renditions.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2008
reviewComment: I bought the book because of the movie. I thought it might have extra detail into the depth of the character Robert Neville, a character I really I liked. However, while the book is quite good as literature, it is quite different from the movie; a fact I knew but I just did not know how different. In the book, our Robert is not a scientist or in the Army and the true origin of the vampire-creating disease is not given. He does however try to figure out as best he can what has happened. He also grapples with his loneliness and the human side of being alone, more so than in the movie. In the book he is not accompanied by a his trusting dog Sam. Robert Neville is essentially not the same as in the movie; which is fine because that was the way the movie makers wanted it. So even though the movie is based on the book, you have to look at each work different, and don't judge one by the other. With the version of the book I received there were also some short stories by the author which I did not expect. I liked the book and it was/is good but I preferred the movie. After you read and see you might think different.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
reviewComment: The story is well-written and engaging. I got the book used and it smells like an old library. I don't think that deserves lowering the rating.

review_title: Better than it could have been, not as good as I'd hoped.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2020
reviewComment: I watched a video of the five scariest books, this was on the list. I thought with three movies based on this one book it would be fantastic, something to keep me up at night. It wasn't. Instead it put me to sleep.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2014
reviewComment: Good story- but there isn't a mention on the book cover or on this page, at least at a quick glance, that mentions only half this book is the actual 'I Am Legend' story. I mean I saw a table of contents but I just assumed that they were the chapter titles or something and just passed over it. It's around 170 pages long.. which is very disappointing because right when the action starts to pick up 'midway' in the book (which I thought was the entire story), it's over.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2014
reviewComment: Setting a meticulously woven stage enhanced by cautious expectation, Richard Matheson manages to encompass claustrophobia in a way that I have not yet experienced in another novel.  He is able to create rivalry between survival of the body and survival of the spirit.  This story is beautifully constructed for those who are seeking entertainment deeper than the obligatory thrills and chills of a typical horror story.  However, within I Am Legend, you will absolutely find action packed moments that will keep you greedily turning page after page.  Matheson with his main character, Neville, has penned a severely sentimental, post-apocalyptic, horror-romance-nightmare.  A classic and a must read.

review_title: As someone who reads nearly EVERY vampire novel that comes along...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2006
reviewComment: That person wouldn't be me but happens to be my husband. He has a thing for vampire novels and vampire films. So I've heard and seen and read quite a lot about vampires, if only by default, not being nearly as obsessed as he is..at first. Then he got me hooked on Buffy The Vampire Slayer (tv show) and that's when I knew I was getting interested in the vampire thing, the pain of remembering what it was like to be human after crossing into the world of immortality, with its own set of pains.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2018
reviewComment: This is an unusual story about a man living two different lives..  One desiring to live surrendered to  God the other wanting to hold onto his worldly possessions.  Very interesting the way it unfo!ds!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2010
reviewComment: When I was in Jr. High my Sunday school class decided to study the book of "Job". Up until this point I had never done any extensive studying of a particular book, just stand alone versus, so the fact that I shook with the anticipation of learning what would happen next (to this poor soul - as I liked to refer to him at the time) floored me. Over the years I have continued to study the bible, reading scripture and trying (sometimes is vain) to make it make sense to me. Sometimes I fail horribly, while other times the message I read sparks like a lightning bolt to my brain, I get it instantly. Now, after all these years one fact remains... I remember the book of "Job" more than any other book I have ever read. Why am I telling you all of this you may ask? Because "Job" has just come back to life in James L Rubarts' novel "Rooms"

review_title: You never know how life can change with one decision!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2020
reviewComment: A thought provoking story with twists and turns you don't see coming! Ingeniously and well written!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020
reviewComment: This book is the story of self-discovery as a man must weigh his life against his heart. It is a search for God.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2018
reviewComment: The rooms of our lives. Each one showing us what was, what is and what could be. The choices we have to make about giving our lives over to God. Amazing book makes you think really hard about your life.

review_title: 5 Star -- Magnificent - Hold your Breath - CF Fiction Novel !!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2010
reviewComment: I waited a few days before I started reading

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2010
reviewComment: I won't take the time to rewrite the book summary as others have--I just want to commend the author of this book! Thank you for a thought provoking, insightful read! While the main story line in this book is a simple, successful man looks back on his life and losses, the underlying philosophical story is well worth the purchase price and investment of your time to read. Although my title marries Pilgrim's Progress and the Shack, this book is relaly not exactly like either one...at first glance...but entrenched within its pages is a deeply spiritual story line that will challenge and inspire all of us. Highly recommended!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2010
reviewComment: First let me say I am not sure why so many people are saying they were duped into reading this book. If you read the product descrition it clearly talks about the house being spiritual, that Micah's faith had slipped away, and that "the home isn't just spiritual, it's a physical manifestation of his soul, which God uses to heal Micah's darkest wounds and lead him into an astonishing new destiny."

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2018
reviewComment: I loved this book. The premise is unique and interesting. I couldn't put the book down. When I was finished I realized it had given me pause as to my relationship with God. It's a very encouraging read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2011

reviewComment: I bought it for a good friend. She loved it and said it was the only one her school would let her use to get school books.  It will save her a lot of money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2016
reviewComment: I liked it. It did have some bad reviews but the story was good, the characters were real and the writing easy to follow.  I will read his next Sherlock Holmes novel.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2018

Its fast pace, the relatable character, the atmosphere that made me dive in and not get up until I finished this intelligently builded world of fiction. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2000
reviewComment: Words cannot express how I enjoy this book, but I will certainly try. I have hunted for this book for years, ever since I saw the movie "The Last Man on Earth" with Vincent Price. And when I finally found it, I  wasn't disappointed. The book was better than the movie (of course)!  Matheson draws you in with the haunting idea of the last man on earth in a  world of vampires. Even though he attempts to discover the cause of the  plague, many things are left unanswered, which only adds to the horror. I  have read this book more times than I can count, and almost always in one  sitting. As an aspiring author, Matheson has inspired me. I hope I can  write a tale that will haunt readers as this one has me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2015
reviewComment: Despite it's deliberate slow pacing this is one of the most chilling novels of the 20th Century.  Written in 1954 by Richard Matheson "I Am Legend" takes a close look at what it means to be human and what it takes to become inhuman.  Robert Neville is the last man on Earth, but he is not alone!  The rest of the human race has died, victims of a mysterious plague that has infected everyone and has a 99% fatality rate.  The problem is, the dead won't stay dead!  Urban legends of The Undead, Vampires, have been with us for centuries, is it possible that these legends have a basis in scientific fact? Matheson explores that possibility from the viewpoint of one man, while also delving into that man's troubled mind.  Beyond the mundane problem of just staying alive; getting enough food, water and shelter, there is the very real problem of being totally alone.  Alone, with his dark thoughts, fighting alcoholism, painful memories of his past life and how his wife died, twice, all combine to threaten his sanity and his life. But there are external threats to his life as well.  The Undead, hungry for Neville's living flesh and blood, surround his fortified house each night where they fight among themselves and seek access to his home.  During the day things are reversed.  Unlike the Undead, Neville can come out in the sunlight and is free to roam the city looking for the sleeping Undead and to drive wooden stakes through their hearts.  But even as he wages his pointless war against the Vampires, Neville realizes that his vendetta can't go on forever, he must find another way.  Questions fill his mind.  Why are the Vampires repulsed by things like garlic and the Holy Cross?  What is it about the sun light that burns their flesh?  If this is a plague then there must be a cure, someway to save what is left of humanity, if there is any humanity left to save.  Dark, brooding and, at times, depressing "I Am Legend" is a true classic of Horror Fiction.  Richard Matheson's low key prose dominated the Speculative Fiction field from the mid 20th century to the early 21st century.  Weather it was a shrinking man, a terrified airline passenger at 20,000 feet or a lonely traveling salesman being stalked by a psychotic trucker, this author excelled at placing ordinary men into extraordinary situations.  "I Am Legend" is such a novel and Hollywood was quick to see it's potential with three different films: The Last Man on Earth 1964, The Omega Man 1971 and I Am Legend 2007.  While all three were faithful to the original story, each one deviated from the novel in its own special way to create a unique take on the "Last Man" scenario.  In the novel, as well as the screenplays, I wondered why the central character did not just pack up and leave the city, seek out an isolated place in whatever wilderness there was and find some measure of peace.  Neville himself had no answer for that question, but maybe you will.  I first read this in my early teens, so reading it now is like revisiting an old friend, but I wonder how modern readers will take to it.  In this day of high-action entertainment like "The Walking Dead" some readers might get impatient with "I Am Legend's" low-key approach but, I think, if they give it a fair chance they may find it to be an important look at the human phyche and what happens when things go terribly wrong.  I had no technical or formatting problems with this Kindle edition.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2013
reviewComment: James Rubart is one of my new favorite authors. I would compare him to Ted Dekker, but he has his own stand-alone style.  I couldn't put Rooms down until it was finished.  It drew me in and never let go.  Such a brilliant story-telling of choosing who and what you will devote your life to... Helped me to see the stark contrasts in choosing Jesus.  It also shows how cleverly deceptive Satan is in trying to get us to follow him without knowing that is what we are doing.  I cannot wait to read all of James Rubart's books!

reviewComment: Rooms was fast paced, thought-provoking, and soul-awakening.  I loved it every step of the way. review_title: Sir Arthur Canon Doyle;  a fluid and renowned writer
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2012
reviewComment: Being neither a reader of Canon Doyle's nor a particular fan of mystery novels, I felt it was time to delve into both.  This collection of short stories exhibited to me that the author truly has a commendable ability to tell an easily understood and very fluid tale.  His exposition is linear and does not rely on flashbacks or forward projections and his utilization of Watson through 1st person singular is unique.  While I still remain less than enamored by mystery tales, I can understand why he is a long-standing favorite of the reading public.

review_title: Mixed Reaction of The House of Silk
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2018
reviewComment: I loved Mr. Horowitz's screenplays for Foyle's War & with the high ratings this novel has been receiving, I thought I'd give this story a try. The House of Silk is among the better written Sherlock Holmes pastiches and it has its moments of adventure and danger, but overall I'd say this was a so-so story.  The beginning of the tale and the moment Holmes finds himself in trouble through to the conclusion of the story was a page turner, but everything in between was slow going and dull.  In addition, I found the inclusion of Mycroft to be something of an unnecessary contrivance as it added nothing to the story and served as an injustice of Mycroft's considerable intellect and influence.  In one of ACD's stories, Mycroft was described as "the British government," but in this story Mycroft was portrayed as fearful & ineffectual, serving only to warn Holmes against his intended actions. Finally,  in the beginning of the story,  Holmes asks a question if Catherine Carstairs can swim at the end of his interview with the Carstairs household which indicated that Holmes already  deduced that Catherine was involved with the burglary and murder. . One has to wonder why he did not address his suspicions immediately other than it might have ended the story right there before Holmes & Watson find themselves embroiled in the House of Silk affair.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2016
reviewComment: My father first told me about this book (and a little bit about how it ended) after I had seen the Will Smith adaptation as well as the Omega Man. I enjoyed both the movies but I was curious how the book played out and I have to say that the book was much more interesting. What's awesome about this book is that the character of Robert Neville feels very authentic. He's just a normal guy, not some action hero or hot shot scientist looking for a cure ... Just a normal guy trying to survive. It's easy to understand why he does what he does and likewise its easy to understand why the vampires do what they do. The end of this book was a very fitting end and one that I am kind of disappointed they didn't transition the the film. I highly recommended this book to anyone who likes vampire stories or stories of survival.

The movie was definitely an alternate version of this story, but this story is far better. The writing is engaging and thought provoking. I'm not saying it's a philosophical masterpiece, but it's definitely one of my favorite vampire books (a list which does not include Twilight). It's a good, short read and I highly recommend it.

review_title: Classic Book, Finally Understand the Title!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2012
reviewComment: I Am legend is a classic science fiction/horror novel written in 1954 by Richard Matheson.  It is a story written in a post-apocalyptic setting.  The hero is what appears to be a lone survivor of the disaster and is having to deal with the results thereof.  I have read that this book has served as inspiration to many of the zombie books and movies from just after it was written through the modern era.  While I'm sure that many will have seen the Will Smith movie version of this book, please do not expect the book to be precisely like the movie.

review_title: it is a wonderful story using mystery and fantasy
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2014
reviewComment: Recently I have been reading George MacDonald, an author that inspired both Tolkien and Lewis.  Rubart is in the same tradition.  It is certainly even explicitly Christian than some of Tolkien or Lewis.  Nonetheless, it is a wonderful story using mystery and fantasy.  His ability to build suspense is some of the best I've read particularly in this genre.  In fact, I don't read that much new fiction generally but this author is getting me back.  I highly recommend it.

Seems through out the book every time a unit of measure is used (such as the lb sterling symbol) the translator screwed up and just stuck in a bunch of symbols. Shortly after arriving, the Japanese invade Burma and the action begins. This writer, writes to any age and I found the story fascinating and adventurous.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2014
reviewComment: Elephant Run was an exceptionally good book to read. Some parts were emotional, however others were confusing, because the dialogue didn’t contain enough detail about the cultural traditions. This story gives details of a Burmese person’s life, including the Mahouts, and other engaging Burmese cultural traditions. I enjoyed learning about the characters as they matured, and understanding the multiple perspectives of WWII. As a result of the war, the lines blurred between protagonists and antagonists. Even though this book is confusing, we liked it because it has a great ending, and can teach several lessons.

I think this book must have played a key role in the development of Justin Cronin's "The Passage", in fact I found the similarities striking; so if you enjoyed "The Passage" and are looking forward to Cronin's next book "The Twelve", you will like this.  It is a quick read, and well worth the time!

review_title: who's perfect for the main character in many ways
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
reviewComment: Can't believe it took me this many years--make that decades--to finally get around to absorbing Matheson's quick-read mid-century masterpiece. In the realm of post-apocalyptic fiction, if any work deserves to be described as seminal, this is it. Its influence is clearly evident to this day in everything from "The Walking Dead" (particularly in the early-going, where a certain character's late wife comes back to haunt him from beyond the grave) to much of dystopian fiction. Never mind that it's been made into a movie no less than three times (1964's "The Last Man on Earth" starring the oddly cast Vincent Price--a messy cheapie that's worth a look as the most faithful adaptation of the book and for its own influence on Romero's "Night of the Living Dead"; 1971's memorable "The Omega Man," starring Charlton Heston in his post "Planet of the Apes" dystopian sci-fi martyr phase [see also: "Soylent Green"], who's perfect for the main character in many ways, though the film is drastically reconceived from the source material and frequently has the aesthetics of a made-for-TV movie, and most recently the years-in-production 2007 Will Smith version that retained the title, if little of the f flavor, though there were at least hints that some involved in the production had read the book). This is a book that earns its classic status for multiple reasons. While the Heston and Smith movies have always leaned into the apocalyptic action and away from the primal horror, Matheson crafts a sci-fi nightmare that would be better served by a mid-budget indie drama vibe than a mega-budget thrill-ride.

review_title: Enjoyed the movies, wanted to read the book.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2013
reviewComment: I saw the movie "Omega Man" (based loosely on this book, "I Am Legend") in the 70's and, a couple years ago, the saw movie "I Am Legend" starring Will Smith.  I enjoyed both movies -- and now I have enjoyed the classic that inspired them as well.  The movies and the book are somewhat similar to each other (and somewhat different as well).  But if you enjoyed either of the movies, you should enjoy this book as well.  A key aspect of both movie and book is the psychological impact of sustained personal isolation (i.e., the lone survivor is not chased by zombies/vampires every night).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2014
reviewComment: This book drew me in from the beginning. I felt like I knew all the characters personally. The flow of the story was spot on every time. Mystery and Suspense around every corner. It was not what I expected at all. I never thought that you could write christian fiction in this manner. Great Job Mr. Rubart for your amazing style of writing. I look forward to reading more from this author. This book is a must read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2010
reviewComment: I have to say this is one of the best books I have read in ages! It was gripping, thrilling and moving beyond my wildest dreams. I am amazed at the depth of the story, the imagery, and the overall ride on which it took me. I don't think I could ever come up with the appropriate words to express the depths that this book touched in my soul. I love the way in which the author touched on the subject of angels and their roles in our lives and their place in the divine ordinance of things. The way in which God has complete and utter control over our lives is stunningly shown in this book and also the complete joy that can come when we give everything over to Him who is perfect. I think that if you need some answers, if you are unsure, or even if you already believe, that this is an amazing book for you. I would start here and follow up with a good bible study. I am more and more intrigued by the storyline and intend to follow up with a bible study of my own, based on the book. I can't wait to see what the Word has to say about some of the themes in here, and I have to admit it has opened my heart up more than it has been in a long time. To the author I can only say thank you, and thank you Lord for inspiring this work!

review_title: A Novel of. Healing and Love
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2016
reviewComment: I enjoyed this book so much that I couldn't put it down.  What a great story of faith, growing,  Healing,, forgiving and love and believing in God. I really enjoyed the Bible verses and references of searching the solutions in your life that produces healing and getting closer to God. I will read more of his books.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2018
reviewComment: This book totally blew me away.  It's an intense journey from one life to another.  I couldn't put it down as it's unlike any Christian novel I've read before.

review_title: This book leaves me meditating on God s great love that pursues us through any means possible
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2017
reviewComment: This book leaves me meditating on God s great love that pursues us through any means possible.  I loved the symbolism of rooms left ready for us to enter but choices that need to be made and the choice to surrender everything that leads to the main character s redemption!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2018
reviewComment: A fascinating tale of a man’s adventures and struggles that paints a grand picture of “what does it profit a man to gain the whole world but forfeit his soul”

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
reviewComment: Chrissy a Shih Tzu maybe small, yet protective of her master, now dead. Detective goes and gets his partner out of the car,Ace a German Shepherd who takes over and gets Chrissy to move,.Detective Reed would like to keep her, and it was pulling on his heartstrings. He arranges for a no kill shelter for her to go to. Autumn needed to open herself to love again,and heads out to adopt one small dog. As she looked at the dogs the desperation in their bark reminded her of the fatal accident. One look at. Chrissy dark sad eyes and knew she’d be going home with her, The newspaper tells the story and the dog being the only witness it seems. Autumn decides to look into and crosses the path of the Detective. A very different type of plot, and very well done intriguing on how the clues with  Chrissy  came about. Will look for more by her,.

review_title: Adorable first book in new series
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2018
reviewComment: Chrissy is the most unusual cozy mystery character I have ever had the pleasure to meet in a book--she has an amazing talent which aids her new owner, Autumn, in solving the murder of her former owner, attorney Gary Martin.

review_title: This book has something for everyone
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
reviewComment: If you do not fall in love with Chrissy the Shih Tzu, you can not call yourself a dog lover.

review_title: I'm a sucker for a good dog book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2018
reviewComment: Generally, I like to read hardboiled thrillers. But, when a good author places a dog on center stage, I can't resist. Attorney-at-Paw: A Chrissy the Shih Tzu Mystery is a fun read. I thoroughly enjoyed it. But, what can I say? Who wouldn't like Chrissy?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
reviewComment: Animal detectives are a fairly recent subgenre, and it is somehow odd that so many different and pleasing books turn up one after another. Chrissy is a delight, with her two and four legged friends. Her unusual skills work wonders

review_title: Just What I Needed To Read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2020
reviewComment: Chrissy stood guard over her owner for 17 hours after his death and she suffered PTSD.  This same scenario played out for our dog after guarding my Mother's body.  After reading this book, I understand the damage her dog  suffered until we took him home.  Sometimes we just don't realize the damage dogs and cats suffer in their lives.  Thank you, Diane Wong for bringing this to our attention.  I needed to read this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2020
reviewComment: I like reading stories involving psychic abilities and animals, especially if they are mysteries.  The poor Shih Tzu master was found dead, and the woman who adopted her discovered the story behind her and decided to see what happened.  She became more and more involved in the story which wound up involving some of the people she knew in her own neighborhood.  A lovely little story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
reviewComment: This book has many things recommend it:  winsome dogs, loyal friends, and a budding romance.  It has pet care tips and tips on dealing with PTSD -- all good.  What it doesn't have for me is an emphasis on the murder.  The writing is pretty good, but the cute factor is a little high for me.  Now bad book, just not my cup of tea.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
reviewComment: Murder, romance, an adorable shih tzu, an heroic German Shepherd and a mystery -  "Attorney at Paw" has it all.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2020
reviewComment: I couldn't resist getting this book because I have a shih  Tzu and have never had a more attentive dog.  This story is well developed with believable characters.  It's a nice mixture of cozy mystery and love story.  There are some grammatical errors, but not so much you don't want  to continue the book.

review_title: Journey to the Burmese Jungle During World War II
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2009
reviewComment: My 10-year-old son and I found this novel captivating. Smith has a knack for conveying a sensitive lesson about colonialism (in this case of Burma by the British) through a suspenseful plot. As a female reader, I wish the character Maya had been a bit more developed, but the protagonist, Nick, is a wonderfully adventurous and self-critical kid, and you learn along with him about the wisdom of indigenous Burmese and their profound relationships with elephants.

reviewComment: Anyone who has seen the film would agree the two are very different. This was more of the story of a man coming to terms with fate. I enjoyed it. Well done.

review_title: Well worth the read and so very different than the movie.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2018
reviewComment: It's rare I'll read a book after seeing the movie, however just based on the description, it made it seem this story is quite different than the big screen version, and it definitely was.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2002
reviewComment: Not quite all it could be...just settling down to enjoy a good novel that would hopefully last a week or so, and finished it in one night. Felt it had a lot more to offer, even though it did have a relatively satisfying ending. Brief, shocking and to the point, the story is luridly entwined around one man's stance against loneliness, and how he responds to unexpected development. Excellent scientific and biological descriptions of vampire anatomy, good characterisation and solid emotional descriptions, but once again, the tale winds down prematurely. Saddened that the second half of the book is filled with four-page long short stories that, although well written, would better serve as furthered chapters of the headline title.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2019
reviewComment: Prepare for a brutal, yet beautiful tale of raw humanity and survival. Gripping until the very end. Couldn't put it down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2017
reviewComment: I thought the theme of understanding and appreciating ones enemies was spectacularly delivered; however, the man versus wild and helpless damsel in distress imagery was a little cliche. I loved the fact that the author took something so mystical as a vampire and explained it away in science, creating something biological rather than a monster story. Overall, I really enjoyed reading the book. The imagery and suspense were well executed, making it a quick and interesting read.

review_title: I am Legend, Hell House, and other stories
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2011
reviewComment: When I ordered this, I wasn't sure what the contents would be, since the reviews only referenced I am Legend and the book is only 301 pages. I consequently purchased Hell House separately and now I have it twice. My review is primarily to help others who may be interested in more than just I am Legend. As horror literature goes, both of these titles are essential reading. They are classics. The included stories are also very good. I respect the author very much. If you like Hell House and haven't already done so, read Shirley Jackson's "The Haunting of Hill House".

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2017
reviewComment: One of the best, if not the best Homes’ books I have read. Hard to put down. Would highly recommend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2016
reviewComment: It is astonishing how Anthony Horowitz succeeded in writing in the voice of Dr. John Watson. House of Silk can easily be another Sherlock Holmes book by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, complete with Victoria era period setting. Masterful!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2016
reviewComment: This is a novel that keeps you guessing till the very end. Being well written make for a daily fast read as the story flows smoothly. A good first read of the Sherlock Holmes collection.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2018
reviewComment: Good read I love Holmes and Watson. Mr. Horowitz is a very talented guy,  I look forward to more of his work.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2016
reviewComment: Though I am not a Holmes purist, this comes across as if it were written by Conan Doyle, or even better. Only caveat is that there is some violence toward children that some readers might find upsetting, but it is not graphic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2012
reviewComment: Horowitz's story is pretty good and it gets better as it goes along.  He does not do well with his flat and slavish depiction of Holmes and Watson, however.  He would have been better advised to create his own characters, as Will Thomas does so brilliantly in his historical mysteries.  Fans of Doyle would do better with Laurie King and Kim Newman.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2014
reviewComment: As an avid Sherlock Holmes fan, the author does a fantastic job. Characters are well defined and descriptions are on the money. You can place yourself at 221B Baker St. Highly recommended to all Sherlock fans. I will definately give this author another read.

review_title: A good book for Holmes fans.

reviewComment: Horowitz did a great job.  Felt like one of the originals. This one got me introduced to Harowitz, and I have read laa his books now.

reviewComment: How wonderful to be back in London, again one step behind the great detective. reviewComment: What started as a spur of the moment subway distraction grew to a life long devotion. Even though I own several variations of the stories in anthologies now and belong to several Sherlockian bookclubs and scions, I still find myself rereading this version on my phone when I had time to kill or need to reference these stories.

review_title: Incredible wit and unique Sherlock Holmes! Bravo for the author
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018
reviewComment: This book takes you away from where you are to be by the side of Sherlock in a Dr. Watson fashion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2011
reviewComment: I've read "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" in a number of formats including paperbacks and a much beloved two volume annotated edition of all of Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes stories and novels in chronological order. In spite of the price this version for the Kindle was a bit disappointing. A huge problem for me was that every time a sum of money was mentioned it was difficult, and sometimes impossible, to determine the correct amount because either there wasn't a symbol for Pounds available or it just didn't transfer properly when it was prepared for the ebook format. It felt as though it was scanned with character recognition software that couldn't read the symbol for Pounds Sterling.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019
reviewComment: Easy read - really like reading on my Kindle

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2010
reviewComment: A great freebie to keep on the kindle for when you've overspent your budget and still want something to read.  You don't have to read the full book - each short mystery is self contained but you learn more about the characters as you read more of the stories.  Especially enjoyable if you have recently seen the blockbuster movie.  You will be surprised how much of the movie details are in the stories.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2012
reviewComment: The Entertainment value is great. The stories are timeless with very realistic yet fantastic content. It holds its own even in today's highly saturated entertainment market. Love to spend time and read these short stories.  As they say it all in the details and the characters deliver every bit in these stories without much investment in your time as a reader.

reviewComment: The plots of these adventures, as well as the methods that are employed by Holmes are legendary and I have enjoyed many of the movies and television programmes which have been based on them, but the writing in this collection is a pleasure to read. I highly recommend this book to those who appreciate a well-written and well-constructed mystery.

reviewComment: This was a very Spiritual novel. Mr. Rubart has two separate life's  of one man who is trying to find the Truth. I felt like I was meditating while reading. It is very powerful.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2014
reviewComment: Each of us struggles in our walk with Jesus. Each bears burdens of life - regret, guilt, sorrow, pain and fear among others - but our Lord calls us to know His freedom. You will laugh and cry and, like the painting, you will change and get closer to completion of who God lovingly calls you to be. This book was a godsend. Thank you for answering His call, James! You make our journey more hope filled and we are watching for our angels, too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2018
reviewComment: Incredible, exciting, thought provoking, awesome, riveting, spiritual, stripping yet filling, painful and exhilarating, deep, soulful, dark, light, hate and above all- unconditional love. Thank you from my heart.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2010
reviewComment: Fascinating story line with fantastical elements to it that I enjoyed (similar to that other book The Shack by William P. Young) but....other than Micah, I thought most of the characters were pretty flat and only used to tell the story of Micah.  I also like other reviewers felt duped into the Christian thing - very heavy into the bible and Christianity.  However, I got something out of this book but telling you would only ruin part of the story.  Lets just say I like to still that negative voice in my head sometimes.  It made me think of the movie 'A Beautiful Mind' where the character had to ignore those three characters that exist only in his mind.  This book was okay....but not my favorite and I probably won't read it again.

review_title: You cannot serve God AND mammon.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2018
reviewComment: This book grabbed my attention from the beginning and kept it 'til the end.  I liked that it challenged my own beliefs and how I live them out.  I have been recommending it to my friends.  My hubby has just finished reading Rooms and we have had good discussions.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2017
reviewComment: This book will be the most unusual book that you have read. It is a book where Michael comes face-to-face with the disappointment and anger from his life. It's a story all of us can identify with and it about giving up everything in life to get what is most important.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2018

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2018
reviewComment: The story of God’s existence, love and mercy is a world all to itself. You have put such touching emotions into this novel it brought tears to my eyes many times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2018
reviewComment: I loved this novel. I laughed, cried and sis some soul searching. Thank you James for following the leading of the Holy Spirit as He gave you the insight to lead people into a deeper relationship with Jesus!

review_title: ... have read this book twice and it just gets better and better
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2015
reviewComment: I have read this book twice and it just gets better and better. William Boyd never fails to engage the reader even after the book is read. These characters are living during a heightened time of purpose and fear during WWII and later, in current times. Betrayal, deception and survival are central to the story. Our heroine is resourceful, and focused which ultimately saves her life. But this is life now informed by a restlessness shaped by unfinished business that takes over her life, potential joy and peace and never ceases.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2013
reviewComment: This was a very well written mystery/suspense.  I liked going back and forth between the mother's history and what was happening in the daughter's life.  Kept my attention the whole way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2017
reviewComment: Well written, good character development and an intriguing story. I enjoyed it very much.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2016
reviewComment: Great

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2013
reviewComment: Eminently readable. Beautifully paced with characters who engage immediately. An engrossing tale of WW2 skulduggery and one amazing woman. Highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2014
reviewComment: good read - a bit difficult at first, but after it got going, hard to put down...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2013
reviewComment: Confused story line but in spite of that it is readable and I quite enjoyed it. OK for a rainy weekend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2012
reviewComment: Moves nice and slowly (if you like that sort of thing), yet with plenty of mystery to uncover.  Brings characters alive from another time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2014
reviewComment: 1st time time I've read William Boyd. Found this because of the movie. I'll look for more titles. Kept me turning the pages quickly !

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2015
reviewComment: Very well written and entertaining.  Mother/daughter drama adds to the war scenario behind it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book. It had a good mystery and a budding romance but I really found the side story of the PTSD. The visits with the psychiatrist in the book sounded like they came from a good therapist. I understand PTSD a little better and gained insight into dealing with mental health issues. I look forward to the next Shih-tsu mystery.

review_title: Besides being a cozy mystery, this is the gentlest and most understanding book about grief that I have read.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2021
reviewComment: As someone who has some understanding of psychology, this is an encouraging book about grief and recovery. It is skillfully intertwined the psychology behind the murderer and how was so many people could have been suspects. Beside all this, the book is Well written for easy reading.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2018
reviewComment: Rin Tin Tin and Lassie would give this murder mystery a 4.5 to 5 barks. It's an easy read that starts out a little slow with a great deal of detail as background and foreground.  The plot takes several twists and turns as Chrissy communicates hints in some surprising ways from her low point of view.  Kids 10 and older will enjoy this book.  A must read if you, a loved one or your friend have had to deal with PTSD.

review_title: Murder in the name of Love
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
reviewComment: I loved getting to meet Crispy and Autumn .  I am so happy they found each other and had such a deep connection. It was a very well written mystery.  I was surprised to find put the real murderer. I look forward to reading more about Autumn, Crispy, Ray and Ace.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2020
reviewComment: Only a few grammatical errors. The story is fast -paced and intriguing. There is no sex or violence. No bad language. All these are pluses for me. There is a sweet dog, a distressed heroine, and a police detective for the hero. Many animals!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
reviewComment: The interaction of the dog Chrissy with the people is the most interesting part of this book. The story is contrived with everything moving too fast.  The human interactions are not realistic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2020
reviewComment: Loved the book am looking forward to other ones. I lost my Shih Tzu. He went to doggie heaven where I know he is making everyone happy

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
reviewComment: Light enjoyable read. A dog who communicates with and is in sync with its new owner leading to the answer of "whodunit". At some point in the book the evidence is clear who the perpetrator is, but the steps taken to discover it has moments of humour.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2021
reviewComment: The book kept me drawn in. Chrissy is amazing and I love how her an autumn connect. I can’t wait to read more

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2020
reviewComment: This really could use smoothing of descriptions.  I like the descriptions of thoughts/feelings of dogs and coping with life’s challenges, but they are emphasized as both “unusual” and as something reasonable.  It reads very much like a first book.

review_title: Aneko Press publisher ( Kindle version ) Reveiw .
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2018
reviewComment: This is a review of Aneko Press ( The publisher is key to correct paring of review ) updated Kindle Edition .This is the complete original Pilgrim's Progress by John Bunyan i. It has been slightly updated , the neat part is what ever they have changed , updated  they give you the original phrasing  as along side it . The really great thing is that they also print the whole scripture verse Bunyan is using to support his Auto Biographical Allegory . It also includes the 100 early wood cut pictures in their entirety , ( Note : the hard back would be a great edition to your Library if you do not already have a illustrated Pilgrim's Progress  .  This makes this a great devotional tool and a great teaching tool . God used J.Bunyan in a remarkable way as he had minimal schooling thus he learned to write , spell and compose sentences based on his learning to read and through the study of the English Bible , basically self taught ( I would say Holy spirit taught ,but that might offend some ) . He has been recognized as the first writer of the English Novel . Many doubted that such an unlearned man could have written this book . His response was to write 'The Holy War " an allegory on the war between Satan and his army in the taking of the City  of Man's Soul  and its recovery by God The Father Son and Holy Spirit and the following attacks made on man's soul for the rest of his mortal life . ( This book also available by Aneko Press ) Note this Aneko Press has a number of Christian Classics in print , Paper back;, hardback ; digital Kindle . They are to be highly commended for the service they are doing to keep these treasures available . First Class would give them 10 stars if I could .

review_title: If you are like me though
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2015
reviewComment: Pilgrim's Progress is a classic that is just as powerful today as it was when it was first written in 1678.  If you are like me though, you have struggled with the reading of this beloved book.  The way we speak now has changed a lot through the years and sometimes picking up a book from a different time period can be challenging to read.

review_title: A Great Version Out of the Many
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2016
reviewComment: This is one of the better versions of the Pilgrim's Progress.  The version is written in clear modern language.  The Bible Verses are conveniently located so one can easily read and compare them to the way John Bunyan uses them in the story. (The Bible verses are actually written out not just marked)  I have several versions of the Pilgrim's Progress, so I have read this story over and over many times.  I would highly recommend this version and the one written by Barry Horner.  Both of the books have their advantages.  If you have read this story before and you really didn't get anything out of it, I would suggest you buying this version and trying it again.  I have gained different insights with each and every reading.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2017
reviewComment: Wow! Just wow, oh wow. Just started reading this book, only up to page 23, 'The Second Stage' and I have to say that it has a hugeeee similarity to a christians struggle and path. Just amazing. This version allows me understand it 100%. Although I've never read the original version, it still tell the exact same story. With verses from the Bible to confirm certain situations, this book is spectacularly written and thoughtfully executed. Just amazing. I recommend this book to alllllllll 'new Christians', and the veterans. Great read for teens walking with God to help them along the way. Found out about this book from one of Ravi Zacarias "sermons." ... check him out as well. He has some amazing books and is an amazing speaker. He's the reason I bought this book, or should I say, God is the reason, after all he made Ravi. Lol anyhow, highly recommend this book. Amazing find and read, I'll definitely be passing this book around to friends and families.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2018
reviewComment: This is my favorite book of all time besides the bible. I've read this maybe 7-10 times in the past year. What I didn't realize it how different it is from the original language. I first found this out by listening to the audio version on ibooks. One section that specifically impacted me was the hill of difficulty and how much more beautiful the old language is in relation to the story. Please see below:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2019
reviewComment: I never thought that I would leave a one star 'ever' because I think that just the effort of writing a book is worth at least three. But reading this book I start to understand the extreme deception in this world and that is worth at least one star.

review_title: The story of Christian and his journey had similarities to ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2015
reviewComment: The story of Christian and his journey had similarities to my own life experiences as a Christian over the last 45 years.  Those comparisons helped to remind me of the grace and help I have received along the way and the many pitfalls that have challenged this passage.  The picture of the fellow raking the muck, so attentive to his work and missing the gift that was being offered, really resonated with me.  So much in this life competes for our attention, often to the demise of those things that are really, and eternally, important.  With the time that I have left, it is my endeavor to focus on the path that is leading me to my final home with Christ.  That's all, and it's enough!  Praise God!

review_title: Wonderful Alegory of the Christian's Spiritual Journey - only partially updated to Modern Language though
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2016
reviewComment: I have loved the story of Pilgrim's Progress since I was a child. Not to give away anything of the plot, twists or turns and spoil the book for anyone who has not had the chance to enjoy reading the book for themselves yet, Pilgrim's Progress in simplest terms is an allegory (a story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one) of the spiritual journey Christian goes on as he makes a decision to follow Jesus Christ.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2014
reviewComment: This book was a pleasure to read. Although the overall plot was a bit predictable, there were more than enough twists and turns to keep me enthralled. I'm a loyal fan of Conan Doyle's original stories and am wary of any Holmes stories penned by another writer, but with this book, there was no need to worry. The writing is so well done that you'll forget it's not an original story and I loved the fresh look on the Baker Street Irregulars.
