review_title: very nice addition to the canon
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2014
reviewComment: Told from the perspective of Watson, as always, but an old, retired Watson writing a story to be kept secret for 100 years. Very nicely done, well in the spirit of Doyle's Holmes and Watson, and with a theme that is actually quite modern in many ways. A very nice read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2011
reviewComment: The House of Silk which is an outstanding Sherlock Holmes Novel.  It was a very exciting read.  I could hardly put it down and was able to read it in only a few days.  I have read all of Sherlock Holmes stories by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and find this one to be just as good as any and is written in the same style.  Author Anthony Horowitz did an outstanding job in writing this book.  I would hope he writes many more!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2020
reviewComment: Loved this Sherlock Holmes story. Hope Mr Horowitz will write others.

review_title: Delivers on all Aspects for the Sherlock Holmes Fan
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2015
reviewComment: Always skeptical of a Sir Arthur Conan Doyle look-alike, but this book delivers on all counts.  The style, the language, the plot, the characters, the settings and the reminiscences are perfectly done.  The juxtaposition and ultimate connection of two seemingly unrelated story lines is exceptionally well done.  A real treat to read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2015
reviewComment: The book had the tone and semantics of a real Sherlock Holmes tale; however, the plot seemed to drag in spots making reading a drudgery. This drudgery never occurred with Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.  I'm not sure I would read another of Mr. Horowitz 's Holmes stories.

review_title: You would believe it was written by that original author of Sherlock Holmes.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2019
reviewComment: I love this author; his writing style; his verbage ; his ability to take you down various roads, each on which are possible solutions.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2003
reviewComment: The story 'I AM LEGEND' is a must for any vampire library and is the story used to make the film, 'The Last Man On Earth'.  It is dark, tragic and enjoyable to read.  Robert Neville is as close to a real person that a fictional character can get, a person trapped between the logic of his mind and the new dark age that has fallen outside his house, a new age of vampires.  This story ALONE is a great reason for buying this book, but wait, there's more.  10 other stories within its covers will delight and entertain you.  In fact, as most of them have been on TV(or the big screen) in one form or the other, they already have.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2011
reviewComment: I have only seen the Will Smith movie that is lightly based on this book.  The movi was just okay.  This book however is a great read and show what the man Robert Neville struggles with as he deals with loneliness, loss, and the struggle to find out what he is dealing with.  This very apocalyptic thriller is a great read and it is hard to believe it was written in the 1950's.  You can tell this is a great precursor to the spike in vampire and zombie novels that are the big craze today.  This novel stands out though in comparison to them and is very interesting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2019
reviewComment: I’ve seen The Omega Man with Heston and I Am Legend with Smith and I finally decided to read the original story. So very different and better than either retelling of the original, although I enjoyed both movies.

review_title: this is THE perfect zombie survival book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2016
reviewComment: Look, this is THE perfect zombie survival book. Not only does it describe the difficulties of being the last person alive,it investigates, in depth, the possible reasons for the apocalypse itself. Fantastic scientific theory, amazing emotional exploration, unequivocal and dangerous encounters. The way its written is as beautiful as the situations itself. Robert Nevil, the main character, is so vulnerable and open with his feelings, you fall right into his POV. Even in a world of zombies and vampires, he reminds me of what it is to be human.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
reviewComment: If you saw the movie.  Or not. This book will not be what you expect.  It will make you think more and react less.  Chilling.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2020
reviewComment: Lonely, captivating and thoughtful. So different from the movie but SO good. I loved it. It's a quick read that will have you questioning what you would do in the same situation. How would you survive?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2014
reviewComment: Matheson's name should live among those of Poe, Lovecraft, King and others as one of the best writers of his genre.  How many can say they they have written one book from which three movies have been made?  If you love books about mad science and the scientists that make them mad, zombies, vampires, end of civilization and much, much more, this is as good as it gets. World War Z meets Salem's Lot with Dr. Strangelove thrown in to get it all cooking.  Enjoy the ride!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2012
reviewComment: This book is not at all like the movie that was released with Will Smith. It instantly pulls you in, alternating between the struggles Neville must face psychologically as well as physically it goes deeper into the Horror genre than just running scarred. He has to accept who he must become in order to live in this bleak new future. New plot elements are introduced in such a way as to keep you on the edge of your seat, hopeing and praying that Robert Neville will find the peace he needs to somehow be happy again. In the end, I was completely surprised by what happened.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2018
reviewComment: This is the second time I have read this book, and it is still good!! It is hard to imagine living in those conditions by yourself for a long period of time. Neville perseveres despite all that is against him. He even tried to learn why these vampires are they way they are they. He doesn't give up even when it gets hard, he still keeps going.

reviewComment: This novel piqued my interest at first because it's setting features one of my favorite beaches and little towns on the Oregon coast. But he weaves in our spiritual state while spinning a story that you want to read to the end.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2012
reviewComment: I love lonely planet guides and I've used them in Malaysia, China, Tokyo, and Istanbul.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2010
reviewComment: I've purchased Lonely Planet travel guides for many of the places I went on vacation.  Korea was my first, and my longest.  I lived and worked in Korea for 2 and a half years, and this guide was helpful on numerous occasions throughout that time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2011
reviewComment: I downloaded this guidebook as a planning tool but, you can not navigate around the book easily enough to plan a trip and I can't imagine myself using it as my reference while traveling.  You really need to be able to access a detailed index in a guide book to make it work.  You also need to be able to comprehend your districts or zones in the country to be able to find things quickly but, every zone in the Table of Contents is labeled with a Korean name instead of a general description like "northeast" or "central mountains" which the beginner needs when trying to figure their itinerary out.  Maps cannot be quickly referenced either.  Most of these difficulties are likely common to all e-reader guidebooks.  For now I suggest sticking with a printed version, at least for this one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2014
reviewComment: I went to Korea for two weeks during the dead of winter when it's very cold and you don't want to be standing around outside trying to figure out your next move. This Lonely Planet guide was so well written and organized that my trip really went off without a hitch. No problems at all, and the book gave amazing advice on everything.

review_title: Lovely walks, could have been a better guide
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2005
reviewComment: I just spent a week in Seoul and I used this book along with the Moon handbook.  I didn't purchase any of the Seoul focused books because they hadn't been updated recently.  While some aspects of this book were good there were a few drawbacks.  The good parts -- there were two good walks which allowed you to see parts of Seoul, the average tourist may not.  The only non-Koreans we passed on these walks had the same guide book.

review_title: it's a good travel pointer for getting around and deciding what to ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2014
reviewComment: For an overview on Korea, it's a good travel pointer for getting around and deciding what to see.  Korea is no France or Italy when it comes to great places to visit, but it is a lovely country and you can drive or train just about everywhere.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2014
reviewComment: A wonderful book that really enriched my experience in Korea. Even though it's a bit old, it still gives a lot of good information.  The Lonely Planet series is great and can help you find places that might not be mentioned on the internet.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2008
reviewComment: Lonely Planet produces some of the best guidebooks available, so it should come as no surprise that their book on Korea is complete, concise, and interesting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2012
reviewComment: This book was great for navigating around, but failed miserably when listing detailed information about particular destinations.  I had to resort greatly to my own savvy and smart phone.  Thank god for free wifi...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2014
reviewComment: I bought this for my son who has now been living in Korea for a year and a half. We visited, and the book was helpful in choosing places to visit, eat, stay.

reviewComment: I love Sherlock Holmes mystery books. but I really like reading them better on my new Kindle Touch.  The print is perfect and the pages turn so easy that one can get lost in the mystery and not have to worry about pages that turn themselves, especially in a new book.  The price for this book was $0.00.  Can't beat that!!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2018
reviewComment: A nice group of short stories narrated by Dr Watson.  I love seeing the logic at play.  A fun, relaxing read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2012
reviewComment: I am only half way through having read 6 chapters (out of 12) as of present and just have to say these are great / fun intriguing tales with Dr. Watson being the main narrative.  I have the Kindle version and so far really nice job with the character illustrations accompanying the story lines in each separate chapter a tale in itself. Really enjoyable and fun reading.

review_title: It claims to be good for readers confined to their beds or people who ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2015
reviewComment: This edition (Bed Book)'s format is very different from 'traditional' books - it is in landscape format, meaning while the title page is vertical (like with most books), the printing inside is landscape. It claims to be good for readers confined to their beds or people who prefer to read in bed. I didn't know this before buying the book, and I must say it's a bit weird to me. I don't usually read in bed so I don't see how it is a superior or revolutionary format. I didn't find such a description about this before purchasing, or I wouldn't have bought it. It's not necessarily bad, just not suitable for me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2012
reviewComment: This is twelve of the numerous Sherlock Holmes cases that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote through his lifetime, there are some issues within the text where the symbol for the pound appears as some sort of code, same with some of what I assume are meant to be letters with various punctuation associated with them, if it were not for that, I would give this five stars.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2019
reviewComment: Now a motion picture and great series

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2015
reviewComment: Crime stories that are a good read. Written in the vernacular, which is as interesting as the stories. Sherlock is the father of CSI. His instant deductions, based on his power of observation are always interesting. This is a book to read again and again.

review_title: If you like unaltered SH mysteries in original text it is a ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2015
reviewComment: I read the electronic version. Typical Sherlock Holmes/Arthur Conan Doyle mystery. If you like unaltered SH mysteries in original text it is a good read. I like the electronic version -- it is easy to take with me anywhere-- shopping, traveling, waiting in offices, etc. plus I can also read it on any device at hand; i.e., smartphone, laptop or tablet & return quickly to the last page read.

review_title: I have always enjoyed Sherlock Holmes but have not read Doyle's work for ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2015
reviewComment: I have always enjoyed Sherlock Holmes but have not read Doyle's work for many years.  This set of cases which I read on my Kindle for free rekindled my interest and I plan to start reading one of the more comprehensive Holmes Kindle collections soon.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
reviewComment: Great volume, great binding

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
reviewComment: I have a very old Pilgrim's Progress handed down from my grandfather to me. It is a bit more difficult to read due to the "olde" wording. This is easier to read and absolutely clarifying.  I first got this book because I was studying it with some high schoolers. It is a revealing story regarding the understanding of walking a path to the Lord. This is a definite must read for anyone interested in understanding the Christian path.

review_title: Classic story that people of today can read with no problem.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2019
reviewComment: The book is in great shape and it is nice to read it without deciphering the language.  It is also very nice to have the original illustrations.  The only reason I am not giving this 5 stars is actually a reason I was excited to get this edition.  Reading about the description, I saw that Bible verse allusions made by Bunyan were included.  I thought that would be wonderful, but it makes the book harder to read.  Bunyan made so many allusions to verses that I found myself only making it a line or to before another entire verse was inserted.  I love the scriptures, but it does make the flow of the story clunky.

review_title: Through the entire read the voice talent constantly re-quotes the bible verses
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2020
reviewComment: Through out the entire read he will quote the main character "God loves us in Christ" and will then say "Scripture: God loves us in Christ" effectively saying the same thing twice over and over and over through the entire thing, it became monotonous and tedious at times, almost like they were trying to impress us with how scriptural the book actually was, which, if you know the Bible this isn't needed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
reviewComment: Growing up, my dad used to read this book to my family after dinner time. It was such a cherished memory, and he made the book come to life with his vivid storytelling. I haven't ever personally read this, so I thought it was a good book to add to my bookshelf. I'm enjoying the illustrations and was pleased to find a hardcover option.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2019
reviewComment: I enjoyed the whole book, I liked all the names you gave them one could understand right away which were good and which were evil! Easy to understand and makes one think when the time comes for ones own time if one would understand or would there be a guide to come tell one it's time to cross the river! Well done, thank you,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
reviewComment: This is a classic written in 1678 that has the honor of being described as the second most read book after the Bible. It is written by John Bunyan, one of the early English Baptist of the seventeenth century who wrote this famous work while he was imprisoned. The story by Bunyan is an allegory of the Christian life. Seeing how significant this work is, it is important to experience this classic.

review_title: God's answer to the desperation all feel before they encounter the Love and Grace of God . . .
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
reviewComment: This classic of the Christian allegory category is without peer in describing the human condition and God's answer for the desperation all feel before they encounter the Love and Grace of God in their lives. The outstanding application of the King James Scriptures throughout the story from beginning to end will inspire those familiar with God's timeless Word, and educate those who never had the training afforded by reading it's message. I first was exposed to it over 50 years ago, and have since read the biography of John Bunyan, an itinerant tinker imprisioned for preaching without a license back in the mid 1500's when the Church of England had supplanted the Catholic Church and was being used to control the people. John Bunyan spent years in jail, and while there, God used him to write Pilgrim's Progress and other works. A book everyone should read, you will find an example of all of humanity in this story, the good and the bad, the saint and the sinner, the overcomer and the backslider. They are all here along with yourself.

review_title: This is a great book that I never really knew about
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2018
reviewComment: This is a great book that I never really knew about.  Somewhere, it was recommended, & when I researched it online, I'm glad I ordered this particular version of the book, because, it has all the original 100+ illustrations, and it has all the related Biblical segments imbedded in the story.  ( rather than listing a reference that you have to look up in the Bible ).  But, either way, it is an amazing story from 1891 that describes a Christian's journey to Mount Zion / Paradise, and his encounters with all the same obstacles that we currently face in life.  The 2nd half of the book is about his family's similar journey, after they all shunned him at the beginning.  A recommended book!

review_title: Over-the-top obvious allegory, but still enjoyable
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2019
reviewComment: Pilgrim’s Progress is a bit of a heavy-handed over-the-top obvious allegory, but I found myself enjoying it. The author did a pretty good job of telling how to get to heaven and navigate through life’s challenges. The version I read had the Biblical references written in the text inside parentheses in italics and I found that took away from the enjoyment of the story and so after a while began to just skip over them. There are quite a few illustrations throughout. I recommend this book to anyone who has ever wanted to read Pilgrim’s Progress, but never got around to it.

review_title: 2nd only to the bible in worldwide production. nuff said.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2017
reviewComment: The highest distribution of any book, second only to the bible itself. The bible is the creation from God's point of view, this is an allegory of Christianity from the point of view of a Christian. It does a great job of explaining what you will face as a believer, or maybe explain that what you have already faced isn't abnormal. Is a slave greater than his master? A true Christian's life will be marked, at different intervals, by trials, loneliness, disparagement, harassment, rejection, chaos, peace and joy. This spells it out in a very concise, yet dramatic way. This book will make more sense of different events in your walk with the Lord, using scripture throughout. My children love this book and even the most mature Christian has something to gain from it. If you haven't yet, find your way to the narrow gate, shrugging off scoffers and keeping your eyes on Him.

reviewComment: Autumn Clarke is suffering from PTSD after surviving the car accident in which her parents were killed. Her therapist suggests that she get a dog, so she goes to the local shelter and finds Chrissy, an adorable Shih Tzu, whose pet father was killed the previous day. Autumn and Chrissy bond instantly and Autumn soon begins to get telepathic messages from Chrissy. Determined to discover who killed Chrissy's pet dad to help Chrissy (who has separation anxiety) heal, Autumn starts asking people in his life questions, including the detective handling the case, Ray Reed.

review_title: I Am Legend is the good part of the book...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2001
reviewComment: I was really enjoying I Am Legend when it suddenly ended just partway through the book.  What I didn't realize, was that this classic vampire yarn is only a novella, and that the rest of this paperback is filled with other short horror stories by the author.  Whereas I Am Legend is still a good read, generally standing the test of time, the other stories are almost comically outdated.  In an era of greatly sophisticated horror films and novels, these short stories of yesterday seem almost like a caricature of themselves, though they must have been scary enough when they were first published. If you're interested in an absorbing vampire tale, definitely pick up a copy of I Am Legend.  Just don't expect it to last for an entire flight across the Atlantic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2017
reviewComment: could have fleshed out the character. the story was slow but then at the end seemed rushed. i love character development and unfortunately, there was really only one character to develop and that was done haphazardly. liked the science behind the story but really not much more to like.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2012
reviewComment: After seeing the movie with Will Smith, I was interested to read the book that supposedly birthed the idea for the movie, so I thought I'd give it a go (and costing only $3.99 wasn't bad either).  This book was different from the movie (aren't they all) and in my opinion was more interesting because it offered a much clearer look inside Neville's head.  His motivations for his actions, his wide-ranging and fast-changing emotions allowed me to connect with him much better than the movie in that I, like many people, have felt these same emotions.  The author did a great job of helping the reader to relate to how he was feeling.

review_title: "Rooms" If you need your soul to be inspired....
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2010
reviewComment: To begin, although I am a avid reader, I have never reviewed a book previously. James L. Rubart's book "Rooms" must have accidentally found it's way onto my Kindle as I typically do not read fiction (with the exception of fairytales). However, this book touched me so deeply, in ways you cannot imagine without having knowledge of the book.  James L. Rubart's "Rooms"  for me,  became impossible to put down as somehow, the words were touching my heart and soul so deeply.... Then when I arrived near the ending of the book, only then I could part with it as I did not want it to be finished, I couldn`t imagine it over... somehow I couldn't imagine something that was able to stimulate my senses as no other book aside from the Bible ever has being finished. I found myself experiencing an all together new feeling once again, not wanting to complete a book as I just did not want an ending. It is that spectacular! Thank God it appears the ending is not really a ending, I haven't researched the information as of yet myself as I only finished the book seconds ago.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2010
reviewComment: I thoroughly enjoyed this book and the characters, although I would have like a little more information on the relationship between Micah and his brother.  While it could be compared the book "The Shack", it was more of a spiritual version of when Alice went down the rabbit hole and when Micah came out on the other side, he had the truth and glory of the Kingdom to look forward to.  This book is for anyone currently struggling with their spirituality as a reminder that that's why it's called "faith."

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
reviewComment: I really enjoyed Attorney-at-Paw, the first book in the A Chrissy the Shih Tzu Mystery by Diane Wing.  I was afraid that it was going to be silly; it wasn't. It was a serious mystery with some humor and a great twist.  Chrissy is precious and all the dogs acted like real dogs; Chrissy is extra special but she plays and fears and loves like so many dogs I know. As a dog lover, I enjoyed watching Chrissy and her new parent come to love each other. I am glad that the author address PTSD driven anxiety and she did a great job of it. The mystery was well done and I suspected the culprit but kept changing my mind because there were several reasonable suspects. I recommend the book for anyone who enjoys animals or cozy mysteries. I can't wait for the next book to release!

review_title: I really like this version of Pilgrim's Progress
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2017
reviewComment: I really like this version of Pilgrim's Progress. For one thing, it actually includes the applicable Bible verses italicized right in the text, so there's no need to stop and look up the verses. It is very helpful for my book group that I can simply read to them the verses they want to hear. I have this on my Kindle and really like it. I like the translation, too. It is in standard English, for the most part, and quite easy to understand.

review_title: Must Read for Anyone Wanting to lead a Christian Life
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2017
reviewComment: What can I say? This book has been around for a long time and in my opinion, should be required reading for every Christian baptized in Christ at the very beginning of their journey. If a person is baptized as an infant, it should be the purpose of the child's sponsor or Godparent(s) to ensure the child reads this book as soon as he/she learns to read and understand. If one is baptized as a teen or adult, this book should be read immediately after.

review_title: Outside the Bible, the Pilgrims Progress is one of the greatest Christan works ever penned
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2016
reviewComment: Outside the Bible, the Pilgrims Progress is one of the greatest Christan works ever penned. It chronicles the spiritual journey of Christian, the main character, from his realization that he needs a Savior through his salvation experience, through his trials as a Christian, until he enters Heaven. The original prose is a bit challenging, but worth the effort. The book has been rewritten by several authors in easier to read syntax. I highly, highly recommend this book in either form for any Christian to read, whether you are  young or old, a new Christian or a mature Christian. It will give you hope, resolve, and will strengthen your daily walk with Christ. I guarantee that! I have read it several times. The only book I have read more often is the Bible. If I could give it ten stars I would.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2019
reviewComment: I thought this book was going to be lame, but WOW! Solid theology and exciting adventure! I look forward to reading it to my children once they're old enough. Good for the soul.

review_title: Classic!  Must-Read for Any Follower of Jesus Today
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2018
reviewComment: I re-read this classic after first experiencing over 30 years ago.  The modern language version makes the plot much easier to follow and allows the reader to be drawn into Christian then Christiana's journies to the Celestial City.  The book is essentially an allegory of the spiritual pilgrimage of a man, and later his wife and children, who have chosen to become disciples of Christ.  The references to the Scriptures are abundant.  I don't just highly recommend this title.  It is a must-read for any follower of Jesus today.  It is truly a classic, only deepening and becoming more engaging as time passes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
reviewComment: Wonderful classic! I am so thankful for the updated language that makes it easier to read without changing the story line.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
reviewComment: I've taught The Pilgrim's Progress for many years.  I am presently going through it again, using this edition and the standard one published by Oxford.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2017
reviewComment: I haven't finished reading this book yet but already am enjoying it very much. It is a Christian based novel. It would be easier to read this book if you have an understanding of The Bible. A man named Christian is the main character. On his journey to heaven, by trying to live a unsoiled life, he meets with friends who help and encourage him on his journey. He also meets many adversaries and pit falls.As I haven't finished it yet I do not know his outcome but I have faith that Christian will find what he is looking for.

review_title: Great book for open family discussion!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2017
reviewComment: I love Pilgrim's Progress! It's a classic that I've read over and over since childhood. I'm thrilled to have this updated version to share with my own children. It's so much easier to get to the meat of the subject matter, when I don't have to continually explain the meaning of the vocabulary! Don't get me wrong, it's still full of rich, thought provoking, descriptive language. But, it is today's rich language.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
reviewComment: I really like this edition of one of the most influential books in human history. My favorite part of this edition is having the scripture references written directly into the text, otherwise you would need Pilgrim's Progress in one hand and your Bible in the other to look up all of the scripture references Bunyan uses,  and that would be way too tedious. It's even more edifying this way. The illustrations are nice too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2013
reviewComment: My 11 yr old daughter had Elephant Run as a summer reading book assignment.  I read it first and was very shocked at the amount of violence in it.  Dogs getting murdered, people getting murdered, and beaten.  There were also a few references to thoughts of rape by one of the characters.  The story also didn't flow.  It went all over the place and you had to reread frequently to see if they were in the past or present.  I do not feel that the author really described things either I could not vividly picture how things looked.  While it is historical fiction you really don't learn much about WWII.  The other problem that I had with this book is that many of the words were written in Burmese with no explanation of how to pronounce them.  I decided to give it a try though and let my daughter read it.  I was sorry that I did.  She began having nightmares after the scence where the Japanese murder people and kill a dog(this was one of the only parts that was pretty descriptive).  She also became frustrated with the fact that she couldn't read/ pronounce the Burmese words.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2013
reviewComment: Purchased for my child for school.  Have no clue about it.  Required reading so I guess it was OK.  Got an A in the class.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2015
reviewComment: It is 1941, and fourteen year old Nicholas Gillis Freestone, known as Nick, lives in London, England, with his mother who works at the American Embassy.  His stepfather, Bernard Culpepper, is an Army intelligence officer who is off on a secret mission.  When Nick was five, his mother divorced his father, Jackson Theodore Freestone the Third, a teak plantation owner in Burma, returned to the States with Nick, and remarried.  But now that bombs are dropping from the night skies of London and demolish their apartment, Nick’s mother sends him to live with his father at Hawk’s Nest, hoping that he will be safer on the Burmese plantation.  There he meets his dad’s foreman, Nang, Nang’s son and daughter, Indaw and Mya, the Buddhist monk known as Taung Baw or “Hilltop,” and the plantation’s mahouts.

review_title: Diverse History Lesson in the Form of Fiction
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2020
reviewComment: Whereas many books are purely fictional or purely historical, Roland Smith excellently blends the two in this book. Elephant Run follows the story of Nick Freestone, his family, and his eventual friends in an adventurous tale of life in Burma and a treacherous journey to freedom. While many books that are set in the time period of the second World War focus on America or Europe, this book gives a glimpse into the war in Southeast Asia. "Elephant Run," geared towards the early- to mid-teen crowd opens up young readers' eyes to the atrocities that occurred all around the world during World War II, giving appreciation to all kinds of heroes, no matter their ethnicity. A wonderful read for those who love history, adventure, and traveling the world by flipping through pages!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2013
reviewComment: I highly recommend Elephant Run, by Roland Smith. Elephant Run is set during World War II in Burma, which is located in Southern Asia. The main character is 14-year-old Nick Freestone who lived in London, England. After Nick's parents' apartment was destroyed during the German bombing of London, Nick's mother and father both decided it would be safest to send Nick to Burma to stay with his dad on a plantation to get away from the bombing.

review_title: A great read, you will love it.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2015
reviewComment: I didn't buy this book on Amazon, but I have read it and I thoroughly enjoyed this book through and through.  At first, the action isn't 'apparent', but keep reading! In the story, it is 1941, and fourteen-year-old Nick Freestone has been sent by his mother to live on his father's teak plantation in Burma to escape the dangers of the London Blitz. Unfortunately, the War in the Pacific is also gearing up, and the Japanese takeover of Burma is imminent. Soon after Nick arrives, Rangoon falls to the invaders, and Japanese troops infiltrate the country. The Freestone plantation is overrun and converted into an operating center for the Japanese command; Nick's father is taken to a labor camp, and Nick himself is held prisoner on the plantation and forced to work for the enemy officers. With the help of ;Taung Baw', a legendary, ancient Buddhist monk whose name means "Hilltop," Nick and 'Mya' (a young Burmese girl whose father was the head "mahout," or elephant handler on the plantation) manage to escape and attempt a daring rescue of Nick's father. Riding on the back of a huge, rogue elephant named Hannibal, Nick, Mya, and Hilltop journey through the dangerous jungle in pursuit of their quest, enduring heat and hunger, evading occupation troops, and navigating among Burmese natives who might be friend or foe. This book is a great read, and I'd recommend for any '10-16 year old'.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2009
reviewComment: Elephant Run is a historical fiction adventure story by Roland Smith. The protagonist, 14-year-old Nick Freestone lives with his mom in London during World War II, but due to the frequent bombings, he is sent to stay with his father in Burma. Nick's father owns a teak plantation where much of the labor is done by elephants. In the nearby village, many of the citizens work as mahouts, or people who drive the elephants. This includes Nang, one of the plantation's most trusted employees, and his son Indaw and daughter Mya, who is about Nick's age.

review_title: it overrules all of the historical fiction books that I have read so far
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2010
reviewComment: Elephant Run By: Roland Smith

review_title: Exciting WWII historical fiction for middle-grade readers
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2008
reviewComment: ELEPHANT RUN is an exciting, historical adventure novel that will appeal to all middle grade readers (and their parents!).  In 1941, Nick Freestone joins his estranged father at the family plantation in Burma to escape the bombs falling on England.  Instead of finding refuge, he is plunged into the Japanese invasion of Burma.  With the help of his young friend, Mya, Nick tries to learn more about the timber elephants trained on the plantation.  Mya, a girl who hopes to become an elephant trainer, or "mahout," barely has time to show Nick around the plantation before Nick's father is taken prisoner by the Japanese.  With Japanese soldiers in charge of the family home, Nick becomes an unwilling servant of the Japanese.  But there are hidden passageways in the house, and soon Mya and Nick have found a way to escape into the jungle, riding on the back of a much-feared rogue elephant named Hannibal.

review_title: Don't you dare run from this book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2011
reviewComment: Elephant Run is one of the best books I've ever read. In this novel, the year is 1941 and Nick Freestone has just moved from his mother's apartment in London to his father's teak plantation in Burma. Relieved to have escaped the German bombings, Nick can't wait to rebuild his relationship with his father, Jackson Freeston, whom he's has little contact with over the past ten years. Their reunion is disrupted, however, when the Japanese take over the plantation and send Jackson to a POW camp. Now a slave to the Japanese, Nick must work with his new friends, Hilltop and Maya to try to escape and rescue both Jackson and Maya's brother Indaw from the camp.

review_title: WTH is wrong with this edition?

Similarly, if anyone found your child's Nook, they too could purchase anything using your credit card information.

review_title: Nook was labeled as a Demo and NOT Brand new as advertised.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2017
reviewComment: "I attempted to contact the seller on 12/27, but received no response. The item was listed as brand new, but when I gifted it to my son-in-law for Christmas, he discovered that it was a Demo unit meaning he couldn't download any of his own books. I'd still like to have a functional Nook sent to my son-in-law, but if the seller remain uncooperative, I will settle for a refund."  Update:  So before going through this huge hassle of returning and waiting on a replacement, etc., I tried a system restore last night on the Nook.  That feature was locked down when the Nook was on, but when I powered it off, I was able to find an online guide to trigger a system restore using the keys on the unit.  That proved successful!  After about 10 minutes, the unit came back up, and all features were unlocked.  I was able to login to my account, access my books, and do everything on it that I could with my previous unit.  No features were grayed out, etc.

review_title: Good Korea coverage in onl y 400 pages
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2006
reviewComment: I travel to Korea on business trips lasting 2-3 weeks, and the many sightseeing days mixed into those frequent trips has allowed me to evaluate this and several other Korea guides. This Lonely Planet's guide covers Korea efficiently, in 400 pages, by including details you'll need, and leaving out details on obscure cities rarely visited, and omitting rambling historical notes found in guides such as Moon Handbooks' South Korea (~850 pages!).  For example, Lonely Planet covers Busan's Geumgang Fortress in less than half the text used by Moon Handbooks; however, the latter fails to provide adequate directions on getting there, and forgets to warn of the maddening crowds found on holidays, and weekends - important info included in Lonely Planet Korea. Faced with the challenge of Busan's tens of thousands of restaurants, Moon Handbooks chooses to review NONE and only suggests city areas to look for them, while Lonely Planet Korea gives us helpful reviews of specific restaurants. If like me you plan on spending more than a few days in Seoul, you'll find it useful to combine Lonely Planet Korea with Lonely Planet Seoul, because the latter includes far more detail for your Seoul visit.  Be sure to visit the tourist information centers (found in major airports) upon your arrival and get the free city maps.  I suggest you withdraw extra Won from the ATM's in Seoul (or Busan's Gimhae airport) because you'll find ATM's that accept international cards very difficult to find in cities outside Seoul. Don't buy Moon Handbooks' South Korea unless you're planning a Korea trip length of over a month and need details on obscure cities, and want pages of historical info on every city.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2008
reviewComment: I've used Lonely Planets for years.  I like some more than others, and there's a few issues I have with the series, but they've always been a useful general guide to my travels.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2015
reviewComment: By their very nature, travel guide books become outdated long before they're even set to be printed.  But of all the Lonely Planet editions I've ever read, this is one of the poorest.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2005
reviewComment: I always buy Lonely Planet guidebooks for the destinations I go to. They are informative, organised, well laid out, list a number of activities which most visitors to the Land of the Morning Calm would be hard pressed to complete.  The latest edition of the Korea guide book is no exception, and is a great introduction to this amazingly deceptive country. South Korea is full of contradictions, sprawling metropolises juxtaposed with ancient Buddhist and Confucian temples.  The book helps visitors explore those contradictions.  Those planning on living in the country (ESL teachers) may find it lacking after they have exhausted all the sights and activities, but for visitors staying a few months or less, and travelling around Korea (not just sticking to Seoul) will find it plenty sufficient.

review_title: not worth the money to buy, borrow from the library if you must
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2010
reviewComment: I've used lonely planet for many years and have traveled in 25+ countries.  Its my travel book by choice since its preplanning logistics are wonderful compared to other travel guide books out there.  However, this is by far the worst lonely planet book I've ever encountered.  I've been severely disappointed by the quality of the information given. i was in South korea for 2 weeks with a couple of days traveling alone outside of Seoul.  My korean friend in seoul was shocked by the quality of information given in the Lonely Planet.  Many locations given in HANGUL were spelled incorrectly (atrocious!).  Times of tourist sites were given incorrectly. (Lets say I had many ill planned days due to this fact.)  The one hostel I tried from the lonely planet was horrible (saranchae in gyeoung ju).  In addition I found inconsistencies within the book itself regarding names of train stations and their translations.  The list goes on. The only thing I found useful was using the book to plan simple travel logistics such as knowing if there was a bus from one city to another.  I found the government tourism office by far more helpful - providing free 24hr. translation, tourist offices in abundance with awesome maps and advice in english.  If you're planning a trip to south korea utilize the official tourism office and website as well as trip advisor (and your hotel/hostel when you arrive!).  That is all you need and if you must get this book - borrow it from the library.  Do not buy it.  I'm SURE lonley planet will come out with an improved better edition later.

review_title: Rely on TIC for current and more comprehensive information/advice
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2009
reviewComment: I saw this latest edition of the Lonely Planet Korea at a tourist store inside Helsinki airport.

review_title: Great story but TERRIBLE E-BOOK CONVERSION
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2011
reviewComment: I highly recommend this book as a story (it is a 100% brilliant reworking of an old-fashioned spy thriller) but my enjoyment was undermined by the shockingly bad Kindle edition. It is filled with typographic horrors: sentences without fullstops; accents that turn into other characters (façade --> fagade); 'w' morphing into 'v/'; missing apostrophes; etc. It is appalling that the publisher thinks that this is acceptable. I don't mind some typos in a free book, but the e-edition of a book still in print from a professional publishing house (Bloomsbury) ought to mirror the 'real' book in every detail. This book has been converted so lazily that they've even left the paragraph at the end saying what font the [real] book is in. Lazy and sloppy.

reviewComment: About 1948 when I was a 9 yo alocal church had after-school film / slideshow sessions. One of the slide shows was text and illustrations from Pilgrim's Progress. The unabridged real thing, dated as it may sometimes seem, is a wonder of holy thought and biblical education: whatever is missing in the like of modern thrilling adventure is outweighed by the inducement to reflection, meditation and scripture reading.  I haven't read it in its entirety yet. It's a go to book when I tire of the too-deep, too-shallow or too-fast.  I don't have much intellectual capacity but I'm sure this book is that river where lambs can wade and elephants can swim
