review_title: An offline tutorial for a Cluster
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2014
reviewComment: I could describe this book as a really nice introduction to create your own Raspberry Pi cluster, consider this an offline compiled tutorial to do it yourself with some code that would give some insights to start your own apps. Little Java or C++ knowledge is necessary, but a lot of self enthusiasm for have it working. It is easy to read and it will walk you through step by step, but in order to bring all what it is exposed within, it is necessary to have the hardware in place (at least two Rasberry Pi).

review_title: A Step by step starter for distributed computing
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2014
reviewComment: This book isn't quite a Swiss Army Knife for Raspberry Pi, but it comes close.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2017
reviewComment: I don't hate it but I do think it is a very poor example of what it should be. I've been building cluster since the 1990's. The first one I built for myself was using SUN SPARCstation 20s. I agree with one of the other reviews that the book is too short and lacking of information for the price tag.

review_title: Great Primer on Raspbery Pi & Cluster Computing
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2014
reviewComment: As the proud owner of more than 15 Raspberry Pis I am always looking for unique projects to either learn from or to implement something useful. This ebook gave me an opportunity to learn Big Data/Hadoop super computing concepts by actually implementing a working system, using the very popular low power and low cost Raspberry Pi SoC.

review_title: A clear and concise introduction to parallel computing
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2014
reviewComment: I've seen several YouTube videos showing clusters of Raspberry Pi's and, as I have a few Raspberry Pi's, thought I would have a go at building my cluster. Looking for information on how to do it, I came across this book which provides a great introduction into parallel computing and also provided very clear, concise instructions to set up a cluster of 2 Raspberry Pi's.

review_title: Closed ePub about Open Source project
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2013
reviewComment: This is closed non-printable ePub about the open-source RaspberryPi project. Need we say more.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2015
reviewComment: I have always wanted to build one of these. This publisher has never let me down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in India on December 9, 2018
reviewComment: Not worth it. Download ebook. Most of it is just basic stuff that can be found on raspberry pi forums and on stackexhange

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on December 4, 2017
reviewComment: Good

reviewDate: Reviewed in India on October 21, 2017
reviewComment: It could be little more easier to understand for the people who do not have computer networking knowledge.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
reviewComment: I read this book because my uncle was a veterinarian on the Burma Road during World War II.  He talked about the tigers, elephants and jungle. It was a good story with elements that will stir the imagination of the younger readers.  It was a good and decent book that introduces the reader to the Japanese occupation of Burma--helps you to know that it happened but there were also "good" people among the enemy who helped those in trouble.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2015
reviewComment: It is a very good book. Nick Freestone is in a tough situation and Smith explains it well.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2013
reviewComment: What would you do if you were captured by Japanese soldiers and forced to be a slave?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2009
reviewComment: This story begins when Germany bombed England. Nick Freestone's mother was worried Nick would not be safe in London. Their apartment was just destroyed and she was responsible for finding a new home for them. In the meantime she decided to send Nick to his father in Burma. Jackson Freestone owned the land of Burma and soon would pass it off to Nick. Though Nick's mother was terrified of the dangers in Burma she thought he would be safer there then in London. So she sent Nick off, but what she didn't know was that Nick wouldn't be back for a long, long time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2011
reviewComment: First of i am 60 ++ years old---that said---I'll continue.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2012
reviewComment: In Elephant Run Nick Freestone, the main character has to live in his dad's elephant farm during WWII.  When the Japanese take over the elephant farm Nick, Mya, Hilltop, and Nick's dad have to find a way to escape without the Japanese discovering them.  When they find Nick's dad near death, they are not sure if he will make the journey.

review_title: so good, we've read it twice
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2013
reviewComment: I think we read this with our son in 3rd grade and again in 5th.  For a boy it is wonderful, with WWII history, an exotic locale, adventure, danger, rampaging elephants and more.  A wonderful and very accessible coming of age story.  We've read 3 or 4 of Smiths books -- a great "go to" author for kids in the upper elementary age group.

review_title: This book made my child love reading!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2009
reviewComment: Thank you, Roland Smith.  My daughter has struggled to enjoy reading for so long (she's 11 in 5th grade).  She just finished this book last night & finally understands what it's like to get wrapped up in a great book!  She's so bummed that it's over.  I'm on Amazon today to buy more books by him for her. Her comment was "They've GOT to make this into a movie!"  I'd appreciate recommendations on comparable books. (We're enjoying Hatchet in audio and everything by Cornelia Funke).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2008
reviewComment: I am a mother of four children under 14, and always looking for well written historical fiction for my boys.  My 10 year old needs the action in a book to start pretty quickly, or he will lose interest.  I just finished reading this today, and I can't wait for him to read it.  Smith is able to take a fairly complex subject, and make it interesting, and understandable, while teaching the reader a piece of the history of Burma during WWII.  By the middle of this book, I could not put it down, I was so anxious to discover the outcome of Nick Freestone's fate.  Fantastic!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2009
reviewComment: This book by: Roland Smith is about a boy named Nick who lives in London with his mom. Because it is world war 2 there are lots of bombings there. Nick's mom thinks he would be safer living with is dad in Burma. Once he finally adjusts to living in

review_title: A dogie detective solves the crime
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2018
reviewComment: Diane has created a heartwarming read for the sleuth and dog lovers. The story underscores that when one door closes another door often opens without one realizing it.  Love is the greatest healer of all pain. After finding and healing each other, Autumn and Chrissy spread love wherever they go while providing healings and even solving a murder. This book is a quick read that holds your attention long after you have read the last sentence. If you liked the Nancy Drew series, you would LOVE the adventures of Autumn and Chrissy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2018
reviewComment: I am a major Diane Wing fan and eagerly looked forward to this new read.  Diane's storytelling gift shines in this supernatural murder mystery that takes us deeply into the emotional memories of Chrissy, the Shih Tzu, the only witness of her owner's shocking murder. The plot is fresh and original, with strong characters and story surprises that will keep you turning pages until the very end. Chrissy will capture the hearts and minds of all of us dog lovers who know there is much more to our furry companions than meets the eye!  Bravo!

review_title: Easy read that holds ones’ attention!!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2018
reviewComment: I loved reading this book!!  As I read, I felt the bond between Chrissy and her new pat parent.  As a pet parent to a Shih Tzu, Ms. Wing has captured the magic and uncanny intelligence of this breed.  I loved the locality to the Philadelphia/Bucks County area.  I truly appreciated the omission of foul language and intimate sexual suggestion.  This book is an easy read and a perfect introduction to continued writings.  Very much looking forward to #2!!!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2018
reviewComment: I absolutely LOVE dogs, so when I heard about this book, of course, I had to read it. I wasn't disappointed at all. Chrissy and Autumn make the perfect detective duo. Chrissy is absolutely adorable, and Wing really brings her to life, personality and all. You'll be left guessing until the end who the culprit is, all while witnessing Autumn and Chrissy bonding and healing from their traumas. I highly recommend for dog lovers and cozy mystery lovers alike!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2018
reviewComment: When Chrissy's daddy is found dead, the little dog is sent off to the shelter. Enter Autumn Clarke, a sufferer of PTSD who needs help with panic attacks. Chrissy helps her new mommy and Autumn decides that for her to give Chrissy the help she needs, they need to find out who killed her daddy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2018
reviewComment: I love cozy mysteries and this one was a delightful read.  Two lonely beings (one human and one adorable canine) are brought together by recent tragedies in their lives.  They bond right away and help each other heal by solving a mystery together.  The telepathic visions are an unexpected touch.  Looking forward to more Autumn & Chrissy mysteries from this author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
reviewComment: A murder mystery that would be good for a long airline trip or on the beach. A few dogs, a romance and several murders to solve.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
reviewComment: This book was so much fun to read.  It is very entertaining and informative.  I guess I enjoyed it more because I have a Shih Tzu.  If you like a good mystery, love story and animals, you'll like this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2019
reviewComment: The connection between Chrissy and her new owner is endearing and tugs at your heart strings, keeping you turning the pages until the mystery is solved.  Who knows, maybe this could encourage kids to read a book again :)  And, not only is this a fun read, but would make for a great tv mystery, appropriate for all ages.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2018
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this story, I always like books with animals.  This story really used some imagination where the dogs were concerned and I really liked that.  The mystery had some twists and turned that kept my interest as well! Good read!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2016
reviewComment: Had to have a wifi connection to work which I do not have. Returned unit for a Kindle.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2014
reviewComment: Like everything about it mostly.  Am going looking for more books to use with it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
reviewComment: I wanted a simple reader and it was just what I wanted.

review_title: Everything my wife wanted for her birthday
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2012
reviewComment: My wife loved her birthday present.  This is her favorite way to read now.  I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a quality eInk reader with none of the other chaff that color tablet-wannabe-readers have these days.

review_title: Screen of the used Nook that I purchased, flickers ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2014
reviewComment: Screen of the used Nook that I purchased, flickers a lot on each touch of the screen. It has been ever since I received it. Screen momentarily goes black. The whole screen flickers on each and every button that i

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2013
reviewComment: A new Nook for $20 less than in the store and other online sellers.  My wife loves the Glowlight feature, plus it's easy to read in the sun light.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2012
reviewComment: Very good technically, however in Europe we don't feel the necessity of the B&N bookstore ! Instead the wifi could be used for searching and downloading directly from the net.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2014
reviewComment: as advertised

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2015
reviewComment: Unfortunately was defective. Had to return(

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2013
reviewComment: I LOVE LOVE LOVE this nook! Perfect for what I wanted.. just reading! the glowlight is awesome, it lights the screen evenly and well, even on the dimmest setting. I would definitely recommend!

review_title: A Good Read -- If You're Not Old Enough To Vote
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 1999
reviewComment: Despite being reasonably entertaining and diverting at times, "I Am Legend" is ultimately unsuccessful.  Despite its short length, it becomes quite silly and boring after a while.  And the inept, juvenile  redundancies!  How many times must the reader be subjected to descriptions  of whiskey being drunk, spilled or thrown across a room?  Who does Matheson  think he is, Charles Jackson?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
reviewComment: I definitely enjoyed this book. No, it is not much like the movie although both are very good. I felt connected to the story and really was curious the whole time how things would work out. It wasn't a read-in-one-setting kind of excitement but the book was well written and easy to read. Although it is older than I typically read, that was not an issue at all, it felt timeless.

review_title: A short glimpse into a world of vampires.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2007
reviewComment: I remember seeing a preview for a movie called I Am Legend a few months back and it looked alright.  When I started talking to some co-workers about it, they urged me to pick up the book before the movie comes out (about a month as of this writing).  They couldn't say enough good things about Matheson's I Am Legend.  So, I purchased it.

review_title: Book is better than both films
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2012
reviewComment: I enjoyed both the earlier film, The Omega Man, as well as the second attempt, I am Legend.  In the book we get a better feel for Neville and his personal vampire/zombie apocalypse as well as his aching loneliness at first.  I wish the developing society of live-vampires had been explored in a little more detail, but it must be kept more unknown to allow the development of the Legend.  Looking at the cover all in red and black I'm glad I have it as an e-book, they really need to reconsider the cover imho.  (I know, bad review, but I'll get better as I go).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2018
reviewComment: No words for this book, ageless and amazing. Do not watch the movie, this is timeless and never fails to chill my very being. Read now!

review_title: I really enjoyed reading this and the twist at the end was ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
reviewComment: If you are looking for something to compare to the movie then don't bother reading this. I will say they should have done the book instead. This book was not only well written, but it was done in a way to make it believable. I really enjoyed reading this and the twist at the end was very unexpected.

review_title: An Underated Classic better than the movie
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2018
reviewComment: I was surprised how much I enjoyed this read. Knowing nothing other than the movie, I was surprised at first how different the two are. That said, the story is a great one with an even better ending. It was very twilight zone like.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2014
reviewComment: Matheson wrote some of the most creative and imaginative tales of the 20th century. Even if you don't know his name, I can guarantee you know his work (any Twilight Zone fans out there?)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020
reviewComment: Movie was much better.  This was different in a lot of (not good) ways.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2021
reviewComment: "I am Legend" is only half the book, approx 200 pgs. The rest of the 200 pages are short stories that are not connected and rather uninteresting. I've never said this before, and I apologize to the book gods, but the movie was better.  Even typing that gives me a bitter metal taste in my mouth.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2017
reviewComment: The physicality and suspense was exhausting, but exciting. I think Doyle would be impressed!

review_title: One of The best Pastiches I've read In Years
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2014
reviewComment: THE HOUSE OF SILK is another of those Watson penned adventures of Sherlock Holmes stored in the dispatch box in the vaults of Cox and Company to be held for a hundred years before publication.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
reviewComment: The Victorian atmosphere and all the attitudes and situations that Homes/Watson fans have come to expect are all here.  Can't wait to read the second one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2017
reviewComment: Clever and interesting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2018
reviewComment: great retake on Sherlock Holmes lore

review_title: Great reimagining of the Sherlock Holmes universe
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2015
reviewComment: I quite enjoyed this book. I can see how it was endorsed by the Conan Doyle family. The basic premise that the events depicted in this book were too controversial to publish at the time seemed plausible to me. If you are a fan of Sherlock Holmes (or would like to see how crimes were solved without all of the forensic resources available today), definitely give it a read.

review_title: Good but cant match doyle's work
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
reviewComment: A good narrative but is still missing something. A bit predictable but still a good tribute to Sherlock Holmes.  Hopefully we will see some more novels.

review_title: Excellent book. Anthony Horowitz captures the spirit and essence ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2016
reviewComment: Excellent book. Anthony Horowitz captures the spirit and essence of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson. Great story. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2013
reviewComment: Author does come close to Arthur Conan Doyle's style of writing. It is very well written, though at times getting into specifics which are not required. I do have an unanswered question here - does author intend the story to be published after the Reichenbach falls encounter? Looks that way though why would Watson wait that long is anybody's guess. Other than that, quite a good one.

review_title: Doesn't get any better than this.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2017
reviewComment: I have read all of the Conan Doyle stories and many of the pastiche stories. This is no pastiche. This is more entertaining and better written. The best detective story I've read in a long time.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2017
reviewComment: I've always enjoyed the stories of Holmes and Watson, and this set did not disappoint. I'm sure any Holmes reader will feel the same.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2009
reviewComment: Super when I am on an airplane and have forgotten to turn on the wireless to pick up new books.  Doyle never ceases to amaze and provide entertainment.  I think I started reading Holmes in the 60s (early 60s) and have yet to stop.  Good emergency book to have if you have a Kindle and enjoy deductive reasoning.  easons to get it are elementary my dear reader!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2010
reviewComment: I had not read the Adventures of Sherlock Holmes before, so this free kindle download was my first taste of the legend himself.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2018
reviewComment: Classic . Nice collection of short stories that stand the test of time.

review_title: Comments for Amazon purchases I really hate having to write comments for any item I purchased ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2014
reviewComment: Comments for Amazon purchases I really hate having to write comments for any item I purchased I feel that the star rating is sufficient to let anyone know how I feel about the product if I really dislike of product I may take the time to write about it or I would just return it that is my comment.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2018
reviewComment: New book, completes a set I had trouble completing.  It showed up in great shape and shipped promptly.  Good stuff!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2020
reviewComment: Gift to my daughter, unfortunately it left mark on cover after removing sticker! Why put a sticker on cover?!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2012
reviewComment: Even after being done over and over in movies to the point of humdrum, the Arthur Conan Doyle Sherlock Holmes stories remain very entertaining. I have read these many times and continue to find points I missed. I started with a collection when I was around 12 years old. This was an Ebook I got for my Kindle. I keep it with me faithfully.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019
reviewComment: This has been on my Kindle since I bought it. I was on a business trip with nothing to read.  I remembered Sherlock Holmes.  A very enjoyable read.

review_title: Twelve Stories, Most Good, Some Just Okay
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2017
reviewComment: Twelve self-contained stories of mysteries solved, some criminal. Entertaining, but the need to wrap up the story in one chapter prevents character development and more interesting twists and turns.

review_title: A relationship and mystery /thriller all in one
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2012
reviewComment: Do you ever really know another person--even your mother?  This book explores this via a mystery or semi-thriller about the mothers past life.  For me it was a rather compelling read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2012
reviewComment: I had not read anything by William Boyd until now.  What a wonderful novel.  Definitely written in a sensory format and I felt as though with each page I was a participant in the story.  A keeper in the sense I know this is one of those few books I will read multiple times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2012
reviewComment: My husband and I both enjoyed this book.  It is so well written and holds your attention from beginning to the end.  I highly recommend it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2012
reviewComment: I don't normally read 'sky" novels but this one was a page turner for me. I like books that are, simply-put, a good story. This was that.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2013
reviewComment: I liked the concept of unraveling the story through a Eva's daughter.  Great tension in the Eva's story.  Knocked it down a star because I found the in the drifting narrative into Bader Meinhof and protests of the Shah (both of which went nowhere) irritating intrusions to a good story.  This is the first of several William Boyd's I have in the hopper so time will tell if some of the raves for his work are justified.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2016
reviewComment: 3.5?  it held my interest, but moved slowly at times.  Loved the dual story-telling format.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2013
reviewComment: This is one of the best books I've read in the last 12 months. The plot developed well and kept the reader's interest right up to the very end. READ IT!

review_title: Well written and captures the tensions of WW2
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2013
reviewComment: This is a well written story of spying and disinformation during WW2. The language flows well and the characters and events are believable. The twist at the end ties up the story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2013
reviewComment: I am a huge fan of William Boyd and once again was not disappointed. One never wants to put the book down and can't wait to get back to it, wonderful characters and and as always an unexpected ending. Most enjoyable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2014
reviewComment: Engrossing, well written,  interesting plot.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2006
reviewComment: To say that this guidebook is lacking would be a bit of an understatement, unfortunately. Why? Because, for example, it includes absolutely NO coverage of one of South Korea's larger cities, Ulsan, which is famous for being the home of the international Hyundai motor company, and was also one of the host cities during the World Cup in 2002. The population is over 1 million people, and to think that such a significant (if slightly industrial) city could be overlooked is proof that the authors of this guide have only scratched the surface of what Korea has to offer the world. Otherwise, I have to give them credit for producing a guide for the country AT ALL, considering that there are hardly any worth buying out that now as it is. I just recommend that for the next edition they do a little more research before publishing it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2004
reviewComment: Took this freshly minted book with me to Korea in June. It services all the main sights well, but there's a general lack of humor and real gritty insight throughout. For example, the Seoul chapter is a perfunctory list of sights, then a list of accomodation, then eating places, etc. etc. Much listing is to be found.

review_title: If you only buy two books on Korea, this is the second
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2005
reviewComment: Or, if you are in a hurry, and can't wade through the thick Moon guide (my choice for #1), get this one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2007
reviewComment: This is my first lonley planet guide.  I know they are typically considered good.  I see looking through reviews of travel books that many people think of themselves as lonely planet kinds of people.  I apparently am just not one of them.  This is easily the worst travel guide I've ever owned.  It had the advantage of being the only book on South Korea in either book store in town.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2009
reviewComment: I have been using Lonely Planet books in all my travels but I am not very satisfied with this one for the first time. It was not a detailed book and I had hard time in finding places such as restaurants because if the name of place is not written in Korean alphabet it is useless! Maps were useless as well but thanks God, information offices in all cities had detailed maps.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2008
reviewComment: Typical of the Lonely Planet series, this book is full of interesting and necessary information.  From sightseeing, to restaurants and accomodation, I found it to be a good help.  It also gives a great insight into the history and culture of Korea, with a food chapter and a language chapter included.  It's not the bible but I would definitely recommend this book to anyone going to Korea. You should also supplement it with stuff from the net or your local Korean tourist office etc.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2008
reviewComment: This book was a very comprehensive and honest guide to the country. It also included a section on North Korea and the possibility of travelling there. I found the information useful in order to decide where to go and the cost of living in Korea.

review_title: Disagreed srongly on what they call the Korean War
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2005
reviewComment: They wrongly refer to it as pointless. Look the war was important in stopping the spread of communism in Asia. It resulted in a very prosperous state of South Korea.It was too nasty to call the whole conflict`pointless. This statement ruins the`whole book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 4, 2012
reviewComment: I bought a number of e-books on a recent 10-day trip to Seoul.  Only this one and the Frommer's guide were of any significant use at all.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 2, 2011
reviewComment: I usually buy the DK Eyewitness books or Time Out books when travelling, but this time neither covered Korea so went with Lonely Planet. The book is fairly thorough in that it covers most cities and towns that a western traveller would want to visit as well as some off the beaten track locations. The book covers accommodation, travel, best sights, restaurants for each of the cities and towns, and because it was revised in 2010, is fairly up to date. My main criticism is that there aren't enough photos to give a visual flavour of the country, and maps (especially for smaller towns like Gyeongju and Busan) could be better. I'd personally prefer a 'top 10 sights to see' approach to the towns with some pictorial accompaniments rather than a grey list. Also, it doesn't always explain how to get to some of the less urban places like mountain parks, e.g. Haeinsa.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
reviewComment: A fascinating and inspiring book.  Well written, it captured my imagination from the very first page.  I couldn't put the book down, finishing it at 5 in the morning!  Although this is the first book I've read by this author, it certainly won't be my last!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2020
reviewComment: Great book, storyline very engaging

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
reviewComment: I have no words to adequately tell potential readers about this book.  It pulls the reader into suffering the main character's confusion, and fears, right along with him. Because we've all been there. Happily, we also get to experience this character's boundless peace, and joy, as well.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2010
reviewComment: I just finished reading James Rubart's debut novel.  I simply couldn't stop reading this book, and I read it all in one setting!  I am thankful I picked this book up as a freebie for the Kindle when it was offered, and my only regret is that it took me a few weeks to make it around to this one.  It does share the same spirit as

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2018
reviewComment: This book is complex but reminds me of the style of C.s. Lewis. This could be a great movie. Look forward to more of this author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2012
reviewComment: I found myself being anxious to get back to my Kindle to read this when I was unable to be reading at the time. If anyone finds this book "boring" ....I don't know what kind of an "exciting" life you lead!! I really enjoyed it. I don't want to give things away about the story but you will find the book speaking to your own life as well as the main character's. I am off to purchase another of his books to read next!!

review_title: My daughter recommended this book so I downloaded it on my Kindle ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2014
reviewComment: My daughter recommended this book so I downloaded it on my Kindle and transferred it to my iPad!  The best book I have read in years other than the Bible!  I highly recommend reading this book.  The author, James L. Rubart paints awesome pictures throughout the book for  your imagination to feed on.  Loved it and have told numerous friends about it, also!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018
reviewComment: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. James Rubart expertly painted (wrote) the metaphor of the soul with thought-provoking dialogue and credible characters. Highly recommended read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2010
reviewComment: I have longed for a book like

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2018
reviewComment: This was simply an outstanding book.  Had a hard time putting it down at 1:00 a.m., but finished it as soon as I was awake!!

review_title: This is a must read book if you’re Christian
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2021
reviewComment: As a Christian if you haven’t read this book it is a must read I love this book so much it has been passed down through generations in my family. It is definitely a book that you’re going to want to read and pass down because it has so much to offer at the same time it keeps you interested the whole time you’re reading.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2020
reviewComment: Do not order this book. It will not come like your expected. The print is small the paper and book is flimsy and the way it was put together is crap.

review_title: Standing the Test of Time - Encouraging and Hopeful - a Joy to Read!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2016
reviewComment: This book has earned a special place in my library! There are so many books out there today that try to teach us how to live a Godly life. The Christian culture is saturated with the world's DIY mentality and it is revealed in too many modern writings. Pilgrim's Progress does one thing and has been doing it very well for almost 400 years: invoking joy and hope in the heart of the reader. Reading this book is like hearing the testimony of a real brother, facing real challenges, and coming face to face with real sin. Then the power of Christ and the hope of salvation is revealed to him and suddenly, the Celestial City becomes strikingly real. This is how souls are encouraged to continue on!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2019
reviewComment: Although the writer lived almost 400 years ago, the struggles and temptations in life are the same then as they are today.  How the main characters dealt with these issues gives us hope and guidance how to defeat those issues in our own lives.  Knowing who and what the enemy is allows us to be overcomes.

review_title: An enduring classic for a reason!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2019
reviewComment: An all-time classic. Recommended for non-theists as much as theists. A wonderful allegory, that's been updated to modern English. Includes the relevant passages of scripture as well. Not sure I like this feature as it can distract from the story, but I got used to skipping over them if I didn't feel like being pulled out of the narrative. I have 3 copies of the Pilgrims Progress, and this one is by far the simplest to read. The illustrations are wonderful as well! Paper quality is decent.

review_title: I like that the scripture that is referred to is actually ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2015
reviewComment: Agrees with my interpretation of the way to heaven. I like that the scripture that is referred to is actually written out. Very creative that the words said by the pilgrim and the people he meets has a scripture that corresponds.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
reviewComment: This is a faithful modernization  from the original Elizabethan English of this Christian devotional classic.  Elizabethan English can sometimes get in the way of catching the meaning of a classic text.  Also I like the fact that the numerous scriptural references are imbedded in the text instead of being Biblical book, chapter and verse references as they are in the original.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
reviewComment: Great book read it 3 times have it now saved on the kindle . So this a old classic as well beautiful written some in older English type some versions are modernized it fantasy type fiction brings you on a journey like how we are on Christian walk what the many trials and tribulations we go through . A definite must read whether once or many times it’s also a long book so be aware of that .

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book. I could see the snares we could so easily get caught in. Crossing over the river was beautifully displayed.

review_title: Every Christian should read this book!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020
reviewComment: This book will open a Christian’s eyes to a whole new meaning of life!  We’re Pilgrim’s in a strange land following the leadership of the Holy Spirit on a journey to the celestial City!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2009
reviewComment: An exciting tale of a 14-year-old boy in WWII Burma. When Japanese soldiers invade his father's plantation, Nick is forced to work as a servant and his father is imprisoned in a labor camp. Nick must join forces with others to make his daring escape and save his father. Great for ages 9-14.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2012
reviewComment: I learned all kinds of things about a country I knew little about.  It's wonderful to read something fun and learn at the same time.  Very good read, both boys and girls ages 8-adult will enjoy this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2011
reviewComment: In middle school? Need to read historical fiction? Try this one! A deft take on different aspects of WWII. I learned a lot and truly felt for the characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2009
reviewComment: I found this book to be more exciting at the begining than the end but it was still a good book. I think that this is a good book to read with a parent because of the Indian words and just some other more difficult things to read. This book takes  place in 1941 and the main character is Nick Freestone. Because of the bombing in England Nick moves with his father in Burma. But it turns out that it is no safer in Burma than it was in England. When the Japanese attack Burma Nick and his friend Mya take care of each other. The Japanese take the family plantation Nick is forced to be a slave. But once Mya and Nick find the secret passageways it is only a matter of time before they plan their escape and make a run for it on a much-feared elephant named Hannibal.

reviewComment: I love this book I grew up with it my mum would read it to me. Its wonderful for children

review_title: Nothing like the movie, great book!

reviewComment: This is a short read, like 6 hours, so it was really no loss to me whether I loved this book or not, but I did!  It's NOTHING like the Will Smith movie. review_title: I Am Legend Not So Much
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2013
reviewComment: Considering all the raves and low price, what could I lose by giving it a try even though I never get excited about vampire stories. Is this the best they got? The writing was weak in character development, inventiveness, plot and action. Very repetitive. Yes, he's angry being the last human in town. I got it the first time. Didn't need any reminding. Yikes! Give it another star if you are into vampire stories, not that this is much of a story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2005
reviewComment: I AM LEGEND is one of the most important vampires stories written.  A lot of what hollywood has done with both vampire and zombies come from this novella.  Chuck Heston has done at least two movies based on it.  The writing is crisp. The story movies at a pace not usually found in horror writing and the whole things wraps up neatly.  If you like this kind of stuff then you need to read this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
reviewComment: I loved this book. Can't say much without spoiling it. Gotta read it for yourself and you should!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2012
reviewComment: I originally bought the book thinking of how much I loved the movie and books are always so much better. This was absolutely the case, only to find out that although the basic premise is the same, there are very few connections between the two. I was swept away with the Robert Neville of the story and the total contrast from the Robert Neville of the movie. Overall, the book had me completely captivated throughout and brought me to a new level of thinking when it comes to vampires.

review_title: Great story, but just the one story.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2012
reviewComment: I just finished this story, and I love it. Matheson really wrote a unique story here. After you read it, you can see how it became an inspiration for much of the horror to come after it. What I really wanted to talk about however, is how it compares to the hardback/paperback version. Buyers should just beware that unlike the print edition, this version is just "I Am Legend." The print version contains several other short stories. However, the progress bar at the bottom still goes by the full-length book, so I was confused for some time. However, since the price is low, I don't fault anyone or subtract from the score for it. This is still a great read for anyone who loves horror with a bit of science.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2007
reviewComment: Good reading and interesting enough to make it a fast read.  I was a littel surprised to find out that I am Legend is a short story.  It is followed by many other, much shorter stories.  My wife read the book too.  She felt there was not a good line of demarcation between I am Legend and the following stories--so much that she was surprised and thought the book was hard to follow.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2014
reviewComment: I am a action/adventure kind of guy and Sherlock Holmes is that guy. I like how he solves the troubles brought to him by the characters in the book. The book flows from one case to another very well.  It is written from Doctor Watson's point of view and is very believable.

review_title: No colloquial parallel intended: it's a classic!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2013
reviewComment: Is my review really an essential contribution for this collection? Doubtful. But since Amazon asked me to write one, here it is: this book is, as you likely already know, engaging, well-written, filled with interesting characterization and quippery, and just plain a pleasure to read. Dive in. You'll be glad you did.

review_title: What more can I say? It's a classic.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2014
reviewComment: Who can match Holmes powers of observation and deduction?  He makes it seem so simple after we know what happened, but to follow the same path to the solution requires his unique brand of sleuthing.  Very readable and entertaining.  Its worth a read or re-read.

review_title: Read it and the pilgrim goes through a spiritual battle ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2016
reviewComment: Read it and the pilgrim goes through a spiritual battle learning how to become and walk as a Christian. The devil and his spirits try to detour the Pilgrim and make him turn from his decision. John Bunyan really captured what the struggle of a Christian is and what everyday challenges that we face are to bring us closer to Christ not far away from Him. Worth the read if You think you mess up.. We have moments of wanting to give up and go back to how we once lived, but in the end it's not worth it. Keep striving, for we press toward the mark of the High calling in Jesus Christ.

review_title: I heard of this book a few times and just ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2015
reviewComment: I heard of this book a few times and just now got around to it. I plan on getting the children's version for my kids too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2019
reviewComment: I haven't read this book since I was a child. What a different experience to read at 50 years old with part of my pilgrimage behind me. A great reminder of the urgency of life and need to be walking faithfully with Christ.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2021
reviewComment: Love the updated translation for a much smoother read for those who aren't as Old English savvy.  Such a wonderful story that can now be enjoyed by those who wouldn't otherwise bother stumbling over the Old English language.  Also, love the referenced scripture placed directly into the story.  Recommend for everyone!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2016
reviewComment: This is absolutely fantastic piece of work from John Bunyon, even though it was written 400 years ago there isn't much other books or sermons out there that can truly show you the Christian walk and the Narrow path to the Heavenly Kingdom really is. Everything in this book is all allegory, including incredible Scriptural teaching (Chapter 2 especially), application, faithfulness, theologically deep conversations amongst characters, incredible discernment, and so much more. Once I started reading I did not want to put it down, I was even considering skipping some classes just to read the book. This updated translation is very easy read and will change the way you view Christianity.

review_title: Come to find out I already have this book...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
reviewComment: It may be under a different title, but the text of this book is pretty much identical to that of the James H. Thomas adaptation from the 1960s... that I already own in paperback. I  was hoping this would be the original Bunyan wording. But I did enjoy the illustrations!

review_title: Love the story but is interrupted in Audible format
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
reviewComment: This version I purchased stops the story every time the footnotes links a Scripture reference and says, "Scripture, (the reference) (the whole Bible verse)." This interrupts the flow of the story. Would be fine in print form but undesirable in audio format.

review_title: The road to heaven is not easy.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2020

review_title: Everything You Know About Vampires is a Lie Or: Richard Matheson and Deconstructing the Vampire Mythos
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2014
reviewComment: I'll keep this brief. This book is phenomenal. I taught it for the first time this semester in a course that's in it's maiden voyage as well. Despite Matheson's comments to the contrary, this IS a multi-layered novel that can elicit many interpretations. Yes, it's a man surviving alone in a world of beings he's trying to both understand and eradicate. But like others of Matheson's works (e.g., "Duel," "Button, Button," "Disappearing Act"), it hits on a beyond-literal level and contains multiple levels of meaning. And yes, it turns the vampire mythos on its ear and was notably an influence on Romero's landmark "Night of the Living Dead." Must-read!

Horowitz had his best touch with Watson. Not so much with Sherlock or Mycroft Holmes, both of whom seemed less rational and more, in Sherlock's case, maudlin, and in Mycroft's case, petulant. Furthermore, Sherlock Holmes seemed to play an odd, second-fiddle to Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 20, 2013
reviewComment: This is a book where if you apply your intellect you will completely miss the point and essence of what it points to: that all new thoughts, changes, ideas, perspectives (which are all thoughts anyway) come from an insight.  That's it. Simple. And when you listen or look for something with the intellect you will just innocently get in the way of yourself, and delay the very insight you are looking for!  That's like chasing the echo of your own voice.  We know what we know, and nothing new comes from that, but listening to someone beyond the words they are saying is when you'll discover new insights.  If you're curious to know more about this, check out Jamie Smart's forthcoming book 'Clarity' (

review_title: It's great for improving your vocabulary

reviewComment: I didn't realize that this had both stories in it; Pilgrims Progress, about Christian's journey, and then the story about his family's journey. That was a pleasant bonus.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2017
reviewComment: Once you start reading, it will open your eyes into a new direction in life.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2016
reviewComment: I read this to my kids ages 6, 4, and 2. They may not have understood everything, but they were very into the story. I loved this book also. It is one you can read over and over again. I enjoyed having the scripture references in it although it made reading it aloud a bit of a pain because I skipped over them while reading to the kids. It is a great modern english version of this book though. My older two picked up the story line with understanding easily.

review_title: Enjoyable version but a bit distracting
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2018
reviewComment: This was an enjoyable version of Pilgrim's Progress but there were a few things that were a bit distracting.  The first being that the illustrations (which were well done) seemed to be situated haphazardly. The Scripture references were sometimes placed in the middle of the sentence (and were often a repeat of what the character had just said). I think it would have been better as a footnote.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
reviewComment: I'd never heard of this book untill RC Sproul recommended reading it. So I bought it. It's a thought provoking read. I feel it's a beautiful explanation for the journey we all should be taking to hopefully get to the Lord.

I purchased this edition because we have young children and I thought it might be easier for a family read aloud--which it surely would be. However I have 2 main complaints:

review_title: The second best selling book of all time does not disappoint
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2019
reviewComment: I’ve truly enjoyed reading this book and plan to do so every year from now on. My favorite part of the book are the various characters that Christian meets along the way. They do a great job of giving names to people I have met along my own pilgrimage and help me to spot them when I encounter them.
