reviewComment: It was exchanged for one that worked.Problem with the first one connecting to internet. Took first one to Barnes & Noble and they worked with my son as it was a gift for him. Personally I love the Kindle.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2013
reviewComment: My 9 year old grandson asked me for a NOOK for his birthday. I never heard of a "NOOK"! I bought this one and I am enjoying it so much that I want one for myself. I see the days of the text-book becoming a thing of the past. Get this, you'll be very satisfied. Easy on the eyes. Great Job B&N.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2015
reviewComment: Has a faint line across reading screen. But it's readable, so not a real problem.

review_title: Love it, especially the background light and additional features
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2015
reviewComment: Love it, especially the background light and additional features.  Changes from the previous Nook Glowlight features were sometimes hard to figure out, but seem reasonable once deciphered.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2005
reviewComment: This book is very well written. The lead story I am Legend is a great tale that breaks down what could be the hard science of vampirism. The lead character is solid and his tale is a sad one, his existence made easier only by the rituals he performs daily. I think the tale is very realistic and it even touches on his basic needs as a mortal man. The other tales are also very good one of my favorites being the one with the phone ringing in the man's mind. I think anyone that is a sci-fi and/or horror fan would thoroughly enjoy it!

review_title: One of my all-time favorite books!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2011
reviewComment: Matheson's I AM LEGEND has been made into three bad movies:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2012
reviewComment: I came by Richard Matheson through his writing for The Twilight Zone. This is the first of his novels I've read and it definitely will not be the last. Though written in 1954 it doesn't feel dated at all. The story is well-paced, thoughtfully written, and easy to follow. I really enjoyed Matheson's writing style. The ending is superb; thoughtful and appropriate. It's no wonder this book is a modern classic. I can't recommend it enough.

review_title: I liked the story I Am Legend well enough
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2018
reviewComment: I liked  the story I Am Legend well enough, but it's only the first 170 pages of this book. There are ten short stories after I Am Legend, half of which I gave one or two stars to. I gave the other short stories four or five stars. I Am Legend has been made into at least three movies that I know of. The Omega Man (1971) is my favorite version. The first movie, The Last Man on Earth (1964) had zombies that were too weak and slow moving to be believable and I Am Legend (2007) had zombies that were too strong and fast to be believable. They could crawl on ceilings like bugs, which was so unbelievable I laughed.

review_title: If you liked "Night of the Living Dead,"...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2001
reviewComment: That movie has been the best interpretation of this novel so far (even though it supposedly has nothing to do with it).  A close second would be "The Homega Man" episode of The Simpsons.  This is one of the many cornerstones of 20th Century horror which Matheson is responsible for.  The story is a character study of Robert Neville--the last human being in a world entirely populated by vampires--and all of the existential implications that entails.  Very well-written, creepy, and thought-provoking.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2016
reviewComment: I wasn't very into this at first, found the prose to be a little wanting in those first chapters, but the more I read the more I got sucked in.  Far bleaker (and certainly more dated) than the Will Smith movie, it was a fast paced and tense read.  You can see the influence this book has had not only on the movies that have been based on it, but on the post apocalyptic and last man on earth genres as a whole.  If that's your kind of thing , I Am Legend is worth checking out.

review_title: ... you see the movie because it is so much better. If you liked I am Legend then check ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2017
reviewComment: Read the book before you see the movie because it is so much better. If you liked I am Legend then check out he other short stories in the Matheson collection.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2005
reviewComment: This is such a outstanding book. It is completely original and told in a unique way. The story is also keep short and this also was the right thing to do. I mean you can only go so long with a story about the only human left on the planet. Be forewarned this is without a doubt the darkest story I have ever read. This is not bad, on the contrary it really gives the story an atheneic feel. You really feel like you are there, like your looking through his eyes. Wow, how depressing and frightning.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2020
reviewComment: Dull, drawn out, boring & sexist.... I was hoping Neville would die a horrible death before I got through the first half of the book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2011
reviewComment: A great short story that stands the test of time.  As soon as you read the first page or two your hooked. It's incredible how Hollywood recently made such a bad film from a such a great short story.  Forget the movie, with the bad fx and acting and read this wonderful book, from the writer who gave us Nightmare at 20,000 feet (the gremlin on the plane wing), Steel (now Real Steal, with Hugh Jackman), Prey, A Stir of Echoes and What Dreams May Come, to name a few.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2015
reviewComment: No!!!! Internet connectivity is not at all working.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2014
reviewComment: Love my nook! It was everything I expected it to be. It is nice to lay in bed and read without disturbing my husband. I would order from this company again

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2013
reviewComment: Too fragile,  a similar Kindle is a little bit more expensibe but much better device, I recommend  Kindle without any doubt

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2013
reviewComment: yet again another software product that is poorly designed.  The basic functionality is not intuitive and the 'light' was dim and the reading pane was dull and lifeless.  The whole thing feels acts cheap.  I really wonder if the Executives at B&N actually use their products???? Who is doing human-machine usability?  Bad experience all in all...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2012
reviewComment: All of the bad reviews for this poor device got me a little worried about getting it.  Let me clear things up.  The guy who said you can't delete books from the nook is TOTALLY wrong.  In your library, all you have to do is double tap the book and hit archive.  And to people who say it can't do as many things as it should, it's an EREADER.  eREADERS are for reading.  If you want to listen to music, get an iPod.  Last time I checked iPod shuffles are like 50 dollars.  Trust me, I'm a musician and i love music too, but the nook without music is fine.  The same thing goes for games.  You get an ereader to read, not to play games.  iPads, iPhones, and iPod touches a great for games.  I have a nook and an ipod, an im surviving.  Now the only other bad thing I've really heard is that the glowlight hassle elope tears and holes in it.  I've only had mine for a few days so I can't say whether or not that will happen.  So far, it hasn't.

review_title: As good as book readers have become
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2020
reviewComment: For years, I have used Android tablets as readers because of their versatility. However, their lousy battery life is a constant irritant. I bought this reader for my wife in 2013 and she's barely used it, so I confiscated it, bought a different cover, and loaded it with books and linked it to my library accounts through my Windows PC. The battery life is terrific, several days of nearly constant use and I almost never turn it off. The back lighting is sufficient, if not exceptional. The screen resolution and contrast is as good as most paperback books.

review_title: software issues and lack of support make this a substandard product. look elsewhere
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
reviewComment: i've had this device for a year or so, but really only used it on vacation a few times. i charged it up the other day and discovered that it would not connect to my wifi. here is a short version of the events that followed:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2015
reviewComment: I currently own this and NSTes without the glow light.  The Kindle - gets all of the rave - and maybe it deserves it  - but I am not convinced.  I recently bough a second generation Paperwhite - but do not even like the way it feels in my hand - so - I went looking for the NST with glow light.  What I love about the NST is its simplicity - all functions that I need are delivered with one - maybe two clicks -  I also love that it readily reads ePubs and PDFs and has an expandable memory slot - making it easy root - which I have done only so that I can get the Kindle app.  I have not had any luck with that so far.  So, if you have rooted this recently and have the Kindle app- please advise.

review_title: So far very happy.  Got it on their sale for $69
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2013
reviewComment: So I really like eInk readers to read on.  We have tablets for pretty much every person in the family in multiple sizes... still, I prefer to read on a eInk reader.  I've owned a Kindle 2, and 3, & a Nook Classic, so this is my fourth eInk reader though I have had a grey scale reader, Libre Pro, which is similar in that it has no backlight but the contrast just doesn't compare.  Still even that is easier on the eyes for long length reading than the tablets.

review_title: A book lover is converted...I never thought that possible.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2015
reviewComment: For the first year I loved my Nook with glowlight and would have given it 5 stars without a second thought. I bought the one with the memory slot and LOVE that feature. The glowlight and memory card slot are what sold me to buy the Nook and not any of the other E-readers. I fought getting an e-reader for years as I love the look and feel of a real book in my hands. My library also has e-books I can 'check' out without leaving my home. Another fantastic feature! And with book sharing from Barnes and Nobles... I couldn't fathom why anyone would want to buy any of the others. Still don't for that matter. The glowlight, if you are a big time reader and like to read in bed next to a sleeping spouse, is perfection. The light isn't intrusive and my husband is finally able to sleep right through the soft glow in the room as opposed to reading on my cell phone with that light. The battery also lasts me through an entire night, even with the glowlight on.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018
reviewComment: Always a good read.

review_title: Classic Sherlock Holmes from the original on my Nexus 7
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2013
reviewComment: One of many free books to download to my Nexus 7, I'd always enjoyed the movies, educational channel series versions, but its reading the book that gives me the greatest please.  Simply reading and enjoying the published original stories.  Rediscover the classics, they're worth it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2015
reviewComment: I am a big Sherlock Holmes fan.  I lost this book a long, long time ago.  Imagine my surprise when I found it here, and for free!  It's an excellent read.  It might be something the "new generation" just doesn't like....  I suppose it's their loss.

review_title: Read the original and enjoy the greatest
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2015
reviewComment: Sherlock Holmes should be read by all. Many modern detective and crime solving shows (House, Psych, Wire In The Blood) use Sherlock as a basis for their characters. Read the original and enjoy the greatest.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2018
reviewComment: Excellent read! Doyle is an awesome writer.

review_title: Even if you have never read a Sherlock Holmes book and enjoy mystery novels
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2015
reviewComment: A must have for anyone who enjoys classic Sherlock Holmes. Rarely have I ever seen any kind of modern adaption that gives these original stories justice. The writing style is superb, the puzzles nearly impossible to solve before Holmes, a masterpiece of classic literature. Even if you have never read a Sherlock Holmes book and enjoy mystery novels, give it a try, definitely the best I've ever read. This is not a definitive collection, rather a collection of the most popular Holmes mysteries.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2013
reviewComment: With this book you have to keep in mind that all of the stories are ones that everyone has heard for years and years.  But, you have to go about this thinking of the times when they were written.  Coming at it from that perspective it makes it a lot of fun.

review_title: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is a genius! Every time ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2015
reviewComment: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is a genius!  Every time I read Sherlock Holmes I learn something new.  It's a phenomenal character with well-developed storylines.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2014
reviewComment: I love this book. It has proved to be well worth the few dollars as I could hardly put it down. I highly recommend this series of adventures to any and all who may have an interest in tales of mystery.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2018
reviewComment: Old time favrorite!

review_title: WWII impacts lives of women unexpetedly
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2016
reviewComment: Another look at the complexity of individual lives affected by WWII.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2007
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book. It kept we wondering what could possibly happen next.......

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2013
reviewComment: Started slow but progressed nicely.enjoyed it very much.well researched.gave me MUCH insight on covert workings of even friendly governments,and how it really uses up people.

review_title: I felt the storyline was weak.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2013
reviewComment: I chose this due to the fact that it will be on TV, but I felt the writing was not up to the standards that I would expect, and the storyline was weak.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2013
reviewComment: Not a very suspenseful book, had to force myself to finish it.  The daughter's story had no purpose except as an avenue to tell her mother's story, so, needles to say, the characters in her life were irrelevant, annoying, pointless.  The mother's story was somewhat predictable, not too surprising. I felt like I was constantly reading about changing buses or walking routes to avoid being followed or Eva and Romers love trysts.  It would have been interesting to find out more about Romer, how he came into his normal, upperclass life after killing everyone else and the war was over.  After all the killing he did, for him to kill himself in the end was too simple a way to end the book, a let down.  The description/write-up of the book was much more exciting than the book itself.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2015
reviewComment: A little slow and not to my liking. I finished it and think there are probably others who have read it who will totally disagree with me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2013
reviewComment: The movie encouraged me to read this book. I agree with many of the negative or lukewarm reviews about how the story is written. But one star for a Kindle version that no one on the sales side evidently has read. In many places one page is missing, so it not only interrupts the reading but leaves the reader wondering what is missing. Bad job.

review_title: Not as good as his other books
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2013
reviewComment: Again mostly written in the first person-cannot deal with stories written this way. Did not finish which is a shame because I have enjoyed William Boyd s work before.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2012
reviewComment: I should have down loaded the excert first.  Then I would have known that this was not a book I would have been interested in.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2015
reviewComment: How many of us believe that we know our own parents? Ruth Gilmartin tutors foreign students in English as a second language in 1970’s Oxford. Now a mom herself, she spend most of her off time caring for her four year old son, except for the one day each week when her own mother, Sally, takes care of him for her. One afternoon, Ruth arrives at Sally’s house to find her in a wheelchair, claiming to have suffered a fall. It’s clear that she’s bothered by something, but Sally’s not talking. Instead, she hands Ruth a manuscript to read when she has the time. This how how Ruth discovers that her mother isn’t Sally Gilmartin at all, but former Russian spy Eva Delectorskaya.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 4, 2015
reviewComment: It's OK

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 28, 2014
reviewComment: Just buy it

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 9, 2015
reviewComment: Great condition.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Spain on March 24, 2020
reviewComment: What a heart-warming and soulful book these authors have put together! Truly inspirational for everyone serious about personal and communal change, drawing from Systems Thinking, Spirituality, Organizational Theory and much more. A winner.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 6, 2010
reviewComment: Oh dear, what a disappointment.  What has happened to Peter Senge ?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 11, 2006
reviewComment: I was recommended this book as a serious book on new types of management practises.  The Theory U, one of the main themes of the book, may turn out to be so.  However, unfortunately the explanation of the Theory U is intervened in the book with lots of personal stories, many referring to their alledged personal experiences of various kinds of sychronicity experiences; quite jungian or new age in my opinion.

review_title: Holmes Comes to Life for Another Adventure
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2015
reviewComment: Horowitz has captured the spirit of Doyle and written a thrilling novel with a great ending tinged with sadness that Holmes is mortal and may not have many cases left.  It was wonderful being in Baker Street again and I thank Anthony Horowitz for that.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2015
reviewComment: Characters are believable as Watson and Holmes, the story is excellent, and the mysteries are compelling. Everything that one would want from a Holmes read

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2018
reviewComment: Did a very good job of following the style of Conan Doyle in writing Sherlock Holmes.  Not an easy task with a well known character.  Enjoyed the book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2017
reviewComment: Classic Holmes! Great job Mr Horowitz you made Arthur Conan proud!

review_title: Closest to Arthur Conan Doyle that I have ever found!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2015
reviewComment: This is an excellent book and you may pinch yourself, thinking that Arthur Conan Doyle had written it himself.  I loved every second of the book and if you love Holmes & Watson, read this one by Mr. Horowitz.  Doyle must be smiling.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2018
reviewComment: Excellent.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2017
reviewComment: This was a very well written Holmes novel.  After finishing it, I went to look for any other Holmes stories written by this author and also took out his novel The Magpie Murders.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2013
reviewComment: As a long time "Holmes addict" I was really grateful to read Mr. Horowitz's book.  I love all the detail and greatly enjoy reading about this era.  I also love and admire the work of Lee Jackson.  The historical knowledge of the time period brings these books to life.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2015
reviewComment: Great book. I totally loved it - kept me on the edge of my seat. Although, the ending came rather suddenly and I didn't like the whole idea about what happens at the House of Silk. Disturbing. But anyways, GREAT job Anthony Horowitz, it was better than I expected. And may I add... Great use of language. *lol, needed many dictionaries!! ❤ Alex Rider!!!! Even though it's off topic!!!

review_title: She loved it! Said it was true to the originals
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2018
reviewComment: Got this for my wife. She loved it! Said it was true to the originals.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2018
reviewComment: What an interesting book. I have never read anything like it. It was pretty awe inspiring. I really loved it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2019
reviewComment: A great reminder that God is in us, loves us, is willing to invest in us.  He never gives up on giving us grace.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2018
reviewComment: Absolutely amazing! A must-read for everyone. It held my attention all day I did not put it down except to get a bite to eat!

review_title: A religious (Christian but not born-again) novel.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2015
reviewComment: A religious (Christian, but not born-again) tome initially disguised as fantasy fiction.  Well written, on the surface, that is, the author writes well, but overly proselyting for my taste, although I agree with what the author says about what Jesus tried to teach us about how to live, but I have great reservations about the God parts, angels coming down to earth and intervening in events, etc.  So if you are into Christian (but not born-again - he slams the born-again types) novels, you will like it, I got bored, and put it down, read some other things, and picked it up again, and finished eventually.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2010
reviewComment: I finally finished "Rooms: A Novel" by James L. Rubart. If you liked "Shack" or "Pilgrims Progress" you will like "Rooms". Themes that it addresses for those of us who are Christians are choices and their consequences, God's grace, trusting God, and spiritual warfare.  Comes with a strong recommendation.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2015
reviewComment: I highly recommend this book. I won't spoil it by revealing the plot but this book will make you view your life in a way that makes it the valuable adventure in truth that it's supposed to be. Well written, great characters, great storyline, great adventure and it really makes you think.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2018
reviewComment: I enjoyed this so much hated for it to be finished. Good clean read. I highly recommend this book to believers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2019
reviewComment: Loved the story!! You can relate to your life!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2018
reviewComment: I don't generally like books involving the supernatural but this was a good change of pace and hard to put down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2015
reviewComment: Their are a few books that I hold in high esteem, to keep going over and over as I continue my journey to "Become more like Him". This I find to be loaded with spiritual nuggets to help with cleansing and healing along the way.  This is for everyone. Thank you James L. Rubart  for writing it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2019
reviewComment: The one I read was anything but modern English. I haven't finished thinking about it. Most impressed with where the author was when he wrote it! Seeing the movie, a good idea if you are old enough or undisturbed by images of Giants, for example.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2019
reviewComment: Being older, it read well and I can understand all of the symbolism I would have missed as a younger man on my walk with faith.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
reviewComment: Every Christian should read this book. Love that it include verses that go along with what happens in the story

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2020
reviewComment: Great allegories with tons of bible verses added to tie the stories to the bible

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
reviewComment: Many people I know have read this book and encouraged me to read it. I am glad I did. It is Biblically grounded and entertaining. The only criticism is the Scripture passages within the text were distracting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2016
reviewComment: Long ago I started reading the original version, but quit as it was tiresome and slow going.  I consider myself an eager and responsive reader of even some tough manuscripts, but for some reason that one beat me down.  I felt it was one classic I should not give up on, however, so when I saw the modern version listed I gave e it another go and am satisfied having read it through.  I am a true believer, and felt that some Biblical truths were stretched and even amiss, but overall was provoked and pricked by the simple faith examples that apply to my own relationship with the Lord.  I believe that anyone of faith who reads this, simple though they may find the text, will find themselves pondering how they stand within their own pilgrimage to the heavenly shore.

review_title: Must buy!!! This needs to be on your shelves !
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2020
reviewComment: This book came second to the Bible with that said it holds weight , it is by far my second favorite book over the Bible . Love how the author uses personification and it’s metaphorically genius . This book is a great guide to focus on the cross !! The 2019 cartoon movie version was awesome and by far one of the greatest movies I’ve seen to depict our Christian walk .

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2020
reviewComment: I always like to read books that have scripture embedded in the story. The writer surely helped with the understanding of the story. This is a book that many read as youngsters but I didn't have time to read it till I retired.

review_title: Great easy to understand explanition of the journey to living a Christian life.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
reviewComment: This version is easier for a person to understand the trials that a Christian must navigate in life. It is hard to believe that it was written over 300 years ago. Modern Christian writers sometimes have the tendency to make the journey to "The Celestial City" to be easier than it really is. There is so much more to being a Christian than just the initial moment of the realization of Christ's salvation, the trail is sometimes difficult but the journey is worth it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 29, 2020
reviewComment: Good book.  Bought as a gift.  Report back was 5 out of 5.

review_title: You've probably seen the movie(s)...so read the book!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2015
reviewComment: If you've seen any of the film adaptations (The Last Man on Earth with Vincent Price, Omega Man with Charlton Heston, or I Am Legend with Will Smith), you obviously have some idea of what you're in for -- if, like me, you've seen all three of them, you probably are curious to find out which is closest to Matheson's original story.  I won't spoil that for you, but I will say this is a very good read, and includes several short stories (some of which may seem familiar because they've been adapted for various TV shows over the years).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2017
reviewComment: I have watched all of the movies based on the"legend" concept..but this book is so much better than the movies...I was really hoping the ending would be different...He was born as a human and left this world a human...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2010
reviewComment: You'll recognize the ideas put forth in the stories in this book because Richard Matheson is one of the most copied authors of his time.  Many horror/thriller/spooky movies & TV episodes have borrowed his creepy ideas.  I Am Legend is very good, better than the 3 or 4 movies based on it in my opinion.  Just remember, half the book is I Am Legend, half the book is weird short stories, and there's basically no transition between the two, so if you're not looking for it it can be confusing : )

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2018
reviewComment: Brilliant prose that reads like a short story. Simple writing but hard to keep-up; pay attention or you'll miss the good parts!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2013
reviewComment: If you are expecting anything like the movie, then don't. The similarities to the movie stop after the name of the book and the name of the main character, Robert Neville. This book is great although not chilling or scary, but it brings the reader to another world in which the whole world has turned into a vampiric race. Most of the novel takes place in Neville's home and I would recommend this book to anyone that can read. 5/5

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2008
reviewComment: I didn't know this story existed until after the movie a friend of mine told me he had read it and wanted to see how they adapted parts to the movie.  And after reading it, I can attest that it was close to the story.  I can tell what was going through the character's head while he's alone, which is one thing that I like more about books than movies.  All in all, the movie was very close to the original story.  The book also come with a number of other stories, too.

review_title: So...that was nothing like the movie...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2017
reviewComment: Very fascinating story and odd experience having seen the movie first. I kept thinking I knew what was going to happen, but then it went in a different direction. The only thing the movie and the book have in common is the title. As usual, I prefer the book's story. It is as if people think movie watchers can't handle the truth.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2007
reviewComment: I AM LEGEND is a classic apocalyptic survivor (at least for a while) story.  When you consider that LEGEND was written in 1954, the story concept is even more outstanding.  It is very well written and fascinating in its charactor depth.  It is no wonder that LEGEND has been made into three successful movies.  If you have loved any of the movies, read the origional story.  You won't regret it.  The book also includes some short stories that are less outstanding.

review_title: Mostly engaging, but disappointing deus ex machina ending
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2012
reviewComment: This book moves about as fast as any 300+ page book I've ever read. That's the good part. It jumps right into the story with Neville isolated in a last-man-on-earth setting, able only to go outside during the day as factions of "living" and "dead" vampires prowl the night. There really are hardly any dull parts. There's one short chapter just of his thoughts that doesn't do much, but that's about the only slow part. And the book introduces a good amount of mystery as Neville tries to sort through the false parts of vampire legend versus the bacterial infection in the blood causing his current plight.

review_title: If you really enjoyed the movie, you'll be disappointed in the book.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2020
reviewComment: After seeing the movie many times, the book was a big letdown. Just a short story really weird ended very oddly. And then the rest of the book is more short stories that has nothing to do with the first story.

We were really disappointed but discovered that we could find better coupons once we got to the casino area we visited (like Vegas) and just picked up the local coupon pamphlets that are free everywhere.

review_title: It is great the first time you get it because most of ...

reviewComment: This is my 4th time buying this book.  It is great the first time you get it because most of the deals are for people who have not been to the casinos before, but if you already have a players card you can't use most of the coupons.

reviewComment: Going to Vegas next week and this thing is crammed with different coupons for all the casinos down there.  I am typically a slot player, because it takes no brains to do lol, but I have learned to play a couple card table games.  I like that it actually shows you break downs of the odds on all the games.  Very helpful!  Hopefully I come home a winner!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2018

reviewComment: This book paid for itself many times over. We used the buy-one-get-one-free coupons for almost every meal we ate over the week we were in Las Vegas.  The match play coupons allowed us to explore games we might not normally invest in. Overall a very good value.

review_title: Lack of Buffet coupons for the casinos on the Strip
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2018
reviewComment: Disappointed that there were not many buffet coupons for the Las Vegas Strip area.  95% of the buffet coupons were in other areas of Vegas like Boulder, Henderson, Red Rock, or North Las Vegas.  It also seems that the gaming coupons are not as good as they used to be.  May not buy the book next year.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2018
reviewComment: We've been buying this guide, mostly for Las Vegas coupons, for years.  Fortunately we stay downtown, rent a car, and love going to the local and more distant casinos.  Probably not worth getting is you're only interested in the LV strip casino coupons.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
reviewComment: The coupons aren't as good as they used to be, but they're still good. If you have a rigid itinerary in Las Vegas, it will be hard to use many coupons. But if you have free time and a rental car you can try some new places with a 2-for-1 buffet or a $10 free bet coupon.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2018
reviewComment: American Casino Guide 2018 is great. It has alot of buy one get one free meals at alot of the casino's in Las Vegas and other areas. Alot of information about every casino in every state of America. Well worth the money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2016
reviewComment: E-readers are rampant throughout the book loving community. As I looked for an e-reader I found numerous devices I could’ve purchased such as the Amazon Kindle, Kobo Aura, Barnes and Noble Nook, and Apple iBooks. Many people today are switching to e-readers as modern technology advances. As I searched for an e-reader, I settled on the Barnes and Noble Nook. My first experience with a nook was the Nook First-Edition which I owned for three years. I only upgraded to a Nook Simple-Touch with Glowlight after an incredible Black Friday sale brought the new one down to thirty-five dollars, and I sold my original nook for fifty. I love my purchase and am glad I decided to purchase an e-reader from Barnes and Noble.

review_title: When rooted I love it and the glowlight feature rocks!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2015
reviewComment: I ordered a used BNRV350 that had 3-tiny cracks on the screen and 1 medium length on the screen. I paid a measly $26 +s/h for a grand total of $36. I also have a new BNRV350 coming my way in a couple of days and I may update the review. In my technology arsenal I have/had/used a BNRV300 (no glowlight version), Ipad 2, Galaxy Note 2, Galaxy Notepro 12.2 and Galaxy Note 8 tablet.

review_title: Great reader, but be careful in the tropics!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2013
reviewComment: I purchased my Nook in January with the intent to use it for international travel.  It has been great - I appreciate that it is inexpensive, light-weight, durable, and easy to use.  I also appreciate how long it can go between charges, which is wonderful when electricity is not a certainty.  I have one observation for those considering its use in the tropics.  I was reading before going to sleep when all of my bunkmates turned off their lights.  As a result, the glowlight was the only source of illumination in the room.  This immediately attracted insects and the larger ones, such as the moths, were capable of turning the virtual pages by walking horizontally across the screen.  Then, one hit the screen so hard that it highlighted a word.  Another moth completed the next command and much to my astonishment, the definition of the word appeared on the screen.  Since it was impossible to continue reading, I turned off the glowlight and moved on to a more sedentary activity!

review_title: My First Nook is a winner!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2012
reviewComment: I've been using ereaders since 2009 and have owned multiple Sony's from the PRS-550 up to the T-1 as well as Kindle 2, Keyboard and touch and an iPad.  All of these have their strong points but so far my favorite brand has been the Sony, even though you can't beat the Kindle for ease of buying books.  However, most of my book purchases are not through the Kindle site and I side load to the readers using Calibre software.

review_title: Love it, no problems so far
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2013
reviewComment: I have been using this device for the last year and a half. I love it. I have had no problems; works like it should. I was surprised to see so many people had received defective devices and wanted to let you know that these are amazing ereaders and you can have a perfectly normal, blah experience like me. It is no better or worse than any other ereader out there. It is my second, so most of my review will be a comparison.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2014
reviewComment: My Kindle broke and I replaced it with an extremely cheap Nook.  Since then I have been extremely disappointed.  I only expect three things out of an e-reader and was shocked to learn that the Nook fails on two of the three counts.

review_title: It's a fantastic single purpose device!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2013
reviewComment: Many moons ago I bought my first Ebook reader, it was a "Rocket Book"!  I must have read hundreds of books on that little device.  It was just about perfect.  Small and light enough (size of a paperback, weight of a hardback) that I could hold it one hand, easy thumb controls, had a backlight for nighttime reading, I could read the screen in daylight (most of the time) and it stored a bunch of books.  Heck, it even had a stylus for lookup and markup.  The day the battery no longer held a charge a small part of me died with it...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2013
reviewComment: I waited a while and was very hesitant to buy this because of all of the negative reviews about the screen problems.  I have a lot of Nook books which I have been reading on the Ipad Mini but I do a lot of my reading at night and the backlight is too harsh for my eyes after working at a computer all day.  I finally decided to take the chance and purchased the Nook Glowlight.  I've had it for three weeks now and so far so good - though there is a little tiny pin hole on the screen.  I had asked the customer service person at BN about the problem and she said it was just a bad batch early on and the problem was fixed.  We'll see.  I did purchase the extended warranty just in case and figured if the screen does fail I'll just give up and use a clip on light.  I like the Nook.  I like the size, the feel and the page turn buttons.  I really hope this device holds up.  It deserves to have a good following - but BN needs to step up and commit to solving whatever is wrong.  If their devices are not selling well it's because they are lagging behind in the solutions and they are only hurting themselves.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2014
reviewComment: Overall the nook glowlight performed well as a simple reader.  However there were a few issues that has convinced me to move to a kindle.  Unfortunately I have invested a few hundred dollars into e books through B&N so I will keep my account so that I can re-read them.

review_title: More storage capacity than a Kindle but it requires effort to use
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2014
reviewComment: Got mine for a considerably cheaper price but it *still* wasn't worth what I paid UNTIL I rooted it. It's native software makes it (virtually) impossible to take advantage of the extra storage and its stock fonts make the screen far more difficult to read than need be.

I would recommend this book to any who would enjoy the original interpretation of Sherlock Holmes (not to be confused with the BBC version).  Great job, Mr. Horowitz!!

reviewComment: At first i was suspicious about buying this book as my mother was skeptical about another author interpreting the great detective. Though the book does not exactly sound like acd it sure was amazing. The best way for hardcore Sherlock fans to read this book is to think that the characters are somebody else. I would not recommend this book to first time Holmes readers as there are several references to various cases in the lexicon

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2015
reviewComment: Mr. Horowitz did an excellent job recreating Conan Doyle's style. It was modern enough to move quickly.  I look forward to reading his next effort.

reviewComment: With an excellent plot the author captures the tone, color and mores of the A. Conan Doyle writing style. This book is a vast improvement over the many bastardized and contemporaneous versions of the inimitable Holmes.

review_title: It would be a great idea when giving description of book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2018
reviewComment: I wish I could get refund on principle even if the cost was only $1.40.  From the start of the book, I did not appreciate use of the "F" word and other explicit details. It would be a great idea when giving description of book, there could be an indication of profane language and/or sexual content rating as used for movies.  Just a suggestion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2017
reviewComment: I read this for 2017 Popsugar Reading Challenge. The category is ‘an espionage thriller’. I borrowed this from the library and voluntarily reviewed it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2013
reviewComment: William Boyd's Restless won the Costa Novel Award in 2006, and when I found a copy in our small library in Sicily (it had probably been left by a guest), I decided I had to read it.  The reviews on the cover were effusive in their praise.  For example, The Times was quoted on the front cover as saying: "Boyd is a first-rate storyteller and this is a first-rate story . . . An utterly absorbing page-turner."

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2012
reviewComment: Unlike many of the current genre of "Spy Trillers", as one of the other commenters stated, this has the feel of a Graham Greene or John LeCarre. And unlike the most negative commentor, nothing is perfect, including opinions concerning the editing and length of a book. As one who favors more editing rather than less usually, my determination is that the editing is fine. I don't detect much "filler".  What is particularly unique about this book, is that the main characters are both females, a mother and daughter. Most of us, myself included, think of the intellegence business a a male profession. Hopefully, my view that women are the more compasionate and thoughtful regarding their lives, the story is primarily about what happens to those who do their duty, and have to live with it, the rest of their lives. As a combat pilot in Viet Nam, I willl live with my actions, loss of comrades, and the innocents I may have killed the rest of my life. Its akin to Post Traumatic Syndome, a word I did not know existed until recently. People who engage in activities that require dedication and in particular, human activities outside the norm represent a minority of the population.  I think the author touches on the subject of life after that period outside the normal existence, and living, or attempting to live a normal life. In this novel, which is placed inside the real historical world of events, most of the public is not aware, the author has written both a history of the individual being there.

review_title: Outstanding -- But Not a Genre Spy Novel
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2008
reviewComment: William Boyd's latest novel, "Restless," is an exceptional and wholly brilliant literary work on the theme of deception. It is also a compelling thriller, an intricate spy novel, and a fascinating work of historical fiction that uncovers little-known and embarrassing realities about the true relationship between Great Britain and the United States in the years immediately preceding the latter's entry into World War II. Don't pick up this book if you are looking for a genre-type spy novel. This is definitely not that type of book. This is an historically based literary novel concerning British espionage against the United States in three years leading up to Pearl Harbor.  If that appeals to you, you won't be disappointed. This book gets my highest recommendation, and is certainly one of the best books I've read all year.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2007
reviewComment: William Boyd's "Any Human Heart" is a modern classic and a revelation - one of my best reads ever - and his latest novel, "Restless", is irrefutable evidence that Boyd is a huge talent and clearly more than equal to the task of tackling different genres and coming away with winners all the same, and  firing from all cylinders. Deservedly, it went on to win the 2006 Costa Book (formerly Whitbread) Award but was inexplicably ignored by the 2006 Booker committee in a lean year if the horribly patchy shortlist is anything to go by.

review_title: Secrets and how they shape you
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2013
reviewComment: I wonder how I would feel if I visited my mother and found her paranoid, thinking someone was out to kill her and she hands me folders containing her memoir of her life as a spy. How would I deal with the knowledge that my mother's name is an assumed one, that she's not the placid ordinary mother and grandmother I've always known, and that she was part of a network of spies during WWII.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2008
reviewComment: William Boyd's "Restless" is an unusual spy novel.  The protagonist is a woman, Eva Delectorskaya, a multi-lingual Russian émigré recruited for the British Secret Service at the start of the Second World War in Europe in 1939.  Through several changes of identity, she has become Sally Gilmarten, a widow living in an out-of-the-way cottage near a small English village called Middle Ashton.

review_title: British Spy Novel --- Tops in Genre
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2007
reviewComment: This is a spy novel, not a thriller, and there is a real difference between the two genres.  Think John LeCarre and Graham Greene, not Robert Ludlum and Ken Follet.  With the spy novel, you have the ever-so-slow peeling of layers, deeper characterizaion, a frequent sense of foreboding and, until all is revealed, some confusion.  The thriller, in contrast, is the page-turning, up-all-night, action-packed adventure that you can't put down.  After finishing a thriller, you are likely to say "where can I get another fix," but not to reflect on what you have just read, and if you try, you may not remember and, if you do, it may not make sense.  With the spy novel, you may want to wait a while before reading another, but you will spend some time reflecting on what you've just read, and it provokes you in a more serious, literary way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2021
reviewComment: Lived Mr. Boyds writing style. He seemlessly moved back and forth in time without confusing the reader.  The characters came to life and I was quickly engulfed within the pages - a participant rather than an observer of the complex plot. The ending was a great surprise for me.  I will read Mr. Boyd again.

reviewComment: I am slowly collecting the Word Cloud Classics.  I love having a special copy of Sherlock Holmes for me to revisit when I am in the mood to solve some mysteries!

review_title: This is a classic must-read Christian book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2016
reviewComment: In this allegorical classic, Christian, who is the pilgrim, represents all that the author considers good Christians. He reads the Bible, the Hebrew Bible and New Testament, and feels that he is carrying a very heavy burden, and he seeks a way to unburden himself of this burden. He is encouraged by an evangelist to go to Mount Zion, and is promised that if he arrives he will be unburdened. The evangelist points out a gate and suggests that he go through that gate. Although his family, wife and children, beg him to stay, he covers his ears and leaves them. Neighbors try to dissuade him from his journey, but he rejects their advice. He is led by a secular man to Mount Sinai and this man tries to persuade him to ascend Mount Sinai and find at its top legality and morality, but the evangelical man returns and warns him that those who follow the way of Mount Sinai are “cursed.” Christian faces many difficulties, which the author Bunyan allegorically describes as the difficulties that Christians face on earth. For example, even as he reaches the gate, he is pulled through quickly and told that Beelzebub and his crew hurl missiles at those who try to enter the gate to stop them from doing so. He is then told to follow the straight path and not swerve to the right or left, to enticing by-paths. He is also told that he will have to bear the load on his back until he comes to “the place of Deliverance for there it will fall from your back of its own accord.” On his way, he meets the Interpreter who teaches him that he must despise everything in this world. He emphasizes again that the law “defiled” man: “when the commandment came, sin revived.” So begins the journey of Christian.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2015
reviewComment: Shawnee Captive is a short novel that has enough verifiable historical research to give an outline to the under-written time period just before the French and Indian War. When the town of Staunton was mentioned early on, I figured that must have been a slip. Indeed, however, Staunton may have been the town's name as early as 1747. The names ring true with historical record and one of the most important facets of historic fiction or historic nonfiction is erasing all history that has happened since the time period being recorded. There is no anachronism here. I understand the author died in 2004, but she should be applauded for her attention to historic record in this novel.

review_title: I might like this product, later on, but not B & N customer service
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2014
reviewComment: I've spent so much time with B & N customer service, I haven't had as much time as I'd like to learn all the features of the Nook Simple Touch. The first day I spent registering it, learning how to access the features, accessing our Wi-Fi, etc. Only after I learned how to turn on the GlowLight did I realize it had a defective display screen and obviously I needed to return it. After calling their customer service, then attempting to explain the problem to a woman who, I assume, understood me better than I understood her, she agreed that I needed it replaced. This phone call seemed to go on for an hour or so, with my trying to understand what she was telling me about their detailed instructions for returns and replacements by mail. In frustration, I finally asked if I couldn't simply return it to their store. After checking, she said they didn't have any in stock.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2014
reviewComment: I have had my Nook Simple Touch with Glowlight for two years now. It really is great, and has a super lightweight feel to it. I love the simplicity of it and the backlight has made a huge difference than a regular e reader with no light. However, the screen is EXTREMELY delicate. I had my Nook for less than a month when I dropped a pen on the screen accidentally, and a nick in the screen was left behind. It seems like the simplest of dings screw up the screen, and it becomes very distracting when there is a bright light leaking out of a nick in the screen. However, as long as you are careful with it, it shouldn't be a problem. I'm not rough with my Nook in any way (I have used my leather case for it since I bought the Nook and have never taken it off), but I am clumsy and that could be why I have screen damage. Another thing is after two years, my Nook is INCREDIBLY slow and glitchy. Mind you, I have only bought about twenty books on here and yet it still freezes or an error message appears almost every time I try to shop for a new book. The Nook also freezes often on the book I am reading, and I have to force it to restart (if it doesn't restart on its own which also happens occasionally). All in all this Nook is super functional and great, but apparently two years is it's lifespan. It's a good e reader for beginners or even those who aren't familiar or aren't looking for complex technology. However, you do get what you pay for in this instance and this Nook definitely is not built to last or have a memory capacity like the newer models of e readers. It's a great buy and is not a money pit like some reviews would have you believe, but if you are looking for a durable e reader that you won't have to replace for a good while definitely dish out the extra cash and invest in the Nook HD or even a Kindle Fire.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2013
reviewComment: I have had the 2nd and 3rd generation kindle, and the Kindle Fire HD in the past. I currently have an iPad mini, so I have the Nook and Kindle reading apps for that. But I have to say that I most enjoy the reading experience on my Nook Simple Touch with GlowLight. My iPad is nice, but honestly I'm on a computer all day at work so my eyes tend to get tired a lot quicker looking at another computer screen, for all intensive purposes. The Nook is much easier on the eyes, and I love how light it is to hold! I do not have mine in a case when I am reading, I bought a padded zippered pouch like holder for when it is not in use and it works well for protecting it while traveling.  I love the feel of the naked Nook. The curved back and rounded corners give it a very organic book like feel. The rubberized texture of the back gives it a nice feel too.  Sometimes I almost forget I'm not reading a real book!  The built in light is great, especially for those nights when my husband is ready to go to sleep and I want to read 'just a little bit longer.'  The light doesn't bother him at all and it's perfect for me to read in the dark. It's nice to be able to do so without the clunky clip on book lights of the past.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2014

Yeah the physical aspects of the Nook are OK, as are most other readers.  What it does lack is any efficient way of organizing the books.  The software interface is incredibly awkward and clunky.  I thought the Sony inteface was bad, but at least you could manipulate books on the computer quickly and easily, and then sync that with the reader.  I don't need a device that is 1/2 oz lighter or a tenth of an inch thinner.  I need one which has a useful gui interface.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2020
reviewComment: I thought this was a book about Mary ingeles, Laura ingeles Wilder sister

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2006
reviewComment: Over the last twenty years, William Boyd has, for me, been among the most consistent writers of narrative fiction.  There have been books that will stand the test of time (New Confessions) and ones that already seem dated (Stars and Bars), but Restless finds him in good form.  Boyd, as flexible as ever, turns his attention to the spy genre.  We are presented with a double narrative, mother and daughter.  The plot is hampered by a slightly overwrought literary device, the mother doling out her diaries at intervals, conveniently allowing the author to flip back and forth in time.  Still, Boyd remains a wonderful writer.  His characters are incisive, full blooded and captivating, even the ones we're not supposed to like.  Boyd, like McEwan, manages the perfect blend of literature and thriller and Restless reads very quickly.  That alone is a reason to buy it, but add in the Paris of 1939, spymasters and double dealings and Boyd is on to another winner.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2013
reviewComment: I just finished this book, and I highly recommend it to fans of the "spy story". I see that some reviewers have complained that most of the characters are one-dimensional; I believe that was deliberate, to make the main character stand out in higher relief. I enjoyed the device of the diary, peeling back the past a bit at a time, leaving the reader eager for the next installment. I also found that knowing in advance that Eva survived her adventures in WWII did not noticeably lessen the tension for me when her memoirs revealed times of danger; I still was on edge to see HOW she survived.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2007
reviewComment: Ruth is a single mother who teaches English as a second language in Oxford, England.  One day her mother hands her the first installment in her autobiography, and Ruth discovers that everything she thought she knew about her mother's background is a lie, and that her mother was actually a secret agent by the name of Eva, who worked for the British immediately prior to and during WW2.

review_title: A very very very very VERY good book
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2007
reviewComment: Always excepting John Le Carré, I'm not ordinarily a big fan of spy stories -- but this one is a considerable exception. Ruth Gilmartin is a late-twenties single mother and tutor at Oxford in 1976 who has a somewhat prickly relationship with her aging but still very sharp widowed mother, Sally. Then one day Sally tells her daughter her real name is Eva Delectorskaya and that she was a Russian émigré recruited by the British Secret Service in 1939. Ruth has doubts about her mother's mental state but the vividness of her extremely detailed memoir -- passed to Ruth episodically -- convinces her. The thing is, Sally is sure someone is planning to kill her. The chapters alternate between Sally/Eva's third-person narrative and Ruth's quiet life teaching English to foreign engineers and businessmen, with Eva doing things as a yong woman in pre-Pearl Harbor Europe and the U.S. that her daughter -- now about the same age -- can hardly believe. Both women are fully three-dimensional, and so is Lucas Romer, the spymaster with his own agenda, with whom Eva fell in love. Boyd also does a terrific job elucidating the propaganda war Britain fought to try to get America into the war, planting false news stories and disinformation to sway public opinion. James Bond this ain't. A remarkable and riveting book with an extremely realistic non-Hollywood ending.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2007
reviewComment: I'm not much of one for so-called "spy novels," but this gripping story almost made me a convert.  It is the premise of the story that gives it such zip, in addition to fine writing by the author.  Think of a situation where it turns out your own mother is entirely a different person, that is has a different background, that you had been led to believe by her, and in fact she had been a spy before and during World War II. Add to this her fears that she is in danger after all these  years (the novel is set in 1976) and this leads her to "come clean" with you.  More I will not reveal but it is, at points, a real "page turner."  The book shifts back and forth between the mother's spy career and the present day activities of her daughter--and this does tend to slow things down a bit.  Also there are some superfluous subplots involving the daughter which also dilute the action sequences on occasion.  Nonetheless, there are stretches where the book is simply gripping and one becomes entirely engrossed in it.  A highly unique premise and a most stimulating story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2006
reviewComment: At this point in his career, I don't know if Boyd is capable of writing a bad book. With his past work he's shown himself to be a writer at ease in multiple locations and time frames, and here he plays to that strength with a narrative moving back and forth between 1939 Paris and 1976 England. The story starts in the latter, where single mother Ruth Gilmartin is given a rather shocking manuscript by her aging, Cotswold village-dwelling mother, Sally. It's a well-worn adage that we can never truly know our parents, and Ruth is given prime evidence of this, as her mother's manuscript reveals her true identity. The sharp, white-haired, garden-tending widow grew up as a White Russian émigré in Paris, and was recruited into the British Secret Service in 1939.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2012
reviewComment: But I have to with this one.  This reminds me of Graham Greene's "The Human Factor".  Not a crackling, action packed spy thriller but one that keeps one transfixed nonetheless.  The secret is in the author's attention to detail, yet it's not overly wordy.  The characters are multi-dimensional yet not overly exposed; there's still room for the reader to to read into the character what one chooses.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2007
reviewComment: Boyd runs two stories in parallel, like the literary spymaster that he is: the first is set in 1939, the story of Eva Delectorskaya, a beautiful and resourceful British agent who is in danger of uncovering a Philby-like mole.  The second is set in 1976 and focusses on Ruth, who suddenly discovers her mother is not Sally Gilmartin (nee Fairchild) but the formidable Eva.  Sally/Eva, although now in her sixties, runs Ruth as a spy, feeding her the story of her life in the hope that she can use her to help her find the man that betrayed her more than thirty years before.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2014
reviewComment: William Boyd has produced another great novel set in two eras and involving a mother and daughter's efforts to understand the past.  You could call "Restless" a double romance as the reader is also lead through a parallel set of complex relationships in which each woman has become entangled.  There is lots of action and intrigue as well as very well worked period settings spanning both sides of the Atlantic.  Boyd is a very versatile and talented writer who can successfully turn his hand to any number of different fictional genres, it seems.

review_title: A New Author For My Reading List
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2011
reviewComment: William Boyd was recently recommended to me. *Restless* was the only available audio book I could locate and it was a good introduction.

review_title: Buy this before your Vegas trip
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2010
reviewComment: Each year we buy 1 American Casino Guide for each person in our party going to Vegas. Before going, cut the coupons for the Free slot play, Match Play and any others that look interesting. One day of our trip is coupon day. We use the GPS we brought on the trip and scoot from casino to casino using the above valuable coupons at the slots/crap table or blackjack table. We go in, get a players card, for a $10 match play coupon, buy $10 in chips, place the coupon and the $10 in chips on the table and if we win we get back our $10 chips plus $20 more. Our last trip in July 2010 we won far more than we lost on these coupons. It was fun visiting a lot of different casinos and seeing a lot of Vegas. These coupons more than pay for the cost of the guide and once you do what I've described you may also make this a tradition on your trips to Vegas.....Note, the coupons are good once per year per casino; you can't go twice during a 12 month period and use the same coupon at that casino from another American Casino Guide. Besides the coupons, the guide has a lot of info on the various games, casinos, points of interest ect..... Buy it well before your trip and read it. Plan your trip and enjoy.

reviewComment: The coupons for free play get worse every year but it's still worth it.  I won $1200 off the free play coupons last year and $85 this year.  Which still makes it a good investment.  Plus it is very informative and a good reference to use if you like to gamble.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2013
reviewComment: I originally bought my wife a BeBook several years ago, mainly because of the format compatibility.  It eventually went to her mother, leaving my wife without an ebook.  I looked and looked and looked trying to find something comparable but could not find anything.  That was until I ran across the Nook Simple.  The Nook Simple had external storage, meaning I could expand it's storage with an sdcard, it was compatible with several of the formats that are popular and in use almost everywhere (epub, pdf, txt, etc.).  But the real deal maker was when I found the Nook Simple with the Glowlight option.  This is an amazing feature that provides just the right amount of light for you to read by, whether you are laying in bed at night, sitting in a car in the middle of the day and anywhere in between.  You can adjust the brightness from just a hint of light (good for reading late at night) up to somewhere close to a mini sun behind the text.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2012
reviewComment: Started out with a Nook Simple Touch, but my eyes aren't what they used to be so I gave that to my wife & got the Simple Touch with Glowlight 4 months ago.  I am 98% happy with it- it loses a point for occasionally going back to the screensaver when I press the Glowlight button, and one point for occasional ghosting in extremely bright sunlight.  Both complaints are trivial, as the Nook's good points far outweigh the bad.

review_title: Cracks in Back-lit Screen and WRETCHED Customer Service
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2014
reviewComment: I hate this product. Actually, you know what? I don't hate the product, because with one exception, it's not so bad - I hate the Barnes and Noble Customer Service that came WITH this product.

review_title: This Is Representative Of An American Product & Service?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2015
reviewComment: What a hassle. Two Nook basics. One without and one with Glowlight. My failures caused the screen to freeze displaying a Salvador Dali like scribble of lines and patches. Used the NOOK charger. Never left my bedside. There are no motors,magnets or anything else with fifteen feet that could have caused this. Had a real nightmare with Barnes & Noble about updating my ship to address. Five years and what, seventy tries online and the site defaulted t my old address. Called customer service. "Oh I am correcting that right this minute" a young man said as I could hear keyboard strokes over the phone. Two weeks later they shipped a replacement to the old address. They want a hundred dollars for a gizmo that costs as much as some basic smart phones. And it breaks. The phones are still working, taking images, playing music but the NOOK cannot display print and chew gum at the same time. Don't even bother going to the B&N site for book reviews. It is a drop box for drug dealer messages. Barnes and Noble is setting themselves up for a Chapter 13.

reviewComment: About a year ago, I bought this device after extensive research and reading of reviews.  This was going to be a replacement for my Sony Touch 600 that got broken and I was really interested in the glowlight technology.  B&N didn't have a store near me at the time, and I wanted to physically handle the Nook so I went to Best Buy.  I played around with it for over 30 minutes and fell in love.  I bought a case with a hard screen cover and once I got it home, loaded books, and blissed out for about a week.  If this is where the story ended, it would easily be a five-star review.

I have to keep hitting the book symbol in upper left corner to go back to the page.

reviewComment: in no way comparable to the movie with Will Smith. This story is far more realistic and therefore darker, better. Despite the fact that it was written in the fifties, it explains many dogmata of the vampire genre in a very plausible way. Never knew a good explanation why vampire fear the cross or garlic, now I know. More than that, Matheson explains also the origin of vampirism and it sounds real.

review_title: And they died unhappily ever after
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2013
reviewComment: So this is about the 10th "last man on earth" (its always a man isn't it, funny) novel that I have read, and I would have to say this is one of the best one so far.  I went into this novel having seen the Will Smith movie, and not liking it so much.  I think the deal is this:  If you like the movie, you won't like the book, and vice versa.  I wondered how I would like a novel where the human race has be destroyed by vampires, rather than zombies, nuclear war, or plague, but I would have to say, I think that for the context of this novel, it matters not at all how the human race was extinguished, it just was, and was replaced with vampire-like beings.  The book reminded me a lot of 'The Road' by Cormac McCarthy, in that the main focus of the novel is this how this last man deals with being alone on earth with little or no companionship.  The book is a touch dated because it was written in the 60's, the vampires are a bit cliched and his views on women and sex are almost funny at times (for example, the female vampires try to lure him out of his house by being naked, and he sits inside and pounds his fist to the walls and drinks and can't look outside for fear of being lured out of the house for cheap sex).  What I really liked about this novel, and why I gave it 5 instead of 4 stars, is it deals with so much, in so little space, its not a long novel, but it has a lot of depth, and its very accessible.  The main character is your typical every day normal guy (I don't think it even said what he did before, other than "he worked at a plant", I assume nuclear power plant?  So he is Homer Simpson then?).  I'm sure you could sit down and pick this novel apart for its cliches and silly vampireisms, but in the end, you turn quickly from page to page, desperately wanting something to go right for this guy, and of course, you know it can't.  He is the last human alive, surrounded by vampires, alone.  Simply put.  He is Legend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2012
reviewComment: Matheson's take on the vampire legends is a quantum jump beyond the nightmarish images conjured by writers from Bram Stoker to Anne Rice, yet presents an even more profound nightmare. A man, Robert Neville, imperfect, realistic and brave in the face of overwhelming circumstances, refuses to abandon hope even though he recognizes the very real possibility that he may be the last of his kind. Neville's desperate grasping at one last hope leads to an unexpected and provocative ending, leaving the reader with a glimpse of primal imperatives rarely sensed in literature attuned to modern, sophisticated sensitivities. It is a reminder that the word, sophisticated, is derived from the same root as sophistry.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2019

It's the sort of story that haunts the reader long after it's over, and unlike the movie, the book makes sense.

Not a bad read for a Christian who wants a parable like reminder of some convicting and encouraging truths.
