reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2014
reviewComment: I read the whole book, though I was never really into it. The ind\side of the cover says that this is the first time in 125 years that the Doyle estate has allowed the publication of a new Holmes novel. They must really need the money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2016
reviewComment: I believe that Horowitz did a wonderful job recreating the Sherlock Holmes of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.  The story is compelling and a must read for fans of Sherlock Holmes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2012
reviewComment: I wasn't sure what to expect of a Holmes story not written by Doyle, but since it was authorised by his estate I jumped on it, and I'm glad I did! Captures the mood and setting and mystery of a Holmes story, and leaves you wanting more!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2012
reviewComment: some of this novel had the snap and wit of Sherlock Holmes but generally it was plodding. Much of the scenes in London seemed to be a little too contrived and too close in distance. And the villain was predictable.

review_title: Nice copy and sender was right on top of the delivery even though ugh it was late!,
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2017
reviewComment: Nice book and good service

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2012
reviewComment: As one of Watson's never-told tales, this story, while well written, does not quite reach the level of Doyle's writing. Nevertheless it is a good read and covers 'unmentionable' issues that sadly were doubtless an important part of Victorian England.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2012
reviewComment: This was my first audio book and will not be my last.  An excellent story read by an excellent reader.  My husband and I listened to it as we drove from Illinois to Florida.  It made the trip fly by!  Now we have to find a book for the return trip!

review_title: "One day someone will come and kill me and then you'll be sorry"
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2006
reviewComment: Alternating between 1976 and the years 1939 to 1941, Restless is an engrossing and compelling literary thriller set in Oxford, and London, and also in Canada and the United States. A truly international accomplishment, the novel tells of an era where British Special Forces and spy networks were bought and sold in an environment where no one is who they seem, and where international humiliation was to be avoided at any cost, regardless of the consequences to the lives of loyal individuals.

review_title: Finest spy novel I've ever read.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2009
reviewComment: Cannot fathom the 4 stars reviews; especially the reviewer who states: "plot is hampered by a slightly overwrought literary device, the mother doling out her diaries at intervals, conveniently allowing the author to flip back and forth in time."  The device is brilliant.  You want to read straight forward and mundane, well, stick to Ludlum or Silva or whomever.  The discerning reader will note the author's subtlety and craft.  His slight of hand if you will.  The slow way the substance of the tale is revealed.  It's like being lost in a forest.  You believe you know which path to take out.  The sun is shining.  You come upon a meadow here, a brook there.  No, wrong way.  It is only when all is revealed and you are safely out that you say, well, I knew where I was all the time.  But, you didn't.  Boyd never disappoints.  I stumbled upon him long ago when I read The Ice Cream War.  His novels are all dissimilar.  He's vastly underrated because he's so accessible.  I cannot wait to see what he gives us next.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2015
reviewComment: I always like Boyd's work, and Armadillo is one of my favorites.  The one critical thing I can say is that things are rather unresolved at the end of his novels...but maybe that is a good thing.  He leaves us wanting more.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2012
reviewComment: This is a very well written book and it is also a real `page turner' as well. The author has a great ear for dialogue and the writing is also very descriptive.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2008
reviewComment: I listened to an unabridged audio version of this book, and I can't say for sure how much I loved it because of the excellent quality of the reading, and how much I loved it for the characters and story.  The mother-daughter storylines are somewhat imbalanced, but they have to be.  The mother's story is revealed to the daughter who has to make sense of it in the midst of her own, complicated, young adult life.  One character's narrative is completed (or is it?), while the other's is temporarily explored, midstream.  There is a satisfying conclusion for one storyline, and merely a stopping place for the other.  Somehow, these two add up to a compelling combination, like the mixed flavors of sweet and tart in a very good cherry pie.  Yum.

review_title: Great to find something from a new author.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2013
reviewComment: I had not read anything by William Boyd before, now I'm going to get the rest of the books he has written.

review_title: Much better than the TV version
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2013
reviewComment: Set in 1976, Restless is really two stories for the price of one. The daughter is, I suppose, the protagonist, writing in the First Person and discovering - much to her surprise - that the mother she has always known had a very different life during the Second World War.

review_title: as usual, Boyd delivers a terrific story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2009
reviewComment: 'Restless' contains two narrative threads, one modern (mid-1970s) and the other circa 1940, that are interlaced as alternate chapters.  In the modern segment we had a young mother trying to sort out her life, and is coping with an increasingly odd-acting mother who announces that she is not who she thinks is; in fact she is a Russian-born WW II spy.  In the pre-WW II thread we see how this woman became a spy and what sort of spying she actually did.  Both narrative threads blend together beautifully; the book is immensely readable.  It all comes together with a satisfying conclusion.

review_title: Fascinating fiction about little-known World War II spy efforts.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2006
reviewComment: When Ruth, a single mother and teacher of English as a Second Language, goes to Middle Ashton to visit her mother, Sally Gilmartin, in 1976, she receives a surprise.  When Ruth is ready to go home, Sally gives her a folder entitled _The Story of Eva Delectorskaya_.  Ruth has never heard of Eva--until her mother stuns her by announcing, "I am Eva Delectorskaya."  Sally believes that someone is trying to kill her, and she wants Ruth to help her find Lucas Romer, her former boss in a British spy agency, during World War II.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2009
reviewComment: I really enjoyed this book even though I was not expecting to. The author blended history and present moments really well. Most books I have read that jump back and forth through time is confusing but I looked forward to the contrast between the mothers life and the daughters current one. Each detail of the mothers life as a spy was so given at a descent enough pace to keep me hooked until it was all laid out in front of me.The two stories he told blended quite well. It has always amazed me what parents were willing to do and did to protect their country and most of the time the children never knew the extent of the sacrifice that was made. The author gave good details without overwhelming the story and by the end the daughters character had actually matured by the things she learned about her mother. Because the story was being told from the daughters point of view and the mothers story as secondary it keeps your focus on the present day. Neither character overwhelms the story line. I would reccomend this book to any one who wants a quick lesson in WWII espionage and how it still affects the people involved to this day. The war has not ended for those individuals and won't til the day they die. It is definitely going on my read again shelf. The only aspect that was not needed was the information on the main characters ex and his brother. There was really no conclusion to their story line and I had to wonder why he included them. I would have liked to see more information or a followup to the characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
reviewComment: I definitely enjoyed reading this, but the end felt uncomfortably rushed.  The rest of the story had such character that was not present in the closing.  Not at all like the Will Smith film, and makes me want to re-watch the Heston version(especially since I haven't seen it as an adult).  All in all I am glad to have read I AM LEGEND.  It does sort of leave me missing Robert.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2018
reviewComment: Read the book years ago decided to get the audible version

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
reviewComment: Loved it, great book a mush read

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2003
reviewComment: I have to say that this book was a pleasant surprise. A nice vacation from reading about the romatic vampire, or the postmodern vampire who is a rockstar and is far too effeminate to take seriously. Matheson's vampire is a filthy corspe who is not quick footed or witted and is basically a zombie only the passion is for blood and not brains. The struggle of the protagonist Neville is both heartfelt and realistic. A great book from beginning to end!

review_title: Slower than expected,  no big surprises, not very compelling
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2015
reviewComment: There was a nice, if poorly reasoned, action scene towards the beginning, and was all down hill from there.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2020
reviewComment: This novel may be short but is a fascinating look at isolation and survival existence. It has a message later seen on Twilight Zone which Mathewson's name has also been credited too.

review_title: Not Exactly What You Pay for
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2007
reviewComment: The book basically consists of many different stories with I Am Legend in the beginning. There are over 300 pages in the book but only the first 160 pages are I Am Legend.  After page 160 Matheson dives into about 10 or so shorter stories which have nothing to do with the main title of the book.  I enjoyed I Am Legend and I found the short stories amusing but I found it kind of disappointing that I thought I payed for a full book about I Am Legend.  I feel a little cheated considering the cover and the back of the book give no indication that the story only lasts for half the book.  I would recommend to buy but just understand that the whole book has more than the main story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2018
reviewComment: Amazing example of what it is - a piece of survival-focused post-apocalyptic fiction with a hint of suspenseful horror. Personally, I found the slow build a little slow, but that's in comparison to the much more pulpy modern stuff I usually read.

review_title: One of the greatest books I've ever read
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2015
reviewComment: I have long been a fan of Richard Matheson's tv work on the twilight zone.  Also I've watched ever film version of this story from Vincent price to Will Smith and never was that impressed. Finally I got around to reading this and my word was I shocked. Not only was it a much scarier than any movie version it was much more complex in the way it made you feel. It was as if you were there with Neville as an observer.  Like I said this is my first Matheson book but it surely won't be my last.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2014
reviewComment: When is it ok to kill?  To torture?  To exterminate?  What does it mean, to be a monster?  Under the outer shell of a horror classic, this work actually forces us to answer the not so easy questions on morality, ethics, and the difference between right and wrong.  Perhaps most disturbingly, it seems like the difference is merely a matter of perception.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2013
reviewComment: I bought this e-reader right before my vacation to Punta Cana.  I was able to read using this on the beach, even with the bright sunlight glaring down.  The glowlight works awesome and you can even adjust the brightness.  The screen itself is a little bit sluggish, but this is because it's e-ink.  This is normal.  I'm glad I made this purchase and would buy again.

review_title: Problems with Nook response to touch
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2013
reviewComment: I have a nook with glolight and in general it is fine. Increasingly, howeve, it freezes up for no reason and I have to completely shut it down to get it to work. This increasing insensitivity is concerning because I have an older model Nook without glolight and its screen is now completely insensitive. No matter what I press the Home page comes up. If I can get into the Settings mode to try and connect with a new wireless network, whenever I try to type in a new password, no matter what key I press, the key to the far left of that row lights up.Booooooooo

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2019
reviewComment: Touch screen does not work if slightly warmed by the sun. The scrolling buttons do not always work and sometimes is stuck. The plastic has degraded completely after several years with almost no usage. It is just a low quality Chinese crap.

review_title: Screen develops bright white spots for no apparent reason
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2012
reviewComment: I have had two previous generations of NOOKs before getting the NOOK Simple Touch with Glowlight (NSTGL) about three months ago.  I don't buy ebooks; I either check them out from the library or get free public domain books.  The NOOK is a great device for that.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2014
reviewComment: I like my Nook GlowLight, but do not like BN's current deceptive marketing of magazines by listing them within "BN's Top 100."  It used to be convenient to use the 100 list to select books, now every other listing is a magazine rendering it useless for finding books.  This practice shows BN is not interested in serving my needs, rather it joins BN's marketing efforts with the shoddy, age old deceptive sales practices of the magazine industry, slipping them in under the radar within what appears to be a book list.  When it's time to replace my Nook, I doubt if I'll stay with a BN product for this reason.  Shame on BN!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2014
reviewComment: My husband just love this , he reads it everyday , love the glow light so when its bedtime he doesn't disturb me , great deal , would recommend to everyone ,he has had it for about 5-6 months and has had to only charge twice ,  great product !!!!!!!!!!

review_title: I wish I had three thumbs! All Up!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2014
reviewComment: The little lady sleeps with it almost every night. She loves the reader and is very happy with it so far. Without the glow light or connected to wifi it can go weeks. She uses the glow light at night (every night) and still gets days of use without charging. Scored major points for this purchase.

review_title: I WISH I'D KNOWN BEFORE I PURCHASED!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2015
reviewComment: I bought my 14 year old stepdaughter a Nook as a graduation gift.  Although I LOVE my Kindle I thought she would like something different, so I got her the Glowlight.  I purchased a gift card and was just setting up an account when I discovered I had to have a credit card on file - even though there is a gift card registered to the account!  A just finished chatting with customer service and was told that the credit card is required in order for the order to go through electronically.  I was not happy about that, but okay fine.  I will just set up the account so it will not charge my credit card if the gift card balance goes to low.  Guess what - YOU CAN'T DO THAT!!  You can password protect the device for purchases - which will keep someone else from purchasing if you lose it; but that same password allows access to the credit card on file if you don't have enough of a balance on the gift card.  I am thinking of selling this and getting her a Kindle, which I myself have been perfectly happy with.  Should have gone with my first instinct and bought a Kindle in the first place.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2012
reviewComment: I have changed my review of this product from 5 stars to 0 stars. I was in love with this thing at one point in time. However, it has a horrible defect that I just cannot live with. If you sideload your books (add your own books to a memory card instead of purchasing from Barnes and Noble), everytime you turn the device completely off and on (like in the event of it freezing, like mine's has done more than once) all of your shelves (like collections on Kindle) will erase. Disappear, your shelves are empty. It also happens if you disconnect your Nook from your Macbook the wrong way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2010
reviewComment: This book is so good I bought 4 of them to utilize all the great coupons.  The first half of the book is a great "how to" guide for all casino games. We spend 3 mths every year in Vegas and I use the extra books so our guests can also use the coupons. Using just 1 buy 1 get 1 free coupon pays for the book, and after that it's profit.  It has great information on hotels, and on all the free attractions, many great discount or buy 1 get 1 free food coupons, match play coupons, Show coupons. You can't beat the value anywhere!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2010
reviewComment: I have been using the American Casino Guide for years and have saved megabucks.  There are many buy one get one free restaurants throughout the country at various casinos as well as the majority of coupons for Las Vegas. Having used this book every year, I can tell you the best of the best in places that you would never think of going.  It is very helpful and imperative that you have a car to use the book.  It could get very costly if you had to take public transportation or taxis. We have found that one of the best buffets in Las Vegas is the Saturday or Sunday Brunch at the Silverton where you have a buy one get one coupon.  In two words, buy it!!

review_title: More than that it contains enough great coupons to pay for itself
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2018
reviewComment: This book contains lots of valuable information about casinos throughout the country. More than that it contains enough great coupons to pay for itself . We really enjoy using the 2 for 1 buffet coupons, we buy at least one book every year.

reviewComment: Great casino information including maps, games and tables. Coupons hard to find for popular casinos.

review_title: Great info for Vegas and other casinos from an insider's perspective
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2009
reviewComment: I've purchased this book several years running and it contains a lot of information about gambling strategy including how to place your bets, payouts, types of slot machines and how they work, etc.  I initially bought the book for the coupons, which are good, but found the background information just as valuable.  The book is cheap, and well worth the money, even if you only use a couple of coupons.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
reviewComment: A waste of money. You don't need this.

reviewComment: I purchased 2 of these books for our July trip to Vegas because there were 4 of us.  There are many coupons in here.  We did not use that many but I still felt it was worth it.  The problem is that many of the free play coupons are for new sign ups and I already have player cards at most of the casinos.  We did like the coupon for the Rio buffet and if you don't have a Venetian player card that coupon is great.  Many of the coupons are for off strip so be aware of that.

reviewComment: Some interesting reading information in the book, but we found ourselves going out of our way to try to use the coupons, just to try and get our money back.  Spent too much time going to casinos that were out of the way and less time just relaxing and enjoing ourselves.  I wouldn't suggest that people buy this books before going to vegas, usually hotels will give better coupons anyway.

review_title: Excellent Bargain  For The Frugal Gambler

I will be leaving for a month in Vegas and will have 2 books with me.  Enjoy! ! !

reviewComment: I have never read a book like this. It was very good. It was a eye opening experience. I also liked the extra touch of design at the top of the pages. I would recommend this to all Christians.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2014
reviewComment: This book was recommended to me and for some reason I immediately downloaded the kindle ebook. I usually take note of recommendations and then research them later. review_title: What more can you ask for?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2011
reviewComment: This was a free book on my Kindle...I love mysteries and this seemed to fit the bill!! Once I started reading this book I couldn't put it down...I loved it and it's meaning of thought and patience and it's mystery in every chapter....I loved this book so much that I went out and bought it for a good friend and she has been passing it on to family and other friends....What an excellent read....read Rooms!!!!

review_title: One of the most inspiring debut novels I've ever read.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2010
reviewComment: Rooms is a tragically beautiful and deeply insightful novel about a soul's redemption. Utilizing mind-twisting conflicts and heart-wrenching loss throughout the story, the author illustrates in a profound way how often to gain what we need we must first abandon what we thought we'd always wanted. Taking it one step further, it made me think in a completely new way about how 1 Corinthians, Chapter 13 states that "without love, I am nothing" (paraphrased by me to illustrate this point).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2013
reviewComment: I think I understand what the author wants us to do. Think...I have to admit that very often I had to reread portions of this book over just to try to make sense of it. It isn't one of those books that you sit and relax reading. It is a working book. So be aware before you start, that you will do a lot of soul searching as you read.

review_title: Beautiful Story about Faith and Love
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2011
reviewComment: This was an absolutely beautiful story about faith and God's love. The main character "lost" his way and his great-uncle was able to help him find the right path again. This story told of God's undying love and the faith and belief in God. I really enjoyed the book because it caused me to think about my life and it also challenged me to do what I have to do in order to attain the "ultimate" goal.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
reviewComment: I really enjoyed reading this book on one sitting. It was like going on a journey...a fantastic one, and one could relate with Micah's struggles of been in two worlds and having to make a difficult decision of letting go of his comfort zone. Although the part where Sarah walks into His heart was abit unreal,  it reminds me of the novel, "The Shack" by William P. Young. Overall a engrossing read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2018
reviewComment: I have not read a lot off Christian fiction,but I am sure glad I chose to read this.  A great story

review_title: You can't go wrong with a classic.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2011
reviewComment: Awsome book.  I love the description of London in the early days.  This is a series of cases / short stories that are separate stories, but in the context of the book are all part of the big story.  They are well written and entertaining.  Stands the test of time.

review_title: Holmes - more than a Deerstalker and Pipe!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2012
reviewComment: The Holmes character we see in advertising is often reduced to a charicature, and the same could be said of recent movies which are energetic, eye catching but really miss the point Doyle was making. Holmes outwitted his opponents. He used his brain. He created the concept of a detective as a methodical, tenacious stalker. So, if you've never read through the original works, you should make the time. You'll see that Holmes is not just brilliant, but also solitary, and a drug abuser (cocaine). Doyle was making him human. Enjoy these wonderful tales.

review_title: Great book - poor conversion to digital
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2011
reviewComment: These are truely wonderful stories and I'm so glad that amazon is making so many classic public domain books easily available through their website; however, they may need a little more work on the digital formatting.

reviewComment: So far it's good just now reading it

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2020
reviewComment: Enjoyable read! Always intrigued by Sherlock Holmes and Dr Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2017
reviewComment: Book is as advertised. The quality matched the description and the shipping was relatively fast. So, I am happy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2012
reviewComment: These stories are nice if you like to expose yourself to small amounts of the deductive processes of Sherlock Holmes. I only have one criticism: several of the mysteries are too easy to solve. If you want a challenge, read Agatha Christie, instead.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2013
reviewComment: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes stories.  The original illustrations brought the story to life.  Most of our modern day detective stories are built on the antics and methods of Sherlock Holmes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2014
reviewComment: This book really keeps you on the tip of your seat! he author writes so greatly.  I

review_title: Still great after all these years!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2013
reviewComment: I was surprised to re-read and read for the first time some of these stories. I have seen many played on the television. They are wonderful stories even after all these years and it's great to read the originals and see the author's vision.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2020
reviewComment: This book is great. The Pilgrims Progress is very inspirational.

review_title: The devious world of the secret service
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2007
reviewComment: A secret service thriller with alternating sections. There is the story of Eva Delektorskaya, who had been recruited into the British Secret Service just before the outbreak of the Second World War.  She was very good  at her work;  but for much of the time the bigger picture is kept from her by her boss, and that picture includes the deadly rivalries within and between the various intelligence agencies.  When she realizes that as part of that game someone has tried to have her killed, she escapes from the outfit and adopts a new identity in England, of which the man who would become her husband and her daughter Ruth are kept in total ignorance.  But in 1976 she thinks she has reason to suspect that whoever wanted her dead in 1941 is still after her;  and she has to recruit Ruth to help her fend off the danger.  In order to do this, she has first to tell her story to Ruth, and she does this by sending her in instalments the story of her previous life.  I found it an unsatisfactory and unconvincing device: it reads like chapters in a novel that she had already written: it is a third-person narrative and there is far too much novelistic detail in the script for it to have been written for the purpose of putting Ruth into the picture.  On the other hand, if the account had already been written, why was it not handed over to Ruth all together, instead of being released to her in sections alternating with the first person narrative of Ruth's life after she is first told that her mother's life might be in danger?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2007
reviewComment: There really ought to be another word for 'gripping' - it's so trite, and yet it's ideal to describe this crackerjack read. I hadn't read anything by William Boyd before this, and I'm delighted to have found him.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
reviewComment: Great story of about British Secret service during WW2 and how they tried to influence USA to join the war prior to Pearl harbor.  Story switches back and forth from the early days of WW 2 and the 1070's.  Lots of suspense and great characters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2014
reviewComment: This is a real spy thriller without the stupid stuff. By that I mean we don't have ridiculous James Bond style chase scenes. Everything that happens is amazing but at the same time believable, possible. What a refreshing approach. I really enjoy well-written stories like this about people who could actually be real, like the rest of us. I could identify with the characters, and was drawn in by the many gray areas that life is all about. Good reading.

review_title: A wonderful read about a part of history most people don't ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2015
reviewComment: A wonderful read about a part of history most people don't know about. I enjoyed reading about these believable and  fascinating characters and the part they played in history. It was so well written I couldn't put the book down. I will definitely read more of William Boyd's books in the future.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2006
reviewComment: What if you discovered your mother was an heroic half-Russian spy in World War II and not just the ordinary - if somewhat eccentric and independent - Englishwoman you thought she was? An adolescent's fantasy, certainly. But an adult woman with a young child of her own, like 28-year-old Oxford language tutor Ruth Gilmartin, might be justified in feeling disoriented, even betrayed.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2007
reviewComment: This is a well enough written book, as one would expect from William Boyd. That said, its the weakest Boyd I've ever read. This time his portrayal of real life characters in interesting times and extraordinary circumstances falls flat. I found it very hard to care even a bit for the daughter's story. I found it only a little harder to care for the mother's pretty-girl-turned-murderous-spy plot. Even the wartime situations the mother is involved in and that lead up to the climax of the novel are very far from enthralling. Its almost as if this is a novel without protagonists, since the protagnists themselves and the plot around them is so uninteresting. Emphasizing all this are the surrounding characters (ie the Iranian english student, the estranged german father of Jochen, his brother and Ilse) who not only add nothing to the plot but provide no really interesting subplots of their own (actually, to the contrary).

review_title: Not your typical spy thriller...much better!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2012
reviewComment: Sort of a spy thriller but from a female and personal perspective. The setting is the 1970s but much is told in flashbacks to the second world war time period. I found it difficult to put this book down; it was a fascinating read and and illuminated me about an oft overlooked facet of the USA's decision to actively join the allied forces. Mr. Boyd's knack for infusing humor and the most basic level of candor in his stories is quite present throughout.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2012
reviewComment: This is not my genre of interest.  But, I have to say that I agree with everyone else who loved the book.  It was engaging and memorable.  The prose was beautiful and thought provoking. The plot was intriguing. I wish I could say that I'd like to read more books like this; however, there is only one William Boyd.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2014
reviewComment: I have had three replacements!!!  You have to drag your fingers across the screen to turn the device on.

review_title: which still works great, or my black and white without the glow ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2014
reviewComment: I have used Nook readers since they came out. That being said, do not buy this version. I have had 3.....all within the same year. All 3 have experienced the screen having "tears" when the glow light is on. That I can live with. The problem I have had with all 3 is freezing, battery discharging, and unresponsiveness. The one I am using now has to be plugged in at all times, or the battery drains within an hour. I've given up on customer support, they just tell me to reset it ( which I do, but it doesn't fix the problem). I am back to using my original Nook, which still works great, or my black and white without the glow light, which also still works great. Avoid the black and white glow light. Seriously.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2014
reviewComment: If your idea of a good time is spending hours trying to get your computer to recognize it, and spending hours on help boards etc this is the device for you. For any sane individual it's clearly a pig in a poke.

review_title: Great Idea, Weak Screen - Small light producing tear
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2012
reviewComment: I was super excited about this product, so much so that my boyfriend pre-ordered it for me so I got it the day it came out.  I was in love with the product for a while, until one night my softish, rubberized watch brushed up against the screen and left a small scratch that allows a bright annoying light to come through.  It's really quite annoying to look at while reading your book at night (which was the point of the whole device).  I've taken really good care of it, it has a padded case.  However, it seems like it is inevitable that the screen will get scratched by something.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2014
reviewComment: It does what it promised, but there's a learning curve and it doesn't respond well to my fat fingers. Light is good. Good for the recipient (a gift) but I don't want one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2012
reviewComment: I couldn't wait to upgrade to this product from the Simple Touch that had no light.  It has worked well, with no problems.  Both Nooks get a little glitchy, I've noticed, when the charge starts getting low.  I will also say that it's my impression that downloading from libraries is still relatively new process; haven't tried it yet myself, and not all libraries even offer the service.  I don't object to the ads; they are not intrusive, and I just don't look at them if I'm not up for it.  However, as with all e-readers, realize that e-books are no bargain, most of the time. Most of the books I've read cost about 10 dollars.  I've downloaded free books from Google e-books that would otherwise have cost a small fortune.  It's nice not to have to find a home for a book that I've read but don't want to keep.  With this product, the advantages are that it is lightweight, you can increase/change the font and size, which is a huge advantage if you have vision issues, you don't accumulate physical books that you don't want to keep, and the Glowlight at night is fantastic when you want to read when your partner is ready for lights out.  I had a clip-on light with the original Simple Touch and it was inconvenient as far as placement, glare, etc.  We have a Kindle e-reader as well, and I much prefer the touchscreen on the Nook to the buttons on the Kindle for page turning.

review_title: If you want something that will freeze up on you in a a year or so...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2015
reviewComment: I thought this was a good buy and honestly it did work well for awhile.  BUT...after a couple months of use -- the screen NO LONGER responds to my touch, I can literally tap tap tap tap and nothing will happen, it's completely unresposive - heck it won't even power off because it won't respond to my touch anymore.  And the screen freezes A LOT!  So be careful with this, if you plan on using this long term I would definitely reccommend AGAINST it.  I had one of the original nooks that came out and that worked so much better than this.  Definitely disappointed.  WIll probably be looking inot getting a Kindle.

review_title: Sadly not the great Holmes story I expected
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2014
reviewComment: I had such high hopes for this book as I so admire Anthony Horowitz' Foyle's War and had heard he was a long time fan of Sherlock Holmes, but what I found was a very rushed book, poorly edited that had horrible anachronisms that had me shaking my head. Didn't anyone read this book and know the difference between a cigar lighter and a gasogene??? Really, if you are going to write about Victorian England know a bit about the time period, and know that Sherlock Holmes wouldn't foolishly walk into a trap without a plan of escape. I was soooo disappointed in this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2015

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2012
reviewComment: Being a reader of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's original Sherlock Holmes detective stories, I was very much surprised how well Horowitz captured the writing style of Doyle.  It was as if I was reading an a lost manuscript.  Very enyoyable reading.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2011
reviewComment: This book was hyped so much that I suppose I should have been prepared to be disappointed.  I was especially let down by Michael Dirda, a member of the Baker Street Irregulars and a respected writer and critic.  His review of "The House of Silk" in "The Washington Post" prompted me to get the book.  He praised "Horowitz's skill in . . . mimicking . . . the style and tone of Arthur Conan Doyle."  I must respectfully disagree with his assessment.  Horowitz's first few sentences reminded me of Mark Twain's comment on his wife's attempts at swearing: she had the words, but she didn't have the tune.  Mr. Horowitz has the words, but the tune is not Doyle/Watson, and the words actually aren't quite right.  Horowitz is prolix, whereas Doyle, Dirda himself says in his book "On Conan Doyle," was "unrivaled for crisp, narrative economy."  In addition, when Horowitz/Doyle morphed into Horowitz/Dickens to comment on social conditions in Victorian England, I almost discarded the book.  There is no question that the conditions existed, but they were not part of the London evoked by Doyle for Holmes and do not belong in a novel purporting to be about his and Watson's adventures.

review_title: An okay return for Sherlock and Watson
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2014
reviewComment: Ending too pat, and too many weird coincidences and references to earlier works. There is too much of the literary equivalent of name dropping. However, not a bad read overall. Don't expect too much from it.

reviewComment: Very lightweight, easy to see.  Great to put in your purse and carry with you.  Love it.

review_title: What happens when you have a twin?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2019
reviewComment: What happens if you have a twin who inhabits your dreams when you sleep? What happens if you live the dreams of your twin? What happens if both you and your twin live in a world of magic? The people who can perform magic do not necessarily correspond to twins. Brannis is heir to a vast magical heritage, but cannot perform magic. Tyrus is his twin and has the magical ability Brannis lacks. But Tyrus is a scribe, not a sorceror. I loved the convoluted plot lines in this book. Watching Tyrus become a general and Tyrus become a pirate was fascinating. So are their lady loves. It will be very interesting to me to see what becomes of them in later books. There is a huge battle scene in this book that was very well written, conveying the scope without getting bogged down in too many details. I'm looking forward to the next book of the series.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2015
reviewComment: Firehurler was just a book I picked up on an off chance - there's a bloke in armour casually summoning some magic in his hand, and it does has a snappy title. It's been some time since I've stumbled on an author whose text was like unto a siren's call to me, and even before I was finished with the book I was all over his twitter, blog, and checking out what other books he had out. I realise that the internet been around for a while, but it only recently occurred to me that I can seek out authors I like and can listen to them talk in other formats. I snagged his freebie intro short stories for his other series which also showed promise.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2013
reviewComment: I will break this novel down based on pros and cons first.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2015
reviewComment: Creative tale about characters in 2 parallel worlds -- one where magic is commonly used and the others where magic is viewed as witchcraft.  The parallel characters -- twins, as it were -- share their experiences in their respective dreams.  So, the main character in the non-magic world (Tellurac) learns to harness his inherent magical power with the help of his twin in the magic world (Veydras) who Is an aberrant shoot of a magical family lacking magical ability but has access to vast information on magic. The Veydras character has his own problems with a war brewing and him being the Grand Marshall -- the leading general of his country's army.  Interesting read.  The writing is OK; it's the story that gets my interest.  I got this book on a free deal.  Usually I just read the free book without bothering with the sequels.  With this one, I'm curious enough to buy the next one of the trilogy.

review_title: Was having difficulty finishing a book, until this one.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2015
reviewComment: As just an occasional fan of the Si-Fi fantasy I tried this book after not finishing the previous 3 books that I tried.  It hooked me pretty quick and had enough action to keep my interest.  Several times I had thought that it was going to take a bad turn and I almost regretted picking it back up. The author did a great turn that turned out not only extended the characters but merged the stories and made the characters human.  Any book I do not put down when I am in this mood gets three stars, any book I think about when I am not reading it gets 4 and any book that I am disappointed that it ended gets 5. This was a 5 star. To be honest though the books ending finished on such a high note that I do not think I will get the next one in the series but look up the Author to see what other original ideas that they have.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2013
reviewComment: Truthfully I would give it a 3.5.  I had serious issues with the flow of the book and had trouble committing to characters.  At points they seem transparently shallow, and without a few of the positive aspects I would have given up on it for sure.  I thought the background was well constructed and thought out, and everything came together nicely by the end.  I liked the magical systems and hierarchy, and the creative landscapes for different perspectives.  Not sure on whether to continue with the series or not.

review_title: Impressive. I did not expect such a quality tale.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
reviewComment: Not only is it a story with an actual Original Premise, but it has an amazing depth of detail.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
reviewComment: I really enjoyed the plot, writing, and characters in this book.  I don’t give spoilers but this plot is very original and actually fascinating in its uniqueness.  Definitely worth reading. I deducted one star because of a major error in the book. I don’t want to give anything away but it involved 2 sneaking scenes on the same night in a castle. The author used the exact same wording for both. That kinda ruined the flow for me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2013
reviewComment: This book read as would R. A. Salvatore. However, the double plot line was the clincher that set it apart. I will not spoil the book, but there are several things happening at the same time, each of which added to my experience. The wording was perfect for the story, although, grammar Nazis might not agree.  Every character was well developed, and the scenes were described in vivid detail. I read the prequel to this book "Warbringer" and simply had to continue. Witches, Warlocks, Knights, goblins, ogres, bloody battles, and love stories all mixed appealingly. I will definitely read the next! Five stars to Mr. Morin.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2014
reviewComment: I have been reading much more lately and happened to come across the Twinborn series. Interesting concepts and a well-woven story. It took a bit to figure out the players and their relationships but this was a hard book to put down from then on. I read a lot before bedtime and the thought that someone was waiting for me to sleep so they might see and experience what I had done that day just wouldn't leave my mind. It never will. When an author can change your perspective like that it's a powerful thing. Excuse me now but I am loading up the 2nd book to continue the story. Sweet dreams!

But reading the same thing said differently encourages learning and memory. This is a very good introduction for someone starting an investigation into the field.

reviewComment: Whenever an author decides to write a parallel narrative the potential pitfall is that one strand becomes more interesting than the other and as a reader you end up skimming half the book to always be getting at the bit of the story you want. So it is with Restless. Eva's story is just more engaging and evocative than her daughter's. The strands tie up cleverly at the end but personally I'd have been happy to have read a full 300 pages set during the war.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2006
reviewComment: This well written book is a clever historical espionage thriller. Alternating between WWII and recent modern Britain, Restless is the stories of 2 women, a mother and daughter.  The mother turns out to have had a hidden history as a spy during WWII which may be coming back to haunt her.  The daughter is at a crossroads in her personal and professional lives.  The story of the mother dominates the book.  A weakness of the book is that the daughter's story seems almost like a accretion, not adding much more than window dressing to the whole story.  Character development is fair and the basic plot mechanism, revealed in a somewhat clunky fashion at the end, is far-fetched.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2007
reviewComment: I've had I Am Legend on my list of books to read ever since I read an interview with Stephen King a couple of decades ago where he cited it as one of his favorite books ever.  When I saw that the trailer for the soon to be released movie I knew that if I saw the movie first then I'd never read the book.  I ordered the copy from Amazon that had the coolest cover and read it when it arrived on Wednesday.  First off, I'll be surprised if the newest movielization of this is any closer to the written story than The Last Man on Earth or Omega Man.  The story is very well-played...but I was completely bamboozled by Amazon when I Am Legend came to an end halfway through the book, and I realized that the other half of the book was a collection of short-stories.  I thought I had quite a bit of story left until I realized that the "next chapter" I had just begun was a completely different story.  I looked the book over, and the only indication that the whole book wasn't I Am Legend was a small phrase on the back just above the bar-code..."The complete novel, plus several more unforgettable tales."  I can't really complain...more stories!...but I thought that it could have been a bit more apparent say...on the cover...or the spine...that I'd bought half a book of filler.

In addition, the text was not particularly crisp and seemed to vary in intensity (darkness) on the page.  It also appears that, when powered up, the device will only return to the home page and not to the page of the book being read when turned off (a feature I appreciate in the Kindle).  All in all, a big disappointment.  I'm just hoping that the retail store from whom I bought the reader will take it back.

review_title: best christian fiction I've read in a long time
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2010
reviewComment: This was the most unusual Christian fiction novel I can remember reading. I enjoy paranormal fantasy literature and occasionally am in the mood for inspirational Christian lit (often that genre has disappointing qualit of writing though) and was pleased to see the blending of the two.  Even though I found the book extremely predicatable and somewhat too long (much was repetitive and could have been cut) it was written so well that I enjoyed relaxing and enjoying the slow pace of the story.  This is not a book to read if you want a fast paced read.  However, if you are willing to be patient and enjoy watching the slow evolution of a changing heart and self discovery with a hint of a supernatural mystery, then you will enjoy this read.

review_title: What will your house in Heaven look like?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2015
reviewComment: The vast majority of Christian literature is either written by a woman, or geared towards women.  Those that are written for men, at least those that aren't written by Ted Dekker, aren't stories that interest me.  James Rubart not only touches on the supernatural, but engages your imagination while remaining true to the bible.  The house in ROOMS is not some magic house like I've seen in other reviews.  To me, the house in ROOMS is reflective of his own soul.  The "voice" of the house was his own, albeit before he came to know the Lord.  The house changes as his soul changes.  So does the voice of the house.  What happens to him and how he reacts is the lesson that this book teaches us.  The bible tells us that the Lord is preparing a house for us in Heaven.  Preparing is a present tense word.  It changes by the day.  What is the state of your soul?  What will your house in Heaven look like?  Read this book and gain a better understanding of the Spirit inside you while being entertained at the same time.

review_title: A Worthy Addition To The Canon of Sherlock Holmes Mysteries
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2011
reviewComment: In 1893, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle retired his much beloved fictional detective Sherlock Holmes by plunging him over the edge of the Reichenbach Falls as he was locked in mortal combat with his nemesis Professor Moriarty. By popular demand, Doyle revived the Holmes character ten years later with the somewhat puzzling explanation that only the evil Moriarty was actually killed. Doyle continued to write Sherlock Holmes stories for another 24 years and his last Holmes mystery was published three years before his death in 1930. Doyle tried hard to distance himself from his Holmes creation to write "serious" literature and ironically 80 years after his death, the Sherlock Holmes mysteries turn out to be Doyle's sole ticket to literary immortality.

reviewComment: Faire le choix de ce livre, c'est faire le choix d’être tenu absorbé du début à l afin par un récit mené de main de maître. Très justement primé, l'auteur et l'ouvrage sont à recommander, que dis-je, à imposer pour le plus grand plaisir de tous et toutes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on March 30, 2020
reviewComment: Ouvrage très agréable à lire qui nous emmène du Pérou, en passant par Paris et bien d'autres régions encore. Les amours de la "vilaine fille" et du "bon garçon" sont drôles, rebondissantes, elles nous surprennent, nous intriguent et nous étonnent.

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on April 13, 2019
reviewComment: Las Travesuras de la niña mala, c'est bien plus qu'une histoire d'amour : c'est l'histoire d'une passion dévorante, des années 60 à nos jours, à travers les pays et les époques. Mario Vargas Llosa mêle une fois de plus la chaleur des émotions à la dureté des contextes nationaux, parlant autant de passion que de dictatures ou des différentes époques. J'ai dévoré ce livre en une semaine, et je me souviendrai de la beauté du texte.

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on July 25, 2018
reviewComment: On a beau trouver le personnage principal un peu mièvre, la lucidité avec laquelle il raconte sa véritable obsession pour La Vilaine fille force l'admiration. Et on me suit dans les soubresauts de cette relation en goûtant le suspense du prochain coup bas, de la prochaine trahison, du prochain mensonge. Belle écriture, roman au charme étrange, à la fois plein de vie et de mélancolie. Je recommande.

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on December 7, 2020
reviewComment: J'ai devoré ce livre dont l'écriture est par ailleurs parfaite. Non seulement l'histoire m'a tenu en haleine jusqu'au bout mais son auteur m'a permis d'en apprendre plus sur des lieux ,des faits historiques ,des citations d'auteurs , preuve d'un grand travail de documentation . Quel dommage que la fin du livre arrive si vite

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on April 29, 2020
reviewComment: Merci beaucoup pour tout. Le livre à recommander. Livraison, sans tours ni détours finalement, fut accompagnée d’un petit mot très agréable ! Merci encore.

review_title: A Great Start to a Fantasy Epic
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2013
reviewComment: A very plot-driven story that any lover of fantasy and epic adventure will like.The four plot threads take a little getting used to, but the twists and conclusions were very entertaining to read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2013
reviewComment: When I first saw this book, I laughed at the title. I thought it was pretty bad. The word hurler did it for me ("Gotta hurl, Dude"). And the cover was not too appealing either.  Is this a representation of the author? A scruffy guy in armor is still a scruffy guy.  But the reviews were good, and the summary sounded interesting, so I gave it a try and to my surprise it was pretty good. There are some good plot elements, very interesting action, and the writing doesn't get in the way. I think most people will like this, but I was somewhat disappointed. It seems more like a fantasy for guys. I read the whole thing, though I did skim through some of the parts with the murdering pirate. When I got to the end there wasn't a feeling of satisfaction and I felt like I really didn't care to read anymore about these characters. I guess what it came down to is that there wasn't a single character that I admired or cared about or wanted to spend more time with. They were all a little morally ambivalent and shallow. In a really addictive story the author makes you care about the character; either he's greatly downtrodden, or he has a great passion or hunger, or a strong love and strong ideals. The character needs to care, and you need to care, or the story doesn't matter as much. I'm not saying these characters don't care at all, but I couldn't get engaged with any of them. SPOILER ALERT  I despised the pirate character, and his revenge-thirsty "twin" and wished for less writing about them. The scribe dude was a bit wishy-washy. We leave him stranded on a tropical island with a bevy of island beauties, and he's not upset at all at being abandoned there. Guy fantasy. If I were in his situation, I would have been furious first, with fantasies of fire-bombing the pirate's ship; then I would have been anxious (would I ever see my beloved again or before I was old? Would I find a reliable ship someday? Where would I go then?), and then I would make the best of it and try to be hopeful. HE just blithely accepts it from the beginning.  The protagonists seem pretty content to just go with the flow and they don't think about it much. I was more hopeful for the knight, although how he could save the story while carrying his albatross of a twin was a puzzle. He's intelligent, a loyal soldier and friend, and risks his life to save others. Admirable.  But his relationships never were developed well. You know he cares about his friend, but he doesn't think about him, or talk to him, much. He sort of loves this girl who has been re-betrothed to his friend, and he's sort  upset about it, but really pragmatic more than passionate. He doesn't agonize over it enough to convince me he really cares. When you truly want something (or someone) you can't have, you are desperately trying to think of a way to make it happen. If you can let it go that easily, then it's just a minor disappointment. The other two main characters, the sorcerer-demon and his son, were also underdeveloped emotionally. I guess what was really lacking was strong feeling and relationships, but also a better understanding of the characters' motivations (i.e. what do they want and why do they want it). Nobody really loves anybody all that much, or it's not explained in a way that makes me feel it. The characters are interesting but need more heart. The story is very good otherwise and I wouldn't be surprised if it becomes popular, but for me, it wasn't entertaining enough to make up for that.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2014
reviewComment: I liked this book a lot.  I only have a few fantasy writers that I follow like Terry Brooks and Tad Williams but this book held my interest and I look forward to the next one.  The idea of the characters dreaming each other's lives was a different spin and an interesting one.  The author occasionally got bogged down in geography and the ease with which one of the characters accepted his accidental killing of dozens of innocent people was a little disconcerting but all in all a an entertaining book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2014
reviewComment: Firehurler is the first in the Twinborn Trilogy series.  It's a LONG book and I read it on my Kindle.  I never lost interest.  Many characters are well developed in this first book.  The author creates a two-dimensional world where Kyros and Brannis are twins (but different eras) as well as Tendak and Jinzan (twins characters in two different eras).  One is the sorcerer / good knight and the other the bad pirate / sorceror.  I'm eager to read the next book in the series.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2013
reviewComment: I've read a lot of fantasy in my time: Dragonlance series (like all of them), Wheel of Time, Neil Gaiman, Patrick Rothfuss, A song of fire and ice, Dresden series, etc. Morin's Firehurler is on par with these series. It has a unique twist on classical fantasy that left me enthralled for two days. I couldn't put this book down (I actually failed a test because i would rather read than study). The writing isn't long or langorous; it's fast, short, and exciting. The character stories are linked together very well. 5/5 and I'll be buying the next two books for sure. So good. It' might not be high fantasy due to the writing style, but hell, it doesn't need to be. A wonderful piece perfect for a weekend read

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2007
reviewComment: The "Cambridge spies" will forever be grist for the British literary mill.  Boyd's entry is a vivid double narrative about a woman's brief career as a spy in the early years of World War II and her daughter's rediscovery of her mother's secret past decades later, capped by a fitting denoument.  Boyd's deservedly-praised ouevre covers the novelistic waterfront and he certainly cannot be pigeonholed in this particular genre, but he does it more than justice.

reviewComment: Strange book indeed. And not necessarily strange in a good way. But it is about the young woman/old woman Eva Delectorskaya/Sally Gilmartin and her daughter Ruth Gilmartin. Eva/Sally was a British spy during the Second World War, taught and trained by the enigmatic Lucas Romer, with whom she also has a steaming love affair, mainly during their stay in America in the beginning of the 1940'es, before Pearl Habor.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2012
reviewComment: I was hooked by the details of espionage.  The characters became important to me.  Also, I was intrigued at how the author used the mother's story to manipulate the daughter's story. I also liked the fact that things were not wrapped up in tidy bow at the end.  I look forward to reading more by this author.

review_title: Perhaps a two star rating should be given on this early work.  Needs revision!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2014
reviewComment: At this time I am writing having read all of Mr. Morin's books to date, and having seen his growth and development as an author.  I have become a huge fan of his work. that said this early work is weak in vocabulary and limited in its descriptions.  If there was an editor involved, a good deal of malpractice is in evidence.  Mr. Morin is a skilled author in desperate need of a literary agent, quality publisher, publishing editor, copy editor.  With support of these professionals there no room for doubt in my mind that he will stand the test of time and be co-equal to the giants of this genre (R.A. Salvatore, Margaret Weiss, etc.) and far superior to those hacks that insist on selling the watered down storytelling that is possible with a series (Robert Jordan's "Wheel of Time", etc..) His work stays fresh and well crafted throughout.

review_title: A solid, worthwhile read for fans of two-world fantasies
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2013
reviewComment: As the first book in a trilogy, J.S. Morin's "Firehurler" carries the burden of introducing us to a whole new world filled with characters we are meeting for the first time. Despite that, Morin does a nice job getting us into the setting quickly and seamlessly, without a lot of time wasted trying to figure out bizarre names or outre concepts. Everything here will be familiar to fans of fantasies, particularly those that span multiple worlds. It's complete in itself, and won't leave you twisting in the wind, forced to buy a second installment to get some sort of conclusion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2014
reviewComment: You must read the others that come before for this installment in the series to really have any continuity.  But it really follows alone with the previous story lines and introduces new characters, that can surprise you.  If you like tales with intricate plots, multiple characters and story lines to keep track of, this one will be a fun read for you.  It is remarkably intricate and yet well balanced.

reviewComment: I Am Legend is a great quick read that keeps you on the edge of your seat waiting for what's coming next. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2013
reviewComment: Descriptively paints the picture for an apocalyptic world.  I don't want to give away anything from the book, so I highly recommend to anyone interested in an end of days crisis or survival in general.  The story is far more about the protagonist, Robert Neville`s ability to survive on an emotional and mental level than that of a physical (food, supplies, etc.) one.  I related to the story because when I think about surviving in this type of situation many of the same ideas play into my head like that of the writer.

reviewComment: ch habe mich so auf dieses Buch gefreut, zum einen weil es wirklich sehr spannend klingt und zum anderen, weil es mal wieder Zeit für einen Fall für Kay Scarpetta war :-) Und ich wurde tatsächlich nicht enttäuscht. Der Schreibstil von Patricia Cornell gefällt mir wirklich gut. Irgendwie wurde mir dieses Mal erst richtig bewusst, dass das Buch aus Sicht von Kay Scarpetta geschrieben ist, obwohl man auch sonst die Eindrücke der anderen Personen gut mitbekam – ganz ehrlich? Ich habe keine Ahnung, wie sie das gemacht hat, aber es hat funktioniert. Dadurch fühlt man sich, meiner Meinung nach viel mehr in die Geschichte ein. Wie schon bei den letzten Malen hat mir die Beziehung zwischen Dr. Kay Scarpetta, Benton Wesley und Pete Marino wirklich gut gefallen. Es sind alles 3 einzigartige Personen, mit so unterschiedlichen Eigenschaften und Ansichten. Und auch wenn sie es vielleicht selbst manchmal nicht so sehen, ich finde es ist eine tolle Freundschaft, die die 3 verbindet.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2017
reviewComment: This is a two-book book. Part I is much different than Part II. I found Part I to be a very spiritual allegory involving Christian on his "christian journey" from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City. The description of these places and the spiritual significance of those places as rooted in either testament of the Bible. The characterization of a solitary journeyman is what I found comforting about Part I. This can also be said about the "eponymous" characters he meets. Therefore, themes of alienation and social isolation are brought to the fore. And although this is in some opinions an ancient text, it translates well to current language and situations. Children can read this in smaller portions, but I think the freedom of movement may be more meaningful than the confusing moral lessons one might take from taking instruction from those it is difficult to evaluate as friend or foe. Both books can assert righteousness and sinful wayfaring on somewhat arbitrary interpretations, not too much different from the Old Testament.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on December 22, 2009
reviewComment: Das Buch erschien im Jahr 2000. Ich lese es erst jetzt, kurz vor Weihnachten 2009, und bin tief beeindruckt. Es hat nichts von seiner Aktualität eingebüßt. Es ist ein Schocker, ein "Sachbuch-Thriller", ein Augenöffner. Und es macht Mut, dass sich friedlicher, aber beharrlicher Widerstand gegen profitgierige Feinde eines mündigen Staatsbürgertums auszahlt. Das Thema ist absolut grundlegend, weil es etwas beschreibt, das an den Grundfesten der Demokratie, unserer marktwirtschaftlichen Bürgergesellschaft rüttelt. Es ist so gut geschrieben ("brilliant" ist nicht übertrieben), dass es "Pflichtlektüre" an Schulen und Universitäten werden sollte. Aber auch Eltern erfahren hier, wie sich ihre Kids von einer schier unvorstellbaren Marketingmaschinerie mit allen Finessen vereinnahmen lassen. Und betriebswirtschaftlich Interessierte lernen, wie sich Produktionskosten unter Ausnutzung internationaler Ungleichgewichte "optimieren" und Gewinne maximieren lassen.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on February 13, 2017
reviewComment: Man erfährt, wie die Konzerne hinter den Kulissen agieren, um jeden Preis Gewinne maximieren, Kunden für dumm verkaufen und dies alles zu Lasten der Umwelt, des sozialen Gefüges und der Dritten Welt. Dieses Buch sollte wirklich jeder lesen, der z.B. gerne Markenklamotten kauft oder Disney für einen sympatischen Konzern hält.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on February 24, 2016
reviewComment: Was in den letzten Jahren bzw. Jahrzehnten abgelaufen ist, kann man eigentlich erst dann verstehen, wenn man „No Logo” (und danach sicherlich noch einige andere Bücher zum Thema) gelesen hat. Die unselige Rolle Amerikas, der Triumphzug der Neoliberalen Lehre mit allen verästelten Auswirkungen auf das, was wir heute gemeinhin als „Globalisierung” bezeichnen, all das führt uns Naomi Klein plastisch und äußerst detailreich vor Augen.

reviewComment: I found this how to book very useful and well written. The author does a great job of offering clear explanations of the processes involved in getting out of the autopilot mode we all tend to live in as well as providing exercises and tips to put the book’s teachings into use.  It’s must have book for anyone who wants to bring their life to the next level and get out of their own way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on December 9, 2019
reviewComment: At a time in my life where I felt myself simply going through the motions and feeling like I was lacking direction, this book helped put a lot of things into perspective for me.  Over the years you simply accept your beliefs and values because of the way you were conditioned, but this book teaches you that you don't have to do that!  We all have full control over our actions, decisions, and beliefs, and this book showed me how to gain that control. reviewComment: First and foremost, this isn’t a novel about vampires so much as it is a novel about loneliness. The shifts in his mood between apathy, anger, depression, desperate hope, and at times seeming madness and cruelty made his character feel real and believable. The chapter about the dog was so human it was painful.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2014
reviewComment: I have a tendency to watch the movie before I read a book, so that the movie doesn't disappoint me ( because the book is ALWAYS better ).  With that said, I chose this title because I had seen the movie, and was not aware that the movie was an adaptation of a book (because I don't always read the credits).  With that said, do not expect this book to be anything like the movie, the story line is actually less developed.  Unless there is a book precluding this one, much of the backstory is left to the imagination, and since the main character Robert Neville is not a research scientist on a mission like the protagonist in the movie, the focus of the story is psychological, not the action packed, CGI fueled storyline of the movie.  And because of this, the book misses plot opportunities than could give more breadth to the psychological drama that is the life of Robert Neville, and to me that equals not much of a stimulating read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2011
reviewComment: This book is a good value for any visitor to Vegas (in particular). The book has some solid advice about many gambling games, although don't look here for winning advice on how to play poker or bets sports (two of the beatable games offered in a casino).  This advice is great for the novice gambler, but someone interested in elevating their game will need to look deeper than this book.  That said, the real reason to buy this book is the coupons.  It is not too hard to make your money back on the purchase price of this book if you use just 2 or 3 of the right coupons.  As stated earlier, however, the largest section of coupons is for Las Vegas, so it is the Las Vegas visitor who will have the easiest time recouping your investment in this book.  Look at the coupons closely to see how they fit your intended 2011 travel schedule.  It is worth noting that most of the Las Vegas coupons are for casinos away from the more popular South and Central Strip locations.  In this regard, it is highly helpful to rent a car to take advantage of all of the Las Vegas coupons.  A final, important note:  the Sahara casino will be closing in early May.  The 2011 American Casino Guide contains a $25 matchplay that will no longer be redeemable after early May, 2011.  So, don't factor that coupon into the value of the guide unless you a headed to Vegas in the next month.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
reviewComment: Reading Pilgrim's Progress has been an enjoyable adventure.  When you say that an author has presented his works in an entirely new way you are probably repeating what you have stated before about another author.  Recently I read a business book written with a fictional storyline, and I stated that this was a unique way for an author to maintain your interest and here it is happening again.  John Bunyan wrote a religious book, Pilgrim's Progress, with a unique fictional storyline.  So, I'm repeating myself in saying that it's rare when an author writes about a major topic utilizing a fictional storyline; this has been going on for a long time and I'm sure will continue as long as there are writers.  John had a clever way of giving his characters their names; such as Christian, Evangelist, Honest,  etc. (Each fitting a particular situation in the story).  I felt this application added to the story and gave you little doubt as to the make up of the particular character or to their placement in the story.  I especially liked how the author would fit a specific verse or verses of the Bible within the story as a highlight or emphasis as additional explanation for the reader.  I started highlighting these while reading and found them to amount to an additional Bible study as well as an important part of the story.  I'm sure that Pilgrim's Progress was on my list of required reading in high school but I found it to be a fresh new read; maybe because of the difference in my age now, approximately 70 years older, then when I was in high school.  I recommend that you read Pilgrim's Progress with an open mind and just enjoy...

reviewDate: Reviewed in France on October 4, 2017
reviewComment: Que de tours et de malices chez cette «vilaine fille», toujours et tant aimée par son ami Ricardo, le «bon garçon». Ils se rencontrent pour la première fois au début des années cinquante, en pleine adolescence, dans l'un des quartiers les plus huppés de Lima, Miraflores. Joyeux, inconscients, ils font partie d'une jeunesse dorée qui se passionne pour les rythmes du mambo et ne connaît d'autre souci que les chagrins d'amour. Rien ne laissait alors deviner que celle qu'on appelait à Miraflores «la petite Chilienne» allait devenir, quelques années plus tard, une farouche guérillera dans la Cuba de Castro, puis l'épouse d'un diplomate dans le Paris des existentialistes, ou encore une richissime aristocrate dans le swinging London. D'une époque, d'un pays à l'autre, Ricardo la suit et la poursuit, comme le plus obscur objet de son désir. Et chaque fois, il ne la retrouve que pour la perdre. Et, bien entendu, ne la perd que pour mieux la rechercher.

review_title: is a great book. Everyone should read it to get a ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2015
reviewComment: I had no idea this book was in German.  If it had been in English it would have gotten 5 stars.  I assumed it was a sequel to 'Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet'.  It is actually the German version of that book (which isn't mentioned anywhere that I could see).  That book, in English, is a great book.  Everyone should read it to get a feel for the hostility and discrimination toward Japanese citizens before and during WWII.  Sensitive handling of the topic from the point of view of a 12 yr old boy.  I had hoped this book(Keiko) would be from the girl's point of view.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on July 6, 2014
reviewComment: Was für ein wundervoller Roman der da in meiner Bücherwand ein nahezu unbeachtetes Dasein fristete. Der Schriftsteller Jamie Ford hat diesen Frühling seinen neuen Roman "Die chinesische Sängerin" veröffentlicht und dies war der Anlass, endlich sein erstes Buch "Keiko" zu lesen. Und ich muss sagen, ich bin von diesem Roman begeistert. Es ist die Geschichte von zwei jugendlichen Aussenseitern die ein einsames Leben führen und sich wegen dieser gefühlten Isolation anfreunden und Gefühle für einander entwickeln. Ich bin mir nicht sicher, ob wir hier bei den zwölfjährigen Keiko und Henry bereits von der ersten grossen Liebe sprechen oder bloss von einer Freundschaft mit Zuneigung aber das darf jede(r) Leser/-in für sich selbst interpretieren.
