reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 17, 2016
reviewComment: I stumbled across William Boyd a few years back after picking up "Waiting for sunrise" out of curiosity and then finding I was unable to book the book down. Since then, I have tended to snap up his novels quite regularly but I had delayed reading "Restless" having seen the TV adaption that was on the BBC a few years ago. Whilst this is perhaps considered Boyd's most exciting novel , I was really struck by the similarities with his recent re-working of James Bond, the terrific "Solo" which effectively out-trumps Fleming.  Like "Solo", the main protagonist is thrown in to a situation where they are out of their depth and the ending similarly hints that matters are not quite fully resolved. "Restless" is similarly a novel about the murky world of espionage and centres around the machinations to disseminate false news stories which , it is hoped, with prompt the United States to join in the war against Nazi Germany.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 15, 2020
reviewComment: This is one of those books that keep you reading on until it's finished, even through episodes where you can't quite fathom what's going on, and you think about going back a bit to see if you've picked up all the clues - but no, you can't stop until it's all over, and then everything is clear, so no need to go back. So why not 5 stars? Only because even the best male writer (so far as I've yet found) can't really write a female point of view, it always feels as if this is a boy telling you what's happening. There are good biological reasons why this should be so - a female person, even in action-packed circumstances, remains aware of a lot of detail that a male doesn't need to think about, and also tends to see more colours, and even perhaps differentiates tones of voice more acutely. I expect that when female writers try to represent a male point of view they also get it a bit wrong. And of course perhaps it doesn't matter: for it's a great complicated story, unputdownable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 9, 2018
reviewComment: This is so well written.  Two women feature throughout the story, mother and daughter. Well managed but written by a man, which shows through in subtle ways here and There.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 29, 2018
reviewComment: Completely absorbing throughout. I stayed up and read throughout last night in order to finish the final chapters.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 26, 2021
reviewComment: I originally read this book 6 years ago or should I say I never actually finished it. I couldn't remember excatly why I didn't finish it, was it because I didn't think much of it ? so I decided to read it again. I'm glad I did, cleverly written gripping in parts the story revolves around two women,  Mother and daughter the story goes from the mother's time to the daughters just pre second world war  to more modern day times it might take a bit of getting use to but unlike some other books it does make it clear which time your in. The best thing I liked  about the book was that it's thought provoking.  Is what we read in the papers and see on television really what it appears to be?  The reason for the four stars is I thought Any Human Heart was better.

reviewComment: Restless begins in 1939. Eva DelectorskIaya is a 28-year-old emigree living in Paris. As war breaks out, she is recruited for the British Secret Service. Under the guidance and training from a mysterious Englishman, Lucas Romer

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 14, 2021
reviewComment: I usually hate spy novels, but I loved this one. I’m surprised, because I tried reading Armadillo some years ago and I hated it. But this novel held my interest and also had enough historical detail to make me feel it was a worthwhile read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 6, 2014
reviewComment: There are three protagonists Lucas, a recruiting agent of the SIS (now MI6), Eva, a single woman of Russian origin, and Eva's daughter, Ruth. The narrative alternates between WW2 (mainly 1939 -1942) and postwar in 1976 when Eva is a widow and Ruth (born in 1949) is an Oxford graduate and a single mother with a boy (Jochen) of her own. Ruth lives in Oxford teaching English (as a foreign language) to young professionals from overseas. Her mother (now in her sixties) lives about an hour's drive away, her deceased husband having left her reasonably well off financially.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 28, 2020
reviewComment: This was my first read of a William Boyd book.  His language and imagery is amazing and his characters well drawn.  The plot is a typical convoluted spy weave of trust and deceit which I thoroughly enjoyed..  Boyd must have researched the background well and he cleverly links the past WW2 with 1972.  However I did wonder why Eva was only now taking action to seek revenge and why her daughter had to be involved.  A jolly good read non the less.

review_title: this book is one of the best books I've read for a high school assignment
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2015
reviewComment: Honestly, this book is one of the best books I've read for a high school assignment. The made-up english dialect creates such an interesting and fun spin for the audience& even past that it reaches such a deep psychological subject of the good and evil in men. The characters were also such a fantastic and creative group and kept the readers enjoying their antics. Overall, its a great fiction piece and read for those who are looking for a dystopian setting.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2000
reviewComment: This great book follows the life of young Alex and his "droogs", from their nightly "ultraviolence" to Alex's prison days. This book has great use of its dark futuristic (of the time that it was written)  setting. I liked how burgess showed who Alex was right in the beginning by  use of showing Alex and his friends prowling the streets, looking for  trouble. At first I didn't like the words that Alex used, but once I got  used to them, they added alot to the book. The book was written very well  and Burgess used very good character development.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2000
reviewComment: Personally, This Is One Of My Favorite Books. I Think That Many People Are Turned Away From This Book Due To The Extremely Violent Content And Horrific Crimes Described Herein, But, Beneath The Violence And Crime Is A  Masterpiece That Gives A Terrifying Vision Of A Possible Future and Poses  An Important Moral Question. The Book Has Some Connections To Christianity  That Are Represented Mainly Through The Prison Chaplain. The Big Moral  Dilemma Of The Book Is Expressed Through The Title. Alex(The Narrator), Is  Subjected To A Treatment In Prison In Which He Is Shown Films Of Violence  And Sex, While Strapped To A Chair With His Eyes Forced Open And While  Feeling Extreme Nausea, Fear, Discomfort, And Feelings Of Paralysis. After  Alex Gets The Treatment In Prison, He Becomes A "Clockwork  Orange," Something That Appears To Be Alive But Is In Fact Mechanical.  The Treatment Forces Alex To Be A Non-Violent, Non-Sexual person. Just The  Thought Of Sex Or Violence Causes Him To Become Incapacitaded By Feelings  Of Extreme Nausea And Severe Discomfort. Alex No Longer Has The Freedom To  Choose How To Behave And He Becomes A Slave To Fear, The Fear Of The  Effects Of The Treatment. Consequently, These Feelings Also Appear When  Alex Hears His One True Love In Life, The Music Of Beethoven. This Is Due  to The Fact That One Of The Treatment Films Had A Piece By Beethoven  Playing In The Background. The Chaplain Sums Up The Main Theme Of The Book  In One Statement: Is A Person Truly Good If They Have No Choice Between  Good Or Bad Behavior, And Are Forced To Do No Wrong. Basically, The Theme  Is The Connection Between Living And Freedom. It Seems To Me That What  Burgess Is Trying To Say Is That People Are Not Truly Alive If They Do Not  Have The Freedom To Choose How To Live Their Lives, And Without This  Choice, Are Nothing But Machines That Have The Characteristics Of Human  Beings. I Couldn't Agree More.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2003
reviewComment: as with many of his novels, he is a one-man showcase for his use of the english language as well as his other learnedness, including, as many reviews have already indicated, his knowledge of the russian language.  the author has incorporated this into a teen-gang-speak (which bart simpson has used in several episodes, with the requisite cockney/estuary accent) that no one should really be diverted by.  humans build their knowledge of written language by understanding an unfamiliar word in the context of the familiar, and can even identify nonsense words as being used as verbs or nouns, as in lewis carrol's "jabberwocky".  so knowing russian would in theory be an asset, but then you would be missing out on the exoticness of the unfamiliar word and its conferred membership of the disaffected underclass to which alex and his friends belong.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 1999
reviewComment: one of the better books available that goes into the psyche of the modern teenager. the events outlined are not as far fetched as they may sound. clockwork orange reflects the reality that we are headed towards. the  events can take place today and in fact may be happening right now! the  novel is a good example of how too much freedom can create so much trouble.  it is scary because it brings out an inner fear in most people that this  may not be totally fictional. one is forced to ask, is this the result of  the overdose of violence that goes hand in hand with entertainment? is it a  result of the myopic attitude of the authorities? are the guardians and  counsellors doing their job properly. the return of alex to his house and  the reception thereafter is quite realistic. it's time for further  introspection. have we at any point of time turned away anyone in desparate  need of help? the language of the teens is hard to follow at the start but  it is very easy to pick up. in fact after a point it becomes addictive. it  would be difficult for me to see a fight without thinking of  "tolchok". there is one drawback. the author practically raises a  toast to alex, at the end of his book. would this not influence wrongly the  impressionable ones, especially ones like me!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2004
reviewComment: I am a senior at Mercy High School in Middletown, CT and I must say that I was incredibly skeptical about reading this book.  I picked it randomly from a list of books to do a project on, and was warned after about its intense violence, and difficult language. After reading it, though, I would rate it was one of the most worthwhile books I've read in my high school career.  I found Burgess's invented slang intriguing (although difficult to comprehend at first) and I felt that it added to Alex's character.  Burgess did an excellent job of developing each of the characters, and even though he was a cruel delinquent I often found myself feeling badly for Alex.  The last chapeter was the one that enjoyed the most (apparently it wasn't included in the original American versions) because it displayed so much hope for this troubled young man.  I would highly recommend this book to anyone, but would strongly warn the reader about its violence.  The book should not be read by those with a weak stomach!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2001
reviewComment: This is one of the few books ive read which not only causes the reader to expand his or her's language and perception of how our speech works but also causes one to evaluate society as a whole. Anthony Burgess's A CLOCKWORK ORANGE is an extremely well written book contaning strong imadges of violence, rape and the tendancies of a malicious youth mind. In the book, he undergoes a treatment in which his body is instructed to become sick. Once his ability to commit these acts has been stripped from him hes left in a world he can nolonger relate to, and a series of excellently written events transpire. This book is one i would reccomend reading twice solely for the many messages within the story that burgess inserts cleverly. Highly recommended

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2003
reviewComment: I'd like to start off by saying I throughly enjoyed this novel.  Anthony Burgess's masterpiece of a novel is deeply intriguing, insightful, and enlightening on matters of free will and human rights.  Through the first person view and acts of violence on behalf of the central character, Alex, we gain insights into the moral issues of what the persuit of happiness can begin to mean; at what point does your pursuit of happiness begin to violate somone elses rights as a human?  And at what point does somone have the right to tell you that you cannot act a certain way?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 29, 2019
reviewComment: I really enjoyed reading this book. I am a fan of William Boyd and this was the best of his I have read so far, the story flipping between timelines is brilliant and shocking at times, The two central characters the Mother and Daughter are excellent especially with their interplay with the other characters in the separate timelines and the action is what makes this standout. Great read highly recommend it

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 1, 2013
reviewComment: I have read and loved William Boyd's books since his very first ones, but have failed to keep up to date with his prodigious output.  Picking up again this year with his excellent "Any Human Heart", I have been dipping in and out of his oeuvre, whilst reminding myself how cleverly he varies the type of books he can write, whilst involving you in the characters and plotlines, descriptions and places, seemingly effortlessly. This of course is the mark of a seriously talented writer.  OK, not all the books are completely even and some appeal to a certain audience more than others. Being on a bit of down time over Christmas, I attacked a few thrillers (not my first choice of reading), whizzing through "the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" (thought it was better than OK but not fantastic) before downloading "Restless" having read about the BBC film being made. Having only caught the first episode, I read the book before watching the recorded second episode.  I thought it was a really classy, well-written good, old-fashioned couldn't-put-it-down type thriller.  The characters had depth and interest, the situations appeared to involve you without suspending your belief and I loved the fact that at the end you were still slightly uncertain as to the ultimate fate of Eva/Sally.  Was she paranoid, did she merely enact the whole thing to involve her daughter, or were the Soviets really out to get her? (cleverly set in the 1970's, so not unfeasible.) I haven't enjoyed a book of this type so much for ages, and find it hard to understand why anybody thought it was slow - but horses  for courses. I also find it hard to understand why Boyd is somehow not as up there in the same critically exalted league as say, Martin Amis & Ian McEwan.  Perhaps the fact he writes beautifully well-structured, accessible books with interesting characters, reasonable plots and generally a beginning, middle and end is just too "well-crafted" for the literati. If you do like a well-crafted novel and a good read, then this definitely recommended. By the way, I had the Kindle edition and it was fine, so clearly the problems mentioned earlier have been rectified.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 10, 2012
reviewComment: Having re-read "Restless" some time after it first came out, I was surprised by just how much more I got out of it second time around, and what another fine piece of storytelling it is from William Boyd.  It's pretty much an action thriller with literary intent, and as usual, Boyd skilfully weaves a number of threads together to make for a compelling, compulsive read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 11, 2016
reviewComment: It's a gripping read, and a well structured plot.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 16, 2013
reviewComment: This is certainly a riveting read. Boyd's knowledge of the different worlds: Oxford, SIS, New York, Albuquerque etc is convincing, enjoyable to those without it. His detailed imagining does not interfere with the narrative drive, a rare gift. What is it really about? Betrayal of country, of colleagues: their murder. That the betrayer gets away with it does not mean that he is laughing at all those he has deceived (those still alive) but there would have to be moral satisfaction in the achievement of being a successful spy, even after 'retirement', right up to the grave, despite his eventual suicide..

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 1, 2021
reviewComment: This book is a classic spy thriller ranging from 1939 to 1967.  If you like Le Carre this is better.  Much clearer plot to follow without all the insider secret service jargon.  I will be reading more by William Boyd as it's such a joy to find beautifully crafted books like this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 28, 2020
reviewComment: I think I have become a William Boyd addict since being introduced to this author earlier this year in Lockdown.  He is a truly gifted storyteller.  He is a superbly knowledgeable historian of 2 world wars, and the inter-war years, but tells very human tales with impeccable style. I’m particularly fascinated with the way he writes from the perspective of females in this and Sweet Caress, (my absolute favourite thus far).  I found Restless slow to get into but in the end I was racing to finish chapters before my Kindle battery expired.  Highly recommended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 8, 2019
reviewComment: I bought this after thoroughly enjoying Boyd’s contribution to the 007 genre ‘Solo’. What a disappointment, irrelevant detail and dull subplots take up far too much paper and the plot itself is never fully resolved with a couple of pages at the end to tie up a few loose ends thrown in as an afterthought. The characters were not likeable and the constant  time lapses only to go back and explain what’s happened in the gap were confusing and pointless.

review_title: If you read only one fantasy this year, make it this one!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2013
reviewComment: Kyrus and Brannis live in different worlds. Kyrus is a scribe in a world where the printing press is just coming into fashion. Brannis is a soldier in a land where dragons, ogres and goblins abound. In Kyrus reasonable world magic is "witchcraft." In Brannis' sorcerers exist and thrive with many different skill levels. But, there is a connection between the two characters - in their dreams they see each other's lives. What the reader is asked - are they one-and-the-same existing in parallel worlds? If they are, then are there others like them with alternate selves? Can they assist one another to conquer their enemies? Obtain their dreams?

It also touts that it has valuable coupons.  Most of the coupons are available free either on the internet or with casino coupon books that are readily available elsewhere.  On the plus side there are good descriptions of casino gaming along with viable betting strategies.  Overall, I wanted more detailed information on Casino attractions and deals.  This book was not a good source of that type of information.

If you enjoyed William  Boyd's book, you will not be disappointed by this DVD unless, that is, you were particularly fascinated by the character Ruth.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 15, 2010
reviewComment: Restless allows the reader just enough information from each of the main characters to keep your interest throughout the book as the story develops.  It relates to a daughter who was completely unaware of her mother's real identify and the part she played as an agent in the Second World War.  The mother is writing her account which is revealed in single chapters and has a bearing on the past, present and future, bringing them closer but not without causing ripples in their joint lives.  A worth while book to take on holiday or just to relax with as it slowly unfolds.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 18, 2013
reviewComment: This book is a very interesting concept.  The central protaganist is a young teaching engliish to foreign students and out of the blue her mother tells her that she, her mother was a spy for the UK during the cold war.  The book tells the mothers story by flashback and the daughter helps her mother to trakc down the man who had been her boss and her lover who led her into a trap and it was only by her own ingenuity that she survived.  IT was suspensful and exciting with a particular twist at the end.  An excellent book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2011
reviewComment: During hollidays, spent under the bright sun with my iPad as a reading device, I was jealously looking at the people using proper e-book readers. Searching for the best matching one, I've found 2 interesting: Barnes & Noble Nook Touch and Kobo Touch. My decision was based on the page-turning knobs implemented in the shell, which were lacking in Kobo device. I'm quite happy with Nook Touch, allthough don't really understand the politics behind the sale of the electronic books outside of North America. It's simply impossible to buy smething from NB, not having an adress in States or Canada. DRM coded books can be readed, but without the cover image - probably software issue. Few times, while pressing over the word, which of course highlighted the marking (without choosing any options) it went out of response from the touch screen. The only solution was, either to plug the USB cable, or wait until the device can be accessed - meaning at least one hour.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 23, 2012
reviewComment: The random nature of ultraviolence is both its most frightening aspect and a clear indication of its evil. It leaves everyone feeling vulnerable because anyone could be a victim of an attack. And this is what makes this book so morally problematic. . In ordinary attempts to justify violence, some claim is made that gives a reason why the victim should be harmed. Such attempts focus on the identity of the recipient of justi'ed violence. In self-defense, one may harm one's assailant because the assailant poses a threat to one ís own well-being. In just war thinking there must be a just cause (usually aggression) and violence has to be focused exclusively against the aggressor. But ultraviolence spreads violence in a way that simply ignores the identities of its victims. It is random and unpredictable violence. In Michael Baur's words, it is "systematically unsystematic." The result of ultraviolence is to create panic and chaos, sometimes in order to advance a political agenda, although in the case of Alex and his droogs violence has to be divorced from a political agenda as a sort of nihilistic glee in causing disorder.

review_title: There is humour in this horror
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2018
reviewComment: I’ve been feeling the need to read a few classics lately. I saw the movie with Will Smith.  A lone survivor of a vampire plague who can’t venture anywhere further than a day’s round trip drive from his home. He’s driven mad with loneliness. He’s also intent on wiping out as many of these vampires as he finds. This is the only point on which the movie and the book agree upon. I was pleasantly surprised to read the book and discover a new ending, new characters, and a new storyline. Had it been exactly the same as the movie I might not have enjoyed it so much. The book contains subtle humour as Robert Neville is constantly harassed by his neighbour, Ben Cortman in the book. By the end you begin to feel sorry for poor old Cortman. Especially his tragic ending.

As you walk with him, you’ll begin to identify today’s many religious pitfalls.  As you walk with him, you’ll begin to identify today’s many religious pitfalls. These are presented by men such as Pliable, who turns back at the Slough of Despond; and Ignorance, who believes he’s a true follower of Christ when he’s really only trusting in himself. Each character represented in this allegory is intentionally and profoundly accurate in its depiction of what we see all around us, and unfortunately, what we too often see in ourselves. But while Christian is injured and nearly killed, he eventually prevails to the end. So can you.”

reviewComment: Having dual story lines rich with characters and action taking place in two different worlds, neither of which is our own, this story takes its time setting up for the book's main event, an epic battle between humans and goblins with a dragon and a demon thrown into the mix for good measure. However, if you aren't afraid of a book with 600+ page count and like high fantasy, you can't go wrong here.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2013
reviewComment: I loved the unique storyline of this novel. It was such a refreshing concept, unlike the similarities seen among many fantasy novels. The idea of the duel storyline, with corresponding characters in two different worlds was unique and fascinating. The novel doesn't answer all the questions about exactly how these duel lives work, but I found that to be part of the charm.

review_title: 2 worlds tangled together in a sprawling novel
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2020
reviewComment: at least 2, or perhaps more?, worlds are tangled together in this sprawling novel.  Kyrus is a sorcerer born into a world with no magic, and Brannis is a knight born into a world teeming with magic.  Both men dream of each other's lives and must save one another, despite living in different worlds.  The author attempts an innovative idea, exploring the ways in which different universes are connected to one another.  I enjoyed the book, although I found it overlong.  Despite this, the characters  did display some complexity and humanity, which is something I look for in a complex novel with intertwining plotlines.  I enjoyed the ways in which the characters had to rely on one another, despite not knowing one another physically.  The end of the novel left me wondering if there were other "twins" in other "worlds who had not yet connected. I look forward to reading the other books in this series.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2013
reviewComment: I have to say that this book really caught me off guard in a good way. This is some serious, classic fantasy. This is sword and sorcery, high fantasy, epic, hard fantasy, you name it. Don't let the size of the book put you off, it is long, yes. However, this is a world that needs some time to be built in the reader's eye and with good reason and fabulous end results.

review_title: Great, Different for a Guy Who Reads Alot!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019
reviewComment: I read a ton of fiction.  Part of my job requires me to be a great story teller, so I read a bunch to keep my own skills honed.  And honestly there isn’t much unique writing out there.  I often feel like I’m reading the same story over and over.  This book is a truly refreshing and unique read.  Great characters draw you in, and the concept of two worlds converging through magic keeps you turning pages. Warning: if you read to fall asleep at night, plan on some late nights!

review_title: For All True Fantasy Book Readers
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2013
reviewComment: Firehurler, Book 1 of the Twinborn Trilogy, by J.S. Morin is a book that will light a fire in all true fantasy lovers’ heart. This book is hard to put down once you start reading it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2014
reviewComment: Parallel universes. This is an idea that has been explored in many science fiction stories as well as fantasy and yet the depths of the idea have clearly not been plumbed yet as evidenced by this book. In this first, of what promises to be a very interesting trilogy, we see how various people interact amongst parallel universes. The two universes in this series are Koriah and Acardia and the connections between them are that people in one universe see how their counterparts in the other conduct their lives in their dream state.  So, Brannis Solaran, who is a Knight dreams of the life of Kyrus Hinterdale who is a scribe, and vice versa. While these two are connected through some sort of unexplained link, so are another pair. To add interest to these links, the world that Brannis occupies uses magic and has a high regard for Sorcerers, while Kyrus's world is more technologically focused and the use of magic is very actively discouraged.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2016
reviewComment: A wonderful epic fantasy. Replete with goblins, ogres, dragons knights, magic and sorcery. But it's the unique concept of being Twinborn and its consequent impact on the unfolding stories of those born with this connection in two very different worlds that lifts it above others in this genre.

reviewComment: This indie fantasy was a great book (no spoilers ahead). reviewComment: The Dell Axim X30 624 Mhz was released in 2004. It still has a lot going for it; it's sleek, compact, and attractive, it's got Bluetooth and WiFi, and a 624 Mhz processor (the fastest processor available then). But I can't imagine why anyone would want to buy this outdated model, especially since the price listed here for a brand new unit is higher than what it retailed for in 2004. It uses Windows Mobile 2003 (WM v4), which isn't supported by MS anymore. The current version of Windows Mobile is 6.1.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2006
reviewComment: I loved my Axim X-30 high. Didn't know how I'd ever lived without one. Read books, watched movies, checked my e-mail on the go ... wonderful! However, after owning it for a year and six months (thus out of warranty), I turned it on one morning to be greeting by a solid, white screen. Hard and soft reset had no effect. Switching batteries didn't help.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2007
reviewComment: This would be a wonderful device if you never needed technical support, or if they offered it in English. I have yet, in numerous calls to Dell, to speak to someone who can understand ordinary English sentences or speak without a heavy middle eastern accent. As I write, I'm on hold for the seventh time in the same call. I have been passed back and forth all morning. Everyone is "sorry" for the inconvenience. All I want to know is the secret technique to replace the backup battery without taking the unit out of service and mailing it to Dell. This question has sent them into an endless loop of confusion. I started with technical support who sent me to parts who sent me to customer service who sent me to parts who sent me to technical support. Now I'm on hold.

Sie erscheint nur aufgesetzt. Die Geschichte fesselt daher auch nicht wirklich. Die Botschaft ist mässig, was noch hinzu kommt. Kriminalität durch klassische Konditionierung abzugewöhnen ist eine nette Idee. Das Ende ist versönlich, aber nicht realistisch. Im Endeffekt ein Roman, der mit einer interessanten Idee den Finger in die Wunde legt, aber doch nur an der Oberfläche behandelt und nicht die Ursache.

review_title: I was enthralled from the first chapter...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2013
reviewComment: The mark of a great storyteller is being able to tell a story using familiar themes and plots in novel ways.  Fantasy novels have used the idea of parallel worlds, doppelgangers, and science vs magic for many years.  It is a theme that often feels repetitive to me and doesn't offer much in new ideas.  This book blew me away and captivated me from start to finish.  Many characters are well fleshed out and often shown in shades of grey. Good guys can do bad things depending on the situation, and the bad guys do have good moments and may even do something honorable.  Black and white characters are boring.  Mr Morin created a great book and can't wait to see how his story continues in the next book !

review_title: Christian polemic dressed up as suspense novel
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2010
reviewComment: "Rooms" is a mediocre mash-up of a mid-life crisis novel and a religious tract.  Spiritual growth is shoe-horned into the protagonist's life through the plot device of a house that grows rooms full of cool toys and stunningly obvious metaphors designed to support the main character's dead-uncle-and-God-administered psychotherapy. This unfortunate book is filled with magic passed off as "miracles", something that should make an intelligent Christian shudder.  Worse, the pace is painfully slow, a mechanism clearly intended to create anticipation in the reader in the absence of interesting content.  The writing technique isn't terrible, but the same can't be said for either the plot or the character development - all sad parodies of real human beings: vapid, self-absorbed, and so completely lacking in self-awareness that I'm hard pressed to think of anyone actually like this.

review_title: so I can easily get around
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2018
reviewComment: I buy Steve's guide every year before I go to Las Vegas for an extended stay.  It's well worth the cost and should be considered an exceptional value.  There are coupons for many of the casinos I would be going to anyway, but it also encourages me to branch out and visit "new" casinos that I might not otherwise get to just to take advantage of the coupons.  I use both the match play and dining coupons.  I'm lucky in that I get to house-sit for friends who live in LV, considerably west of the Strip, and I have use of their car, so I can easily get around.  If you're stuck on the Strip, you might not get as much use out of the guide, but remember, it's not only good for coupons, it's also a good source of gambling information generally.  I highly recommend the guide.  Otherwise, I certainly wouldn't buy it year after year!

reviewComment: The match play coupons (there's several $10 and one $25 coupons) are very useful for those who don't have a lot of money to gamble.  Also, there's several free slot play coupons, which I used and won a few dollars, and in turn, used that won money with the match play coupons (essentially, gambling for free).  The only caveat is that with most of these coupons, you need to become a new member of the casinos players club.  I would suggest that you use these coupons during the day, to avoid long lines and any embarrassment.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2011
reviewComment: For what I wanted it to do, namely display some of the pdf files and books that I already have on hand, this does a pretty poor job of it. The default software is not compatible with many would-be useful formats such as txt or rtf. There is no folder view for displaying the books you put on it, you are constrained to a library view that tries to sort everything for you. The settings page is a joke, there is almost no customization to be had there. The shop's main view was nonfunctional out of the box; every time I tried to access it, it kicked me back out to the main page, and I had to access it by going to the "top 100" page instead, and even then the search would sometimes not work. The battery capacity went down 20% over 4 days, so I don't think that it would make the 2 month mark that it should have.

reviewComment: Looked forward to reading this Conan Doyle Estate - approved Novel. A First for a Holmes novel. Found it well written and in the style of the original canon. I just found the resulting subject matter to be unnecessary and distasteful. It may be an historically accurate subject, but I do not read the canon or pastiches to be reminded of today's debauched headlines. I read them to escape to a simpler time when the Master and his loyal friend would cut through the fog and save the day. I read them to escape the ugliness of the world. This book reminded me too much of what is prevalent today. No disrespect meant to the author.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 2, 2013
reviewComment: An Intriguing story of the strange world of spies during the Second World War . Eva ,the main character is recruited by the mysterious and ultimately unknowable spymaster Romer. The book charts her assignments and their affair, as told by Eva to her daughter years later. The author skilfully draws the reader into the troubled , uncertain , desperate lives of the spies, using the late 20th century focus provided by Eva's daughter's ordinary life, as a contrast. The writer skilfully shows the cost to those who chose or were persuaded into spying and this aspect of the book is powerful and disturbing .  I'd recommend this book to anyone who likes a well written and intelligent thriller.

reviewComment: One of William Boyd's best.  Gripping, tantalising, complex, and set in the fascinating world of British espionage in World War II, the little known 'BSC' based in New York. This unusual setting alone makes it compelling, and the characters and action are excellent.  Has to be read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 4, 2018
reviewComment: All you could expect in a modern spy novel.  Develops characters, creates tension, credulous.  Enjoyable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 22, 2019
reviewComment: good story

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 2, 2013
reviewComment: Couldn't put this book down.  Terrific plot and story telling.  Back and forward between the 2nd world war and the 1970's.  Eva Delectorskaya, spy, mother, wife.  Her daughter, Ruth Gilmartin, learns of her mothers history in disbelief through reading her memoirs.  Loved it and thoroughly recommend. My favourite Boyd read so far ............

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 14, 2012
reviewComment: This was my first William Boyd book and I loved it. Some people have given the book 1 star and think it drags. For me that wasn't true. I really enjoyed the slow, tense build up and the characterisations. I was completely drawn into the story and it will stay with me for a long time. I'm off to recommend it to my friends.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 15, 2013
reviewComment: Bought the paperback after watching the television adaptation, which closely followed the novel. Excellent plotline and and atmosphere: both wartime and the 1970s are created in detail and I can vouch for the 1970s, at least, being authentic! Restless has encouraged me to read more of Boyd's fiction.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 30, 2016

review_title: Not perfect, but  a great product
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2000
reviewComment: I have wanted a Palm Pilot since they came out and being a poorcollege student, I wanted to make sure that I got the best dealpossible.  I have had my Palm IIIx for about a month and I can say that I am quite pleased with it. There are a few flaws, but I will present the pros and cons of purchasing a Palm IIIx. Please email me with any questions.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2005
reviewComment: I have had my Palm IIIx for almost 5 years now, and it is still working as well as the day I bought it!  I am more than satisfied with Palm products, and am currently looking into a Tungsten as an upgrade.  The Windows based palmtops are nice too, but they cannot beat the Palm's reliability and ease of use.  The software is also very stable and easy to use.  This is the only device of its kind I own that has never lost data or become corrupted.  Reliability goes a long way with me, so I give it 5 stars!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2012
reviewComment: It works for me. That's all it has to do. It was and still is, an interesting idea who's time came and is still with us.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2016
reviewComment: LNIB

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2009
reviewComment: Pretty easy to use and down load programs for someone that can spell kompooter 2 out of 3 times.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2000
reviewComment: I've had my Palm IIIx for over a year now, but I'm going to have to get another, because I dropped it. The Palm didn't fall far -- 3 feet or so -- but it is now useless. White lines cover the display, and the digitizer no  longer works reliably. I have tried opening up the case and re-seating the  circuit boards, which fixed most of the problems, but the digitizer is  permanently inaccurate. Even with re-calibration of the digitizer using  preferences, the location the Palm thinks I'm hitting with the stylus is  wrong, and this makes using the Palm impossible.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2000
reviewComment: If you don't want to spend all that money on the slimmer, sleeker Palm V, and you know you don't want a WinCE device, then the IIIx is the way to go.

review_title: A great choice but not perfect
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2000
reviewComment: The big questions these days is what organizer to get. I'll assume you are reading these reviews because you already know that the Palm OS beats CE any day. So the choice is a Palm Vx, a Palm V, a IIIx or a Visor. I can't recommend the Visor right now due to the horrible problems people are  having with Handspring...maybe in another year, but not now.

review_title: What wouldl I do without it?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2000
reviewComment: Having used a paper Daytimer for years, I was a little skeptical about going electronic with my datebook and phone listing.  Boy, have I been converted!  The Palm IIIx (my second Palm - the first being a III) is, for  me, a great value.

review_title: When it worked, I couldn't live without it...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2000
reviewComment: When I first got my IIIx, I adored it.  I simply couldn't live without it.  All of my appointments were in there, my friends addresses, phone numbers, everything.  As soon as I knew of a meeting or doctor's visit, got a new phone number, I would pop it open and enter it.  I was in heaven.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2008
reviewComment: This is a must for me to buy every year because of the money it saves me in coupons. I've been buying this guide every year for at least the last 5 years just for the coupons.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2018
reviewComment: I loved this book. I read it prior to moving to Las Vegas. It may have been a factor in my decision to uproot my family from the midwest to Vegas. I would read a little every day. It felt good reading it while it was -20 degrees on those cold January nights.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2010
reviewComment: My copmlaint is not with the value of the content of the book but with the terrible quality of the binding.  Every time I open the book a few more pages fall out so I end up with a stack of looseleaf papers.  Because we carry the book in our motorhome it gets handled more than if it was sitting on a shelf at home and even though we have learned to handle it carefully it keeps disassembling itself.  We had the 2008 version and it did the same thing.  They need to hire a new bookbinder.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2003
reviewComment: While this guide is quite comprehensive, it's really more of a yellow pages for casinos than a good all-around guide. With chaning casino conditions and (in some cases) locations, this guide is a handy starting point, but you're best off researching the particulars of any casino on your own. Also, the book touts the value of the included coupons, but the majority of the coupons are worthless or contain offers that you can get by just walking into any casino.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2010
reviewComment: If you are going to Vegas, there is no reason not to purchase this book. We used a lot of the matchplay coupons and came out ahead $80 just on those during our last visit. The restaurant and buffet coupons for 2009 were good, but 2010 looks even better. There is a BOGO for the Rio's amazing buffet. If you only use that coupon for dinner, you've paid for the cost of the book. Just picked up our 2010 copy for our trip to Vegas early next month. A must have if you are willing to try something other than just walking up and down the strip.

review_title: New Coupon Procedure Not Well Thought Out
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2004
reviewComment: I get this book every year and find it to be a great source of savings. However, this years edition requires you when using the coupons to comply with a new condition printed on the coupon. It states: "Offer void if detached from book. This coupon should only be removed at the time of redemption." The author states in his remarks in the book as well as his remarks here on Amazon that this was done as a reult of abuses and counterfeiting of the coupons. I can understand this and have no problem with this. My problem is the fact that there are three coupons per page and the coupons do not have preforations to easily remove the coupon at the time of use. This is especially hastlesome if you need to use the middle coupon, as you usually end up ripping the top and bottom coupons trying to evenly remove the center coupon. A little common sense and forethought should have been used when designing the coupon section of the book......maybe next year's issue will come with a pair of mini scissors. Other than this years coupon 'preforation oversight' this book is well worth the money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2008
reviewComment: We made 5 trips from FL to Vegas last year,11 wks total, 2 to Biloxi, and 1 to Atlantic City. This year we've made 1 trip to Vegas, 3 wks, we're going to Biloxi next week, 2/20, Mohegan Sun on 3/6 (will go to Foxwood), and back to Vegas on 4/23 for another 2 wks. Weve saved hundreds using the 5 we bought last year and the 3 we purchased in the later part of 07, and ordered 3 more today, 2/14. Someone posted you can find deals like this on line-where???? Please put your ans. on this web site. We either get free rooms or pay $20-25 per night, and have never, never, found better coupons then what's in this book. PERIOD. We also use LVA and the Entertainment book, but ACG is the best for the $$$$$$$.

review_title: An amazing resource for the Vegas gambler pro or wannabe!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2011
reviewComment: You're planning for a little vacation to Vegas? You must buy this book, the coupons alone are worth the book 20 fold. And this counts to if you're not planning to go to Vegas only, it covers all the casino's from the US. Great tips on biggest pay outs on the slots. I was very happy with this book. I combined this book with the [...] system and with the assistance of this book did some serious 'casino-hopping' and did some serious damage :-)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2008
reviewComment: Our third trip to Vegas is coming up in October. I always use Alamo for our car rental and I have used the same coupon to book the car every trip. This alone more than paid for the cost of the book the first time I used it. I have never been asked for the coupon at the rental car center so am able to use it multiple times. We have also used several of the match play and food coupons. Although the majority of the coupons are for off strip locations, many are for downtown including Binions Steakhouse, Main Street Station etc. You won't be disappointed.

review_title: expired coupons, little information for tourist

reviewComment: this book sounds great, but then you find that the coupons are expired, there is little information for the tourist and not much more information than one can find just reading a few sites online. this book is definately geared toward those tht gamble or are starting to learn to gamble, not the travel guide that many may think it to be. very disapointed.

O livro trata de temas muito profundos, e ao mesmo tempo fala da mulher, do papel na sociedade, das pressões e culpas. É muito bom.

reviewComment: This was recommended to me by Cornerstones UK Literary Consultancy on what it takes to write a compelling wartime fictional thriller. Boy, were they right. I loved the way Boyd leapfrogged the story between several decades, the tensions encountered by a female spy in the wartime forties to the quiet and undisclosed simmering seventies when she's become a mother, still harassed by what happened to her more than 40 years before.

reviewComment: This book was selected by a Reading Group and not my usual choice.  However, beautiful writing style, interesting characters  and absorbing plot. reviewComment: Once I figured out how to turn it on it was great.  As advertised, really tough so good for me.  I dropped the last one and that was it.  This is much more durable

review_title: A Great Choice, If You Can Afford It
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2000
reviewComment: I have been very satisfied with this product since I bought it a year ago.  It is definitely more rugged than most portable CD players, and it does survive encounters with dirt and splashes.  The anti-skip mechanism works  as advertised, for the most part.  It works pretty well for low impact  activity, like bike riding and jogging.  The CD will still skip during very  jarring activity, though.  That's probably unavoidable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2001
reviewComment: I hate to join in this chorus of unsatisfied customers, but I'm not given much of a choice.  I'm on my 2nd and last Sony Sport Discman.  It's been consistently breaking down with either the LCD screen blanking out, the volume adjustment getting screwed up, or it just not working at all.  Now, they don't even offer it with a rechargeable battery alternative. I say to SONY--either improve this product, or DO THE RIGHT THING--Take it off the market to not damage SONY's product quality!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2002
reviewComment: I am ashamed to admit it, but I actually bought two of these. My first one suffered a small drop onto carpet, after which the LCD display, then the entire player quit working. Although I thought that this was supposed to be a very rugged player, I felt that perhaps that was too much of a jolt, even for this player. Assuming that the mistake was mine, I bought another one. The new one was never dropped, never jostled, I even kept it unnecessarily dry. However, after only a few months... same story: LCD display goes first, then the entire player.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 19, 2000
reviewComment: This is acually a good player when you first purchase it. You really notice the sound quality and the different features such as "groove" and "mega bass" functions. The water resistant  body is also good for pool side listening. The head phones that are  included are not very good ones and are easy to break. They also feel very  weak when you wear them. The anti-shock memory could have more capacity but  with the locking hood, it helps. This is a great CD player until it begins  to age. After a year and two months, mine started to act up. You would have  to push play three or four times before it would start. The LCD screen  started to blink and go out at times. Eventually you have to put foil on  the button inside or else the CD player will not know the lid is closed.  Then my motor went out. This is a good player but for a short amount of  time.

review_title: Sony made a very bad product.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2003
reviewComment: After about two months, the LCD malfunctioned.  It only occasionally worked.  After three years, the unit stopped working altogether.  After taking the unit apart to see what is wrong with it, I've discovered opening and closing the waterproof top contributes to the destruction of the unit.  When you open the top, you will notice a series of connectors in a plastic electronic strip at the bottom of the lid, below this the electronic strip is folded in an awkward way, which after several hundred openings, the slight tension causes the strip to naturally sever, hence the unit ceases to operate.  The sad fact of the matter is I've owned this unit for three years and only used it for about 100 hours of operation.  Not much!

review_title: Gratified and thrilled that Holmes is back.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2015
reviewComment: Having discovered Sherlock Holmes when I was 14 and bedridden while recovering from an injury and surgery, I was overjoyed to find that Mr. Horowitz  has brought him back to us. Over the years, I had introduced Holmes to my daughter, who now uses the stories to teach high school students the joy that can be found in reading; that a Kindle is more fun than an X box, and that comprehending any well written piece is an accomplishment that adds enjoyment, and even self-esteem to one's life. I cannot wait to tell her this evening that Holmes has been reborn, and that Mr. Horowitz  does justice to Conan Doyle in every way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
reviewComment: Fantasy story lovers will love how this portrays Sorcerers, Ogres, Goblins & other magic & put it together with a twin from another world/universe,one who lives your life while he dreams & vice versa. If you want to be entertained for many hours then Beginning this trilogy is for you. The book on the whole is very well written & the characters play very well off of their own settings. It well deserves a 5 star rating for its writing & rewriting character development.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 25, 2015
reviewComment: Firehurler is a brilliant fantasy story with a simple and wonderfully creative plot device; essentially it gives the reader two stories in one, but is really one story (if that makes sense). Morin’s plot device consists of two worlds linked and running side by side which makes this story very interesting. It allows for some fun character interaction across the link and uniquely affects how the characters behave in each world. I really enjoyed the plot devices impact on the story and it is used well.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 7, 2014

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 10, 2018
reviewComment: I stumbled across this via a Goodreads recommendation.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 26, 2015
reviewComment: A fascinating and unique concept, and the execution (mostly) did not disappoint. The characters are well developed, the two worlds are clearly differentiated and yet connected, and the plot had me staying up late trying to finish. Unfortunately, there were a few issues of style that kept jolting me out of my enjoyment, specifically the author's tendency to keep falling out of POV. I realize that omniscient 3rd is a valid narrative decision, and it can work, but the abrupt changes between solid, in-their-head 3rd person and objective character description - and then right back - kept throwing me, and at times seemed rather random, as did the jumps between characters in the same place. For example, at one point Brannis and Iridan are in the same place, viewing the same event, and both their reactions are shown in quick succession, which was slightly jarring. In another place, Rashan's actions are shown from a distance rather than from his POV for no apparent reason. The biggest offender, though, is the description of the characters the first time you meet them - detailed, and helpful for building up a mental image, but objective and from an outside viewpoint, and usually dropped in the middle of a passage that is anything but.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2009
reviewComment: I buy this book every year and would no visit any casino without it. I have probably saved over $3000 over the years with this book and it has made me a better gambler which has save me thousands more.

reviewComment: The American Casino Guide is perfect for anyone going to a gaming area in the United States. Since I travel to Las Vegas at least once a year, I appreciated having this book. reviewComment: For anyone living in Vegas, or for someone coming to visit, this book is a must.  It gathers together in one place deals throughout the strip and community.  Some are available on premise or in other coupon books, but this book puts them all in one place, good for the year.  It makes both planning ahead and impulse entertainment both fun and money saving.  Worth many time the cover price!

reviewComment: A "must have" book for anyone planning a trip to Las Vegas. A great reference source for casinos anywhere in the USA, but with tremendous amount of information on Las Vegas (things to see, things to do, best deals, etc.). Section in the back of the book contains dozens of discount coupons for rooms, food, sight seeing, gaming, etc., that can pay for the book many times over, in most cases.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2009
reviewComment: We saved several times the cost of the book and only used a few of the coupons.  All the free slot play coupons would more than pay for the book for new slot club members.  Make sure you use the Ellis Island (behind Ballys) 2 for 1 coupon-ribs are great.  With coupon, 2 1/2 rack baby back rib dinners with cole slaw, baked beans & bread are just $11.99.  Next year we are going to buy two books.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2000
reviewComment: I have to say that I've grown very dependent on my IIIx.  I'd give it a score of 5 except for the streaking problem.  Mine didn't do this right away.  It started hapening about 6 months after I began to use it.  Sometimes its there sometimes it isn't.  When its there, the streaking  (looks like water was spilled on a sheet of ink writing) can make the  screen totally unreadable.  Five minutes later, all can be fine.  PDA need  to be dependable.  Mine isn't always.  Before I started reading other  reviews, I thought mine was just broken.  I was considering buying another  but not if by luck, I get another "streaker".  Even though I like  the IIIx, its reasonably priced (though still expensive), has great  software options, I'd be cautious about buying another one.  Probably  wouldn't go with the IIIx if I had known about the streaking problem in  advance.

review_title: The best value for your money
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2000
reviewComment: As an obsessive-compulsive middle-management suck-up, I knew that I would ultimately own a Palm of some sort.  Deciding which PDA to purchase proved extremely difficult.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2000
reviewComment: The palm will certainly revolutionize the way you arrange your life. At the touch of a button, you can connect it to your PC and transfer all of its information (which also means you can input information to your palm  from your PC). There's a myriad of freeware available on the net that will  enhance the performance of the Palm IIIx. The screen is great for viewing.  4MB is more than you'll ever need (I have many programs loaded, and  thousands of phone numbers and appointments, and I only use 1.3 MB).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2000
reviewComment: This latest incarnation of the Palm III adds memory and the capability to expand, a little.  While lacking the sex appeal of the Palm V and the Dick  Tracy like abilities of the Palm VII, the IIIx also lacks it's sibling's  extravagant price tags.  With 4 megs of memory, there is plenty of room for  data with enough left over to add some favorite software.  The IR port  makes it possible to beam data to Palm owning friends and the solid, no  frills operating system and software are easy to use and crash free.  If I  had a complaint, it would be that graffiti is not as intuitive as I would  like.  It could have something to do with my sloppy writing, but the Palm  seems so smart in other ways that I expect it to do better.  Still,  Graffiti is more than adequate for entering the occasional appointment or  business card.  This Palm has performed for me as advertised.  My life is  more organized and I have more valuable information at my fingertips.  It  is reliable and easy to use.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 1999
reviewComment: I bought by Palm IIIx on a whim.  I figured, "Well, everyone else seems to think they're great."  They were right.  The Palm IIIx is fantastic.  For me, the best features are its address book and the "To  Do List."  Gone are the little scraps of paper I used to use to keep  all my lists of stuff to do.  I've been completely neglecting my paper  address book ever since I got the IIIx.  Between its small size, its ease  of use, and its versatility, this Palm is a winner all around.  BTW, I  highly recommend the O'Reilly PalmPilot guide to go with it.  Like all  O'Reilly books, this one cuts right to the chase.  It makes the IIIx even  easier to use.

review_title: First time user: a solid all around product
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2000
reviewComment: It's been about a month since I got my Palm IIIx. Since then, I'm more organized than I've ever been. I decided to get myself a palm pilot for two reasons. I hated having to manually update my monthly planner whenever a  new year rolled in (things like birthdays, anniversaries, etc.). Another  reason was because I wanted all my contact information to be in one single  place.  I had these info spread out all around me like a wild fire (some at  home, at work, in the bathroom, ah... just kidding on the bathroom, but you  get the point, right?). With this Palm I can have upto 12,000 people in my  address book (I have 100 so far and I've been telling people that the  10,000th person to go into my palm address book gets free dinner from me,  ha.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2000
reviewComment: I bought a PalmIIIx about 6 months ago and I have been very dissapointed.  Don't get me wrong... in principle the ability to store and beam addresses & business cards, manage my calander, securely store network passwords  is great!  When the unit was working I loved it.  However, after about  three months of ownership, I began loosing all my data at random  internvals, forcing me to revert back to my last sync with my computer. I  would turn the unit on and all my data was gone... evern with fresh  batteries.  Palm was not able to diaganise the problem... just telling me  to re-set it again... duh.  The last time this happened the unit went  completely dead. It could be that I just had a bad unit.  However, I would  advise other Palm purchacers not to store any critical data on the unit. As  for me, I would not buy another Palm product.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2000
reviewComment: Does Palm have a problem it's not admitting? My two-day old Palm IIIx lost all its data this morning--garbage on the screen, no response to power button. A soft reset "restored" the unit--not the data, of  course, just the factory defaults.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 1999
reviewComment: I have had a Palm for the past two years and found I cannot live without it. It is not only the built in applications which make my life easier, but the thousands of 3rd party applications available for free or next to  nothing on the internet, which expand the use of my palm to something I use  20 times a day. There is software which will allow you to track your  banking and merge the data with Quicken or other banking software, store  maps, look up a zip code or area code, download entire books, play games,  create shopping lists, and with a modem, even let you surf the internet, or  send and receive e-mail and faxes. I even have my entire CD collection of  over 600 cd's stored by artist, title and song name which I converted from  a spreadsheet and stored on my Palm. When I go to the record store to find  new songs, I can instantly see if I have a particular song on another disk.  The endless expandibility via 3rd party applications is probably the Palm  IIIx best feature.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2010
reviewComment: Yes, still using it most days for work after 11years of hard knocks. Great for note padding, phone book and diary keeping. So suprised my one hasn't packed up yet, always expecting one day I will upgrade when it gives up the ghost. Its been a great back up when I've been on the road rushing about my job and even when my employer changed all office based PCs from 98 to XP, the palm download upgrade accessed from the net gave me no problems with compatibility. Mine just will not die, even in the past when I have noticed a brief screen issue with the odd rare black out and thinking has it finally reached its holy grail, it always sorts itself out and gets back to normal fairly quickly.I have had it so long that I cannot remember if I could edit the downloaded excel and word docs with the stylus. It does not do it now so it might have failed in one aspect. The PC software has always been very user friendly and I use both the hand held and the PC on a regular basis to edit its data. Top marks to Palm for a state of the art unit when I got it in '99 and therefore I shall be buying my next from Palm without doubt (looking forward to a colour screen at last).

reviewComment: I purchased the Kindle (Wi-Fi) and the original Nook (the B&W one) and tried them out during the return period. reviewComment: I'm one of those readers that loves buying physical books and who has avoided e-readers and e-books for as long as I could. It's been sitting around the house for about two years now, getting extremely occasional use. Recently I've found myself in a situation where I have to purchase e-books regularly because many of my favorite authors are releasing novellas or short story collections without print versions, and this has come in extremely handy.

review_title: It is great if you know what you are in for
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2014
reviewComment: I love the B&N Nook Simple Touch.  I can't compare it to the Amazon Paperwhite, because I refuse to try one.  The Nook has expandable memory (which I do not believe the Paperwhite does).  Up to 32GB, which means I can save around 32,000 books.  If, for some reason, I need more space, then I can just drop another 15-20 bucks, and have another 32GB (though I will have my collection split over two memory cards).  I also like that B&N accepts ePub, which is pretty much the universal standard, whereas Amazon locks you into their own store.  This means that you can shop Sony's store with a Nook, and Nook's store with a Sony, but Amazon can't access either of those stores.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2011
reviewComment: This novel, based on the original period and characters of Conan Doyle's invention, is excellent. I've enjoyed Sherlock Holmes stories since boyhood, and read many extensions of the works, and this ranks among the best. The writing style is strongly aligned with Conan Doyle's, the mysteries are solved in the inimitable Holmes style, and the locales are captured wonderfully. I rarely have my eyes nailed to the page throughout the resolution of a novel, but from start to finish, Horowitz keeps you riveted. After so many Jack Reacher-esque books, one begins to despair that someone can finish a novel as strongly as they start it. Reading this is like returning to a gallery filled with masters' works after tiring of shoddy modern stuff. Great, and reassuring that the genre has not been drained of elegance, style, and complexity.

review_title: It's easy to use, dubs and plays commercial tapes well ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2001
reviewComment: I have this VCR for about two years. The commercial advance stopped working properly and I am starting to get error messages and the tape pops out for no reason. However, I record on a daily basis then watch the shows at night so the machine gets a lot of wear and tear and could probably use a good cleaning. My only real problem with the machine is it doesn't pull in the channels as well as it should. For that reason I only record shows I plan to watch and tape over. I use my SONY to tape any shows I wish to save and have a noce copy of. However, to dub tape to tape or watch commercial tapes, it is a great machine. It is very easy to use and I like that I never have to reset the clock, not even for daylight savings time. But I bought it to tape from the TV, and it is a very poor machine for that. It could use more insulation or whatever is needed to block out interference.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 1999
reviewComment: This is a good enough VCR, which I bought to replace a Sony in the same price range. The machine just arrived and I'm both happy and disappointed. There is no counter on the unit  itself, which is an annoyance (especially since you can't hear the unit  playing, rewinding, anything). I'm happy enough to keep it and it plays  prerecorded tapes beautifully... but I liked my Sony better.

This PDA can organize your life and add functionality to YOU. I love it!  gives you newspapers, tv listings, maps and more. You need, want, desire the  increased memory - trust me. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2005
reviewComment: I purchased the Palm IIIX because I thought that it had an open expansion slot for addition of memory upgrade cards.  I wasn't able to locate the expansion slot for additional memory, so, I contacted Palm.  The customer representative stated that it is only upgradeable as far as the operating system is concerned.  You aren't able to use an additional memory card for this handheld.

review_title: For a first purchase...this is the one
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2000
reviewComment: This was the first PDA I had ever purchased and I was unsure if the product would meet my needs.  After reading all the reviews I decided to purchase the Palm IIIx...and I have to say that the product more than lives up to the reviews.  It is easy to use and has more than enough features for  the standard user.  I wonder why it took me so long to purchase one after  using my Palm IIIx.  I would recommend this product to anyone.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2000
reviewComment: I am a first time owner of the Palm IIIx and I am currently searching for an alternative.  I received my Palm IIIx as a gift about 7 months ago, and I have lost all of the data in my organizer 8 times.  I am an active  professional in the television industry and I travel to remote parts of the  world for weeks at a time.  I have been away from my computer (to HotSync  and restore the data) all but one time and have been left without vital  professional and personal contacts as well as lost all new contacts and  production memos and notes.  I have determined the cause of the failure.  If you own a Palm IIIx and have it with you, follow along with me.  Locate  the battery compartment on the back of the unit.  Open it up and look at  the way the compartment is designed to have the batteries installed.  The  top AAA battery slot is designed such that the positive end of the battery  (the one with the 'bump') must maintain contact with a wire coil.  What  happens is this.  Let's say you have your Palm IIIx in your purse,  briefcase, backpack, fannypack or WHEREVER.  If you drop your bag, set it  down a little too hard, or even RUN with it, chances are that the contact  coil will slip off of the positive terminal on the battery and you'll lose  all of the memory in your organizer.  First and foremost, I CANNOT BELIEVE  that 3Com allowed this product to be released with such an incredibly inept  design flaw.  Second, I can't believe that they didn't install a back-up  battery to which the organizer defaults in cases of lost power for ANY  reason (let alone because the inherent design of the product leaves it  prone to losing power and therefore data).  Finally, 3Com Customer Service  has done NOTHING to respond to my repeated attempts to bring this to their  attention and ameliorate the situation.  The Palm IIIx is SUPPOSED to be a  powerful tool for powerful people.  I'd be surprised if the execs at 3Com  would utilize their own product.

review_title: The PalmIIIx is great, but I have a few problems.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2000
reviewComment: First, I have to agree with the electronics fan from Chicago.  Although my Palm got the date right, some of the pixels on the screen would stay lit no matter what program was running.  At first the "Customer Care  Center" with Palm accused me of dropping it or something;  "physical damage".  They told me it would cost me $100 (US) to  have it replaced (I assumed a new unit). This really irrtated me.  When I  bought it (Dec. '99)it worked fine, when I replaced the batteries once, I  started to have problems like this.  Eventually, after some serious,  pissiness on the phone with representitive, they offered me a used unit.  I  sympathize with the electronics fan.  After all, it doesn't even feel like  mine, call me crazy, but I bought MINE not someone else's.  So far the used  Palm has worked fine, but I would really like them to fix their mistakes  for us insted of shipping off the other misfit products to their customers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 1999
reviewComment: WOW! Such power in a very small package. The IIIx came into my paper strewed life just when I lost my last paper Day Timer---Yeech!  With a Palm it gets to be easy to write down your important notes, appointments and  numbers. Hot Sync with your desktop and you have instant backup. At first,  I thought it would be very difficult starting from ground zero to use and  transfer information from other desktop programs. But with the help of an  "Idiot" book on the Palm it was very easy. It was a big help. I  hope I find my Day Timer before tax time or the IRS will have a field day  with me and my mileage expenses!  Some programs like Card Scan were tricky  to transfer data but I managed. This is not against the Palm, but rather,  programs that give little explaination to help make a smooth transfer of  data to the Palm. Another WOW! Someone just found my Day Timer in  Baltimore!

review_title: Love it so much I'm neglecting my laptop!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 1999
reviewComment: I absolutely love my Palm IIIx.  Originally, my wife ordered a Handspring Visor for my birthday.  Six weeks later, with no indication of when (if ever) the Visor would be shipping, she cancelled it and ordered the Palm  IIIx for me instead.  I've been playing endless with it since.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2000
reviewComment: As a frequent traveler I've often found myself in a situation where a notebook/laptop was a burden to carry and use (where do I plug in to recharge?). With Palm IIIx i've met a device which can hold the regular  data I need :bussiness and personal contacts, appointments, e-mails.  The  new screen offers better contrast and the AAA batteries seem to run  forever.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2000
reviewComment: I bought the IIIx last Christmas and 3Com has already upgraded it with the IIIxe and the IIIc, the major upgrades being the extra memory for the xe  and the color for the c.  However, the IIIx still stands on it's own quite  well.  With 4 mb of memory, it still has lots of room for applications and  data.  It took a few weeks to get used to using a PDA, but once I did, it  has saved me time and time again as I have not once doubled booked an  appointment since having this device.  Right now it's the lowest cost 3com  unit that has the upgradable OS capability, which I think is an important  feature.  If you have the $50, you might as well move up to the xe and get  the extra 4 mb of memory, but if you don't and need a workhorse, there  isn't much the more expensive IIIxe will do that the IIIx can do just as  well.  I'm sold on mine.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2000
reviewComment: This is my third Palm and the best yet. I chose the the IIIx because of the 4meg and the fact that it uses AAA batteries. I travel often and cannot worry about keeping the Palm in a cradle to re-charge. The V is a  disappointment unless you are only into style and keeping a few  appointments and addresses. The 2meg is a huge downside and is only good  for the casual user. If you use Avantgo daily, then the V is going to hold  you back from fully utilizing this great site.The Vx, which is still pricy,  is an 8meg unit and far beyond the needs of the average user.If price is no  object, then this a great unit, except for the re-charging needs of being  in a cradle.  At it's current pricing, there is no question that the IIIx  is the best valued PDA in the marketplace .
