reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2012
reviewComment: As a librarian, I can not and do not recommend this product to my patrons.  The product itself is faulty, and the customer service and return policies are very poor.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2012
reviewComment: I purchased a Nook in Chicago in 10/2011. I explained to the salesperson that I lived outside of the US and needed assurance that the device would work outside the US. I was assured that there was no problem. I paid for the Nook with my non-US credit card. I returned to Guatemala the next day. I excitedly booted up my Nook only to find out that it would not work with a non-US credit card. I immediately contact the Nook on-line support. They told me that I would have to return the Nook within 15 days to get a refund. I explained that was impossible as I was in Guatemala.

review_title: Simple touch Reader is not one that I can use
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2014
reviewComment: I got this as a  birthday gift from my kids. I was really excited to get a reader but because of some diabetic retinopathy I couldn't read it well. I need something with a backlight. I tried to take it back to Barnes and Noble to purchase a more expensive one that I could use but as always they were not willing to help me. They are the worst at customer service I have ever seen. I won't buy anything from them ever again. They are just unwilling to help. They always have a very lame excuse. I've asked my kids not to buy anything for me from them every again. I sure won't. This NOOK is of no use to me at all, it's not easy to use or easy to read and I just wanted to trade it in, pay more for something I could use but they said sense I had opened the package and tried to use it that I could not return it. Now I have a NOOK that is of know value at all to me and a store that is unwilling to help me in any way even though I had a receipt and an unused product. I will buy product from Amazon because they are so good to support their customers but I won't buy any product that is a Barnes and Noble. product at all.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2011
reviewComment: I got this nook for Christmas from my parents, it is light and easy to use. My only issue is that you can't go on the internet with the nook, but it is still really good for reading. review_title: Permanently frozen screens on 2x Nook Simple Touch.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2013
reviewComment: Yes, the Nook Simple Touch is a lovely little ereader - when it works. I bought one last year while living in the US, and soon after the screen startet freezing on a regular basis, requiring a hard reset to start working again. Then after a while the customer service kindly send me a new one, which soon after had the exact same problem - only even worse. Now I am back in Europe and stuck with a useless device, and there seems to be no repair solution! B&N; stop sending people defect products, it would save a lot of effort in the first place.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 22, 2007
reviewComment: I enjoyed "Restless" immensely. I've long been a fan of William Boyd. He writes with highly descriptive, flowing, easily readable style. Each of his books is very different from the last. "Restless" is about Russian born Eva Delectorskaya, who becomes an agent for the British secret service during WWII. However, the book is set in 1976, and the story is told by Eva's daughter who belatedly finds out about her mother's past. The chapters alternate between Eva's wartime spy stories, which are brilliant and utterly absorbing, and the 1976 exploits of her daughter which are not quite so entertaining. I actually formed quite a dislike to the daughter very early in the book. I don't know whether or not Boyd intended this. However it didn't spoil the novel for me and the overall reading experience was extremely good. I would strongly recommend this novel.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 29, 2014
reviewComment: Excellent book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 4, 2007
reviewComment: I started reading this book and couldn't put it down. The detailed account of the training and life of a female spy, the complicated but well-described plot, the action, the terrific characters and the historical context, all made for a highly enjoyable read from start to finish.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Italy on August 2, 2018
reviewComment: Un bel colpo, scoprire che la propria madre non è mai stata quella che abbiamo immaginato di conoscere per tutta la nostra vita. Ancora di più, se la mamma 2.0, si rivela essere stata un'attivissima membro dei servizi segreti militari inglesi. Sempre grande nella narrazione e nella lingua, un inglese semplice e non banale. Una storia solo apparentemente gialla (anche se potente), perché a Boyd, in fin dei conti, ciò che interessa è indagare l'agnizione e il mondo delle possibili personalità e vite alternative (grande esempio in Ordinary Thunderstorms...ad esempio) di un individuo, non necessariamente migliori. Da leggere e godere.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Italy on August 20, 2017
reviewComment: I had a hard time to connect with the story and its characters for more than a third of the book; I found both rather irrelevant and I have been a step away from putting the book down more than once.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on June 10, 2018
reviewComment: Good intrigue involving a daughter trying to comprehend her mother's hidden past.  By moving between the two worlds, Boyd's tale slowly reveals a WWII espionage endeavour. The two women are original and interesting and completely credible. Boyd's sensitivity to telling details of setting create the worlds of mother and daughter with ease. By dispensing detailed accounts intermittently, suspense is sustained ( improbable events aside) until a satisfying resolution.

reviewDate: Reviewed in Germany on December 28, 2013
reviewComment: Ja, teilweise ist der Roman ein richtiger Thriller, den man ungerne aus der Hand legt, bis man durch ist. Durchaus großes Lesevergnügen. Nur wenn dann in den 70er-Jahren undurchsichtige Deutsche auftauchen, die vielleicht Beziehungen zur RAF haben könnten, dann wird die Geschichte billig. Hier scheint Boyd sich an einem Motiv zu vergreifen, von dem er, mangels Ahnung und ohne emsige Recherche, besser die Finger gelassen hätte. Das ist übrigens in "Any Human Heart" ebenso. Die deutsche Terroristenszene der 70er taugt nicht als Randmotiv.

reviewComment: This CD player is slim, lightweight, strong, absolutely won't skip, has an excellent volume control and bass booster, all sorts of accessories, and fabulous sound. You won't regret this purchase and you'll be glad you  didn't waste money on a bigger name brand.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2001
reviewComment: A terrific cd player!  Got this for my 7 year old son and he loves it.  It has plenty of features and with the car kit and adapter included, it's a great value.  The sound is very good with the headphones but I really like it in my van, especially with the bass boosted!  I read a lot of negative comments about the headphones, but they seem fine to us.  They're not broken yet.  They do fit better backwards, at least on adults.  The anti-skip works really well-even on Cleveland (Ohio) streets which are always in need of repair. I'm buying another one for my husband for Christmas now.

reviewComment: I am a person who likes music and would like to be able to listen to it!The GPX DISCMAN works fine. I mean extremley well but the head phones are just horrible. I think that this  discman is worth the money but deinetly not the head phones. If your going  to bye this then bye a new set of headphones with it. I'd take this  advice!

reviewComment: This cd player is excellent, although it isn't perfect. It's to your benefit to use the skip protection unless you're not moving. The headphones have less than average sound quality. It looks great, plays great, and, with a new pair of headphones (Sony  - trust me on that) sounds great. It's priced quite nicely considering it  comes with a car kit and AC adapter. If you're looking for a new cd player  and don't want to spend too much, this is a great buy.

reviewComment: I worked at a rather well-known books-movies-music-games store a year back, and upon a customer purchasing anything GPX, we either  chuckled or groaned. If you're heart's set, by  all means get this player..but if you see yourself playing with it a year  or so down the line, forget it. Try Panasonic (the Shockwave line is  great(!), but one of the most expensive) or Sony, who is good, too.

review_title: E-readers are a waste of time
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2012
reviewComment: I've had a nook for almost a year now and I spend all my time trying to download files, renew books from the library (the only lend for two weeks), and mess with files that won't open for whatever reason.  Then I have no time left to actually read anything and I'm left frustrated and annoyed.  E-readers seem great in theory, but are a nightmare in practice.  I guess I can't speak for the kindle, but using our Nook to borrow from libraries has been a total waste of time.  Do yourself a favor and stick to the printed books.  No hassle, you can renew as often as you like via internet at most libraries, and when you buy it you can lend it to your friends, pass it on to your kids, sell it at a garage sale, etc.  All the copyright protection surrounding e-books makes them absolutely a horrible value for the money you spend and a waste of time on top of it all.  And when you leave your e-reader in the taxi, at the restaurant, or some opportunistic thief snatches it when your not looking, you are out $100.  What thief would target your $6 paperback?  Yeah, that's what I'm talking about.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2011
reviewComment: The Nook Simple Touch E-reader is a great tool. I use it often in all kinds of locations. Originally I was concerned when it did not connect to my wi-fi but I went on to B&N and did their download and it worked fine after that. It is exactly what is it says it is. The screen quality is amazing. Some of the transissions are not efficient, but overall it is a nice reader.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2011
reviewComment: I would like to have known this product could only be used if you have a WiFi connection to set it up. There is nothing on the box which states this need and you do not find this out until you get home and the Christmas present will not work without it. I understand you should do some research on products before you buy them but reading the users guide may be a stretch. I am now stuck with a $100 paperweight until I get to a WiFi connection.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2011
reviewComment: Before you read my review I want to clarify something. I'm a vanity person and I couldn't care less about how well a product works as long as it's pretty. As long as it works, it's fine. Also I'm a very simple minded person so I only use it for reading. And those 2 things are what I'm reviewing. I fell in love with this ereader the moment I laid eyes on it. It was like they finally made one for me. I do not buy anything that is not fully touch screen if it can be. I would feel old and degraded. So the fact that they finally came up with this is like magical. No glare, but touch screen is exactly what I wanted from an ebook reader. It works perfect and it's so cute and pretty. It does exactly what it's for. Displays books for you to read. Plus even if it only works ok, it's so cute it will make up for all the problems.

review_title: He's Back!  And the game's afoot!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2011
reviewComment: 60 years ago, as a teenager, I devoured the complete Sherlock Holmes lexicon with the greatest of excitement and joy.  Since then I have read, watched and listened carefully -- Holmes-like -- to all things Sherlock.  Sometimes pleased (the early Britt portrayals) sometimes disgusted (Robert Downey, Jr, need I say more?) I have hungered and thirsted for the real Sherlock.  And here he is, in his full and real glory, on the trail of the bad guys, making progress from the slightest of clues, adding two and two and getting the real answer, not the four I get with the evidence.  This is the real Holmes in the real London with the real characters we knew and loved but with devilishly new crimes to stop and perplexing trails to follow.  As anyone who watched "Foyle's War" knows, Horowitz is a genius, never more than here.  Every nuance, every phrase, every fog-lit street, everything is right -- Sherlock and Watson are back, and we can all say hallelujah!

review_title: New Sherlock Holmes Adventure Ably Executed by Anthony Horowitz
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2019
reviewComment: Dr. John Watson has one last tale to tell of a case Sherlock Holmes worked on in 1890. Sherlock has passed away and Watson is both elderly and failing in health. Twenty five years have passed since the events he is writing about. Even so, he knows that this case was so sensitive that it is still not time for it to be published. He intends that it be held for one hundred years before publication.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2020
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz does an amazing job capturing the Victorian era of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and his wonderful characters.  Watson and Holmes are portrayed just as if this was written by the pen of Conan Doyle.  This story is very true to form and even the plotting is very similar to the original author's, but you will find that the story is a bit more graphic and puts the famous detective into some very tricky and dangerous situations.  When a man comes to see Sherlock at 221B Baker Street asking him to find an Irish man who had terrorized him on his recent trip to America and followed him back home to England.  This request puts Holmes and Watson on an extremely dangerous journey that unearths some very powerful men, and the abhorrent secrets that they will stop at nothing to protect.  Horowitz does a  truly remarkable job of creating this mystery and its realistic atmosphere.  Highly entertaining.  It was a pleasant surprise as I felt that I was reading a newly found story by the great man himself.

review_title: A decent mystery, a decent story, a decent pastiche, and a decent diversion
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2019
reviewComment: I don't really read too many Sherlock Holmes pastiches, because the stories are never really as fulfilling as those by the master. Still, there are some decent ones, like Meyer's Seven-Percent Solution, and this one by British screenwriter and author Anthony Horowitz is pretty good. There are some issues. It is very long, even compared to Doyle's longest Holmes novel, and thus it sticks out for that reason. Sometimes this novel sounds like a Holmes story, sometimes he is too in-depth and artsy. At times, the conceit that this is Watson writing in his dotage and retirement is strained by the excessive detail. Watson never described extraneous details so thoroughly as Horowitz does, and probably wouldn't decades after the event. For instance, at random, p. 180: "The kitchen knife laying on the table, the soup bubbling on the hearth, the brace of pheasants hanging from a hook in the pantry, Kirby casting eyes downwards, his wife standing with her hands on her apron, Patrick still smiling...." Do we really believe Watson would have written this scene in any story of the Canon, even if he wrote it right after the event, much less decades after the event? Watson never was so loquacious and descriptive, especially with pointless details for characters that are just added to divert attention and add to the suspect list. Still, it is a decent mystery, a decent story, a decent pastiche, and a decent diversion.

review_title: And he does an excellent job of the setting (London and its environs in ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2018
reviewComment: While his wife is assisting her former employer (Mrs. Cecil Forester) deal with the severe bout of flu being suffered by Mrs. Forester’s son, Watson has returned to spend some time with Holmes.  Very soon, three cases engage Holmes’ attention.  First, art dealer Edmund Carstairs, asks Holmes to find the man who has apparently been following him.  He suspects the man of being Keelan O’Donaghue, the surviving member of a gang of thieves who destroyed (accidentally) a shipment of paintings he had sent to an American client.  And, it appears, this man has broken into his home and stolen a family heirloom necklace.  With the assistance of the street urchins dubbed the Baker Street Irregulars (especially Wiggins and Ross), Holmes traces the necklace to a pawn shop, and follows that up by tracking down the apparent thief—whom he finds murdered in a cheap boarding house.

review_title: A Pleasant Read but a Mature rated theme handled poorly
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
reviewComment: I've read three pastiches of three different authors by Horowitz, and this one is the best, although it has a mature theme that means a child must be reasonably mature before reading it and that a parent should discuss it with them after they have read it.  Horowitz imitates the language and superficial style of Doyle very well and with some wit.  Even though there were relatively few surprises for me, that was probably because I've read too many Horowitz books in a row and too many mysteries in general.  By the ratings it receives, I'm clearly in a minority that way.

reviewComment: William Boyd will finally achieve the wider readership he deserves, now that his new novel Restless has won the Costa Novel Award and - more importantly in terms of sales - been given pride of place on Richard & Judy's sofa.  He's been writing varied and engaging novels for twenty-five years, which manage to worm their way into every aspect of their characters' lives, and in turn sink deep into the reader's mind.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 23, 2007
reviewComment: This was recommended to me by someone whose judgement I trust.  I had not read any of Boyd's novels before, and was not certain about this book for the first 20 pages or so.  But the more I read the more it gripped me, and I am likely to go on to read more of his books.  The twin stories interleaved chapter by chapter made for an interesting approach to the telling of the main story, and the contrasting atmospheres of the two very different eras - World War 2 and 1970s Oxford - were well captured.  There was more depth to the wartime story - but then it was the main one - and its denouement was good.  And while there was less flesh to some of the Oxford story and its characters, for me that mattered less as the main interest was the developing understanding of the 2 primary characters and the interaction between them.

review_title: From the creator of Foyle’s War, in the style of Conan Doyle
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2019
reviewComment: Horowitz has all the elements you’d expect in a classic Holmes and has absolutely nailed the style. There’s a clever plot that weaves together two mysteries, memorable characters, and puzzles. What surprised me was that my favorite parts were where Horowitz carefully colored outside the lines in the narration—reflecting on the humanitarian problem of childhood poverty in London in 1890, which the Baker Street Irregulars brings up, but Conan Doyle never “saw” because it was simply part of the backdrop of his life. Horowitz also spares quick, more compassionate asides for characters like Lestrade and Mrs. Hudson, remarking that while she appears in his narratives, he regrets never taking the time to know her. I thought these “blindspots” Horowitz has the sensitivity to see were quite touching and made the novel something better than just another mystery.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2016
reviewComment: Just not my style of book.  Not a fair review.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2018
reviewComment: "The hype surrounding what's being billed as the first pastiche ever officially approved by the Conan Doyle estate is..." just that. The prose of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle sweeps the reader along delightfully and effortlessly. This, on the other hand,  is something of a slow trudge.  The author has a penchant for strange, distracting word choices that he apparently believes make his writing more "authentic". As other reviewers have noted, he seems to have striven to sprinkle elements from almost every one of the original stories throughout.  His Watson is a doggedly devoted caricature and Holmes rather weak and irrational. Nonetheless, it's an interesting mystery, but I wonder if the only reason it was "officially approved by the Conan Doyle estate" is that it's the only one ever to apply. I've certainly read better.

review_title: Who doesn't love a good Sherlock Holmes story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2015
reviewComment: Who doesn't love a good Sherlock Holmes story? I think it's safe to say his adventures are timeless, if at times more satisfying for the byplay between Watson and Holmes than the actual mystery. This new entry in to Sherlock lore offers a new story, supposedly locked away by John because of the sensitive nature of its contents, and now it is here to quench the thirst for more Holmes adventures.

review_title: Another "newly discovered" Sherlock Holmes adventure, but unusually faithful in style to the originals for a change
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2015
reviewComment: The production of pastiches of and literary homages to Sherlock Holmes began before Arthur Conan Doyle even finished the series -- “the Canon,” as his avid fans refer to it. Dozens of later adventures of the Great Detective have been written, some of them deliberate send-ups (usually not very successfully), and many placing Holmes and Watson in new situations that would never have occurred to Sir Arthur. The most interesting of the many I’ve read of these over the years was probably Nicholas Meyer’s _The Seven-Per-Cent Solution_ (1974), which brings in Sigmund Freud, but it wasn’t very close to the flavor of the original. (And the Robert Duvall film two years later was absolutely dreadful.)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2015
reviewComment: I was, of course, skeptical when I first read about Anthony Horowitz’s The House of Silk. It is very, very rare that I’ve enjoyed any author’s reboot of a classical series or work of literature. Sherlock Holmes has been especially abused, from what I’ve read. However, the combination of some good reviews and a good deal on the book convinced me to give The House of Silk a try. I enjoyed it thoroughly.

review_title: Would've made a good Holmes short story
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2020
reviewComment: While Anthony Horowitz does an admirable job of aping the style and cadence of Conan Doyle and Holmes, he falls into the trap of overwriting every chapter and skimping on the main mystery.  He goes into absurd amounts of detail about every entry room, courthouse, canal that they pass through and offers a page-long preamble on every new character's clothing and comportment.  This might mirror Holmes' deductive abilities, but it distracts from the main selling point of the novel: the actual mystery.  The book finally picks up in the last 60 or so pages, offering two conclusions which while clever do not feel like they warrant an entire novel's worth.  As an exercise in continuing Conan Doyle's writing style, The House of Silk is a moderate success.  As a page turning whodunnit, it lacks substance.

review_title: Horowitz is channeling Arthur Conan Doyle beautifully!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2017
reviewComment: First in the Sherlock Holmes mystery series and revolving around Dr. Watson's memories. This particular memory takes place in November 1890.

review_title: but allow me to state it once more – I greatly enjoy the tales of Sherlock Holmes and Dr
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2016
reviewComment: I am sure I have said it before dear reader, and I know for certain I shall say it again in the future, but allow me to state it once more – I greatly enjoy the tales of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson. Be they in the form of books, short stories, movies or even TV series, their adventures both old and new never fail to make my heart skip a beat.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2000
reviewComment: This is a really great player!  It doesn't skip, even without the esp on, and with the esp, it's indestructable.  I took it with me on a class trip to Washington D.C. where it was julted, dropped, and stepped on repeatedly.  Then it traveled with me throughout Europe, where it is brutally treated  by all of my friends and me.  We even dropped it out of one of our fourth  floor hotel room windows (accedentally, of corse), and it still plays  beautifully.  And it doesn't suck up as much power as my first Panasonic  one did.  I'd definitly say that you should buy this one.  It's cheap, and  it's just as good as my friend's $130 Sony one (at least, about 7 of us  thought so).  If you're looking for a lot of player for your money, buy  this player!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2000
reviewComment: I have the car kit version (D-E446CK) and I've had it for about 4 months now, I've dropped it twice, once 5 ft on hardwood floor, the other time only about 4 ft on the floor of the school hall, it went flying down the hall a bit cuz the headphone wire got caught on someones backpack. It  survived these drops (and not to mention people hitting it to test its esp)  without even a scratch. I think there may be a difference in reliability  between the car version and regular version, because all the reviews that  say they got the car kit version are good reviews, and also read the  D-E456CK reviews as well to back this up.  I can use it in my pocket  walking without esp on and it won't skip. the only thing ESP would be  needed for is to keep it from skipping while you are trying to damage and  break it. plus it sounds better with the esp off. I use koss sporta pro  headphones which sound great.

It didn't read discs very well, couldn't read a cd-r disc, and  barely had esp function.  I returned mine and got a panasonic, works great.  I'll have to do better research in the future, or buy from a store with a  return period.  I did that with the last sony television I bought and am I  glad I did it.

Therefore I'm only going to comment on the one thing I actually dislike about it thus far. There is no back light. If the screen was white, it wouldn't be such a problem. It's not though. I got the reader for my 88 year old mother and was looking forward to being able to adjust the contrast to help her see the page more clearly. I should have done more research.

reviewComment: I have had my Nook for over a year now and I think it is a great ereader. HOWEVER DO NOT buy your content from Barnes and Noble. I hadn't yet updated my new card on Barnes and Noble's site when I went to reread a book I had purchased months before. IT WOULD NOT DOWNLOAD. I called support and was told that their policy requires an active credit card to access books I have already paid for. This policy creates a lot of the problems.

reviewComment: I love the device and everything its super wonderful. However ummm the price here on amazon is a bit high its cheaper on bn website or at bestbuy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2011
reviewComment: The book wouldn't half bad if it was not supposed to be a Sherlock Holmes story. The writing style doesn't do a half bad job of imitating the originals, but unfortunately it's just an imitation and not evocation (most of time he just references details in other stories to give it familiarity).  Holmes character is pretty far off - a lot more emotional and less scientific and calculating.

review_title: in the way one remembers loved stories, and of course have seen the movies ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2015
reviewComment: I think it important to note before we begin that I have not read any of the actual Arthur Conan Doyle stories in years. I remember them, in the way one remembers loved stories, and of course have seen the movies and the tv show. I say this to point out that the tone and wording and some of the nuance of the original works are things I have perhaps forgotten. So I cannot say with any conviction that someone who has read the original stories in the past week would not find fault with the tone and wording and nuance found in The House of Silk. I can only say that I found no fault in them. Anthony Horowitz is the author blessed by the Conan Doyle Estate to continue expanding the Holmes canon, and I am happy with their choice.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2011
reviewComment: Of all the Holmes pastiches I have read (and there have been many), Horowitz has, I believe, achieved the most authentic Watsonian voice. For most of the time, it is possible to believe the book was written by Conan Doyle, the master storyteller, himself. All the regular characters are there - Inspector Lestrade, Mrs Hudson, brother Mycroft - and as a Holmes fanatic, I wasn't conscious of any of those jarring inconsistencies that mar many a Holmes tribute. The plot is complex and well written, and we see Holmes both as the calculating thinker and as the man of action. The Holmes/Watson relationship is very faithfully portrayed.

review_title: We Can All Go Holmes Again
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2012
reviewComment: Alright, so here's the thing - we're never gonna get another Sherlock Holmes novel. Neither are we going to get another novel from Victorian England. It's just not going to happen, so for everybody scowling and fussing about how there are bits and pieces here that aren't "wholly authentic", my response is "of course it's not!". But that doesn't mean we don't get some pretty good fabrications from time to time, and I'll be darned it Horowitz hasn't made one that's a head and shoulders above the rest.

review_title: Mr. Horowitz delivers a novel worthy of inclusion in the Holmes canon.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
reviewComment: I am usually pretty skeptical about authors trying to add to classic canons of literature.  However, I really enjoyed this addition to the Sherlock Holmes stories.  The book is definitely darker than most Holmes and Watson novels, but it is also longer and has more details.  I am always partial to longer novels rather than short stories.  I think most fans of Sherlock Holmes will enjoy this book, and I will definitely read more from the series myself.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
reviewComment: Horowitz does an extraordinary job of taking the reader back to Baker Street!  I could see Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce as Holmes and Watson riding in their carriage amidst the fog of London!!  Horowitz absolutely captures the style of Arthur Conan Doyle's writings, and leaves the reader well satisfied!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2012
reviewComment: I can't accept that this is a Holmes pastiche for reasons I'll get too later.

review_title: A satisfying if somewhat cautious homage
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2013
reviewComment: The first couple of chapters left me underwhelmed - the case of an effete English art dealer being stalked by an Irish-American gangster intent on revenge isn't exactly original or compelling.  I braced myself for yet another tired pastiche in which Holmes is dragged through his customary paces (the pipe, the violin, the needle, dazzling deductions, disguises, bolt holes, 221B, Lestrade, Mrs. Hudson, the Baker Street irregulars, Mycroft ... even a cameo appearance by Moriarty) as the story relentlessly marches towards a predictable denouement.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2014
reviewComment: Before I even start to review the contents of this book I need to spend time on the cover. I picked up a hard cover copy and the jacket was what initial drew me to it. It is a rich midnight blue in colour, and the feel of it... well it feels like silk. The choice of cover was very well thought out and fits perfectly with the book.

review_title: A Worthy Successor to Conan Doyle
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2015
reviewComment: In "The House of Silk", Anthony Horowitz channels Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Dr. John Watson in presenting a "lost" Holmes mystery, for which Watson had given instructions to delay the publication for 100 years out of fear of causing a scandal. Horowitz clearly knows the Holmes canon and perfectly sets this novel within Conan Doyle's work, possibly during "The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes" or immediately following "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes", though there is a possible reference to "The Adventure of the Dying Detective" from "His Last Bow". In any event, Horowitz effortlessly evokes the spirit and feel of Conan Doyle's original work.

reviewComment: I love it. A great product. Worth every dime with one big "but" that drops me to 4 stars.. The software and information provided is very bad.  Both incompete as well as hard to use.  The Audio Manager software  shipped with the Rio never did work fully for me. I tried on two different  machines.  There is no way to even understand some of the Rio500 features  from the material shipped, or from their web site. Although eMail questions  are answered in about 24 hours, after a week of ongoing frustration I  discovered MusicMatch. I tried Real Jukebox, but suggest downloading the  free version of MusicMatch software from MusicMatch.com to use for  downloading files and for ripping CDs for use with the Rio500.  I found it  to work intuitively and easly almost from the beginning.  You will also  need to down load the free plug in from MusicMatch to enable downloading to  the Rio device. After installing Jukebox, then go to the Jukebox tab on the  website, then to plugins. I will cheerfully upgrade MusicMatch and send  them my money even though the free version is fully functional and more  than satisfactory.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2000
reviewComment: I am thrilled with the quality and capabilities of this small, light weight player.  It's very easy to use, and you can take it anywhere.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2000
reviewComment: This MP3 was nice, when it worked.  I returned my first Rio because it stopped working on me within the 1st month of my purchase.  Fortunately, Amazon has a great return policy so this was no hassle at all.  Although I was without an MP3 player for about 1 week.

review_title: My special use of the Rio and MP3 for speed learning.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 1999
reviewComment: I give the Rio 5 stars in spite of some flaws. It is a new product, yet when compared to its unique features gets a high rating from me. I do use the RIO for music when walking, etc. However I have found it very valuable  to me as an education cram machine. I bought a series of videos on SQL7  Database certification. Most of the instruction is audio (90%) which lends  itself to the RIO audio player. What I do is digitally record each chapter  as a .WAV file about 10 to 18 minutes each. I use soundforge software. I  normalize to -10db. Then noisefilter the gaps for silence. I then do a time  compression of about 30%; this seems to work the best, then convert the  .WAV to .MP3 at 32 bits mono. This is about the lowest bit-rate before it  sounds like Darth Vader. I am getting about a 1-10 file size reduction and  30% time reduction before loading to the RIO. I can load 4 hours of clean,  clear voice instructions in one package. I play it when I walk, in my car  and other free listening time. Great educational aid!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2000
reviewComment: While uploading mp3 files using the WIN software provided with the player - The RIO suddenly went black - that is all the pixels turned black on its screen.  This condition persists even after turning the unit on and off  again or replacing the battery.  I called Diamond customer service and they  said that this is a problem they are discovering - that if the battery is  not fully energized (Brand new) that the ROM in the RIO can become  permanently scrambled during a download session making the RIO totally  unusable. So - I think I'll wait for a better solution after Amazon refunds  my money.  My RIO is fried, dead, kaput,  ruined, lost.  Maybe there is a  ROM upgrade they might figure out - but I would wait for a while.

review_title: True to the Holmes style and signature
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2015
reviewComment: A London art dealer comes to Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson, reporting that he’s being followed by the leader of an American criminal gang bent on revenge. Because of art (paintings by John Constable) caught up and destroyed during a train robbery, and the busting up of the gang involved (and the death of its co-leader), the art dealer fears for his life.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2012
reviewComment: A Sherlock Holmes story, particularly a novel, labors under a double burden. It must succeed on its own terms, as a story. But it must also read like Conan Doyle, or rather like Dr. Watson. The original stories have some exceedingly distinctive markers of tone, pacing, language, and style--markers that are often quite subtle, but that (to a connoisseur) become jarring if they're omitted or mishandled.

review_title: The genuine authorized book of Holmes & Watson.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2016
reviewComment: The House of Silk by Anthony Horowitz.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2014
reviewComment: Finding a new Sherlock Holmes novel is akin to learning that there is one more Cherry Popsicle left in a box you thought was empty.  For a moment, life could not be better.  When the novel lives up to the expectations of such a famous detective, with a “modern” crime, the elation increases exponentially.  Mr. Horowitz has earned his place among “The Baker Street Irregulars” and displays not only his talent as a writer but as one who seems to channel Sir Author Conan Doyle’s most famous Personal Detective.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2011
reviewComment: The House of Silk by Anthony Horowitz is a new Sherlock Holmes novel, which is the first officially sanctioned take-off of Sherlock Holmes by the Arthur Conan Doyle Estate.  For the Sherlock Holmes lover, this is a must read.  For everyone else, I'd  highly recommend it.

review_title: Horowitz's work on Foyle's War led me to this strong new tale of Sherlock Holmes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2016
reviewComment: After watching Foyle's War, I was already aware that Anthony Horowitz knew his way around historical detail and could tell an engrossing tale. All that I needed to discover was how Horowitz's Holmes and Watson compare to all the other versions I've read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2012
reviewComment: I've read some children's books by Anthony Horowitz and he wrote some of my favourite episodes of Robin of Sherwood in the 80s, so I was intrigued by this new Sherlock Holmes mystery written by him. It's been a while since I've read original Holmes, but I have to say that the story Horowitz has written had the same mysterious, intriguing feel as the originals. He has an excellent eye for description, but without going overboard. You can see what the characters see.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2012
reviewComment: I usually reserve 5 stars for life-changing books - the kind of book I want to own, the one I will re-read 20 years later to see if it had the same effect...okay The House of Silk isn't one of those, but it came at just the right time. I wanted a good, meaty novel to escape with, one that was smart, full of good language, a real page-turner. That it is.

review_title: And thoroughly annoying. " Those were words uttered by John Watson ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2015
reviewComment: "Secretive. Confident. And thoroughly annoying." Those were words uttered by John Watson after a trying ordeal involving Sherlock Holmes. While Watson seems to struggle in dealing with the after effects, Holmes, not surprisingly, has bounced back. The quote made me smile. As much as Watson cared for Holmes, at times he still grated on Watson's nerves.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2014
reviewComment: Holmes is dead and Watson, now nearing the end of his own long and fruitful life, tells the tale of Holmes' most shocking case - a case that he could not tell while the principals were still alive.

reviewComment: The device itself is amazing...

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2011
reviewComment: Just a short review of my two weeks with the Nook Simple Touch.  This looked the the reader to get when it came out.  Specifically for me the touch screen was a must.  I enjoyed reading on it everyday until I returned it.  It was light and extremely easy to navigate with its touch screen.  What happened though, was on about the 12th day while using it the touch screen stopped responding.  I couldn't turn a page with the screen or pull up a menu with the screen or do anything else.  And, when I shut it off and turned it back on I couldn't swipe the screen to get into the book - I was completely stuck...locked out.  Finally after fiddling with it after about 15 minutes it started to work again.  I went on the web and found out that others had this same thing happen to them so I decided to return it rather then hope for a fix (I was still within my 14 days return policy).

reviewComment: I recently purchased the nook thinking it would be great for school.  Most of my readings for class are pdf's that the professors post online.  Reading on the computer screen hurts my eyes and it seems wasteful to print out all the pages.  This seemed like the perfect solution.  However, the result was teeny tiny print on the screen that I was unable to enlarge because it wasn't the Barnes and Noble e-book format.  In addition, the capacity of the device is grossly overestimated.  I have no idea how it is supposed to fit so many books if it couldn't even store 500 pages of pdf document for me.  Definitely something to skip purchasing.  Save your money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 22, 2007
reviewComment: One of Boyd's best novels. Elegently written, mixing events which happened in the early 80s to a woman who surprisingly discovered her mother used to be a British spy in WWII with the narrative of HOW she was recruited and ultimately betrayed by her boss, who proceeds to become a British Lord. The sentences Boyd uses are beautiful, the situations and references to England during the 80s and her travels through Europe, Canada and USA in the tail-end of the war are well-constructed. Loved it!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in Canada on May 8, 2015
reviewComment: Book in good condition. Arrived early. Good read. Satisfied overall

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 31, 2013
reviewComment: All praise to the person who wrote the screenplay for the two part TV adaptation. It was better, tighter and more suspenseful than the book. That said, it wasn't quite faithful to Boyd's characterisation of Eva. The young Eva in the TV version, played by the pulchritudinous Hayley Atwell was portrayed as an innocent girl who had to grow up at a spectacular pace when becoming a spy whereas the Eva of the book was already a shrewd and more believable 29 year old when recruited. The Charlotte Rampling portrayal of the older Eva (circa 1976)is more like the book's character and you could readily believe that she is a wary former spy who has lived in hiding for over 30 years. There are other differences; in the book, Eva didn't disappear after a blitz shootout, she didn't escape with a colleague to Canada but went alone, Eva didn't kill the unit's communications specialist, much was made of an irrelevant quasi relationship between Eva's daughter and an Iranian dissident and her sheltering of Baader-Meinhof squatters. These were not in the TV adaptation and for good reason.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2014
reviewComment: I am one of those readers who most emphatically does NOT care for modern authors trying to take up where classics left off. (See the horrid recent attempt by a modern author to write as Agatha Christie in a new novel called The Monogram Murders, it was awful!) In fact, had I known that this was what The House of Silk *was*, I would never have picked it up. But I didn't get to read the blurb because it was an audiobook that I quickly downloaded from my library website before I took off overseas for vacation and by the time I figured out what was going on (first paragraph), I had no internet connection to download another book. And all I can say is: Thank the literary Gods for that! Because I was in for one of the biggest reading treats ever!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
reviewComment: I started this book with no small amount of trepidation - after all, while I liked some of Horowitz's fiction, I was not sure he could pull of Dr. Watson narrating a new game afoot. But Horowitz did a great job, balancing two seemingly unrelated mysteries and bringing them, and a host of related complications, together. The writing let me guess some of the story, while hiding the rest from me. The resolution was very satisfying. A cozy winter read in front of the fire.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2012
reviewComment: From the first word, the style, the tone, the characters, the language, the inter-twining of plots and sub-plots and the little puzzles and deductions in which Holmes has always excelled, are all faithfully and skilfully adhered to by Anthony Horowitz. The result is superb and delightful.

review_title: Thank God the game's afoot again!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2015
reviewComment: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote four novels and 56 short stories featuring Sherlock Holmes; while such an output might have been sufficient for a lesser light, fans of the Great Detective have been clamoring for more for more than a century now. Authors ranging from Tod Browning to Roger Zelazny — B to Z, as it were — have featured Holmes in their own work.

review_title: Too dark to be Conan Doyle's, but otherwise excellent!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2012
reviewComment: "Shock & Awe": this much used motto of George Bush et.al, seems to be the `mission statement' of modern authors who, while ostensibly dealing with 19th Century crimes & society either in the form of pastiches (e.g. the book under review), or otherwise (Caleb Carr's

reviewComment: It had been a year since Sherlock Holmes was found at his home on the Downs, stretched out and still, that great mind forever silent.

reviewComment: As I become a more passionate Sherlock Holmes fan, I seem to be more critical of the work. I tend to not stray from the original Conan Doyle material because nothing can truly compare. With house of Silk I was excited that the Conan Doyle foundation commissioned Anthony Horowitz to write the official novel. Still I had mixed feelings, excitement that there is another true novel, and dismay that it will not be written by Conan Doyle.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
reviewComment: Having just read 2 other mysteries by Anthony Horowitz I was really looking forward to this book. I was disappointed! Hate to give bad reviews, but I put this book down 3/4 way through and read a synopsis to see how it ended.

reviewComment: I know ereaders have been reviewed to death, so I will make my review short and sweet. I am glad I decided to go with B&N's ereader for the following reasons: nice matte screen; smooth, comfortable, curved ergonomic shape; epub support; longer battery life; touch AND button operation. The main downside for me is the lack of free books/special offers that Amazon does for the Kindle. B&N just doesn't have as many good deals or as often. Aside from that, highly recommend!

review_title: The S-VHS recordings and ET recordings look really great but will not play back on a standard VHS ...
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2016
reviewComment: I have owned the JVC HR-S3600U S-VHS machine for many years and it is in fabulous working condition. However, the tuner is an analog tuner that does not tune in today's digital over the air broadcasts. You can hook a cable box, satellite box, or analog to digital adapter (sold in electronic stores for about $60) to get TV channels. I believe the VCR+ function is no longer available.The S-VHS recordings and ET recordings look really great but will not play back on a standard VHS machine. They only play back on S-VHS machines that record and playback these special recorded tapes. Standard VHS tapes recorded in the regular VHS mode on this machine should have no problem playing back on another VHS machine. Using a wet style cartridge cleaner on a regular basis will help prevent tapes from breaking or getting jammed in the machine.

review_title: Good Value, Not Perfect, but A Perfection for viewing needs
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2003
reviewComment: Pros: Excellent value, great picture quality in S-VHS, jog/shuttle, S-Video in/outs, Easy setup, cables included, quality construction, lots of features, OK tracking, Super VHS ET mode, 400+ lines of resolution, Has 19u Heads For Taping In The Extended Mode, Can Record Super VHS On Standard Tapes, do I need to say more?!?!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2000
reviewComment: If you've never had an S-VHSVCR,as most people have not,this would be a good one tohave.Super VHS is an improvedversion of VHS and nearly doubles the picture quality!All S-VHS decks also record and playback ordinary VHS  too.Actually this deck supportsthree formats VHS,S-VHS,andS-VHS ET.S-VHS ET  (ET standsfor expansion technology,notextra terrestial!) allows oneto use  ordinary VHS tapes tomake S-VHS recordings.If youuse very-high quality VHS  tapes,your results will beclose to full-fledged S-VHS!You will lose only 2  to 4 %picture quality as opposed tousing higher-price S-VHS tapes.S-VHS ET  works best forS.P. (standard play) speedrecording.If you want to makeE.P.  (extended play) tapes,Ireccomend you use S-VHS tapes.Super VHS at E.P.  speed looksbetter than regular VHS doesat S.P. ,hands down! This VCRwill  make tapes off sateliteand digital cable that areatleast close to the  originalbroadcast,unlike ordinary VHS,the difference isn't obvious!This  deck is feature-ladden too.It has VCR Plus +,which takes about a half-hour  to set-up but allows you to program very quickly via the VCR Plus + codes  found in most all TV guides.If you program using the onscreen menu,that's  easy too!On the remote the keys used for programing are inside a lined-off  area and steps are numbered on the remote so it's hard to make a  mistake.Other notable features include automatic clock set( if your PBS  station is doing this service),automatic clock adjust for daylight savings  time,multi-brand TV control,and skip search (each push of the button  fast-forwards your tape thirty seconds,I think you know why!).The remote is  an excellent design in the best JVC tradition.Other VCR manufacturers  should copy their remotes,they're that good! With today's improved video  sources like DBS,S-VHS recording is the ticket! You can buy just any VHS  recorder real cheap,but if you want a really good one,pay a little more for  this unit.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2005
reviewComment: I have no complaints. I love the picture quality. The picture quality is even further raised with features like VIDEO STABLIZER, VIDEO CALIBRATION, and you can change the sharp tone to "SHARP" for a sharp picture, "SOFT" for a smooth picture, and "AUTO" for use with VIDEO CALIBRATION. This VCR is the most reliable I have ever seen. Sometimes the picture quality is better that DVD recorders. Unlike DVD recorders, there are certain tapes that can record HDTV. Use that tape with its Super Video connection, and you will have a knock-out.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2000
reviewComment: I bought an S-VHS unit simply to get the s-video in/out plugs.  Now I can have just one wire (s-video) going to my TV.  The JVC VCR has a nice feature in that when you change channels up/down, included in the list is  Line-1 (where I input from my dish).  So, after the highest TV channel it  just goes to the dish input -- nice!  I don't need the TV remote except to  turn the thing on.  Also, any time I want to play a tape, I just put in a  tape and run it and it just takes over the TV picture.  The instructions  were not clear on the 'plug/play' hookup.  It didn't seem to be working but  I left it alone for a while and it was OK.  It just needed to find the time  signal from my local PBS station which is only sent once per hour -- I hope  that's helpful. I haven't tried it with an S-VHS tape.  A complaint I have  is that when useing S-VHS ET with a regular VHS tape, there is no indicator  that shows the quality that it allowed itself to record at.  One could  argue that one could just observe the tape, post recording.  However, I'd  like to try a tape to see if that important movie will record on *that*  tape in a high quality.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2000
reviewComment: I'm pleased with the VCR, but it took about an hour to get it set up properly.  Plug & play didn't work.  I finally ended up setting the channels and clock manually, and the initial configuration is relatively  complicated.  I am a little bit disappointed with the remote.  One reason  that I selected a JVC VCR is because I hoped it would interoperate well  with my other JVC components, but the remote is awkward to use with my TV  and DBS.  Overall though, it has a lot of nice features for the money, and  the picture quality is good.

review_title: Good player to save videos to DVD.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2006
reviewComment: I got this JVC video tape player a long time ago and guess I paid about $100 for it back then. It's the only VCR we have now that still works and don't eat up VHS tapes. I got it because of the S/Video and I can play are old VHS tapes with S/Video to a DVD recorder S/Video input to save are old VHS tapes to DVD. With the way are other VCR's are not working and messing up VHS tapes it is very good to get them saved to DVD and this is about the best way using S/Video.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 1999
reviewComment: I've owned an S3600 for about six months.  It's my third JVC SVHS deck (the other two are 8 and 10 YEARS old, and both still work) and I am  completely satisfied.  Aside from the ability to go to a particular time  mark on the tape -- which only my oldest unit has -- it is wonderful.  Highly recommended.

I am not much interested in vampire nonsense but this was so highly recommended by a friend I had to read it and it justified the praise. Interestingly enough it also deals with the question of boredom: What would you do if you had all the time in the world and no one to talk to? The extra stories at the end are quite short and look more like aborted attempts at novels, skim read over them, one or two are worth a read. However, the main feature deserves the reputation it has.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 12, 2017
reviewComment: This is what I'd call a literary espionage thriller.  At face value, it's a spy story, but given the quality of Boyd's narrative, characters and plotting, it's a true cut above most in the genre. Boyd, I think, likes to play with his readers and challenge them to think beyond the fare words on the page. So there's a bit of a conundrum around Eve in this story. The plotting is intricate with a few historical facts woven into the overall detail. Gives it a really authentic feel. The characters gave depth and intelligence, so there's food for thought along the way.

review_title: House of Silk is first class!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2012
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz, it is said, has killed more people, buried more bodies, and stolen more treasures than just about any writer today!  From his immensely successful screen plays ("Foyle's War," "Midsomer Murders," etc.), Mr. Horowitz now moves into really, really sacred literary ground.  He joins the ranks of other Sherlock Holmes "revivers."  And in "The House of Silk," he's done a first rate job and this reader can hardly wait for another episode.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2012
reviewComment: The House of Silk - Anthony Horowitz

review_title: I hope that Anthony Horowitz will write some more!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2012
reviewComment: For the first since April 1927 the famous detective Sherlock Holmes is back in print with a new canonized adventure chronicled by Dr. John H. Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2012
reviewComment: Sherlock is back!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2011
reviewComment: Kudos to Mr. Horowitz for taking on such a project. To be the first officially authorized Sherlock Holmes novel in 125 years, as granted by the Arthur Conan Doyle Estate, is a daunting task. Any use of this icon is subject to intense scrutiny by legions of fans and the clubs dedicated to his study and enjoyment. As a fan of Foyle's War, I was sure Mr. Horowitz would be a stickler for detail which was so ably demonstrated in that Second World War mystery series.

review_title: An excellent portrayal of the world's greatest detective and his friend
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2018
reviewComment: I listened to the audiobook version of this book.  I had my doubts at first, but I just finished listening to it yesterday, and I will miss listening to it on my commute.  I had a sense of satisfaction upon finishing it, and deep admiration for the friendship shared by these two gentleman, which I believe is what  the author captured best.  There were moments at which I kept wondering what the actual crime was, and towards the end very fast paced moments that had me at the edge of my seat figuratively.  The person who recorded the audio book did a very good job.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2015
reviewComment: This novel is a mixed bag for me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2012
reviewComment: In House of Silk, the game is afoot in so many ways that it makes your head spin. On one hand, the mystery of a gang leader stalking a wronged antique's dealer, and on the other, a secret agency with deadly intentions. There's as much mystery, intrigue, deductions, danger, Watson getting whacked about, and dastardly criminals to keep even the most ADHD reader such as myself completely involved and madly turning pages to figure everything out. But the great thing is that I was never confused. Even though House of Silk has so many seperate elements and mysteries, I never had a headache trying to figure out what I'd just read.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2012
reviewComment: Okay, I admit that chronology is one of my pet peeves. But it seems like such an easy thing to get straight. I just don't understand books where the main characters are childhood friends, aged 5 and 7, and then meet later in adulthood, now aged 28 and 33. Or characters who marry and have a child, and 15 years later the child is all grown, out of college, and busy in the working world. Yet things like that happen *all the time*. And this book has all sorts of inconsistencies of that type.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2013
reviewComment: Let me first state that I have never read a Sherlock Holmes/Dr. Watson novel by Arthur Conan Doyle.  This is my first novel containing these two esteemed protagonist.  I found that my interpretation and opinion of the book was based on what I have experienced of Holmes & Watson in the movies of the late 30's & early 40's with Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2002
reviewComment: So, I just bought this wee beastie via Amazon's used marketplace, and, right off the bat, I'm pretty happy. The price was right ...; it's worth the hunt), the size is right (bigger and thinner than a pager), and, hey, it holds an hour of music right out of the box! I have yet to see if the firmware update holds true; supposedly, I'll be able to pop a 64 meg flash card into my Rio and carry two hours around with me.

review_title: I wish I had one in college!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2000
reviewComment: When the Rio 300 first came out, I couldn't believe the freedom that I was buying myself.  After years of relying on cassette tapes and endless times of rewinding to hear a song again or fast-forwarding past a song that I wanted to hear at the time of taping but changed my mind when I was on the road, I would finally have the random access that a CD gives you along with the flexibility to mix artists that a cassette has.  Sure you could burn a CD, but then you're going to wind up with a bunch of CDs every time you want to add a new song to your traveling collection.

review_title: The end of mp3 handhelds? I think not
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2000
reviewComment: What some electronics fans will have you believe about mp3 players is that they are too expensive and they have been beaten by the CD. This is hardly the case. While the CD is able to hold large amounts of DATA it is only  able to hold about 74mins of music. This is of course unless you'd rather  burn MP3s onto the CD, which cannot be read by your average CD player. So  forget anything you've heard about CDs being able to hold astronomical  amounts of music. Another factor that plagues the CD medium is that CDs are  easily damaged. I don't care how much ESP your CD player has it cannot fix  scratches. Obviously MP3s cannot be scratched. Next there is the time  issue. It takes the average CD burner anywhere from 30-60mins to burn a  full music CD. A MP3 player with USB support such as this one can download  a full hour of music in about 10 mins. Then, as if I needed to continue,  there is the permanence of CDs. Yes I know there are new re-writeable CDs  but the burners that support them are pricey. Traditionally once you burn a  CD, listen to a few times and become bored with it you can either use it as  a coaster or trash it. There is not permanence with MP3 handhelds. I hope I  have convinced all of you CD die-hards that the CD (soon to be followed by  the MD) is on the way out the door while MP3 handhelds are checking real  estate.

review_title: Great Device Terrible Technical Support and Documentation
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 1999
reviewComment: I just purchased the Diamond Rio 500 and after you get it working it is super but don't look to Diamond for any kind of support. The technician I spoke to didn't even seem to know what a MP3 player was much less how it  works. He referred me to a manual on the CD that doesn't exist and provided  nonsense answers to my questions.

review_title: Looks like a brick, plays like a champ
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2001
reviewComment: I actually got this player free with an offer at audible.  I had every intention of using my Pocket PC to play the books, but I ended up using this little guy more than I thought I would.  At first glance, it seems far more bulky than it is.  It slips easily into your pocket or similarly sized space making it perfect for travel. I use it almost everywhere now to listen to audiobooks: in the car, riding my bike, when I work out, etc.

review_title: Wait for better price or buy Rio 600
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2000
reviewComment: I just recently received the Rio 500 for a Father's Day gift. I wanted one to paly audible files so I was pleasently suprised to receive it. Unfortunately I'm returning it because the device doesn't live up to it's billing.

review_title: Great machine.  Easy to use.  Great sound.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2001
reviewComment: Very well made unit.  Great sound.  Connects via USB cable to PC. Battery life is so-so.  Good support from manufacturer.  You can get firmware updates easily at their website.  Comes with a "card", not a manual.  But there is a good manual, and a printable version, at the RIO website.  Provided headphones stink.  You can get a NICE leather case from the Sonicblue website store.  64mb stores a lot of music.  I added 64mb card, which are coming down nicely in price.  I have two RIO500's, one for music, and one for my audio books.  Decent headphone volume. Display with latest firmware is sometimes hard to read.  If you pull the USB plug during download, or if download is interrupted, the RIO will lock up, good.  BUT, Sonicblue tech support website does have program you can download for free that will fix it (usually).  This happened to me, and the program worked fine!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 1999
reviewComment: I just got the Diamond Rio. It is a wonderful product, here's why : What do you strive for in a MP3 player ? Good sound, Space for music, compactness, cool look, competitive pricing, and I can honestly say that  the Rio 500 meets each of these qualities. The sound is barely  distinguishable from a true CD. Unless your are a true audiophile you will  not be able to tell the difference, UNLESS you like listening to music  REALLY LOUD, then you might be able too find a small distortion in the MP3  version. The 500 can also hold a lot of songs, because it is 64 Megs and  also you can transfer your songs because of its USB connection. It looks  great! It is also the size of a pager. AND IT DOESN'T SKIP! This product is  worth its price. This maybe the last "pure mp3" model available  because after christmas the SDIC will be putting a detector which won't let  you download free mp3's unless explicity stated by the musician. SO GET EM  NOW! It only takes one AA batteria for 12 hrs of playback which is pretty  good. The LCD is a very nice neon blue. The only problem with this product  are the bad earphones. Contrary to one of the reviewers I believe it is  quite easy to install. I didn't read the manual. Just plug it into your USB  port ( IMPORTANT YOU NEED A USB PORT TO RUN IT )and then windows  automatically asks you for the driver cd, then you pop it in restart your  computer and Viola! Don't ponder the value of this product too long because  before you know it they will be Sold OUT! Happy Listening! Cheers

reviewComment: Fast forward and rewind buttons sticks .

review_title: Great for beginning concert recording or MP3 recording
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2000
reviewComment: I bought the MZ-R37 early this summer.  I got a refurbished model on Ebay for a resonsable price for recording concerts over the summer.  This is a great model, durable and very shock resistant.  I purchased a binaural microphone after I recorded a couple shows on a cheaper mono and man what a difference.  One major tip if you are starting to record with the MZ-R37 - be sure to hold the record button in place and be sure recording has commenced, I missed some songs at gigs because the recorder didn't start.  Better to be safe than sorry.  Anyway, this is also great for recording MP3s off of your computer just get a connection line from your sound card to the line in and you are set.  You can also transfer concert recordings or band demos onto you computer if you have a recordable sound card.  Great investment.  Forget about MP3 players, too expensive to add memory.  Minidiscs are inexpensive and far more durable than CDs also, with identical sound quality.  If you are a music fan I don't know how you could live without one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2002
reviewComment: I got this as a birthday present over a year ago and I love it. This minidisc player is such a great benefit that any music lover or electronics enthusiast (sorry for the spelling) should enjoy. With this gadget I was able to record from everything and it saved me a lot of money. I didnt have to buy cds to listen to one song. I would just borrow from friends or family and record the track or  tracks that I liked and return the cd to them. The sound was incredible. I no longer have to worry about not being able to listen to cds because they're scratched, because when I put it on minidisc, its impossible for the cd inside to  get scratched. Another plus is it does not skip. There are so many positives about the minidisc player that I can go on forever. Its like having a cd burner in your pocket. However despite the positives, it has its downfalls. The buttons are really small and I jammed my skip search button. It cost 50 dollars to get it fixed. I would definately recommend getting a warranty. Also this one eats batterys fast. It takes only 15 hours on 2 batterys. I think  its definately great and I enjoy this player.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2001
reviewComment: I got this model MD as a present last Christmas and I love it for many reasons:  1.) It is sturdy yet compact.  The newer models I have seen don't seem as durable as this model.  2.) I can make my own "mix tapes" thousands of times over because MD's are re-recordable without losing audio quality.  Also I can take my favorite songs from CDs and put them on one disc instead of lugging around several CDs.  3.) I can record from any audio source.  Download from the internet and make your own MD without investing in blank CDs.  4.) The batteries last forever, or seemingly forever.  I listen on long road trips (8 hours +) and seldom need lots of extra batteries.  5.) It's so easy to use that I am able to use it.  6.) I have never had any problems with it.  I have even dropped it on the ground (accidentally) a few times and nothing has been damaged on the inside, or outside  7.) It's less bulky than a portable CD player.

review_title: JVC is the best S-VHS for the money!

reviewComment: I have a HR-S3500U and most recently bought a HR-S3800U and am very pleased with both of them.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 1999
reviewComment: We have had our JVC VCR for 1.5 yrs.  Three weeks ago, the power just completely blew out.  Since we spent a little more for what we thought was a good VCR, we took it for repair.  The repair man just called me to say  that JVC has parts to repair our VCR on backorder for 2 months, and this is  a sign to him that it has serious problems.  He also said we spent  about$280 for a $100 VCR.  So needless to say, we are feeling a bit ripped  off.

reviewComment: Horowitz captures the time period’s vernacular, speech patterns, and styling, bringing authenticity to Holmes and Watson, and their surroundings.  To immerse myself in one more of the worlds most famous consulting detectives and his constant companion’s adventures was a fine treat.  The game was surely and wonderfully ‘afoot’ once more.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2011
reviewComment: The wikipedia article on this novel reads more like a publicist's flack piece than a dispassionate review.  I have three comments:

review_title: The Most Worthy Successor to Conan Doyle Ever Written
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2015
reviewComment: As a long-time Sherlock Holmes fan, to hear that there was an authorized new Holmes story was like finding water in Las Vegas; I had to read it.  Not only was the mystery truly worthy of any of the originals, but Horowitz captures Conan Doyle's writing style as Watson perfectly.  For a story that feels as if it fits neatly into the classic canon, House of Silk is also wonderfully modern in a way that only enhances the story and characters.  I highly recommend this for all Sherlock Holmes fans!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2018
reviewComment: The editing is so poor that it is an enormous distraction. Words are used incorrectly. (I am not speaking of grammar.)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2014
reviewComment: Just finished "The House of Silk".  I have been rationing this book out for days, wanting to read it all at once, but also not wanting the tale to be over too soon..  I don't often come across a great book that is not predictable, has an interesting plot, no vulgar language/smut, and also has words that challenge my vocabulary & send me across the room to my trusty dictionary.  If only there were more books like this out there- modern fiction has become so repetitive, predictable, and crass.  Of course, my love for historical fiction may be a bit of bias here, I do love a good book set in earlier times of days gone by.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2015
reviewComment: I'm a big fan of Sherlock Holmes, having read all of Doyle's short stories and novellas, and having read numerous other books, as well as listened to audio adaptations, seen various film and television adaptations, and even played one of the Sherlock Holmes video games.  I was pretty excited to read Horowitz's take, since it seemed that many people were praising it as one of the better adaptations of Holmes.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2012
reviewComment: Maybe it's a coming trend.  First the Gershwin estate authorizes a Broadway version of "Porgy & Bess,"  in an attempt to milk its assets.  Then the Arthur Conan Doyle estate authorizes for the first time a Sherlock Holmes novel.  Another similar event and we might just be enjoying a fad.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2012
reviewComment: Horowitz undertook the huge challenge of producing a quality novel AND doing so when certain to be measured against A.C. Doyle. I think he achieved both goals.  In my opinion the story stands on its own merits and Horowitz captured Doyle's style quite well.  He reintroduced favorites like Lestrade, the Baker Street Irregulars and even Mycroft Holmes. (And offered us a nice take on Dr. Watson true thoughts of Lestrade.)  And unlike some reviews I've read criticizing his writing style and in particular the interaction between Holmes and his brother, I thought both were reminiscent of the original novels (which I just recently re-read for the first time in probably twenty years).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2013
reviewComment: Like a lot of people, I'm a casual fan of the original Sherlock Holmes stories (ie. "the canon"), but am also plenty willing to pick up and enjoy one of the hundreds of pastiches for what they are. However, this first "authorized" Holmes story is a huge disappointment -- especially given my admiration for Horowitz's excellent TV series
