reviewComment: In our house's home network, Internet service from Comcast goes to a modem then to a router with four outgoing slots -- one to each of four computers by CAT-5 cables. The wires snake through the house and give us fast Internet service.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2010
reviewComment: This switch works fine and does what it's supposed to do. The one I received is all black, and there is another listing for it on Amazon.

review_title: This does NOT share internet access from a DSL/Cable modem!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2011
reviewComment: Just to be clear, this is a switch and not a router! Search online for the difference between a switch and a router to learn more. I wanted to share the internet access from my cable modem with my computer and my new internet capable blu-ray player. Well, I found out the hard way that this switch will not do the trick! If you already have a (wired or wireless) router between your cable modem and your computer then you can use a switch like this to connect more computers. It just gives you more ports but it does not convert IP addresses to the outside world (which is what you need when you want to access the internet from multiple network devices).

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2008
reviewComment: This Linksys switch is a basic network device that is used in home networks and large companies. It does what it is designed to do, and does it well. There is no configuration, and no set up, just plug and play. I own several of these, and I have never had to touch it after installing it onto my network.

We get features like a microphone jack, a headphone jack--and there's even automatic shutoff for when we can't be there right at the exact minute the tape stops playing! The handle also makes for easy portability; this can be used to record just about any sound. Words, music, lectures and conversations, you name it.

To go into more detail would undermine the reader's "pleasure" with the book as much as reading the book to its end will undermine the reader's "pleasure" with the book.

review_title: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is rolling over in his grave
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2011
reviewComment: This is NOT a good story for children to read - Sir Arthur Conan Doyle would NEVER EVER write about a group of pedophiles. I'm absolutely disgusted.  I am a huge Sherlock Holmes fan - I've read the original books and short stories numerous times.  I will give Anthony Horowitz credit that he does evoke the writing style of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle but that is as far as it goes in similarity. First, the story itself is not only revolting but really far off base from the adventures we have in the original series - I'm fairly certain Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is rolling over in his grave.  I think that the trustees of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle let this go forward because all the copyrights have run out and they want more money coming in. Pathetic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2020
reviewComment: Excellent book. Enjoyed it very much. Great ending and build up to the ending. Highly recommended. You will enjoy it

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 18, 2019
reviewComment: It seems churlish to criticise this book.  The author is so proudly and disarmingly pleased with his handiwork, and insists on taking us into his confidence (in a note at the end) as to how he accomplished it, that I hesitate to point out that it contains several inexplicable deficiencies.  The story as a whole is a real cracker – a genuine mystery, and the reader is always agog to find out what’s going to happen next.  The pace is too hectic, however, as we’re whisked from one mysterious highlight to another with scarcely a pause for breath.  Dr Watson, on the other hand, is rather too garrulous, and pontificates and reminisces at the drop of a hat – largely to help fill up space, it appears, to gratify the publishers.  But the timing is all wrong.  We are told that the action is taking place in 1890 and that Holmes and his exploits are, by that time, famous throughout the land.  But in actual fact, the short stories did not start appearing until July 1891.  They were published, we learn, in the Cornhill Magazine, whereas in reality they were the making of The Strand Magazine.  And Watson is apparently writing in 1915, long after the death of Holmes, whereas we know that Holmes was still active in August 1914 and scarcely in his dotage at that time.  It might be best to think of Holmes and Watson, as conceived by Horowitz, as occupying some kind of parallel universe to the one conceived by Conan Doyle.  One small point that niggles is that the strange behaviour of the Irish scullery boy in the house at Wimbledon is truly never explained.  It’s enjoyable, in short, but not quite the genuine article.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 24, 2018
reviewComment: Having read Conan Doyle's original works, I was a little sceptical of another author's attempt to write a Sherlock Holmes case. However, I was blown away by Horowitz's novel. He has captured Doyle's voice so well that if I had been shown Doyle's and Horowitz's novels with blank covers and asked to say which is which, I wouldn't be able to tell them apart. Horowitz's narrative voice is that authentic.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 24, 2016
reviewComment: I have read other books by Anthony Horowitz and found them quite enjoyable, dont be put off that he writes childrens books too as this is a very different kettle of fish.I am a big fan of the original Sherlock Holmes books and was more than a little unsure if another author could capture the feeling of the era and pace of Arthur Conan Doyles creation. I was not disappointed, it was as if a lost book of  Conan Doyles had been discovered and put into print. A thoroughly good read, dont just take my word for it as it has been officially been endorsed by the Conan Doyle family (the only author to have done so). He could have just written it without endorsement but it was they who contacted him to write a new book for Holmes, and there is also the follow up Moriarty to savour.........Now where is my companion.....“Come Watson, come! The game is afoot! Not a word! Into your clothes and come!”

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2001
reviewComment: Purchased this hub for my little VAIO SuperSlim to simplify my connections to the printer, CDRW, scanner and flash reader.  Works great!  I did not realize how much faster USB printing was compared to the old parallel interface.  I really like this little hub and the price was cheaper than the local stores even after shipping.

reviewComment: This hub is really very easy to install. Plug it and you're done! The AC adapter is included in case the devices need more power. It can be used without the adapter as well. It looks great, it's very small so it doesn't occupied precious space and it's affordable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2011
reviewComment: I own the version of this switch back when Cisco wasn't a part of it. In fact the computer this is being typed on is hooked up to it. That feeds a cable threaded through my basement to an old Netgear switch that died, hence the need for this new EZXS55W ver. 4.2 switch. reviewComment: I've had one of these switches in service on my home network for 2 years now.  So when an old hub I was using quit, I bought another one of these to replace it. If you currently use a hub and you upgrade to a switch like this one, you won't be disappointed.

review_title: Where Have You Gone, Charleton Heston?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2008
reviewComment: It's beyond me to understand how horror fans can go on and on about their favorite horror novels as if they were masterpieces by Pynchon or Nabokov.  The bottomline about "I Am Legend" is simple:  it's about loneliness and loss in a post-apocalypse world overrun by vampires.  If that doesn't cause you to dissolve with laughter, then "I Am Legend" might be for you.  It's well-written, holds the reader's interest, and has been the basis for three movies.  It will appeal to most teenage boys (or to grown up men who remember how the world feels to teenage boys).  However, it doesn't deserve five stars because it doesn't have enough cool details about the end of humanity.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2015
reviewComment: I have one I got used in 2003/4 or so, and the battery still lasts for 1.5 weeks or so.  It does what I need it to do.  This was for my son because getting a smart phone for him now is foolish, and I do not expect newer stripped-down planners for kids to be nearly as good as this thing.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2001
reviewComment: Other reviewers will be able to do a better job than me in discussing the full extent of the Palm Vx's capabilities, but I can give it a ringing endorsement from the technically competent layman.  I'm not someone who gets all excited about the latest electronic gadget - the only thing I care about is whether it is truly useful in organizing my life.  The Palm Vx has definitely passed that test.  I found it incredibly easy to install and get started with, and I was quickly addicted to being able to download Outlook with the punch of a button.  Among other things, my Palm has made my cell phone a more useful tool because I now always have hundreds of phone numbers with me at all times.  One of the advantages of the Palm Vx over other handhelds is that it is so light and easy to carry.  I know lots of people who got Handsprings lured by the promose of all the fancy attachments.  To a man they regret it - they don't use the attachments and it's significantly more difficult to carry.  Still, the Palm Vx wouldn't be worth it if it was just a very expensive address book.  I suggest buying "Palm Pilot:  The Ultimate Guide" to find out how to really get the most out of your Palm V.  It's an essential supplement to the basic information that comes with the Palm, and it comes with a handy CD with great programs. I've used my Palm Vx for about 8 months and find it more useful all the time.  However, I recently put the Palm Vx through the ultimate challenge:  I gave my 61 year-old and technicially challenged Dad one for Christmas.  Within in hours he was hooked up and writing graffitti like a pro. He's had it for a couple of months, and like me he swears by it.

review_title: You won't understand how you lived without one!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2001
reviewComment: I've owned a few palm pilots over the past several years.  I switched to the Palm Vx because my Palm III gave out after months of abuse riding in my back pocket.  The Vx is solidly built, very reliable and never needs batteries.  I use mine heavily and sometimes forget to recharge it in the cradle.  I've found that the battery lasts about three weeks with heavy use as long as you don't use the backlight.  I now use my Palm Vx with my laptop running Windows 2000 and synchronize my data using the infrared port.  The cradle is just a charge stand for me!  If you're nervous about buying this product... relax!  I teach computer skills to executives in the Chicago area.  The learning curve for Palm devices is about 20 minutes.  There is a shorthand called "graffiti" that you will need to learn to write in your information, but you can also use your computer or a separately available keyboard to enter in your data.  Newer and more powerful palm devices have been introduced since I bought mine, but the Vx is an excellent value now that the price has dropped.  And it's still the smallest!  If you're looking for a PDA to handle your personal and business information and do not need to display color photos, videos or play MP3s, the Palm Vx is perfect.

review_title: Doctor, Mac User says: Gotta have it!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2000
reviewComment: I am a busy doctor, a Macintosh user, and an avid Palm enthusiast.  Here is my bottom line: if you don't have a Palm Vx, you have to get one, right  now.

reviewComment: Works well for the most part, but if the battery dies all of it's information gets wiped. reviewComment: I bought one used from a store near my house. It works really well and does everything I expected it to. One of the answered questions say an aux cable doesn't let you record from your computer. That is not true. reviewComment: I bought this item and had to return it because it didn't work, BUT the return process was very simple and not the hassle that I thought it would be at all.  The second tape player that I received has worked fine.  This is fine for light to moderate use by someone who takes care of their things.  I wouldn't trust it to children who will bang it around a lot, but for older kids or adults who can treat it gently it would be fine.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2008
reviewComment: The Sony TCM-929 Pressman Desktop Cassette Recorder with Automatic Shut-Off is a perfectly serviceable cassette tape recorder and player.  I bought it specifically to move my cassette tape collection to digital format on the computer.  You will need a couple of double male-male patch cords to connect the earphone and mike ports to your sound card.  Then, with an inline .wav, .mp3 or .ogg sound recorder program, you're all set.  The system worked fine for me, and I completed the conversions in several weekend evenings.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2008
reviewComment: THIS TURNED OUT TO BE A GREAT LITTLE RECORDER FOR JUST WHAT WE NEEDED. WHEN I SAW THE PICTURE OF THE SONY RECORDER IT LOOKED JUST LIKE THE GOOD OLD RELIABLE ONES WE USED TO HAVE 20 OR 30 YEARS AGO AND I DIDN'T THINK I COULD FIND ANYTHING LIKE THAT IN THE STORES, SO I WENT ON LINE AND FOUND EXACTLY WHAT I WANTED. WE ATTEND A BIBLE STUDY AND MY HUSBAND WOULD TRY TO WRITE D0WN WHAT WAS BEING SAID AND IT WAS HARD TO WRITE AND CONCENTRATE ON OUR TEACHER. WE SAT AROUND A TABLE AT A RESTAURANT EVERY WEDNESDAY AND PUT THE RECORDER IN THE MIDDLE OF THE TABLE AND WE COULD HEAR HIM REALLY WELL EVEN THOUGH THERE WAS ALOT OF BACKGROUND NOISE. HIS VOICE COMES THROUGH VERY CLEARLY AND HE DOESN'T HAVE TO TALK LOUD. IT IS SO WONDERFUL TO COME HOME AND BE ABLE TO REVIEW EVERYTHING THAT WAS SAID.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2007
reviewComment: I agree with the other positive comments, with one exception.  This is a good, economical cassettee player for my purposes, which mainly involve listening to talking books.  However, it only has a MONO output which means, if you are listening through regular headphones, ONLY THE LEFT HAND speaker has any volume!  It was bothering me--perhaps it wouldn't someone else--so I took it to my local Radio Shack and bought the following adapter, which has corrected the problem...I now hear out of both sides of my headset.  The adapter cost approx. $4.00, and is called a "Gold-Plated Stereo-to-Mono Audio Adapter; Accepts 1/8" stereo plug; Fits 1/8" mono jack, part number:  274-882."  Without this one issue, I'd give this recorder/player five stars.  It is very well made for the money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2008
reviewComment: I purchased the Sony TCM-929 Pressman Desktop Cassette Recorder through Amazon.com because of the Sony name and the most reasonable price.

reviewComment: I love this recorder. It is smaller and more light weight than others that I have purchased. Unfortunately, it is more and more difficult to find a cassette player with decent quality sound. I don't use it for recording, just play back.  The motor does run a little loud, so it may not be as good as another type for actual recording purposes.  It has auto stop (kind of loud) and can be powered with either batteries or the power adapter that is included with it. I liked this model so well, I ordered a second one.

review_title: For the price, excellent...very good sound
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2005
reviewComment: I made the mistake of buying a slightly cheaper GE recorder, with horrible sound.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 31, 2018
reviewComment: This was a compelling crime thriller, well written with plenty of twists and turns. At the end, there was an interesting commentary on his own work by the author, telling us how he came to write the book and what his ‘rules’ were for writing a fanfiction novel featuring Sherlock Holmes. I wish more authors took the trouble to do that sort of thing.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 23, 2015
reviewComment: So there are quite a few Sherlock Holmes novels written post Sir Arthur Conan Doyle by various authors, until now I have avoided them. It's rare that people can step into the shoes of dead men in almost any position in life and have the same impression, the same feeling. The positive reception The House of Silk received however drew my attention and I came away suitably impressed by not only the content but the tone of the writing.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 20, 2016
reviewComment: Like most of the amazon reading public, apparently, I enjoyed The House of Silk. There's a clear echo of Conan Doyle's John Watson voice. The first few chapters are a good, fairly self-contained, traditional Holmes story. As you'd expect from the professional writer behind Midsomer Murders and Foyle's War, the book as a whole also bowls along at a decent pace.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 14, 2019
reviewComment: Having never read a Sherlock Holmes book I bought this one based on reviews and recognition of the author. I must admit to being pleasantly surprised and having thoroughly enjoyed reading it I would highly recommend it to anyone who likes a good murder mystery, modern or otherwise. Although written in the style you would probably associate with the original books it is easy reading and the story has plenty of  twists and turns along the way to keep the junior detective in us interested.....over to you Sherlock!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 31, 2016
reviewComment: I discovered Anthony Horowitz  via Trigger Mortis, and I do know Sherlock Holmes, and this  seemed well reviewed, and I have been wondering what I would want to add to the Holmes canon, so I wanted to give this a try.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 1, 2019
reviewComment: This story at least matches if not exceeds the imaginative writing of Conan Doyle. I felt immersed in the ambience constructed around this complicated tale.  You can visualise the action, the environment and the characters involved. Anthony Horowitz has captured all the elements that made Sherlock Holmes' stories so readable using Dr Watson's authorship. A great rad that I would recommend highly.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 29, 2016
reviewComment: Anthony Horowitz does a really good job of capturing the voice of narrator Dr Watson and the story is tense, exciting and worthy of the Sherlock Holmes name. The story interweaves 2 investigations, crosses the Atlantic, sees Sherlock arrested for murder and shows the worst side of Victorian England. There aren't too many of the traditional ratiocinations (for which I deducted a star) but the plot is clever and satisfying and shows Lestrade in a better light. The ebook also includes a taster chapter for the sequel 'Moriarty' who we meet very briefly, and includes an essay by Horowitz including his 10 tips for writing the book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 24, 2015
reviewComment: I've read a number of Sherlock Holmes short stories in the past, though never a novel. The characterisation was pretty good, as was the story. Sure, some bits defy reason. Why did H and W have to blag their way in to the house? Why did the mysterious stranger abduct Watson rather than just send another clue? But this sort of problem is endemic in the genre and probably present just as much in Conan Doyle. I guessed quite a few bits of what was going on (not the prison breakout, that was rather a classic) but most of my book group didn't. I did find it a bit overlong, with slightly too many strands of plot, and I didn't really like the affectation of Watson writing it in his dotage - didn't really add anything for me, and distances you from the action.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 7, 2016
reviewComment: Sherlock Holmes is dead and now his ageing companion Dr Watson also teeters towards death. With no-one left to answer to, the great detective's biographer puts pen to paper one last time to document two very different, yet inexplicably connected, mysteries. When Edmund Carstairs turns up at 221B Baker Street, he unfolds a strange tale of ruined artworks, a pair of villainous brothers and a stranger in a flat cap.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 4, 2015
reviewComment: NB this is not strictly a review of the book, but also a comment on other reviews. In my view Anthony Horowitz has superbly captured the essence of Sherlock Holmes. All the Holmesian traits are there, including the falibility, but primarily the sense of justice and the refusal to accept a man's right to be believed simply because of who he is. This is an excellent addition to the post-Conan Doyle canon and I shall definitely be reading its successor. (I would have given 5 stars, but as one who rarely guesses whodunnit, the key theme of the plot came a little too easily for me.)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2014
reviewComment: If your motion sensor isn't working on distances over 30 feet get this one. I started out with this one and a 300 watt halogen rectangular light. The sensor worked but the 300 watt halogen did not put out enough light for my cameras. I removed both and installed an "all in one" "sensor + light" combo with screw in bulbs so I could use two 150 watt par 38 GE flood light screw in bulbs. Now I had plenty of light but the motion sensor was not working at the distance I needed. I removed the wires from the "all in one"sensor and reinstalled this sensor and now all is great. Try and steal my mail now, just make sure you smile for the camera... :)

review_title: Good replacement for a similar older model
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2019
reviewComment: This was perfect remedy for a malfunctioning older version of the same motion detector.  I didn't need anything but a motion detector connected to my exterior driveway floodlights. It was easy to hook up and has again given me the ability to see what is in my  driveway when coming home after dark. And it lets me know when the coyote walks through the driveway...lol.

review_title: a simple swap out of Motion Sensor.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2016
reviewComment: My old unit couldn't detect an intruder, even at 10 ft, This was a simple swap out of Motion Sensor. Instructions were simple, it took 45 minutes to pull old package off the peak of the house, swap the Motion Sensor units, climb back up, reinstall! Works great! You got to love Heath, I built their kits as a kid! Nice!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2019
reviewComment: I installed this to control 2 floodlights to light my driveway when someone drives up. the photocell is energized 24/7 that comes exclusively from the breaker. ( another words there's no switch involved)  I would have to say that about 25% of the time the lights just stay on or upon movement being detected they cause the floodlights to flash erratically for about 30 seconds and then just cut out. To get them to work normal again I end up having to turn the breaker off for about a minute then turn the power back on and it's fine for a while.

review_title: Works great. Compatible with my cheap front porch light fixture
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2016
reviewComment: Added to a cheap front porch light fixture. Works great so far. Installation is straightforward and manual is clear. Took me about 1 hr to install myself and that was mainly screwing all the fixtures in place.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2019
reviewComment: Bought two of these and installed one on a halogen flood light and the other on a standard 400 watt incandescent.  Both work well.  I purposely bought this over others that could not reach the wattage level I needed.  The halogen did have a heating issue as I had the sensor too close to the lamp housing.  Provided the required 1" separation and all is well.  Directions were easy to follow and no issues there.  Would and will buy again for other floods.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2013
reviewComment: This no frills model installed easily and works without issue. There is a motion sensor range adjustment and adjustable on time selector on this unit. The override feature can be confusing if you are not aware of how it works. If you quickly flick the light switch off then on the motion sensor portion is not used and the light stays on. I learned this after seeing that the light had stayed on all night.You also must take care to ensure that the photocell (light sensor) on the bottom of this box is not at or above the level of the light that it controls. If light can get to the photocell it may turn on in the dark then the resulting light tells the box to turn off. This will repeat indefinitely sending anyone attempting to work under said light completely off their rocker.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
reviewComment: took couple of times to figure out the wiring.. wiring diagram not that detailed.. i have my on a 3 way switch to turn on lights all the time and then flip switch and motion sensor will work the lights.. wiring diagram does not show how to wire it that way.. motion sensor works like it should!! great product

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
reviewComment: This was a perfect replacement for a unit that I had for few years. The only thing lacking was inability to softly light and dim the lights like my old one. This one just snap on once something or someone is in the zone. But it has worked fine so far.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2020
reviewComment: This is a great motion sensor. Has dual bright and you can adjust the sensitivity pretty easily.  My previous one lasted about 6-years of heavy use in direct sunlight.  I have found the day/night sensor is typically the 1st thing to fail.  Amazon prime shipping took longer than expected. You can pick these up at ACE Hardwear for right around the same price.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2015
reviewComment: I keep this in a drawer in my kitchen. When i have to setup a new network dvice I get it out and route my laptop through it to my network main switch.  I cut he power cord down to a foot so I'm not cluttering my wifes kitchen more than possible. I bought it in early 2010 and never had a problem.

review_title: Good Port for when you need network jack options
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2015
reviewComment: This port worked great as solution in our office to connect multiple printers to one network jack. It was easy to connect and we have not had any problems with this. I have 3 printers connected to this and about 30 people using the printers daily. It is a good buy for the price.

review_title: Very easy to get up and running
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2007
reviewComment: If you have a wired connection to your router, and want to branch it to other equipment - this works fine, fast and easily. I bought a DHP-301 to bring my router "downstairs" via the electrical system in my house, and then bought this switch to allow multiple connections in my home office. Not only is it doing the job very well, but I was able to install it myself (without paying for a network administrator) - a huge plus. Linksys has come a long way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2007
reviewComment: Well, plug-in #1, plug-in # 2, plug-in #3, etc. and it WORKS. That's all there is to it. All my computers are now connected to my DSL router. The unit performs transparently, that is - no loss of performance [internet speed] when using ONE computer. When more than one computer is "on," the internet access speed seems to slowdown, since my connection is being "shared." That's expected!

review_title: Excellent Little Switch - Does What it's Designed For!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2004
reviewComment: This switch does exactly what it's designed for, sharing an Ethernet connnection. Don't expect to be able to configure VLANs, multilayer switching, VLAN trunks, load balancing, etc. This does not have any routing, NAT, or firewall capabilities. You would use this switch when you already have a router between your internal network and the Internet, and you need additional Ethernet ports. This gives you a full duplex Ethernet connection at wired speed, and it delivers! Perfect for the home office/LAN or for technicians needing extra Etherenet ports for their workbench, as this is what I use mine for. Thanks for reading! Hope this helps!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
reviewComment: good

review_title: Will NOT work with XBOX Live!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2005
reviewComment: I purchased this switch because we have two desktops, a laptop, XBOX Live, and a PS2 broadband adapter - the latter three of which are in my bedroom. I didn't want to have three wires running from my router in the hallway into my bedroom, so I thought a switch would be the way to go. [For those who don't know, hubs divide the bandwidth between all connected devices, while switches will distribute 100 mbps to EACH connected device. An important factor for online gaming.] This little switch, and I DO mean little, is very compact, attractive and seems well-built. I felt very excited by its appearance upon opening it. Unfortunately, it did not serve my purpose as it would not work with XBOX Live. It worked seemlessly with my laptop and PS2 though, so if it's needed for computers only, I think it's an excellent little switch and would rate it a 5.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2007
reviewComment: I bought this when my Network Router went on the blink.  Since I had a DSL Modem with a firewall, I didn't need another router and this product allowed me to connect 5 computers to the switch.  Installation took about 5 minutes and I noticed an increase in speed right away.  I recommend this product to someone that doesn't need a firewall.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 11, 2016
reviewComment: I am a Sherlock Holmes fan and in my opinion Anthony Horowitz has done a great job.  I would really give this 4.5 stars as there are a couple of questionable issues e.g. apart from finding a way to include a character, why go to all that trouble to give someone a key when the person giving it would clearly know it would be of little use. However, it is a very well written murder mystery and just great to have Holmes and Watson on the case. At the end Anthony explains his approach to writing the story which is also very interesting. More please.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 1, 2013
reviewComment: The hype surrounding the publication of this book put me off buying it for a while but as a Sherlock fan I gave in and I am glad I did.  I think Anthony Horowitz has captured the narrative voice of Watson very well.  London has just enough fog, crime and street urchins.  It feels authentic and Horowitz has not given us an overdone pastiche of Holmes and Watson nor an out of character melodrama.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 6, 2013
reviewComment: It is very difficult for me to fully do justice to a review here without giving the plot away so I shall have to be brief.  The opening reminded me very much of my response to the raising of the curtain of an Agatha Christie theatre production.  One knows immediately if it is going to be authentic. So with this reproduction from the first page it was convincing as an "original".  I think had it not been I couldn't have continued and would have binned it.  Yes there were differences, the main one being the crime to be solved.  It was too modern in theme. The other has been touched on by other reviewers: the Holmes-Watson relationship.  More difficult to assess as at times I could have been reading an original such was the symbiotic gel between them, at others I felt Horowitz missed it, but only just.  Yet that was enough to cause me to say "no" out loud. At other times I could have forgotten completely that this was not the trusty pen of our own Dr Watson. Background research was brilliantly executed as we were transported around the streets of London, feeling the exclusive power of Gentlemen's clubs, society drawing rooms and the stench and poverty of the slums. The energy of Holmes and his speech and manner were captured wonderfully, as were the asides to himself of Watson's references to Holmes's "habit" and his morocco pouch. Is there to be another one from this pen?

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 11, 2012
reviewComment: With the renewed interest in all things Sherlock Holmes through the BBC series and Guy Ritchie's films there are now several people adding to the canonical works of Sir Arthur, all of whom are attempting to recreate the voice of Watson.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 12, 2014
reviewComment: i enjoyed 'The House if Silk' but have to admit that I found it lacking in ... the wow factor ... that certain something to set it apart. It is well written and cracks along at quite a pace. However, in my opinion, It does not compare well with the best of Arthur Conan Doyle ... but then, one would hardly have expected it to ... a photocopy, no matter how well contrived, can never be as good as the original.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 17, 2017
reviewComment: I enjoyed this book and in the most part found it painted what I feel was an accurate picture of the late 1800s / early 1900s. However, whilst I can quite believe that there were ragged ill-fed and desperate kids all over the city I cannot believe they would be running around barefooted on cobble streets in December (this was referenced on more than one occasion) Even the very poorest would have had some means of foot cover, if only rags wrapped around their feet, because otherwise they would almost immediately suffer frostbite and inevitably death. sorry to be a pedant.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 3, 2017
reviewComment: I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It is full of amazing descriptions of the poorer side of London life and I felt like I had been transported back in time. I know that some may feel that this book is not a traditional Sherlock Holmes tale, but I thoroughly enjoyed getting lost in the criminal underworld of Victorian London. I will admit that I haven't read many of the original tales, but after reading this one I am definitely going to read some, especially as reviewers have stated that book stays true to the original style.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 27, 2016
reviewComment: A modernised take on Sherlock Holmes. There's something that doesn't quite hit the spot in the way that Conan Doyle does, but it's a good enough read anyway. The plot is a modern topical story that is already done to death in other places, so that's a bit disappointing. We are transported back to what we imagine London was like at the turn of the 20th century, although the fact that the minimum drinking age at that time was 14 seems to have eluded the author, and there are one or two historical inaccuracies in the language.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 3, 2012
reviewComment: This is a well executed homage to Conan Doyle which, in my opinion anyway, makes a very good stab at capturing Watson's narrative voice. One could clearly quibble with how well it fits in with the canon at a detailed level. For example, Watson did not take part in the investigation into the Giant Rat of Sumatra, a case which predated his meeting Holmes, and more importantly a significant part of the action here doesn't make any sense when viewed against the background of 'The Man With The Twisted Lip'. However, as Horowitz himself points out in his note on the writing of the novel, Conan Doyle was himself inconsistent about details such as the bodily location of Watson's war wound so I think that we can let that pass.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 29, 2017
reviewComment: It wasn't all that long ago that I read all the original Sherlock Holmes stories and so I was a little wary of this one. I know many people have tried to emulate Doyle in the past with varying degrees of success. What I can say is that this story is great. The spirit of Holmes and Watson, and indeed, Victorian London, is brilliantly captured, and if the conclusion of the story eventually shows merely how little has changed in the last over a 100 years, it's a sobering appreciation that corruption simply never goes away. I'm looking forward to the next book in the series

reviewComment: I like the product but had a question that was not answered by the documentation. I went to the Linksys web page and engaged their tech support via chat. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2019
reviewComment: Installed this motion detector so my light can be controlled by the switch as a normal light but is always on motion when the switch is off.  You should be an electrician or understand how it will need to be wired.

review_title: It sensed motion, but couldn't turn on the lights.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2018
reviewComment: I used it to replace the motion sensor on a Heath Zenith SL-5411-GR Dual flood unit.  I bought this SL-5407-BZ a number of years before I needed it, knowing that motion sensors don't last forever.  When I finally needed it, it installed just the same as the original.  After it was installed, the first time the motion sensor attempted to power-on the lights, there was faint "click" sound from the sensor, but no lights.  The red light on the unit would light-up when it sensed motion, but the flood lights never illuminated.  I quickly ordered a HZ-5316-BZ sensor, installed it exactly the same as this SL-5407-BZ. Then the sensor and lights worked better than new.  I threw this SL-5407-BZ that had never worked, in the trash.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
reviewComment: Works how I needed. Used in a sort of traditional way, but not with floodlights. I installed this by itself to do trol can light fixtures spaced approximately 6 feet apart, with this sensor centered between.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
reviewComment: This product has a wide field of view for motion sensing, but a rather short distance for detecting motion straight ahead. It was very easy to install and has adjustable sensitivity and duration options including a test mode.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2018
reviewComment: I got a 1600 lumin LED light and an old flood light and a halogen light, all on linked mounting boxes. I added this to give the whole thing motion detection. Works great. I'm going to replace teh halogen and flood light with more LED's but it is working the way I wanted. Great add on. Just note, you have to provide your own box that it will screw into.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
reviewComment: Works great.  Everything you need including wire nuts.  Just follow instructions....red is the switched line that goes to the lights (to black "hot" line going to lights).  Really need a switch for these to work properly.  Most lights are on switched power anyway.  Good price too.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2019
reviewComment: At first I had some flickering problems, but after reading the instructions, I turned down the sensitivity a bit and now it operates just like I need.  The ability to simply flipping the power switch off and then back on to make the light turn on constantly is a very nice option.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2019
reviewComment: I purchased four of these to illuminate my property so that would not get hurt trying to steal my stuff. I also installed three cameras to take their picture while they're doing it. Very effective. Great product. Worth the money.

review_title: A good buy for the price
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2013
reviewComment: Not much to say about a simple motion sensor. It works. I don't ask much for the field of response, so I can not tell if this will work well at great distances - say 30 feet. But at 20 feet it is reliable and the coverage is good/ The unit turns on at dusk just as you would like. But, does not turn on for grey or foggy days. The range of directional adjustment is good. I had trouble fitting the unit in to a 3-hole floodlight unit. Since it was too wide to go in the middle hole, this unit had to go in one of the outside holes. but the wide range of adjustment meant I could do this without getting any extra hardware.

review_title: A great device - you probably need it more than you think
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2001
reviewComment: You can read all you want about the specs on this thing.  Instead, I'm going to go at this review by giving you a flavor for how I use mine.  I've had my Vx for about a year and a half now.  I'm very computer literate, with a professional job in which I travel often, have numerous appointments and am on the phone regularly.  But until last year, I was married to my appointment book and Rolodex.  In fact, I carried my Rolodex (yes, the entire thing) with me on trips.  I finally gave up that circus act and bought a PDA.  All I can say is that I feel empowered now.  I have all my key information at my fingertips and the ability to add and delete, on a moment's notice, information like a new phone number or a change in the time of an appointment.

review_title: Perfect upgrade from a Palm IIIe
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2015
reviewComment: I've had a Palm IIIe for around 15 years now, and very near the beginning I switched over to the Handspring Visor deluxe with the IIIe as a backup. Call me old fashioned but I always did like the look of the Palm III series, but 2mb isn't always enough. I also had a Palm Vx before my Visor so I was spoiled for 8mb already. Long story short, for someones who likes the III series the IIIxe is the perfect upgrade from all the previous IIIs unless you want color, but I own a IIIc already.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2001
reviewComment: I purchased the IIIxe (for $... with rebate) as my first Palm. Previously I used a planner and a sharp wizard. I wasn't sure just how much I would use the Palm, but it is now a part of my being! The IIIXE screen is larger than the Palm screen on the M105, the memory is the same, and I don't find the squared shape at all uncomfortable. I highly recommend a Palm to women ...it's easy to learn graffiti, and it leaves a heck of a lot of room in your purse (no more planner, or little scraps of notes). I use it constantly, from "Handy Shopper" to jog my memory for groceries and even sequence them by aisle (shopping in 1/4 the time because of fewer returns to the same section) -- to Avantgo internet surfing, freeing up the home internet for my son. I read books, I play games, I track all of my work stuff, and I keep better track of all my finances (actually recording all my debit card expenditures!). Balancing my checkbook is a snap. It can be an adult "gameboy" and a geek organizer as well as a library and reference tool. The software available is amazing and I find new uses almost daily.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2001
reviewComment: After a great deal of research as to the best price/performance I could get out of a handheld, I decided that the Palm IIIxe was the cream of the crop. I wanted long battery life, a programmable environment, and simple functionality -- I found all three in the Palm IIIxe and felt I needed the 8Mb of RAM for flexibility's sake. I bought my Palm IIIxe at Amazon.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2005
reviewComment: I still use my palm IIIxe.. bought it in 2001 from Amazon.  Actually this is my second one, my first one bit the dust, so I bought a refurb for $39.00 and it synced up with the 4.1 OS... it is great for addresses and calendar + todos... I also type memos with a keyboard when I'm in the field.  Also this is used daily from am to pm... at night I dl avantgo and read news from the otherside of the world before bed...

review_title: I miss my Palm Personal; IIIxe not as solid, screen lacks!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2000
reviewComment: I owned [or perhaps it owned me] a Palm Personal for four years.  It died earlier this month (RIP).  Even with only 1/2 Meg of ram, I never outgrew it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2000
reviewComment: The Palm IIIxe is a nice handheld for the money.  With 8 mb of memory, and software to link to Microsoft Outlook, this is definitely the business person's machine.  I looked at the Palm IIIc, but wasn't impressed with the display, and for nearly twice the price, didn't feel it was worth it to get color.  I started out wanting the Palm V - but then realized its limitations - only 2 mb memory, no flash rom (so you can never upgrade the operating system), and it isn't even loaded with the most current palm OS operating system (the Palm V has OS version 3.1, vs the Palm IIIxe which has version 3.5).  The major benefits of the newer version are some new features and faster hotsinking.  I've been a Palm user for over 2 years and am so pleased with these machines that I wouldn't consider a Visor or anything else!  The one drawbrack (and the reason for 4 stars and not 5), is that Palm still has some work to do on their displays - need a higher resolution, easier to read display.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2000
reviewComment: The other reviews are helpful but I will boil it all down to this.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2000
reviewComment: This was my first PDA, and I really looked into it before purchasing.  I would like to say that it was a great buy, and all the other advice supportive of this product was really helpful.  I opened up the package, inserted the batteries, and turned it on.  It takes you through a quick tutoral which allows you to get started right away.  It also includes the Hot Sync Cradle, which allows you to connect it to your computer to make this a truly versatile product.  (Also, you can protect yourself of losing information by keeping a copy on your computer - an unlikely event, but this feature gives you the security)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2000
reviewComment: I had long wanted to buy a Palm product of my own, and for this purchase, I was deciding between the Palm IIIxe and the Palm Vx. Both essentially have the same specs, but the Vx has the obvious "cool" factor. I decided on the IIIxe for a number of reasons. Firstly, the IIIxe was value  for money. The Vx cost... more but does exactly the same things.  Secondly, there are more (and better) after-market cases for the IIIxe. Vx  owners invariably complain of the lack of good cases for their Palm.  Thirdly, there have also been a good number of complaints regarding the  location of the Vx's on/off switch. Personally, I find this rather critical  since I put the Palm in my pocket most of the time. There are other  reasons, including the flip cover which the Vx does not have. The Vx is  also not expandable. This is, of course, assuming that Palm will develop an  expansion kit for the Palm in the near future. One also has to send in the  Vx back to Palm when its internal rechargeable battery is no longer  working. However, I did encounter a couple of problems with the IIIxe. Less  than a week after receiving my unit, two buttons used to launch the main  applications were broken. The alarm on the IIIxe is also rather feeble,  making it hard to hear when you are outdoors.

review_title: Excellent device, if you can find one
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2001
reviewComment: This is without a doubt, Palm's best PDA. Just as powerful and useful as Palm's higher priced V and Vx models, at about $100 cheaper. Plus, its got an edge over the models its been replaced by. The m100 and m105 do not contain Flash memory like this unit does. That means the users of those machines are stuck with whatever OS comes on the PDA. The IIIxe has 2 MB of Flash memory, so its readily upgradable. The only mistake Palm made with this model was to discontinue it. If your in the market for a PDA and you can find a IIIxe, I whole heartedly recommend it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2006
reviewComment: We currently have the Linksys BEFSR41 4-port router/switch for our home network.  It's been working great for about 4 years now, but we've now run out of ports.  I did some research on the 8 port router/switch product from Linksys, but the reviews were mixed.  The reviews were mixed for similar competing products also.  So I took the route of getting the EZXS55W to expand our existing home network.  I just plugged it into the network and it just worked out of the box.  No configuration needed.  It's also very tiny.  I highly recommend the product.

I really like the size which is about half is big as my router.  The status indicator lights on the front are great too; some other brands put these lights on the back.  What's not to like?

reviewComment: A+

reviewComment: In the reviews there are some frankly nonesense thing said about this book, all about not being up to Conan Doyle's standard and pointing our historical inaccuracies around when Bridge was introduced to the UK.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 11, 2013
reviewComment: I approached The House of Silk with a little trepidation having been a fan of the original stories. However, it seems that the Conan Doyle estate was right to entrust Horowitz with continuing the Holmes canon.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 1, 2019
reviewComment: Horowitz gets his pastiche just right in this seemingly classic Holmes story.  He keeps the atmosphere of Victorian London while maintaining the interest of modern day readers by calling upon issues that trouble the city still. I really enjoyed this book and would recommend to those readers that enjoy classic whodunit stories such as Poirot and the original Doyle catalogue.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 28, 2020
reviewComment: I bought this for my 10 year old son's birthday after reading the reviews.  We played it in the car, however I was a bit shocked to discover it was a paedophil ring. This appears to have gone over my son's head though.  It held his attention and has some lovely language which he wouldn't normally meet while playing video games!!!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 14, 2012
reviewComment: I first thought it was a bit weird that an author can create a sequal to a classic when I read P D James Death comes to Pemberley, a follow on story from Austen's Pride and Prejudice. But it was absolutely brilliant. I had never read Austen's book before but it wasn't a disadvantage, as Ms James's story telling was adequate.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 24, 2013
reviewComment: I think it helped that I read this book without having previously read any of the other non-canon unauthorised Holmes fiction so I didn't have any preconceived ideas of how authentic it may or may not read. Having read through some of the reviews, I think some die-hard fans may have slightly unrealistic expectations and were expecting some sort of lost manuscript that's just been discovered originally written by Conan Doyle?! I've read all the originals and loved them; I thought this was a very very good imitation of the style, tone and personalities of the characters we love. I don't have any criticism at all in that regard.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 25, 2020
reviewComment: Such a brilliantly crafted book with Holmes exactly as I imagine him to behave, I immediately ordered the next one and its not only the best book the author has written but the best I have read this year,

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 25, 2020
reviewComment: A well plotted story, well written and with a genuine feel of Conan Doyle about it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 8, 2012
reviewComment: I have read and enjoyed many of the Conan Doyle stories about Holmes, so I wondered whether this book would maintain the standard. It certainly does and I enjoyed it very much. All the hoped for features are present; analysing obscure clues to form lucid patterns of action, convoluted verbal contests with brother Mycroft, evocative scenes of London and even Moriaty makes a useful contribution to the eventual solution.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 4, 2019
reviewComment: It feels awkward to read about Holmes from other authors. However the book does render the methods of deduction, though the plot is a bit weak. Additionally, Watson is strange, but he is a friend as usual.

reviewComment: With the Toshiba W-603 you get what you pay for; an inexpensive VCR that will play and record.  It performs these functions ably, but when its drawbacks are taken into account, the consumer may well decide to spend a little more money and purchase a better product.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2000
reviewComment: I wanted to be fair and re-rate this VCR.  You will see my previous review, I rated this VCR two stars.  I'm rating this four stars for an average of three stars. The reason?  Well, Charter Communications was upgrading the cable in my area and affected the the performance of the VCR.  The following problems I had identified were impacted by the cable  upgrade:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2000
reviewComment: This is my third mp3 player.  BEST BY FAR.  After this, I will never by another diamond product.  MP3's sound fantastic and the volume is great, I love to listen loud.  The FM tuner sounds great despite what I've read from other reviewers.  As an owner of a sound studio, my standards are high, and the Nomad sounds excellent.  The big test was to see if the management software and data transfer was a breeze or not.  Took about 15 secs to load the software plug in the device and start transferring my mp3s.  the software is the better than rio port (diamond's).  I haven't owned this product long enough to speak for its durability, but the basic design is tight and puts the new RIO 600 to shame, and is a step above my old RIO 500.  The remote control is a very handy tool to keep the main unit deep in your pocket or backpack.  As long as it keeps up what it's doing, it will be on my recommend list for all. enjoy.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2000
reviewComment: I purchased the Nomad II because it was one of the few at the time that had a built-in FM receiver (a must-have for the commute!).  I'm very pleased with the device itself:  FM reception is good, the MP3 player has all the necessary features, and the large LCD display is kind to my old eyes!  The in-cable control dongle is particularly useful.  And the machine is flash programmable, which means as new music formats come out they can provide an updater for them (there's already an update available for WMA!).

review_title: Excellent for music on the go
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2001
reviewComment: I was looking for an MP3 player to bring on long runs (I'm a marathon runner) and trips to the gym.  This was one of the few MP3 players that met a series of criteria I had chosen: lightweight, capable of carrying over an hour of music, a good remote control, and an FM radio.  I've used it for four months and I'm very satisfied.  The remote takes a little time to learn how to use, but works very well.  The remote clips easily on a belt or clothing, and is both sturdy and light weight.  The sound is excellent, and it has performed perfectly on long runs.  The software is relatively easy to use for loading songs.  Here are the limitations: the FM reception is not as good as on my old Sony FM Walkman.  The battery life is fairly short (about 4-5 hours)- I now go running with an extra AA battery as back-up.  The software is not very sophisticated.  For example, you have to move songs to a different position by moving them one position at a time as you can't drag and drop a song to a different position.  You can preset a lot of FM radio stations (32), but setting them is a little tricky- if you push the set button more than a second it switches you to the old preset station rather than setting it on the new station.  This can be painful as switching stations is slow.  Despite these limitations, the final tribute came from my wife.  She scoffed at my purchase as an excess expense in which I got carried away with technology.  Now she steals my Nomad II so often that I may have to get one for her if I hope to use it myself!

review_title: THIS IS A GREAT MP3 PLAYER BUT....
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2001
reviewComment: THIS MP3 PLAYER IS RATED BY CONSUMER REPORTS AS #1 ALL AROUND . BUT THAT ONLY COMPARING TO OTHER MP3 PLAYERS THAT ARE NOT SO NEW. I PURCHASED THIS MP3 PLAYER LOOKING TO USE IT IN THE GYM. IT HAS GREAT FEATURES AND IS VERY USER FRIENDLY. VERY LIGHT IN WEIGHT AND SMALL TO FIT WITH ITS HANDY BELT CLIP. THE ONLY PROBLEM IS THIS UNIT ONLY CAN HOLD 64MB MEMORY (ABOUT LESS THEN AN HOURE OF MUSIC). THIS WAS NOT ENOUGH FOR MY TO USE WITH A 2 HOUR WORK OUT . THE OTHER NEGATIVES ARE THE MEMORY SLOT IS IN THE BATTERY COMPARTMENT SNUG TIGHT. THEIR IS NO ROOM FOR YOU OT PULL THE CARD OUT AND THE BATTERY IS IN THE WAY. VERY POOR DESIGN ON THIS MATTER. I ASK MY SELF WHY CREATIVE WOULD DESIGN SUCH A GREAT DEVICE BUT ONLY STORES UP TO 64MB OR MUSIC AND HAVE SUCH A POOR DESING FOR MEMORY STORAGE. ALSO IF YOU ARE BUYING THIS ITEM BUT ABOUT 4 BATTERIES YOU WILL NEED THEM IT EATS THE POWER UP 2 HOURS A BATTERY IF THAT. SUGGEST THE NOMAD 2 MG  WITH 128-190 MB . THIS ITEM IS NOT PRICE JUSTIFIED DUE TO THE LACK OF MEMORY

review_title: Except for a few glitches, this is a great product
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2000
reviewComment: The quality of sound and thoughtfulness in making this product is  remarkable.  It has a lot of features, including lock feature, remote  control, voice recording, fm radio, and a usb cable.  There however a few  glitches, which in my opinion makes the Nomad less than perfect and not  quite as close to the level of a Sony product.  First, the headphones are  not too comfortable. The band tends to hit your ears. Second, taking out  the battery cover requires a lot of effort which, up to this point, I have  not figured yet a reliable way of doing it.  And there is no ac battery  output unless you get a docking station. Thus, except for those few  noticeable glitches this is a great product

review_title: Please don't buy this defective wonder
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2000
reviewComment: I got my Nomad II today and immediately downloaded some favorite MP3s, as well as 'samples' included in the box.  ALL files were sampled at  128kps/44.1 KhZ.  ALL files also play back with compression artifacts  (flanging): pops, whistles, cracks, and 'skips'.  The firmware CODEC is  defective, as these files play fine on my PC with software CODECs.  I tried  upgrading the firmware to the latest version, but keep getting an error.  The only way to get tech support from Creative is to call a toll number.

review_title: If this was your firts choice, go with your second
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2001
reviewComment: As far as hardware goes, it's a great player - that's why I gave it two stars.  Unfortunately hardware requires software, and in this case, Creative's software support is terrible.

review_title: WOW Holy Apples The Real Revolution Started Here At Creative Labs!!!! Nomad II ROCKS!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2012
reviewComment: You can see all the great features / patents Apple stole from Creative Labs on this one. In 2000 this one did it all played MP3's on a skip free flash player and removable media card's. Built in voice recorder with FM radio, clock, timer. In a matter of seconds you can replace the removable rechargeable battery. Its compact small and light weight well built and under $340.00 dollars. In my opinion that what makes you beautiful!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2000

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2000
reviewComment: I bought my husband a Palm in March as an early Father's Day present and  after watching how it changed his life I decided to get one for  myself.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2002
reviewComment: As an owner of Jornada 548 and Jornada 720 Pocket PCs and a Handspring Visor Prism I've had ample time to consider which of them is my favorite - and the Palm Vx wins.

review_title: The PDA for those who shun toys and gadgets.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2000
reviewComment: I outgrew my spiral-bound DayTimer books after 22 years -- the need to keep notes from month to month, place extra pages on busy days, and keep "project note" folders became overwhelming.  So late last year I  got a DayTimer ring binder that was also pocket size.  It fixed the  problems with keeping notes, but I still had the problem of finding  specific notes, getting info from previous months, and remembering  appointments.  I also discovered, at age 42, I have ADD -- and I'm trying  to better compensate for it now that I'm aware.

review_title: How did I survive without it?
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2000
reviewComment: For years I've been using one of those little 32KB "digital diaries" to store all my phone numbers, shopping lists etc. I debated getting one of the Palms but could never convince myself to spring for one.  Then, when I was able to expense one on the company dime, I thought I'd go  for one of the III series or maybe the VII. But luckily a co-worker  convinced me to get the Vx, citing all the usual reasons (more memory,  looks cooler, rechargeable battery). After a few days of using it, I  couldn't even fathom going back to the digital diary. Not only is it now a  snap to transfer all my appointments, contacts, and notes into a portable  medium (one press of the Hot Sync button versus entering it all manually on  the digital diary's keyboard), but the Palm can do so much more. I get  news, sports, Rolling Stone, weather reports and movie listings on my Vx  with every Sync. I can play games. I can beam my business card to someone  else (weird the first time you do it, sort of like Star Trek) and receive  one in return. Plus there is a lot of Palm software out there for almost  any purpose. The Vx allows you to have this wealth of capabilities  literally at your fingertips, and the 8MB of memory means you have room for  lots more. And the V series is much more stylish and professional-looking  than the VII and the III series which are also physically larger and thus  less convenient to carry in a pocket. If you have even the slightest need  to be organized, or to have useful information close at hand, then the Palm  Vx is for you.

The To do list  also replaces my paper agenda and is a very nice feature allowing you to  check off items upon completion.  What can I say? I used to have the IIIe and this is a  much better model allowing me to put in a ton more programs.  An ingenious  device.  I can't think of going back to the old way of using paper anymore. reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 16, 2016
reviewComment: He writes well and tells a good tale, but lets be honest, he just doesn't know when to stop, in places he meanders on endlessly gushing words until you are tempted to shout, Put a sock in it and get in with it, for crying out loud. Concise and succinct he is not. Be ready to speed read and jump passages now and again or you may get bogged down in his meandering verbosity and end up not appreciating his story telling ability.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 19, 2015
reviewComment: This takes the Victorian detective into a new and more contemporary area of crime and the author manages it remarkably well. The plot starts with a single theme which, develops into different and seemingly random tangents then carefully and believably brings them to a climactic solution. It's clear the author is a genuine fan of the original stories and at times I was genuinely amazed at how his writing perfectly aligned with the feel of the original stories authentically catching the tone of the elderly Watson. There are thousands of contemporary Holmes stories and many of them are good stories in their own right, but this is the best I've read and the one that for me captures the essence of Conan Doyles plot, style and writing. Can't wait for the next one.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 1, 2015
reviewComment: Thank you Anthony Horowitz for giving me once more the pleasure of reading a Sherlock Holmes story. I have never bought books in the past that have been a "continuation" of a dead author but I so love Conan Doyle's creation (and Anthony Horowitz's work) that I thought I would give it a try. I am so glad I did - only one page in and I was once again transported back with Dr. Watson to Baker Street in Victorian London. This is a really good story and most definitely in the voice of Dr. Watson, it was like meeting an old friend again after a gap of many years. No wonder it was a best seller!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 23, 2017
reviewComment: Terrific yarn in the style of Conan Doyle. I surprised myself by how much I like this. It's well plotted and moves at a cracking pace without ever feeling ersatz. Horowitz has done a stellar job of maintaining the oeuvre and his Holmes and Watson are true to the characters we know and love. Few liberties are taken and there are plenty of little references that die hard Doyle fans will spot. Highly reccomended.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 6, 2019
reviewComment: This is the second book Horowitz wrote about Sherlock Holmes at the request of the Conan Doyle Estate. It's a good read, if perhaps not quite as good as the other in the pair.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 12, 2018
reviewComment: A really good plot, well written in a style Conan Doyle himself would be proud of. I read many Sherlock Holmes books when I was younger and this seems to be very much in the same vein, as you would expect from a writer of the calibre of Anthony Horowitz. I thoroughly enjoyed this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 4, 2015
reviewComment: Just like reading a Doyle book. Very entertaining. Great use of the characters and twits in the story were played out like I say above just like a Doyle book. Yes it's quite easy to figure out the script but that's the beauty of Holmes in that it feels like you and him are in on the big picture while Watson isn't. The reason it's not a 5 star is I don't think any Holmes novels are plus a bit of jiggery pokery in chapter 14 which isn't needed. Also the details on London could be better.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 12, 2014
reviewComment: I have never been a fan of Sherlock but this was chosen as a read for the book club I belong to. It was a very well written book, very descriptive with lots of twists and turns in the plot, all that you would expect to find in a Sherlock Holmes mystery. You could almost feel the cold, damp eeriness of a London pea souper in the late 1800's. I would think this is a good Sherlock Holmes story but just not for me :-) I don't think Holmes fans will be disappointed in this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 14, 2014
reviewComment: I bought this to read with my book group and finished it in almost one sitting (though will probably re-read before the group meets!).  As a Conan Doyle fan I was not disappointed with this book.  Previous experience with Anthony Horowitz is only through children's books, but I found his style just as good to read in a more adult format.  Good story.  Definitely fitted the genre.  And apparently, one of the only (?) Sherlock Holmes books written since his death, to be approved by his estate.  Good for Conan Doyle fans of Holmes as well as for those who have never read any of the original.

reviewComment: very good workgroup switch it seems it imporved my connection a lot better and took a HUGE load off my router its self what used to take 10 seconds to load a webpage only takes like 3 seconds now i think it imporved my connection to the PSN on ps3 witch my games never did LAG before using this but it has imporved the connection status & PS3 connection overall this is PREFECT plus the bandwidth is 10/100% BETTER then using the standard modem & router a must buy for those looking to improve a lot on there connection & bandwidth i,m most impressed with this product now its time to switch my NETGREAR router out with a LINKSYS wireless or wired....

review_title: Be Sure Placed in Right Order
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2009
reviewComment: I purchased this switch like most folks to allow an existing Linksys cable modem/router to provide an Internet signal to an additional Ethernet port in my house. In the meantime, I recently bought a Sony Blu-Ray player with Internet video streaming, but I found that the existing Linksys modem/router could not handle the upgraded high-speed service. So I bought a new Motorola DOCSIS 3.0 cable modem. I naively thought I could simply use this Linksys switch to send the signal along its merry way throughout my house. WRONG. After several hours of reseting the IP address on each computer, and several calls to Charter (my ISP), I called Motorola. The Motorola SurfBoard modem is a throughput device, that assigns only one IP and the Linksys switch is not a smart/managed type that can assign individual IP addresses. So I have a new router on its way from Amazon, which should solve the problem, once I place the router immediately after the modem but before the switch! The router will then assign an unique IP address to my four computers and Blu-Ray player. Perhaps this is common knowledge, but the technical support staff at Charter were not aware of this. So just an FYI.
