review_title: Using PACBell DSL with P.P.P.o.E. and a Dynamic IP address
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2000
reviewComment: I've been sitting on the fence wondering whether to buy the LinkSys unit or not. The main reason for my wait, is that I've read many reviews of the LinkSys BEFSR41, including all of the information on the LinkSys web site,  but it seems that no one is using the exact same DSL setup as I am. They  either have PACBell and a Dynamic IP address, but no P.P.P.o.E, or they  have PACBell and P.P.P.o.E and a static IP address.

review_title: I LOVE stuff that installs super easy and works great!!!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2001
reviewComment: I've been putting off hooking up a router to get my son and wife's PC on the internet because I dreaded having to slog through getting information from my ISP (Verizon), configuring network cards and generally mucking around in places I wasn't comfortable mucking around in.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2010
reviewComment: I bought this because my Netgear router wasn't working. The only problem I've had is that I can't access the printer on our network and Linksys customer support sucks. They told me they were transferring me to get help but actually transferred me to a third party CS that wanted me to pay about $25 for tech support.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2012
reviewComment: Linksys quality, easy setup, worked out of the box.  Extensive hardware firewall options for the power user who is looking for a wired router.  I have to say though that my first router gave up its electronic life after about 5 years.  Even though I am electronically versed I was unable to troubleshoot or repair it.  Thus I bought another one of this type, and it is still going strong.  Keep in mind that the firmware is upgradable, i.e. if you don't mind working with .bin files and flashing EEPROMs through the router's internal setup page you can keep it updated very easily.  I used these boxes under Win95, WinXP, Win7, and never had any problems.

review_title: Works just like it should! Hurray for Linksys!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2001
reviewComment: I'm a network administrator for a software company, so I didn't expect to have any problems setting up this unit.  After a quick glance at the instructions (which seemed a little scant, but certainly passable) I was pluggin' and goin'.  I was able to download a newer version of the firmware (the code that runs the unit) and configured everything in about 10 minutes.  Couldn't ask for more, setup-wise.  Perfect!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2007
reviewComment: This router performed as promised. Following the CD to INSTALL it, is essential, and easy to do.  But there is no manual, no quickstart guide, and no trouble-shooter that comes with it.  All of those things are on the CD; limited as that is.  And to make personal settings, refine it, or trouble-shoot it; you have to go online, and do research.  The internal settings can be VERY complicated.  I'm attempting to use it for my TiVo to transfer recordings from my TiVo to my PC.  It is taking almost more work than is worth the effort.  The Router itself works exactly as it should.  Since there is no manual, and findind Linksys Tech Support is very difficult; I'd suggest finding a good tech support place online, read it, and see if you want to delve into all that this type of connection may require.  All in all, I may go back to NOT using a router at all.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2002
reviewComment: Well I installed this router today; setup was so fast it was almost anticlimatic! I was concerned that I would have problems because I had to deinstall existing setup. For internet sharing between 2 pcs, I was using Winpoet software with Microsoft Internet sharing activated and two network cards in one pc acting as the server. The existing setup was clunky and the main pc had to be on for the other pc to connect. Before setting up the Linksys router, I took out 2nd network card out of the main pc and deleted it from the network listing. Also uninstalled WinPoet software and Microsoft internet sharing. After that, shut down everything hooked up network cables, turned everything on, used the Linksys web page setup and within 5 minutes I was connected! Both pc's too, together or separately; and performance is way better now!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2002
reviewComment: Installation after all was smooth but the CD wizard didn't work; it was telling me it couldn't establish connection to the Internet. I went then with the manual approach, which was pretty straightforward.

review_title: Works well, but a few annoyances
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2004
reviewComment: I've been running the BEFSR41 for about a year and for the most part it's worked flawlessly.  However, the DHCP server appears faulty.  Occasionally, I get an IP Conflict when a new computer logs in.  In addition, when looking at the computers that have DHCP-assigned IP addresses (through the administration access), the reporting is almost completely erratic.  For example, almost never are all the computers shown, and refreshing the screen has no effect.  Linksys tech support has verified this is not working properly, but has no solution.  PPoE to log into SBC's DSL works great, and port forwarding is also passable, though you have to assign a static IP to the devive you want to route to (rather than the MAC address or device name), which is a bit of a pain.  Overall, for the price, it works pretty well.

review_title: Works great w/ Win98,95 and @home cable
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2000
reviewComment: Setup instructions are easy to follow. If you are really a beginning level computer user it may be difficult.  If you have some computer hardware experience things work like a breeze.  I have it hooked up with two win98 computer and one win 95 computer using athome cable modem service.  It works flawlessly most of the time.

review_title: Depending on old fixture, may have limited range to adjust motion field.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2019
reviewComment: Repaired 2 fixtures using these sensors.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2018
reviewComment: Works as advertised and will operate a relay (not all motion sensors will operate a standard relay)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2020
reviewComment: It sticks in the on position ALL THE TIME!!!! Have to power cycle it to make it work again.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
reviewComment: Good product

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2019
reviewComment: Does not detect motion, but turns on randomly every few minutes without any motion. Waste of money.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2020
reviewComment: I mounted my lights on the soffit.  The old sensor was on a longer more flexible mount.  As a result this unit does not read as far.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2013
reviewComment: Works like they all do. Just install it and forget about it. What's really nice, is that you can locate it away from the fixture to better sense movement. Mine turns on the front porch lights. I located it in a position where it best senses someone approaching. Some basic knowledge of electrical work is required.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2021
reviewComment: Works fine

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2018
reviewComment: It failed after 3 years

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2018
reviewComment: I will give it a 4 for now just installed. I will let u all know .

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2000
reviewComment: Using this for my home network of 3 100 Mbps LinkSys in Win98 machines plus a 10 Mbps Linux machine. Works fine. There is no software driver required for this (drivers are required and supplied with the NIC cards that go in your machine). Looks really cute sitting on the shelf with the blinking LEDs!  Hope to use it when eventually get DSL or cable internet access out here.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2007
reviewComment: Switch works great! Expanded my home network to hard wire 4 more computers. This switch gave me an alternate location for tying in home computers. I have not daisy-chained another switch to th first one, but probably will soon because I'm out of available connections again. Should have gotten 7 port, but I like the option of setting up another location in the house to connect other computers.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2006
reviewComment: this little baby is just hook up my desktop, wireless AP, wired router together

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2002
reviewComment: This switch is an excellent choice for LAN parties and home networks where wireless access and internet routing are not important.  I've never had any trouble using this switch, and you have instant connectivity the second you plug in. It has a sixth port for uplink to another switch etc..., this is helpful for expansion.  It is rather small, and I find myself buying a bigger one now... So, you can save money by buying a big one first instead of buying a small one and expanding with another small one later.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2008
reviewComment: I purchased the Worgroup Switch because I wanted everyone on my home network to be able to use my network-ready All-in-one graphic printer, yet I wanted it next to my machine in the basement.  Instead of running another long cable from my router on my second floor, I added the switch near my basement computer and attached the original network cable from my computer to the Workgroup Switch and then added my computer and the printer with short cables to the Workgroup Switch.  There were no software modifications required.

review_title: An awesome, convenient little ethernet switch
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2002
reviewComment: I have two of these Linksys switches on my home network. They are inexpensive, well constructed, and conveniently small. They have really fast throughput, and I've never once had a problem with them--you just plug them in and they work.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2004
reviewComment: This product has served me just fine. I have experienced no problems with this switch, and I am certainly glad that I got this because I have a computer on 10Mb (instead of 100Mb), and I would not want that one computer to slow all the others down. It seems a little overpriced for what it does, but as a product, its performance has been optimal.

review_title: Works Great, and Easy to Install
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2002
reviewComment: I needed an additional hub or switch to run from my Wireless DSL/Cable Router (which only had 1 PC/Uplink Port).  This switch worked great, and seemed to be priced comparable to many hubs, which would have worked fine for me, but obviously not given the benefits of the switch.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2007
reviewComment: as long as what you need is a switch (takes an ip address from a router and shares it among multiple devices) and not a router, this thing is perfect.  It is the only networking device I've ever set up based solely on the picture on the back of the box.  It took longer to unpack than to get set up.  I have two different computers at work and only one network jack, so I put the network feed into the switch and cabled in the two computers.  Works great and no performance issues at all.  Love it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2008
reviewComment: I bought two EZXS55W units.  One worked for nine months before two ports failed.  I called Linksys to have it replaced and they told me I had to ship the unit to them before I got my replacement.  I talked them into sending a replacment to me first so I could use the same box to return the defective unit.  Then they said they would charge my credit card for the full MSRP until they received the failed unit, plus I had to pay for the shipping back to them.  I refused, talked to a supervisor, and still no joy.  The shipping would cost me almost as much as a new unit.  This feedback is not just about the EZXS55W.  It's about the company in general.  They represent the typical greedy big business with their attitude concerning customer service and their products fail too often.  I had two of their routers fail as well.  No more Cisco/Linksys for me.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 21, 2020
reviewComment: this is a really good read  -  up to date but still authentic sherlock.  Think conan doyal would be pleased.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 13, 2019
reviewComment: Really enjoyed this book.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 5, 2018
reviewComment: Nothing

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 28, 2015
reviewComment: As a Sherlock Holmes Dan I was a bit apprehensive about this one but I enjoyed every minute of it! Even the writing was period placed! I prefer to read a book which shows that the other actually paid attention in English class! Just about to purchase the second!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 14, 2017
reviewComment: I loved this book. Horowitz has captured Watson, the narrator, brilliantly. Read it in two days flat, as I couldn't put it down.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 20, 2015
reviewComment: Too much effort, too little inspiration. I found it almost impossible to engage with the story - which never happened with the originals. This may be due to the publisher's demand for a certain length, in the insane assumption that the reader wants bulk rather than essence. Wake up to the fact that some of the gems of literature were very short: The Little Prince and Siddharta, for example.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 23, 2014
reviewComment: I loved the style of writing here - just as though Conan Doyle was writing it!  That is just as important to me as the story itself.  The story was rather horribly plausible which was rather disquieting!  However, a damn good read and I do recommend it highly.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 13, 2019
reviewComment: Very well written in the Sherlock Holmes style.  Some compelling twists to the story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 10, 2016
reviewComment: A present for my mum who liked it but not as much as the originals. Not an easy thing to replicate a classic author and I think she would say that this was a 'nearly there' rather than outright success.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 7, 2016
reviewComment: I liked it! There are a few negative reviews about this and the subject matter it covers, but having "found" Moriarty was keen to read this. I'm a traditional Holmes fan and enjoyed the plot and characters. No - it wasn't written by Conan-Doyle and may offend the purists. But as a work of fiction I enjoyed it and would recommend.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2000
reviewComment: I had been researching PDAs for almost a year.  I looked at the Palm, the Handspring, the Helio (by V-Tech), and even the new Pocket PC compatibles. I decided Palm was the way to go.  After all, why not go to the source of  the technology!  I decided on the IIIxe for a couple of reasons.  1)  More  memory.  2)  Newest OS.  3)  Great value.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2000
reviewComment: I never wanted to be one of 'those people' who you think are computer geeks walking around with a Palm. Now, I am one of them. I've had my Palm IIIxe for two weeks now and I really like it. I only had a slight problem  setting up the AvantGo software (offline reading of websites) because of a  firewall setting problem where I work. Otherwise the setup was very smooth.  The Palm hotsync'd with Outlook both at home (via dial up to work) and at  work. I would recommend buying some sort of protective case right away. I  also have now ordered a hotsync cable to use at home since I've been  leaving the hotsync cradle at work. Now that I have the AvantGo software  working, I want to be able to hotsync at home as well. It's nice having  some stuff to read say on a long car ride....and it's so much nicer having  the Palm rather than hauling around a big laptop. The real beauty of the  whole thing is that everything is backed up...by that I mean since we use  Outlook at work for e-mail and calendar and stuff, even if I have to reset  the Palm, or one of my kids erases/deletes something, all I have to do is  hotsync and I'm back in business. I'm sorry I waited this long to get one.

review_title: Defective right out of the box
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2001
reviewComment: After much deliberation and comparison I decided to buy a Palm IIIxe. I was excited about this purchased and eager to organise my life. Right away it had problems. In the first 24 hours I had it I spent over 3 hours on the phone with Palm customer support. These were a sad group of individuals. They kept having me try the same things over and over again. My problem was the Palm Desktop would Hotsync, but would not send my datebook over to the handheld. I was getting angry and telling them "look, I'm just going to return it, there is something wroung with it." "No," they said, "we can fix it its in the Palm desktop not the hand held." So I went over and over the same backing up of data and resetting the handheld and reinstalling the software with three different support persons. Finally, I said "Look, I have the info I have entered in the desk-top backed up. I'm just going to return it for a new one." Finally the Palm support guy admitted to me that, Yes, The handheld was defective. By this time I wanted nothing to do with the Palm Brand, But I did not want to lose my Information I had already entered. So I returned it for another Palm IIIxe. This one appears to work fine. But, The entire ordeal of going around and around with their customer support has soured me on their products. I'm glad I don't own stock in Palm!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2001
reviewComment: Having been a Palm user since '98, I recently bought a handspring visor deluxe, only because of the 56k Modem. I must say at first I was quite impressed at the Visor's speed but soon came to realize it's high battery consumption.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2001
reviewComment: The Palm IIIxe is my fifth PDA, and I recommend very highly for anyone who is looking for value combined with great functionaliy!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2001
reviewComment: My husband bought this for me as a "just because I love you" gift.  He had bought himself one a month before he bought mine and he said he just loves it.  So do I.  I love everything about it.  It's so functional and anyone can use it, very user-friendly.  You don't have to be an executive to own one.  If you need some organization in your life, whether you're a mother, father, student, administrative assistant, doctor or a president of a company this will do the trick for you.  I especially like downloading and hot syncing all the different freeware and shareware software I get off the internet. Buy it!  You won't regret it!

review_title: How did I ever get along without it??
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2001
reviewComment: In a word - WOW!! As a novice Palm IIIxe user, I've found it to be very easy to learn and use.  As a long-time Franklin Planner user, I have been able to retire my planner.  The Palm is simply always there - to check the calendar, to make a note, to make a calculation, to take meeting notes, you name it and it's available.  The biggest problem I have is deciding which of the hundreds of software applications to try.  My Palm is with me from early morning until I go to bed at night.  I think it's the greatest thing since sliced bread or round wheels.

review_title: Stop reading this and buy that sucker!
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2001
reviewComment: When I bought this Palm, I was planning on using it in school for keeping track of homework, taking notes in class, and playing pong or chess during lunch time. I quickly found that while the stylis graffiti is easy to work with, and very accurate, I can take notes faster on paper. Other than not being able to take notes at a reasonable speed in class, it does everything I want it to. The operating system took me about 10 minutes to master (I had no prior experiance with the Palm). Syncronizing with my computer is easy-there's only 1 button on the Hot Sync cradle and it takes an average of 15 seconds to syncronize via serial port, unless I'm installing applications, which there are a ton of free ones on the web. I wouldn't bother with the USB connection kit unless you don't have a serial port. This Palm IIIxe features everything the IIIc does, except a color screen and a built in rechargeble battery. The Vx is the same as the IIIxe, except thinner, a rechargeble battery, and more expensive. The VII has a modem, which you can buy seperatly for the IIIxe. Unless you want a color screen, don't bother with the other Palms. Get this one.

review_title: Put your life in your Palm
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2001
reviewComment: Some call it being organized some call it being anal, whatever you call it, it's great. I've begun to put my life in my "Palm Pilot IIIxe" and it's wonderful. No longer do I have an excuse for missing a meeting, deadline, birthday or occasional birthday.

review_title: Palm III great device at the beginning
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2001
reviewComment: GREAT AT THE BEGINNING,  I have given this device excited endorsments, and have 6 freinds who have purchased PALM products on my recomendation.  HOWEVER,  this device is my Third. Started with the PALM PROFESSIONAL, and decided 2MB was not enough.  Purchased a IIIxe and sold my PRO to a friend (it latet died on him). The first IIIxe worked great for aprox 4 months and then gave serious display problems.  This was exchanged by customer support (who are great, but I later had a problem which they still have not answered, 3weeks).  I have almost maxed out the memory and use it for everything from contact, schedule, to do, and even my checkbook, and some medical stats. Use it with the modem for e-mail and minor net lookups.  BUT after 1 1/2 years, the device is giving me a HUGE headache.  My computers are USB only,  IT WILL NOT SYNC.  The adapters seem to have a lifespan, of only 7 months,  currently on my third.  But Now WILL NOT SYNC AT ALL and customer support is confused. Am now shopping for replacement and not ordering PALM

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2000
reviewComment: OK, so I admit to being a bit of a loser when it comes tolearning these gadgets, but so far I haven't understood why I needed to buy this thing. I had a HUGE amount of problems trying to import my 400 contacts from Microsoft Outlook (nothing matched up and it took me 5 hours of editing to get SOME similarities between the two lists), then I accidentally deleted all the email from my home computer, and I am deathly afraid of bringing my Intellisync into the office and trying to do similar damage here. WHAT DOES THIS THING DO? (I know... RTFM... something I am NOT good at)

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2000
reviewComment: I have to admit, I bought my Pilot more because it was cool than because I actually thought I would keep myself organized with it. Fortunately, I was pleasantly surprised; it's hard to imagine now how I would manage without  it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2000
reviewComment: HotSync works like a dream.  The unit is so flexible, it was very easy to make it accommodate my needs.  The ability and ease to add new applications is great.  The available applications and additional accessories make this  a tool I will be able to utilize and enhance for years.  I don't know why I  never bought one before.  Definately worth the price.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2001
reviewComment: It's all about what they fail to tell you . . . The Palm Vx is not compatible, thus not supported by 3COMM, with Windows ME. PalmPilot/3COM says to keep checking back with the Web site to see when it is compatible/supported. Not in this lifetime buster! I have better things to do than checking Palm's Web page every few days to find out when their product will be usable.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2001
reviewComment: I bought this for her for Mother's day and she absolutely loves it.  She's not so computer savy so we learned to use it together. In about a couple of hours she was transitioning her data from her old daytimer to the "New" Palm.  She and I both are surprised at how easy to use and functional this guy really is.  I recommend it to anyone who uses a daytimer or other such planner.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2003
reviewComment: This handheld is made with great quality!  I myself had a Palm M105 which has very similar stats.  The Palm Vx is so much better made and the rechargible battery is awesome!  I would recomend this to anybody who needs to get organized or just likes to play games in school or work!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2001
reviewComment: Tengo 6 meses de utilizar una Palm Vx, mantengo toda la informacion de mi agenda diaria, a la mano, es muy confiable y rapida, nunca he tenido problema de perdida de informacion o cualquier otro tipo de problemas. Considero una muy buena eleccion comprarse una.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2000
reviewComment: A friend of mine has this model and I just love it. My next electronic purchase will be this one. Did you know that you can update your online  journal with your palm pilot? WOW!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2001
reviewComment: The palm vx is the best thing ever!!!!  There is endless uses for it and not to mention the ultra sleek and thin case, in which it attracts alot of attention with friends.  Im a freshman in high school and i found it to be really useful in keeping track of my assignments, help to do my math, and keep me up to date with up-to-date new (and its also fun to play a game or two during class =) ) At first i was prolly like some of you. You want one, but you dont think that you would have much use for it and your kinda skeptical. Now I would be totally lost without it.  In conclusion, the palm vx is the best thing that i have come across.  It's the best invention since the flushable toilet. I believe that everyone should have a palm.  GET A PALM VX!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2000
reviewComment: Best business investment I (actually my company) ever made.  I now have a powerful calendar and address book that is convenient and small enough that I actually carry it with me everywhere I go.  Sure it would be nice to have  color, but for the way I use it, color is not really necessary.  Looks very  sleek, also.

review_title: A Good Product marred by poor quality control
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2000
reviewComment: Ok, I had some savings in my pocket and I thought "Hmmm...what should I buy?" Voila! I decided to get an MP3 player...Rio600. Let's see what problems I've encountered with this nifty device:

review_title: Easily the best portable, but there's room for improvement
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2000
reviewComment: The Diamond Rio 600 is a paradox.  It's twice as good as anything currently on the market, but half as much as you need.  There's something  very right about each of the three components of the system--headphones,  body and software--and yet there are serious deficiencies with each  part.

review_title: Haven't had a problem so far :)
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2001
reviewComment: I got this as a Christmas present December 2000, and have used it moderately throughout the whole time.  Overall, it's a great mp3 player, and one of the cheaper ones out there (too bad it hasn't gone done in price at all it seems :(.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2001
reviewComment: I got the Rio 600 through the Pepsi Points promotion last year (2000).  The audio is great, the menu structure is very understandable, the screen has a light function that's very similar to Indiglo, and the casing fits your hand well enough that you can operate it with one hand.  Unfortunately, the Rio 600 has some flaws.  First, the Rio says it can run off one AA battery for 11 hours.  That's true in more than one sense of the word.  The clock inside runs off the battery, greatly reducing playtime.  Unless you use the Rio constantly, you're going to be changing batteries every two weeks.  Second, 32 Mb of memory is not a lot unless you convert your mp3s to Windows Media Audio (WMA).  To do this, you will need to download the powertoys package for the Windows Media Player, it does not ship with the Rio (at least when I got mine).  Finally, the control program you install on your computer to transfer songs is very cumbersome.  I have a part-time job as a computer lab consultant and even I have to look around in order to make the program work.  I don't even use it anymore, I just use the "Portable Device function" in Windows Media Player--which is a lot easier to use.  In short, the Rio 600 has a short battery life and a complicated control program, but makes up for it with an affordable price and excellent sound quality.  If you get it, I recommend getting the rechargeable battery.

review_title: Horrible battery life, cheap quality plastic design
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2004
reviewComment: I was not impressed with this MP3 player at all. First of all, im not sure if mine was defective but it would only go 2-3 hours of playing time before the battery would flat out die. I tried upgrading the firmware or calibrating the battery beforehand. This brings me to the quality of the design, when I try and get to the battery compartment. You have to remove the entire back cover and then open this other flimsy door to get to the one AA battery. Try and squeeze the battery in the small space while so worried that the small plastic holders are going to break off. One you got that in, you have to carefully position the back cover to fit back on with the metal contacts in place. Whew.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2000
reviewComment: I read a lot of other reviews before deciding to ask for the rio 600 for christmas. This is the first portable mp3 player I've gotten and I honestly love it. The 32 megs it comes with may not seem like much, but by recording music in the windows WMA file format I've been able to fit over 16 3-5 minute songs in it, and the reason for getting something like the rio instead of a cd/mp3 player is so that you don't have to worry about scratched discs & skipping.  This is definitely the best player for it's price range.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2000
reviewComment: I really like the Rio 600.  But somehow, mine came without any software  (no CD).  When I called Customer Support, they said there were problems  with the current version of Rioport Manager, and a new one would be posted  to the S3 website soon.  So far, it hasn't been.  BUT.... There is software  that allows you to download files using Windows Media Player 7, and this  works fine.  Windows Media Player also automatically converts MP3s to WMAs  (if you want it to, by setting the writing speed to 64mps).  It can also  transfer MP3s, but since the WMAS take up half the space and (to my ears)  sound just as good, why not use wmas?  I can get about 14 songs on this  way.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2003
reviewComment: I was so excited to buy my first mp3 player about a year ago, however I should have done a little more research first.  I was happy with all the features, the display, etc., but there are a few issues worth noting with this.  First of all, the battery doesn't last anywhere near the 11 hours it says.  If I leave it for any length of time without using it, the battery dies as well.  Then there is the memory issue.  I realize that is an issue with any 32 MB mp3 player, however, the memory backpack things are impossible to find; though the wonderful people at the store I purchased it at assured me I could order them online, that was not the case.  I suspect the reason they didn't have them at the store was that this model was on its way out. The website currently makes no acknowledgement of the memory "backpacks", and while they do still have software updates for the 600 model, they don't sell it anymore.  I have not been able to find them ANYWHERE.  If you want more than 10 songs, do not buy this.

review_title: Good quality MP3 player. Here's why you should buy this one.
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2000
reviewComment: I did lots of research before I purchased my MP3 player. I even purchased a MiniDisc player before I lay the cash down for the RIO 600. Here's why:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2001
reviewComment: I received this as a Holiday gift recently and initially was very impressed.  Cool design, and easy to install and use software.  Music capacity is defintely skimpy, however.  MP3 format takes up much more memory than WMA format, so it helps to search for music in WMA format.  Even more helpful would be the upgrade, and frankly they should make it with the higher memory to start.  Out of the box I would say the memory capacity can sometimes be closer to 30 minutes than 60 minutes.  Biggest problem: after only a couple of weeks of using it, it died.  No warning, it wasn't dropped.  Everything appears to be fine except that no sound comes out of it.  Tech support was very matter-of-fact about the problem as if it happened all the time and said they would authorize a replacement, though I have yet to get the paperwork that will allow me to send it back.  Bottom line seems to be: good product with quality control problems!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2015
reviewComment: Excellent

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2017
reviewComment: absolutely brilliant. To be read along with the Bible. A must for all Christians. Gives a  clearer view of The Way!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
reviewComment: A classic, to be sure.  But very 17th century Puritan in tone.  One I needed to read just to be familiar with the story.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2018
reviewComment: Have been wanting to reread this. Now, it is not REQUIRED reading.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2017
reviewComment: The book was very good. Made you think!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2016
reviewComment: In some places in the book I found was just repletion.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2017
reviewComment: Excellent book, fast ship.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2016
reviewComment: appears for good content

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2017
reviewComment: too predictable and bit long winded.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2016
reviewComment: Great book in language easily understood.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2014
reviewComment: I like it!

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2015
reviewComment: ok

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2016
reviewComment: A series of short stories - very well written and enjoyable

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2012
reviewComment: I'm reading this on my Kindle now. I LOVE IT. I will definitely be back for more Sherlock after this one is done.  The stories are witty, interesting, and fun.  Great read!

review_title: Large print is easy on my aging eyes
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2010

review_title: review for tuff stuff tape recorder
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2010
reviewComment: I think the toy is ok ,I was just a little upset that it was just put in a box and shipped there was only a piece of brown paper in  with it, nothing to protect it from bouncing around and absorbing the shock of being dropped or thrown,Thankfully it does work even tho the voice,through the micro phone skips sometimes.:-[

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2002
reviewComment: This was a Christmas present to my son, along with some books on tape and music tapes. He loves it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2002
reviewComment: My 2 year old daughter has had this player for a few months now and really loves it.  She plays her tapes on it quite a bit (to the chagrin of her parents!) and it has taken a couple of falls but has held up well so far.  But I do have a few complaints. It is quite heavy once batteries are in it! The "play" button is pretty hard to push.  It took some practice for her to be able to depress it by herself but with 2 fingers pushing fairly hard, she can do it.  I feel the buttons aren't ideally placed as the large handle is right over them making it sometimes challenging for the less dexterious hands of toddlers to manipulate.  Sometimes my daughter inadvertantly blocks the door with her fingers when she is trying to eject the tapes and doesn't understand why the door won't open.  The microphone doesn't stay attached well so is always dragging on the floor. Plus, I think its a little pricey for a tape recorder geared towards children.  But, it does sound pretty good for a kids player and we're still on the first set of batteries after daily use for 6 months.  Honestly, I'm not sure if I'd buy this one again I had the choice.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2002
reviewComment: I purchased this recorder for my 2 year old son (and he needed something that could stand up to him putting it through the wringer!!!)  It was perfect!!!  He uses it to record songs he sings to play back to me when he thinks I don't feel good, he records himself mimmicking his father's voice and reprimands his brother.  He then plays it back to my 11 year old's closed door.  He drags it out in the yard and records the dog barking at squirrels.  He then plays back his recording to scare the squirrels and, if they don't run from the sound, he throws the recorder at them.  He uses it to stand on in front of his television while watching his favorite shows, then records himself reviewing the show to play back to his friend at football practice.  It gets banged around, kicked, dropped, and stepped on, only to keep working flawlessly.  This was the perfect pick to entertain my little one, who is jealous of the electronics his older brother has, including a cassette deck he uses to record his friends and family for later playback.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2002
reviewComment: My one huge complaint about it is that the recorder quit working about a month after receiving it as a present.  At first, the sound would come out broken and intermittently and for some reason I thought it were the speakers that were bad.  Eventually it produced no more sound until I connected it to a boom box.  The toy is way too heavy for children under 35 lbs.  My son is 3 and he had trouble maneuvering this clunker while in his car seat (if only for a few weeks).  The sound quality is ok, the recorder is attractive and colorful, but all and all, this Fisher Price Toy does not live up to FP's reputation.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2012
reviewComment: Really now, is this really a fair price for a toddler toy? It should be priced along

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2001
reviewComment: I agree with the editorial review, the buttons are very hard for my 2-1/2 year old to operate.  The short cord for the microphone causes a lot of feedback even when the volume is low prompting my son to say too loud!  I don't know why the fast-forward and rewind (who can tell the difference they way they're marked) buttons don't stay down.  It took me a while to believe they don't stay down by design, since even the play button requires so much effort to get it to stay engaged.  Definitely not kid tested.  The microphone falls out of its holder constantly.  This toy is so frustrating for me I can't imagine using it with the patience of a two year old.  Thankfully my son loves music and is still enjoying this gift.  Hopefully it will continue to work for a while, the build quality seems very flimsy.  Buy something else, I can't imagine it would be worse.  This is not anywhere near as good as the Fisher Price toys I remember from my youth.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2002
reviewComment: So far this seems like a great toy. My daughter (2 1/2) loves music, but hasn't quite gotten the hang of working this thing. She thinks to use the microphone, you just push the button, then talk, when you really have to hold the button down the whole time you talk. I'm sure she'll get it once she's older, along with the buttons to work it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2001
reviewComment: I got the tape recorder for my 4 year for Christmas. The fact you had to hold the buttons down was not a problem. The door has come off more then once and it is hard for me and my 4 year old to get the tape out. The volum knob does not work anymore, so we either can not hear the music or it gets to loud. I wrote to Fisher-Price and they are sending me another one. As of today (8/26/01) I have not received it. On 8/27/01 I received the new tape recorder from Fisher Price. I did not have to send the broken one back.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2008
reviewComment: I received my unit via an Amazon Marketplace vendor early. I bought it primarily for trying out the programs I hope to write, and were testing via the emulators that Microsoft makes available for VS2005 and VS2008.

review_title: iPAQ makes any Palm-based device look like a big chief pad
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2000
reviewComment: The iPAQ has got to be the slickest and most useful high-tech gadget ever invented. In regards to any Palm device, there is simply no comparison. Heres why:

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2000
reviewComment: The iPaq H3650 has just about everything you want. It has a sufficient  amount of built-in storage; it records voice at the touch of a button; it  plays voice and MP3s through a built-in speaker, which does not sound bad  (or you can use headphones); it syncs with your Outlook and other Office  documents; and it also includes IE and MS Reader.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2002
reviewComment: I had an Ipaq 3150 before this unit.  That unit was a replacement for my Palm IIIXE.  Each time I have changed my Handheld, it has been a step up.  Now, going to the 3650 has been a giant step forward.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2000
reviewComment: So I finally managed to get my hands on the iPaq pda. I was tempted to  write a completely un-objective review but after a day with the new gadget  I think I will do just the opposite. At a local cafe I sat down with a  frapuccino and the new package to see what was it all about. The packaging  is very nice, divided between the hardware from Compaq on one side and the  software bundle from Microsoft on the other. Compaq included a very nice  demo CD of the product, which pretty much goes through all the details of  setting up your iPaq (nice job.) They also included a booklet for the  accessories, service and a quick tips card.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2000
reviewComment: NOTICE:  The IPAQ does not support "Open Host Control"  USB.

review_title: Very good to understand life's journey
reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2016
reviewComment: This book is ok but has violence that is not suitable for children under 12 years old.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2015
reviewComment: I made a serious effort to read this book 20 or 25 years ago, but  I stopped about 1/3 of the way through.  I was bored to tears!  Due to its reputation as a great piece of Christian literature, I decided to give it another try. It is one of the most difficult books to read for me. I now know that I hate allegories, and I will try to avoid them at all cost in the future.  I much prefer to read the Bible and modern day Christian writers. I could have easily given this book one star, but due to the subject matter, I just could not bring myself to do it. If you like allegories, you will love this book. But, it is not my cup of tea!  I found it humorous that there is an  appendix at the end of the book where the author goes into a lengthy defense of the book. So, apparently, I am not the only person to dislike it.

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2015

reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2018
